title: 8. Road to World War II (1931-1939)
abstract: In the history of international relations, the 1920\u27s are characterized by tidying up after the  war to make the world safe for democracy;  the 1930\u27s, by preparations for World War II. In general, the causes of the renewal of global war are the same as those listed earlier for World War I, with several major additions. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, European History, Military History, Political History, Social History, United States History
summary: This chapter examines the historical context of the Western World in the 20th century, specifically focusing on the period from 1931-1939, often referred to as the 'Road to World War II'. It characterizes the 1920s as a period of post-war tidying, while the 1930s were dominated by preparations for global conflict. The text outlines the major additions to the causes of renewed global war, detailing events such as the Spanish Civil War, the formation of the Rome-Berlin-Tokyo Axis, German annexation of Austria and parts of Czechoslovakia, and the immediate causes leading to the invasion of Poland and the outbreak of World War II. Keywords: World War II, international relations, European history, Axis powers, Spanish Civil War.

title: The World War II Patriotic Mother
abstract: The archetypal good mother and the archetypal patriotic mother are important symbols in American culture. Both are rooted in maternal work but are separated by two conflicting assumptions. The good mother nurtures her children and protects them from harm, while the patriotic wartime mother remains silent when the government sends her child directly into harm\u27s way. This study explores how the World War II press positioned mothers of soldiers to sacrifice their children in support of the nation\u27s war effort. The findings point to the importance of understanding the role of archetypes in news narratives
summary: This study explores the cultural symbols of the 'good mother' and the 'patriotic mother' in American culture, particularly focusing on their conflicting assumptions regarding maternal work and national duty. The research examines how the World War II press influenced mothers of soldiers to support the war effort by sacrificing their children. Findings underscore the critical role of archetypes in shaping news narratives, shedding light on the historical construction of maternal sacrifice and national identity during wartime. Key concepts include archetypes, news narratives, World War II, patriotic mothers, and maternal sacrifice.

title: Canada and the First World War: A Canadian War Museum Internet Exhibition
abstract:
Canada and the First World War is the largest internet resource ever developed by the Canadian War Museum. The goal of this site is to provide visitors across the country and around the world with the most comprehensive and authoritative site for the history of Canada and Canadians in the First World War.
Like our permanent galleries, the site’s goal is to tell the story of Canada’s role in the First World War at the international, national, and personal levels. While the CWM’s collection dictated, to some degree, the extent of the storyline, this will be an important site for researchers, students, and the interested public
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, First World War
summary: This document introduces "Canada and the First World War," the Canadian War Museum's most extensive internet resource, designed to offer a comprehensive and authoritative history of Canada's role in the First World War. The site aims to tell the story at international, national, and personal levels, leveraging the CWM's collection. It serves as an important resource for researchers, students, and the general public, providing a richly detailed narrative. The project involved significant digitization of artifacts, images, and material culture to explore Canada's involvement in the conflict.

title: Christ in the Post-War World
summary: This article, "Christ in the Post-War World," argues that a just and lasting peace after World War II can only be achieved by returning to Christian principles. Written by Bernard Ray, it asserts that Catholics have a duty to promote these values and that the doctrines of dictators, which enslave humanity, must be eradicated. The text emphasizes that adherence to Christian principles in the post-war era will lead to a God-fearing society, contrasting it with a "might makes right" barbarianism. It underscores the importance of integrating Christ into daily life for achieving this goal. It also contains a brief section on a new wound treatment, Protlavin powder, effective against infections where sulfanilamide failed, demonstrating its success in a North African base hospital.

title: Conrad and the First World War
abstract: During the First World War, Conrad believed himself peripheral to a transitional historical moment. In November 1914, he wrote: 'the thoughts of this war sit on one's chest like a nightmare. I am painfully aware of being crippled, of being idle, of being useless with a sort of absurd anxiety' (CL 5, 427). In August 1915, Conrad felt the 'world of 15 years ago is gone to pieces; what will come in its place God knows, but I imagine doesn't care' (CL 5, 503). The political forces of nineteenth-century Europe that had fashioned Conrad's literature, notably imperialism and nationalism, were undermined and unleashed anew by the violence of the Great War and the uncertain legacy of the conflict. Conrad closely observed Poland's fate throughout the war in his relationship with Polish activist Józef Retinger, which inspired 'A Note on the Polish Problem' (1916) and 'The Crime of Partition' (1919). While 1918 saw the political rebirth of Poland, antagonisms provoked by the redrawing of Europe's historical boundaries made Conrad uneasy. On Armistice Day, he wrote: 'The great sacrifice is consummated - and what will come of it to the nations of the earth the future will show. I can not confess to an easy mind. Great and very blind forces are set free catastrophically all over the world' (CL 6, 302)
fieldOfStudy: History, Literary Studies, First World War, Joseph Conrad
summary:
This article explores Joseph Conrad's personal and artistic struggles during the First World War, highlighting his feeling of being peripheral and useless amidst a transitional historical moment. It examines how the war undermined and reshaped 19th-century European political forces, particularly imperialism and nationalism, which had influenced Conrad's literature. The study focuses on Conrad's observations of Poland's fate through his relationship with J

```jsef Retinger, inspiring works like 'A Note on the Polish Problem' and 'The Crime of Partition.' It concludes by noting Conrad's uneasiness with the redrawing of Europe's boundaries and the catastrophic release of 'blind forces' after the Armistice, ultimately leading to his artistic marginalisation.

title: Equipment of the Canadian Infantrymen, 1939–1982: A Material/Historical Assessment
abstract: The history of Canada’s soldiers in the twentieth century tends to incorporate a few recurrent themes. One of these is the changing nature of the soldier’s experience of war, from the Boer War through to the Second World War and beyond. Another is the gradual transition of Canadian military forces from British to American spheres of influence, a theme that has become particularly relevant since 1939. This article will explore these two themes from a material history perspective, an approach that is generally absent from the broader historiography. The focus will be the transformations in the Canadian infantry soldier’s personal field equipment and kit from the Second World War through to the 1980s. The evidence from this period points to two conclusions: first, that the experience of war and the growing professionalism of the Canadian infantryman has been reflected in his equipment; and second, that there has been an American influence on the equipment of the Canadian soldier since the outbreak of the Second World War
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Canadian Military History
summary: This article explores the evolving experience of Canadian soldiers and the shift from British to American military influence since 1939, focusing on the material history of infantry personal field equipment from WWII to the 1980s. It employs a material history perspective, a generally absent approach in broader historiography. The research concludes that the Canadian infantryman's equipment reflects increasing professionalism and the changing nature of war, alongside a growing American influence since the Second World War. Key entities include Canadian military history, infantry equipment, material history, and military professionalism.

title: Rhapsody in Red, White and Blue: The Co-Evolution of Popular and Art Music in the United States during World War II
abstract: World War II was a watershed event in twentieth century American history. All aspects of life, including music, both found roles to play in the war effort and were forever altered by the conflict. Past work on the subject of American music in World War II tends to focus heavily on the nature and impact of popular music during this time period. While this paper will review and build upon this scholarship, art music during the war will also be considered. Using two distinctly different, yet complementary, autobiographies – those of army band musician Frank Mathias and composer Gunther Schuller – the functions and impacts of both popular and art music on the American war effort will be analyzed and compared. Their stories will then be contextualized within the larger narrative of twentieth century American music, showcasing how World War II – through the increased influence of jazz – shaped the evolution of both popular and art music in the United States during the early 1940s
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Cultural History, Military History, Music, United States History
summary: This paper analyzes the functions and impacts of popular and art music on the American war effort during World War II, a pivotal event in twentieth-century American history. Building upon existing scholarship that often focuses on popular music, this study also considers art music. Using autobiographies of army band musician Frank Mathias and composer Gunther Schuller, the research compares their experiences. It contextualizes these narratives within the broader evolution of twentieth-century American music, demonstrating how the increased influence of jazz during the early 1940s shaped both popular and art music in the United States.

title: Songs of War: Anglo-Canadian Popular Songs on the Home Front, 1914-1918
abstract: This article explores the production, content, and reception of Anglo-Canadian popular songs composed during the First World War. It argues that popular songs reflected the changing attitudes of Anglo-Canadians, as composers and publishers created music to fulfill different purposes for those on the home front at various stages of the war. In the beginning, the majority of songs were patriotic marches composed to gather support for Britain and the Empire. As the war continued, there was an increase in the number of patriotic songs that expressed a growing sense of wartime Canadian nationalism to enlist recruits. Throughout the war, music was significant to the First World War experience on Canada’s home front
fieldOfStudy: History, Canadian Military History, First World War Studies
summary: This article examines Anglo-Canadian popular songs from the First World War, analyzing their production, content, and reception. It argues that these songs mirrored the evolving attitudes of Anglo-Canadians, as composers and publishers crafted music for diverse purposes on the home front throughout the war. Initially, patriotic marches aimed to garner support for Britain and the Empire. Over time, an increase in patriotic songs promoted a growing sense of wartime Canadian nationalism to recruit soldiers. Music played a significant role in the First World War experience on Canada's home front, revealing popular discourse and cultural perspectives.

title: The Other \u27VD\u27: The Educational Campaign to Reduce Venereal Disease Rate During World War II
abstract: Venereal disease was a major contributor to lost man days in World War I so the government attempted to implement an educational campaign beginning in 1918. After a loss of funding, venereal disease became unattended until 1936 when Thomas Parran was appointed as Surgeon General. He made prevention of venereal disease his top priority and began a new campaign, determined to make it more effective and better funding than its predecessor. The subsequent advent of World War II strengthened national interest. With the inspiration of Parran, the Public Health Service and other organizations made movies, posters, pamphlets, books, and school curriculums. Despite these efforts beginning before the war and only intensifying during the war years, venereal disease rates during World War II climbed through 1943. However, in contrast to the first campaign, Parran’s attempt to end venereal diseases was better funded and longer lasting than its predecessor
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, History of Science Technology and Medicine, United States History
summary: This paper examines the educational campaigns aimed at reducing venereal disease (VD) rates among American soldiers during World War II, a significant contributor to lost man-days. Following a largely ineffective World War I effort, Surgeon General Thomas Parran initiated a new, better-funded campaign in 1936, intensified by the onset of WWII. Utilizing various media like movies, posters, pamphlets, and school curricula, the Public Health Service and other organizations strove to prevent VD. Despite these extensive efforts, VD rates continued to climb through 1943. The study highlights the sustained nature and improved funding of Parran's initiative compared to its predecessor.

title: Toronto’s Reponse to the Outbreak of War, 1939
abstract:
Canadian historians have paid little attention to the transition from peace to war in late August and early September 1939. Jonathan Vance’s award-winning Death So Noble: Memory, Meaning and the First World War (1997) does a marvelous job of surveying attitudes towards war in the wake of the Great War, but it does not expand into the start of the Second. C.P. Stacey’s official history, Six Years of War, devotes only minimal space to exploring the transition, focusing instead on the activities of Canadian servicemen and women. The dozens of militia histories written by the units after the war dwell on the fighting, not the training.
After telling of the story of Toronto’s experience of the first months of the Second World War, it is possible to reflect on why events unfolded as they did. Community reaction to the transformation of Toronto’s militia force into Canadian Active Service Force (CASF) units provides a window into the world of late August and early September 1939. Through what process did this body of militia men transform themselves into the backbone of First Canadian Army? How many of them volunteered to serve the Empire in the second continental European war in a generation? How did Toronto’s citizens respond to the need to equip another generation of its sons with the tools of war
summary: This article examines Toronto's response to the outbreak of World War II in late August and early September 1939, a period often overlooked by Canadian historians. It investigates how Toronto's militia force transformed into Canadian Active Service Force (CASF) units, forming the backbone of the First Canadian Army. The study explores community reactions, the volunteerism of militiamen, and how citizens equipped their sons for war. By focusing on Toronto's experience, the author sheds light on the transition from peace to war and the initial mobilization efforts in Canada, addressing gaps in existing historical accounts.

title: Writing 'The War': John Buchan's lost journalism of the First World War
fieldOfStudy: History, First World War, Journalism, Propaganda
summary: This paper examines John Buchan's 'lost journalism' of the First World War, analyzing his extensive output beyond fiction, including essays, histories, biographies, and his role in propaganda. It explores how Buchan navigated the complexities of wartime writing, often conflating fact and fiction to subtly express his personal views on the war, distinct from official government narratives. The article highlights his use of fictional personae to evade responsibility for critical remarks and his technique of embedding war facts within imaginative landscapes, suppressing but not denying reality for his thrillers. The research focuses on Buchan's methods of persuasion and his exploration of authorial freedom during wartime.

title: The Myth of the Good War: America in the Second World War Revised Edition (Book Review) by Jacques R. Pauwels
abstract: Review of The Myth of the Good War: America in the Second World War Revised Edition by Jacques R. Pauwel
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Second World War
summary: This review analyzes Jacques R. Pauwels' "The Myth of the Good War: America in the Second World War Revised Edition," which challenges traditional perceptions of U.S. government goals during WWII. Pauwels argues that a primary motivation was to have the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany deplete each other, delaying Western European invasion due to ulterior motives. The reviewer critiques the book for lacking primary evidence and relying on tenuous secondary support, deeming it unsuitable for academic audiences due to historical errors and logical leaps. However, it is recommended for a general audience interested in revisionist ideas about American involvement in WWII, with a caution for critical reading.

title: Writing the Self-at-War: World War I Popular Writings as \u201cTechnologies of the Self\u201d
abstract: Based on the analysis of more than 150 diaries and memoirs, this article highlights the rhetorical strategies used to define the self and shape the idea of war that characterized a specific peasant community, the Italian-speaking soldiers from the Trentino region that fought for Austria-Hungary in World War I. Through this case study the essay discusses how the Foucauldian notion of “technology of the self” can be applied to the study of war testimonies and to the historiographical debate on the nature of World War I “war culture”. By looking at the texts not in their message but in their form and in their function for the authors the study proposes a methodology to interpret sources that have been often deemed too repetitive and hermetic to be part of a systematic historical analysis.
fieldOfStudy: History, War Culture, World War One, Popular Writing, War Violence
summary: This article analyzes over 150 diaries and memoirs from Italian-speaking soldiers from Trentino fighting for Austria-Hungary in World War I, examining the rhetorical strategies used to define the self and shape their perception of war. It applies Foucault's "technology of the self" to war testimonies and the historiographical debate on WWI "war culture." By focusing on the form and function of these texts for their authors, the study proposes a methodology for interpreting sources often dismissed as repetitive, enabling systematic historical analysis and semantic search for keywords like World War I, war culture, and popular writing.

title: The First World War between Memory and History: A Conference Retrospective
abstract: Long after the guns of the First World War went silent on 11 November 1918, the war continues to spark debate. The many points of contention were on full display at the “From Memory to History” conference, hosted by Western University in London, Ontario, over three days in November 2011. Scholars and enthusiasts from around the world gathered to share, debate, and ultimately demonstrate that the war’s many legacies are still open to interpretation, even as the centenary of the war’s outbreak approaches. Perhaps the most crucial lesson learned is that both memory and history are malleable concepts, prone to revision, and there are numerous narratives in many disciplines that remain untold, even with an event as well-documented as the First World War
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, World War I
summary: This article reflects on the "From Memory to History" conference held in November 2011, which explored the ongoing debates and interpretations surrounding the First World War. Scholars and enthusiasts gathered to demonstrate that the war's legacies remain open to discussion, even approaching its centenary. A key insight was the malleable nature of both memory and history, emphasizing that numerous narratives across various disciplines still need to be told, even for a well-documented event like WWI. The conference highlighted the persistent scholarly engagement with World War I history, memory, and its diverse interpretations.

title: Reviving the Legacy of World War I
abstract: Students research what Americans remember and have forgotten about the Great War
summary: This article discusses a collaborative Honors Program project by Roger Williams University students, Tori Bodozian and Kellie Dean, who researched Americans' collective memory of World War I. Their research, titled "Forgetting the Past: A Discussion of the Myth and National Memory of WW-I," highlighted that common recollections focus on trench warfare and chemical gases, often overlooking other aspects like rapid troop mobilization. The students observed a similar pattern in Europe and expressed concern about public apathy surrounding the war's centennial. They conclude that improved education is crucial to counter the fading interest in WWI history. Keywords: World War I, collective memory, history education, public apathy, Great War.

title: War, Peace and Third World Development
abstract: human development, human security, peace
summary: This paper, "WAR, PEACE AND THIRD WORLD DEVELOPMENT" by Dan Smith, explores the intricate relationship between armed conflict, peace, and development, particularly focusing on the Third World. It highlights that systemic violence, including war, is a chronic development problem, with 52 wars and widespread political violence observed in 1993, predominantly in Third World countries. The study emphasizes that most modern conflicts are civil wars and often do not conform to Western perceptions of warfare. The research delves into concepts, priorities, routes to war, and the possibility of peace, challenging conventional definitions of war and underscoring the necessity for development agendas to address violence for effective progress. Key terms include human development, human security, and peace.

title: Experiencing War as the \u27Enemy Other\u27: Italian Scottish experience in World War II (Book Review)  by Wendy Ugolini
abstract: Review of Experiencing War as the \u27Enemy Other\u27: Italian Scottish experience in World War II. Wendy Ugolini. Manchester: Manchester University Press, 2011. Pp. 288
summary: This review discusses Wendy Ugolini's "Experiencing War as the 'Enemy Other': Italian Scottish experience in World War II," a significant contribution to the literature on "enemy aliens" during WWII. Ugolini's study moves beyond typical regional internment histories, advocating for a nuanced analysis of wartime internment and other experiences of "enemy" minorities. It explores the diverse impact of war on Italians in Scotland, providing a stimulating case study of immigrant experiences during conflict. The work is highly recommended for those interested in social military history, offering insights into military strategies, political transitions, and coastal defense.

title: One Family’s War: World War Two as seen through the Craig Family
fieldOfStudy: History, World War Two, Canadian Military History
summary: This article, "One Family's War: World War Two as seen through the Craig Family" by Jeff Keshen, explores the impact of World War Two on a Canadian family, Jim and Grace Craig. It utilizes their extensive wartime correspondence, consisting of nearly 400 letters each, to illuminate their experiences during Jim's two-and-a-half-year overseas deployment. The study analyzes the family's resilience, the dynamics of their marriage, and their patriotic contributions, providing a detailed personal perspective on the broader historical context of the war and its effects on Canadian families.

title: “The moaning of the world” and the “words that bring me peace”: Modernism and the First World War
abstract: This chapter takes its place in a huge new project on twentieth-century British and American war literature. It focuses on technology and sense perception in First World War writing in its account of the formal and contextual relationships between modernism and the war
summary: This chapter explores the intricate relationship between modernism and First World War literature, forming part of a larger project on twentieth-century British and American war writing. It specifically investigates the role of technology and sense perception in shaping war narratives, analyzing their formal and contextual connections to modernist literary trends. The discussion considers the varied 'testaments of experience' from the war and challenges critical consensus on language and narrative in war literature. Key themes include the impact of traumatic sounds and physical experiences on neuroses, and the struggle to publish war memoirs, demonstrating the profound influence of the war on literary expression and public reception. Keywords: modernism, First World War literature, technology, sense perception, war narratives.

title: Running Wires: Digital History in the Classroom and the Field
abstract: The First World War Letters of H.J.C. Peirs is a digital history project that publishes the letters of a British World War I officer 100 years to the day they were written. By telling the story of one person, we have aimed to humanize a dehumanizing war and supported the effort to commemorate the centennial of the conflict. While the project was conceived with pedagogy in mind, it has grown beyond the letters and crossed boundaries: from the analog to the digital, from the classroom to the public, and from the archives to the field
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Digital Humanities, European History, Military History
summary: The digital history project "The First World War Letters of H.J.C. Peirs" publishes the letters of a British WWI officer a century after their writing. This initiative humanizes the conflict, commemorates its centennial, and serves a pedagogical purpose. The project expanded from analog to digital, classroom to public, and archives to the field, leveraging field research in France and Belgium, archival research in London, and a photographic survey of Peirs-related sites. It integrates digital humanities to provide insights into individual experiences during World War I.

title: May it Please Your Honor : Letters of Petition as Historical Evidence in an African Colonial Context
abstract: This paper presents some preliminary conclusions drawn from an ongoing project which aims to collect and collate letters of petitions in colonial Nigeria as primary source for historians and other scholars. The goal is to show the potential use of petitions as a foundation for gauging African reactions and responses to colonialism focusing on the petitions that emerged during the Second World War in colonial Eastern Nigeria. The paper is based on the collection of petitions located at the National Archives of Nigeria at Enugu written by people living in the rural and urban areas in colonial Eastern Nigeria during the Second World War. Mainly addressed to District Officers in Colonial Eastern Nigeria from within the region, they reflect the concerns of individuals and groups as they relate to the crisis engendered by the Second World War and the policies and controls imposed by officials to bolster the British war effort
summary: This paper analyzes letters of petition from colonial Eastern Nigeria during World War II as primary historical sources. It aims to reveal African reactions and responses to colonialism, particularly concerning the crisis and policies imposed by British officials to support the war effort. Collected from the National Archives of Nigeria at Enugu, these petitions, primarily addressed to District Officers, offer unique insights into the concerns of individuals and groups in rural and urban areas. The study highlights the potential of petitions to provide African voices and perspectives, enriching the historical narrative of colonialism where other indigenous sources are scarce.

title: Review of Klippenstein\u27s  Peace and War, Mennonite Conscientious Objectors in Tsarist Russia and the Soviet Union before World War II, and other COs in Eastern Europe
abstract: Review of Lawrence Klippenstein, Peace and War, Mennonite Conscientious Objectors in Tsarist Russia and the Soviet Union before World War II, and other COs in Eastern Europe, Winnipeg, MB. 2017. 367pp. $30.00 including postage outside Canada
summary: This review examines Lawrence Klippenstein's "Peace and War, Mennonite Conscientious Objectors in Tsarist Russia and the Soviet Union before World War II, and other COs in Eastern Europe." The book explores the history of pacifist movements, particularly focusing on Mennonites in Russia, Doukhobors, and British Quakers' efforts for peace, including their opposition to the Crimean War. Klippenstein argues that a witness for peace, rooted in biblical pacifism and often expressed through exemption from military service, can be a powerful societal force. The work serves as an inspiration for those valuing biblical peacemaking in a violent world.

title: The Generation of Memory: Reflections on the “Memory Boom” in Contemporary Historical Studies
abstract:
Jay Winter delivered the following in the form of a lecture at the Canadian War Museum on 31 October 2000. A distinguished academic, Winter has been writing about the cultural history of the First World War for nearly three decades. He has taught at the University of Cambridge in England and is presently at Yale University. Since 1988, he has been a director of the Historial de la grande guerre in Peronne, an important war museum in northern France. In this capacity, he has become familiar with a great many institutions of war and military history around the world and he has great knowledge and familiarity with the important historical and intellectual debates that will be fundamental to the creation of a new Canadian War Museum, which is now slated to open in May 2005.
Probably Winter’s best-known book is Sites of Memory, Sites of Mourning: the Great War in European Cultural History published in 1995. In it, he argues that the rituals of mourning associated with commemoration after the First World War had a history stretching far back in human life and experience. In this he contradicts the thinking of Canadian historian Modris Eksteins who argued that the Great War marked the birth of the modern age. Lately, Daniel Sherman has proposed that commemorative ceremonies and memorials are significantly politicized in the interests of state control. In the following paper Winter warns against the dangers of collective memory being collapsed into “a set of stories formed by or about the state” while also providing a rich overview of the great importance that attention to memory and culture studies has taken on in contemporary thought. These cannot be ignored in any serious attempt to lay the intellectual foundation of any new museum, and perhaps especially may have specific relevance to a new war museum
summary: Jay Winter's lecture, "The Generation of Memory," delivered at the Canadian War Museum in 2000, reflects on the growing importance of memory and culture studies in contemporary historical thought, particularly concerning the First World War. Winter, a distinguished academic and director of the Historial de la grande guerre, challenges Modris Eksteins's view by arguing that mourning rituals have deep historical roots, not solely marking the modern age. He warns against state-controlled collective memory, advocating for a nuanced understanding. This work is crucial for shaping new war museums and advancing the field of public history, highlighting the need for rigorous propositions about memory's nature and historical role.

title: Home Front to War Front: The Navy Nurse Corps During World War II
abstract: The Navy Nurse Corps was created in 1908, when President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Naval Appropriations Bill. Twenty women were selected to become the corps’ first members. These women were referred to as the “The Sacred Twenty.” On December 7, 1941, when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, the Navy Nurse Corps, was one of the first groups to respond. These women were important in preventing further deaths following the attack. However the experiences of Navy nurses during World II are often left untold because their story is overshadowed by the Army Nurse Corps, which doubled in size during the war. However, not one person’s experience is typical. This paper tells the stories of the women in the Navy Nurse Corps during World War II, through the experiences of Dora Cline Fechtmann, Dorothy Still Danner, Mary Rose “Red” Harrington and other Navy nurses
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, History of Gender
summary: This paper aims to illuminate the often-untold experiences of women in the Navy Nurse Corps during World War II, a narrative frequently overshadowed by the Army Nurse Corps. Established in 1908, the Navy Nurse Corps responded immediately to the Pearl Harbor attack in 1941, playing a crucial role in preventing further casualties. The study employs a biographical approach, focusing on the personal stories of Dora Cline Fechtmann, Dorothy Still Danner, Mary Rose "Red" Harrington, and other Navy nurses to provide a comprehensive understanding of their wartime contributions and challenges.

title: Shooting the War: The Canadian Army Film Unit in the Second World War
abstract:
Very little has been written about the Canadian Army Film Unit (CAFU) since the end of the Second World War, despite Jon Farrell’s postulation. There have been a few short newspaper articles related to teh Film Unit and the D-Day footage that made it famous, but there has been no scholarly study by either military or film historians. The purpose of the CAFU was to create an official audio-visual record of Canada’s Army, just as the official historians, war artists, and photographers were documenting other aspects of the war. The Film Unit started as only a few men, but expanded substantially throughout the war, increasing the scope and breadth of its productions. The men and women of the CAFU who operated the cameras, edited the film, and then distributed the finished products were different from the civilian war correspondents and commercial newsreel cameramen who were also creating a visual record of the war. The CAFU attached cameramen to military units and they shot real-time footage of Canadians in battle. This footage was then used to create the CAFU films, and formed the basis of the National Film Board of Canada (NFB) and commercial newsreel company productions.
Most of the existing scholarship exploring Canadian film and the Second World War focuses on the NFB and John Grierson, the father of the documentary in Canada and the NFB’s first film commissioner. The historiography suggests that NFB was, for all practical purposes, the main film institution creating Canadian motion pictures. This was true, but much of its wartime film footage came from the cameras of the CAFU—footage that was shot in harm’s way. Despite this neglect by historians, the CAFU played an essential role in the history of Canadian film. Much of what subsequent generations have seen or know about the Second World War comes from footage shot by the Film Unit. Yet it is a difficult story to tell since it must be pieced together using primary sources, both textual and audio-visual. The Film Unit will receive the credit that it deserves and will find its place again in the history of the Second World War
summary: This study addresses the scholarly neglect of the Canadian Army Film Unit (CAFU) during the Second World War. Its purpose was to create an official audio-visual record of the Canadian Army, documenting real-time footage of Canadians in battle. While the National Film Board (NFB) is often credited as the primary wartime film institution, much of its material originated from CAFU cameramen. The article argues that the CAFU played a crucial, under-recognized role in Canadian film history, providing much of the visual record of the Second World War. It emphasizes piecing together this difficult story using primary textual and audio-visual sources to ensure the Film Unit receives due credit.

title: 10. Notes on the Postwar Political Scene
abstract: The legacy of World War II was a heavy load for statesmen to bear. The collapse of Germany, Italy, Japan, and their lesser allies left a power vacuum, temporarily filled by the armies of occupation. Military losses were half again as high as in World War I. Even greater was the different in civilian losses. For every civilian who died a war death in 1914-1918, at least a score (a total of some 20,000,000) perished in 1939-1945. Material losses in housing and productive capacity were staggering. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, European History, International Relations, Military History, Political History, United States History
summary: This document examines the profound and multifaceted legacy of World War II, emphasizing the immense human and material costs that created a significant power vacuum and reshaped the global political landscape. It details the unprecedented civilian losses and the staggering destruction of infrastructure, leading to the rise of new geopolitical alignments. The text discusses the collapse of colonial empires, the emergence of nationalist and Communist movements, particularly in Asia, and the ensuing conflicts such as the Korean War and the situation in French Indochina, highlighting the complex post-war challenges faced by statesmen. The text also touches on the anticolonial tide in Africa, ultimately demonstrating how the war propelled significant shifts towards decolonization and new world orders.

title: John Terrane: A Study of a First World War Revisionist
abstract: Of all the British military historians who started writing about the First World War during the  boom  of the sixties, perhaps no one has had greater influence or generated more controversy than John Alfred Terraine. As G.F. Elliot wrote in a 1965 review,  John Terraine is one of the younger generation of British military analysts who are now proving, with brilliance and vigour, the value of the long view in putting World War I in proper perspective.  It is this idea of perspective, trying to bring balance to the historical arguments concerning the British contribution to the First World War, that drove John Terraine in all his work. Terraine\u27s nine books on the British Expeditionary Force challenged the comfortable mainstream theories and assumptions, defended the generals, and debunked the myths. His opinions gave him both notoreity and influence
summary: This article examines John Alfred Terraine, a highly influential and controversial British military historian of the First World War. It explores how Terraine challenged mainstream theories, defended generals, and debunked myths about the British Expeditionary Force through his nine books. His work aimed to bring balance and new perspective to historical arguments surrounding Britain's contribution to the conflict, earning him both notoriety and significant influence among scholars and analysts, particularly during the 1960s boom in WWI scholarship.

title: 2. The Postwar Scene
abstract: Turning now from the immediate diplomatic aftermath of World War I, let us examine some major features of Western Civilization during what has been called the long weekend, the two decades between that war and World War II (1919-1939). We will note first the way in which the West generated within itself economic stresses, local and general, which prevented it from realizing the tremendous potential created by continuing technological advances. Then we will note how these economic changes were paralleled by changes in social organization and attitudes. We will see these new attitudes in conflict with each other and with survivals from earlier ages. This will be illustrated in greater detail in three sections in which the democracies and their chief competitors are studied. All the above topics will deal with aspects of the civil wars — military and otherwise — which are one of the features of Western Civilization. This stands out sharply in the next section on the shifting balance of military power in the West and the road to World War II. At this point we will note the increasing impact of the non-Western world. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, European History, Military History, Political History, Social History, United States History
summary: This text explores the major features of Western Civilization during the interwar period (1919-1939), dubbed the "long weekend." It examines economic stresses that hindered technological potential, alongside shifts in social organization and attitudes. The analysis delves into conflicts among these new attitudes and older traditions, illustrating them through studies of democracies and their competitors. The text also addresses the "civil wars" within Western Civilization, the evolving military power balance leading to World War II, and the growing influence of the non-Western world. Key themes include the normalization of crisis and the transformative impact of global conflicts.

title: Peacebuilding After Civil War
abstract:
Book Summary: This comprehensive new Handbook explores the significance and nature of armed intrastate conflict and civil war in the modern world. Civil wars and intrastate conflict represent the principal form of organised violence since the end of World War II, and certainly in the contemporary era. These conflicts have a huge impact and drive major political change within the societies in which they occur, as well as on an international scale. The global importance of recent intrastate and regional conflicts in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iraq, Somalia, Nepal, Cote d\u27Ivoire, Syria and Libya – amongst others – has served to refocus academic and policy interest upon civil war.
Chapter Summary: This chapter provides an assessment of current theories regarding peacebuilding efforts following civil war, evaluates UN peacebuilding efforts over the past 20 years, and offers suggestions regarding future research on the topic
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, International Relations, Military History, Peace and Conflict Studies
summary: This book chapter assesses current theories and practices of peacebuilding following civil wars, which represent the principal form of organized violence since World War II. It evaluates the effectiveness of UN peacebuilding efforts over the past two decades and offers suggestions for future research in this critical area. The work highlights the significant impact of intrastate conflicts on political change, both domestically and internationally, underscoring the renewed academic and policy interest in civil war and post-conflict reconstruction. Keywords include peacebuilding, civil war, intrastate conflict, UN interventions, and political science.

title: Yours for Victory: The Wartime Story of Howard Peach
abstract: This study is based on the World War II experiences of Howard Peach, Bryant class of 1942 and founding member of the Bryant Service Club (BSC), a student organization that supported Bryant alumni during the war years. It is based on letters that Peach received and wrote to the BSC during his service with the Army Signal Corps from 1942 until early 1946 as well as oral interviews that the authors conducted at his home in Cape Cod, Massachusetts during 2009. Stationed in Europe during much of the war, Peach participated in the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944, the last major German offensive and one of the bloodiest battles of World War II. After the war, Peach started his own business as a representative for jewelry manufacturers which he ran until his retirement in 1985. He and his wife, Glenna, celebrated their 65th wedding anniversary in October 2008
fieldOfStudy: History, World War II, Military History, American History
summary: This study chronicles the World War II experiences of Howard Peach, a Bryant College alumnus (class of 1942) and founding member of the Bryant Service Club (BSC), a student organization supporting alumni during the war. Drawing on letters between Peach and the BSC (1942-1946) and oral interviews from 2009, the paper details his service with the Army Signal Corps in Europe, including participation in the Battle of the Bulge. It also touches on his post-war entrepreneurial career in jewelry manufacturing and personal life, highlighting his journey from student to soldier, entrepreneur, and devoted husband.

title: America Must Make Good
abstract: Bulletin urging prospective male and female students to enroll in business programs at Bryant & Stratton, particularly those who were not going off to war (World War I). From the brochure:  The nation needs many stenographers and bookkeepers - It needs them sorely to win the war. Every department of the Government seeks additional office assistants ..
summary: This bulletin from Bryant & Stratton urges male and female students, particularly those not engaged in direct combat, to enroll in business programs to support the World War I effort. It emphasizes the nation's urgent need for stenographers and bookkeepers in government departments, framing business education as a patriotic service. The institution highlights its practical, war-time relevant training methods, such as 'learn-to-do-by-doing,' and its success in placing graduates in critical roles. Keywords: World War I, business education, vocational training, patriotism, stenography, bookkeeping, Bryant & Stratton.

title: The World War II Letters of Richard Schade
abstract: Richard Schade was a newlywed when he was drafted into the United States Army on January 29, 1943, in Camden, New Jersey. While stationed in the United States during World War II, he wrote a series of letters to his new wife, Betty. Many of these letters were love letters discussing deep love as well as the active plan to start a family. Through the letters written over the course of months he records his daily duties, concerns, dreams, and various information about the conditions in the military. His letters developed into a valuable insight into the life of a soldier stationed in America during World War II. This research paper uncovers information about Richard Schade and his military time that had been lost not only to his family but also to some military records, creating a fuller picture and providing many answers to questions left unanswered over time
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History
summary: This research paper explores the World War II letters of Richard Schade, a newlywed drafted into the U.S. Army in 1943. While stationed in America, Schade wrote extensively to his wife, Betty, detailing his daily duties, concerns, and dreams, alongside expressions of love and plans for a family. These letters offer valuable insights into a soldier's life during wartime, uncovering lost information about Schade's military service and providing answers to long-unanswered questions. The study reconstructs a fuller picture of his time in the military, enriching historical understanding of personal experiences during World War II.

title: War Gender and Dancing: Gettysburg College and the USO During World War II
abstract: Made up of women and the men who could not join the military, the home front was more than just victory gardens and factory jobs. Although factory work was seen as a way for women both to help the war effort and at the same time gain some independence outside the home, not every woman was ready to hang up her dress and start donning pants full time. There was a middle ground where women were able to break traditional feminine roles yet still keep their dresses and serve the servicemen fighting the war between victory gardens and factory jobs; a balance was found in volunteer organizations designed to serve the military. The largest and most well-known organization on the home front was the United Services Organization, more commonly referred to as the USO. After the outbreak of World War II, USO canteens start to appear everywhere across the United States in towns and cities alike. Gettysburg, Pennsylvania was one of many towns with their own USO branch. The Gettysburg branch was supported by the female students at Gettysburg College and the Army Air Corps detachment stationed on campus which provided an opportunity for local young women to explore new social roles while supporting the war effort. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Social History, United States History, Women's History
summary: This article examines the role of the United Services Organization (USO) and its interaction with Gettysburg College during World War II, focusing on how it provided unique opportunities for young women on the home front. Beyond traditional factory jobs or victory gardens, volunteer organizations like the USO allowed women to support the war effort while breaking from conventional feminine roles and exploring new social independence. Specifically, the Gettysburg branch, supported by female students and an Army Air Corps detachment, facilitated these social changes. The study highlights the temporary yet significant impact of the USO in shaping women's roles and offering experiences that would influence their pursuit of independence post-war.

title: Canada Museum: The Second World War in Flanders
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, World War II
summary: This feature describes the "Canada Museum" in Adagem, Belgium, a significant tribute to Canada's role in liberating Europe during World War II, specifically in Flanders. The museum vividly portrays the war experience through exhibits, photos, documents, life-size panoramas of the Leopold Canal battle, and artifacts. Conceived by Alex Martens and funded by Gilbert Van Landschoot, whose father was saved by Canadian troops, the museum honors those who endured and sacrificed. It features exceptional architecture and an extensive collection of uniforms and historical items, offering a comprehensive view of the area's history and liberation.

title: Adams County in the Great War
abstract: The First World War has generally faded from American memory, and is generally considered to have not cost the United States much. Although the country did not experience the total destruction that Europe endured, even small towns such as Gettysburg paid a cost, and the sacrifices made one hundred years ago should not be forgotten. First off is a brief summary of Adams County in the war, sourced primarily from Paul Foulk and Percy Eichelberger’s “Adams County in the World War.” Foulk and Eichelberger were students of Gettysburg College (then Pennsylvania College) and returned from service in the war and wrote the book to chronicle the county’s involvement. Consisting primarily of statistics and lists of soldiers from each town in the county, the book concludes with accounts written by soldiers about their overseas experiences
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Public History, United States History, World War I
summary: This article aims to remind readers of the significant, yet often forgotten, sacrifices made by small American towns like Gettysburg during World War I, despite the U.S. not experiencing Europe's total destruction. It summarizes Adams County's involvement in the war, drawing primarily from Paul Foulk and Percy Eichelberger's "Adams County in the World War." The article highlights the county's contributions, including statistics on soldiers, accounts of overseas experiences, and the enthusiasm with which residents supported the war effort through military service, Red Cross work, and war bonds, emphasizing the local impact of a global conflict.

title: Toward a Transnational History of World War I
abstract: Michael S. Neiberg delivered the keynote address at the 19th Military History Colloquium, held at the University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, 1–3 May 2008. This is the text of his address
summary: This paper, based on Michael S. Neiberg's keynote address, advocates for a transnational approach to World War I history, moving beyond national narratives to understand broader global dynamics and interconnected experiences. The author uses an experiment demonstrating selective attention to illustrate how historians can overlook crucial aspects when focused on narrow perspectives. This work emphasizes the need for a holistic view, incorporating diverse perspectives and international interactions to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the conflict and its enduring legacies. Key themes include global history, military history, and the historiography of World War I.

title: Women and war zones: May Sinclair’s personal negotiation with the First World War
fieldOfStudy: History, World War I, Women's Studies
summary: This essay explores May Sinclair's personal account of female presence near the Belgian front lines during World War I, drawn from her emotionally-charged journal. It analyzes the roles and spaces encountered by Sinclair and other women, revealing the complex relationship between women and war zones. The study utilizes personal experiences, masculine attitudes, and Sinclair's modernist writing techniques to illuminate psychological responses to WW1, shell shock, and women's access to the front. Keywords include May Sinclair, World War I, women writers, and interior/exterior war zones.

title: Readers and Reading in the First World War
abstract: This essay consists of three individually authored and interlinked sections. In ‘A Digital Humanities Approach’, Francesca Benatti looks at datasets and databases (including the UK Reading Experience Database) and shows how a systematic, macro-analytical use of digital humanities tools and resources might yield answers to some key questions about reading in the First World War. In ‘Reading behind the Wire in the First World War’ Edmund G. C. King scrutinizes the reading practices and preferences of Allied prisoners of war in Mainz, showing that reading circumscribed by the contingencies of a prison camp created an unique literary community, whose legacy can be traced through their literary output after the war. In ‘Book-hunger in Salonika’, Shafquat Towheed examines the record of a single reader in a specific and fairly static frontline, and argues that in the case of the Salonika campaign, reading communities emerged in close proximity to existing centres of print culture. The focus of this essay moves from the general to the particular, from the scoping of large datasets, to the analyses of identified readers within a specific geographical and temporal space. The authors engage with the wider issues and problems of recovering, interpreting, visualizing, narrating, and representing readers in the First World War
authors: The Stanford Natural Language Processing Group
summary: This essay explores reading practices during the First World War through three interconnected sections. Francesca Benatti uses digital humanities tools and datasets, like the UK Reading Experience Database, for macro-analysis of wartime reading. Edmund G. C. King examines Allied prisoners of war in Mainz, revealing a unique literary community shaped by camp conditions. Shafquat Towheed investigates a single reader in the Salonika campaign, arguing for reading communities near existing print culture centers. The study combines large dataset analysis with specific reader case studies to recover, interpret, and represent readers in this conflict, utilizing newly digitized materials to address fundamental questions about wartime reading.

title: Developing Deadly Skies
abstract: The Canadian War Museum’s exhibition Deadly Skies – Air War, 1914-1918 examines the first air war from the perspective of nine international participants representing Canada, the United States, France, Great Britain, and Germany. Eschewing the romantic mythology of First World War aviation that focuses on the achievements of individual fighter pilots, the exhibition examines four key aspects of the air war: training, observation, bombing, and aerial combat. Adopting an interpretive approach that appeals to intergenerational audiences and that highlights personal experience in the war, the exhibition is presented as a series of life-sized graphic novels, supplemented with key artifacts, photos, audio clips, and videos. The historical and interpretative approaches together present a holistic and modern examination of the world’s first air war
summary: This article discusses the Canadian War Museum's exhibition "Deadly Skies – Air War, 1914-1918," which examines the First World War's aerial combat. It moves beyond romanticized individual pilot narratives to explore four key aspects: training, observation, bombing, and aerial combat, from the perspectives of nine international participants. The exhibition employs an intergenerational interpretive approach, using life-sized graphic novels, artifacts, and multimedia to present a holistic, modern understanding of the world's first air war, focusing on personal experiences of thousands of ordinary participants rather than just famous figures. Keywords: Canadian War Museum, Deadly Skies, First World War, Air War, aviation, exhibition, military history.

title: Statutory Reemployment Rights of World War II Veterans
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
summary: This article from the Fordham Law Review (1945) analyzes the statutory reemployment rights of World War II veterans, focusing on Section 8 and its application. It critiques the complexity and occasional misinterpretations in administering these rights, emphasizing that while the language of Section 8 is broad, its purpose is to assure employment for qualified veterans. The text also touches on the diminishing role of non-lawyer justices. The authors argue against new "clarifying legislation" for Section 8, suggesting that if additional legislation is needed to assist displaced non-veterans, it should be supplementary, not at the expense of veteran reemployment provisions.

title: CHA visit to the War Museum
abstract:
During CHA council meetings last November of 2006 CHA council members were given a first-rate tour of the recently completed Canadian War Museum, located on the LeBreton Flats, a plain of wetland and former industrial land adjascent to networks of mill races and hydro dams on the right bank of the Ottawa River. The tour was given by CWM World War. One curator and historian Tim Cook. The tour allowed visitors to take in the remarkable breadth, chronological and thematic, of the CWM permanent exhibition, from the pre-contact(native) ways of fighting to the Seven Years War and all the way up to and well into the 20th century marked by two World Wars, the Korean War etc. Dr. Cook shared with visitors the challenges of preparing a display — what works, what
does not work
publisher: Canadian Historical Association / Société historique du Canada
summary: This document describes a tour of the Canadian War Museum given to CHA council members in November 2006 by curator Tim Cook. The tour covered the museum's permanent exhibition, spanning from pre-contact fighting to the 20th century, including the Seven Years' War, World Wars, and the Korean War. Dr. Cook also discussed challenges in display preparation and public debates over historical interpretations, particularly regarding World War One. He is planning a temporary exhibition focusing on trench culture during 1914-1918, aiming to engage with Canadian socio-cultural historiography and popular perceptions.

title: American Grand Strategy in the Mediterranean during World War II (Book Review)  by Andrew Buchanan
abstract: Review of American Grand Strategy in the Mediterranean during World War II by Andrew Buchanan
fieldOfStudy: History, American diplomatic history, Anglo-U.S. relations, international relations
summary: This book review examines Andrew Buchanan's "American Grand Strategy in the Mediterranean during World War II," offering a new interpretation of the U.S. experience. Buchanan argues that the U.S. did not initially seek Mediterranean dominance but overcame difficulties to shape a new liberal world order, exemplified by the Truman Doctrine. The review praises the book as a comprehensive analysis of American diplomatic history, Anglo-U.S. relations, and Second World War strategy. It is recommended for scholars of international relations, especially those interested in power transitions and global order construction, as well as general readers.

title: The First World Oil War (Book Review)  by Timothy C. Winegard
abstract: Review of The First World Oil War by Timothy C. Winegar
fieldOfStudy: Military History, World War I, Oil History
summary: This is a review of Timothy C. Winegard's book, "The First World Oil War," which examines the pivotal role of oil in shaping the First World War and its aftermath. Winegard argues that the conflict and its immediate consequences established Anglo-American dominance over global oil supplies, specifically focusing on a British military force sent to Baku in 1918. Drawing on Australian, Canadian, and British sources, the book connects these historical events to contemporary issues in the Middle East and the modern oil market, including hydraulic fracturing. The review highlights the book's effectiveness in demonstrating oil's significance in WWI and its enduring impact.

title: Review of  Morale and Discipline in the Royal Navy during the First World War  by Laura Rowe
abstract: Review of Morale and Discipline in the Royal Navy during the First World War by Laura Row
summary: This review examines Laura Rowe's "Morale and Discipline in the Royal Navy during the First World War," which addresses a significant gap in First World War historiography by focusing on the experiences and culture of Royal Navy sailors rather than solely on Western Front soldiers. Rowe's social history explores concepts of morale and discipline, presenting a new framework for analysis. While praised for its thorough research and fresh perspective, the review suggests areas for further exploration, such as sailor reactions to specific naval disasters and their views on enemy forces, setting a strong foundation for future studies in naval history.

title: Crossing the Canal: Combined Arms Operations at the Canal Du Nord, Sept–Oct 1918
abstract: The crossing of the Canal du Nord stands as one of the most impressive Canadian tactical operations of the First World War. Incorporating a risky battle plan, emphasizing combined arms operations and utilizing the recently re-organized Canadian Engineers, the battle stands as benchmark for the evolution of 20th century combat. Although sustaining high casualties, the Canadian Corps overcame one of the strongest German defensive positions along the Westner Front in an operation that foreshadowed the mobile, combined arms doctrine of the Second World War
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, First World War
summary: This article examines the Canadian Corps' crossing of the Canal du Nord during the First World War, highlighting it as a pivotal tactical operation. The study emphasizes the risky battle plan, successful combined arms operations, and the crucial role of the re-organized Canadian Engineers. Despite high casualties, the Canadian Corps overcame strong German defenses on the Western Front, an operation that prefigured the mobile, combined arms doctrine prominent in the Second World War. This analysis contributes to understanding 20th-century combat evolution and Canadian military history.

title: Perception vs. Reality: WWII Veterans are More Than Willing to Share their Stories
abstract:
I created the Bristol Veterans History Project to record and preserve the stories from World War II and Korean War veterans in the local area.
The attached paper and corresponding PowerPoint presentation were created for a presentation with Professor Debbie Mulligan in Washington, DC
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Oral History, United States History
summary: This project, the Bristol Veterans History Project, aims to record and preserve the personal narratives of World War II and Korean War veterans from the local area. The author, inspired by grandparents who endured Nazi occupation, explores the perception versus reality of veterans' willingness to share their stories. Through interviews, the study finds that veterans, even those previously reluctant, are often willing to recount their experiences, highlighting the unique and varied individual memories of wartime events. The project emphasizes the critical importance of preserving these stories to honor their sacrifices and provide insights into global conflicts.

title: World trade: pirated by the downturn
abstract: A post-World War II record decline in world trade is likely in 2009.International trade ; Exports
summary: This essay examines the projected record decline in world trade in 2009, anticipated to be the largest since 1951, surpassing the post-World War II period. The purpose is to explain the reasons for this significant downturn. Key methods involve analyzing historical trends of world trade relative to GDP and identifying contributing factors. Main findings indicate that the decline is primarily due to the current global recession, which causes a fall in demand for traded goods, and disruptions in financial markets, leading to reduced credit for international trade. Global supply chains and potential protectionism are also discussed as contributing issues.

title: Review of  Double Threat: Canadian Jews, the Military, and World War II  by Ellin Bessner
abstract: Review of Double Threat: Canadian Jews, the Military, and World War II by Ellin Bessne
summary: This review examines Ellin Bessner's "Double Threat: Canadian Jews, the Military, and World War II," a book that explores the significant contributions of Canada's Jewish population during World War II, both in combating Nazism abroad and antisemitism at home. The book highlights the sacrifices of 17,000 Canadian Jews who served, overcoming challenges like mandatory church parades and difficulty keeping kosher. It argues that this military participation ultimately forced wider society to confront its bigotry, leading to greater acceptance and integration of Jewish Canadians. The review suggests the book serves as an essential touchstone for Canadian Jewish military history.

title: Excavaciones arqueológicas y el entorno urbano de Berlín : recordar y olvidar la huellas de la Segunda Guerra Mundial
abstract: This essay examines how the Second World War can be remembered through archeology at two tourism sites in Berlin. Through data collected from site visits and observations, the motifs of burial, authenticity, and historical value are found to engage directly with ongoing negotiations of remembering the Second World War. This contributes a revised way of examining cultural remembering through material traces of the war on Berlin’s urban environment.Este ensayo examina cómo la memoria de la Segunda Guerra Mundial está mediada por la arqueología en dos sitios turísticos en Berlín. A través de los datos compilado de sitios visitados y observaciones del sitio, los motivos de entierro, autenticidad y valor histórico se relacionan directamente con la negociación en curso de recordar y olvidar la Segunda Guerra Mundial, ya que está integrada en el entorno urbano de Berlín
publisher: 'Universidad de Sevilla - Secretariado de Recursos Audiovisuales y Nuevas Tecnologias'
summary: This essay explores how the Second World War is remembered through archaeology at two tourism sites in Berlin. By analyzing data from site visits and observations, the study identifies burial, authenticity, and historical value as key motifs that directly engage with ongoing negotiations of war memory. This research offers a refined approach to understanding cultural remembering through the material remnants of the war embedded within Berlin's urban environment, focusing on memory, archaeology, and historical value in a tourism context.

title: The Embattled General: Sir Richard Turner and the First World War (Book Review)  by William F. Stewart
abstract: Review of The Embattled General: Sir Richard Turner and the First World War by William F. Stewar
summary: This book review discusses William F. Stewart's "The Embattled General: Sir Richard Turner and the First World War," a long-overdue biographical study. It highlights the neglect of Canadian generals in First World War historiography, with the exception of Arthur Currie. The review praises Stewart for his examination of Richard Turner, challenging the historical dismissal of him as a failure and emphasizing the crucial role of organization, training, and administration in modern warfare, often overlooked in favor of battlefield accounts. The work aims to provoke a re-evaluation of Turner's contributions and the broader understanding of wartime success beyond field command.

title: Doe v. Ashcroft and Its Place in the Judicial Trend: How the Courts Have Advanced Civil Liberties in Step with Advances in Technology
abstract:
As many jurists and scholars have noted, the United States has a long-standing history of encroaching upon the civil liberties of its citizens, especially during times of war or conflict.\ud
\ud
For instance, during the Civil War, President Lincoln unilaterally suspended the writ of habeas corpus in response to increased violence and the threat of Southern succession.During World War I, Postmaster General Albert Burleson used the Espionage Act to suspend mailing privileges for certain “non-mailable” materials, such as newspapers and other dissident publications critical of the war effort
summary: This paper examines the historical encroachment on civil liberties in the United States, particularly during wartime, citing examples like the suspension of habeas corpus during the Civil War, the Espionage Act during World War I, and Japanese Internment during World War II. The author analyzes Doe v. Ashcroft as a significant judicial development that reinforces the trend of courts advancing civil liberties in step with technological progress. The ruling is presented as a victory for privacy advocates, establishing judicial review for technologically-oriented government surveillance, weakening NSL statutes, and declaring a section of the Patriot Act unconstitutional, particularly concerning access to online records.

title: Terminations After World War I
summary: This article examines the historical experience of war contract terminations and settlements following World War I to inform policies for the post-World War II era. It highlights the differences in scale and complexity between the two periods, emphasizing that the volume of cancellations and the number of affected entities were significantly smaller after WWI. The authors argue for prioritizing speedy and just settlements over meticulous ones, recognizing the potential economic costs of delayed transitions to peacetime production. Keywords: war contracts, contract termination, World War I, World War II, economic policy, government contracts, reconversion, settlement procedures.

title: For the conscientious objector, it is better to die than to kill
abstract: Article discussing conscientious objection. References Buddhism, Gandhi, pacifism and the Christian church and both world war
summary: This article explores conscientious objection, focusing on individuals who refuse to participate in warfare based on moral or religious principles. It examines the perspectives of figures like Vajrabandhu, an ordained Western Buddhist, and historical examples such as Gandhi. The discussion delves into the ethical dilemmas of non-violent resistance against absolute evil, drawing parallels to challenges posed by regimes like Nazi Germany. The text also critically assesses modern applications of pacifism, considering the complexities of international conflict, arms trade, and the fusion of Eastern and Western ethics. Key themes include pacifism, non-violence, and the morality of warfare.

title: Zombie Army: The Canadian Army and Conscription in the Second World War (Book Review)  by Daniel Byers
abstract: Review of Zombie Army: The Canadian Army and Conscription in the Second World War by Daniel Byers
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Canadian History, World War II
summary: This review examines Daniel Byers' book, "Zombie Army: The Canadian Army and Conscription in the Second World War." The book explores the contentious issue of conscription in Canada during WWII, focusing on the deployment of conscripts to Europe late in the war due to high casualties. The reviewer discusses the historical context and public perception of conscripts, who were often labeled a "zombie army." While acknowledging the book's broad coverage, the reviewer suggests a deeper analysis of conscripts' combat performance could have been included, comparing it to recent scholarship on similar topics in WWI. The review highlights the significance of conscription in Canadian military history.

title: War Correspondents
abstract:
At its outbreak, newspapers in the Allied and neutral democracies hoped to present vivid descriptions of the First World War. They were soon frustrated. Censorship obstructed the

adventurous style of war reporting to which readers had grown accustomed. Belligerent governments wanted journalists to encourage enlistment and maintain home front morale.

Many newspapers in Britain, France and America were content to behave as patriotic propagandists. All were constrained by rules and circumstances. War correspondents

downplayed misery and extolled victory. Soldiers found their behavior hard to forgive. War reporting promoted the belief that newspapers could not be trusted to tell the truth
fieldOfStudy: History, War Correspondents, Censorship, Propaganda, First World War
summary: This article examines how censorship during the First World War impacted war reporting in Allied and neutral democracies, frustrating journalists' attempts to provide vivid descriptions of the conflict. Belligerent governments used censorship to encourage enlistment and maintain home front morale, leading many newspapers to behave as patriotic propagandists. Consequently, war correspondents downplayed misery and extolled victory, which soldiers found hard to forgive, ultimately fostering public distrust in newspapers. The study aims to contrast the prevailing view of over-optimistic reporting with the argument that correspondents depicted grim realities as accurately as possible within constraints, focusing on censorship, propaganda, and journalistic practices.

title: Russo-German Negotioations Leading to the Second World War
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Soviet and Post-Soviet Studies
summary: This article examines the Russo-German negotiations preceding the Second World War, aiming to demystify Soviet foreign policy during this critical period. It analyzes the diplomatic interactions and strategic calculations of both nations, particularly focusing on the events leading to the invasion of Poland. The text explores key dates, orders, and statements from prominent figures like Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin, shedding light on the complex geopolitical landscape of 1938-1939 and Hitler's expansionist plans. This historical analysis provides insights into the immediate causes of the global conflict, emphasizing the roles of military history and Soviet studies.

title: Love and War: A Serendipitous Sweetheart Story
abstract: Let me just say that I love that its my job to read and process the recorded memories of alumni during World War II. It is just so amazing to me that I can take part in the eternal preservation of these pieces of history! As I mentioned in my last post, I am in the midst of processing a collection of letters, papers and photographs compiled by the senior editor of the Gettysburg Magazine, Jerold Wikoff. Last week, I spent the majority of my time simply reading through and getting to know the stories of various Gettysburg alums that lived through the Second World War. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: Archival Science, World War II, College Archive
summary: This blog post details the process of archiving recorded memories of Gettysburg College alumni who lived through World War II. The author, an intern at Musselman Library, focuses on processing a collection of letters, papers, and photographs compiled by Jerold Wikoff for Gettysburg Magazine. A significant part of this involves collecting "sweetheart stories" from alumni who met at Gettysburg. The author shares a particularly serendipitous love story between Robert and Esther Kenyon Fortenbaugh, emphasizing the personal connection to the Fortenbaugh Internship. Keywords: archival science, World War II, WWII, Gettysburg College, alumni stories, love stories, college archives, war memoir.

title: Christian World Community and the Cold War  Projects Statement
summary: This project statement, "Christian World Community and the Cold War," addresses the role of churches and ecumenical organizations during the Cold War (1945-1989/90). It highlights the period's complexity, characterized by political, ideological, diplomatic, economic, social, and military dimensions. The study aims to analyze how religious institutions navigated this era, the impact of the Cold War on Christian unity and mission, and the persistent divisions within and between churches. It seeks to understand the historical context and its relevance to contemporary challenges concerning justice and peace, inviting further research into this under-examined aspect of Cold War history.

title: Japan and the Second World War as Global History
publisher: Institute of Japan Studies, Tokyo University of Foreign Studies
fieldOfStudy: History, Global History, World War II
