The work involved analyzing visual details to extract historical narratives and engaging with the challenge of writing for a popular audience. Key findings include the importance of interdisciplinary approaches to history and the symbolic interpretation of landscapes, such as comparing decimated trees to fallen soldiers at Culp's Hill.

title: Wittingly Effaced for Too Long: Hidden in Plain Sight
abstract: A few years ago, Gettysburg College changed their wordmark. The previous college logo featured the words  Gettysburg College  topped with a line art version of the flag flying from the cupola of Pennsylvania Hall. The logo explicitly acknowledged the sense of place, referencing the 34-star flag which flies above the Civil War era field hospital both night and day. The logo acknowledged the Civil War inherently. [excerpt

The author explores how the college's students and faculty connect with the historical landscape and uncovers intriguing artifacts from a 1937 excavation on campus, including human remains and Civil War-era items. The piece advocates for embracing complex histories rather than avoiding them, emphasizing the rich stories embedded in Gettysburg's past.

title: Marching in Step:  USCT Veterans and the Grand Army of the Republic
abstract: For many United States Colored Troops, remembering the Civil War and their comrades who fell in it became an important part of their post-war life. One of the primary opportunities for public expression of remembrance was Decoration Day, now known as Memorial Day. African Americans played a critical part in the creation of this holiday. On May 1, 1865, the newly-freed black residents of Charleston asserted their place in Civil War memory by leading a parade to a recently constructed cemetery for Union prisoners at the city’s horseracing course. The procession heaped flowers upon the graves of the honored dead, after which ministers from the town’s black congregations gave dedicatory speeches. This event, known among some in the North as the “First Decoration Day,” exemplified African American interest in perpetuating the memory of the Civil War. However, the resentment of white Southerners at the time towards this instance of black agency led to the marginalization and eventual forgetting of the event in the mind of the public at large

The study highlights how white Southern resentment led to the forgetting of this black agency. title: Russia’s Home Front, 1914-1922: The Economy
abstract: This paper describes the main trends of the Russian economy through the Great War (1914 to 1917), Civil War (1918 to 1921), and postwar famine (1921 to 1922) for the general reader. During its Great War mobilization the Russian economy declined, but no more than other continental economies under similar pressures. In contrast, the Civil War inflicted the greatest economic trauma that Russians suffered in the course of the twentieth century. The paper identifies the main shocks in each period evaluates the relative contributions of circumstances and policy, and sums up their historical significance.Civil War, Russia, Soviet Union, World War I
fieldOfStudy: History, Civil War, Russia, Soviet Union, World War I, Economic History
summary: This paper examines the economic trends in Russia during the Great War (1914-1917), Civil War (1918-1921), and postwar famine (1921-1922). It asserts that while the Russian economy declined during World War I mobilization, it did not suffer more than other continental economies. In stark contrast, the Civil War inflicted the most severe economic trauma of the 20th century. The study identifies key shocks in each period, evaluates the impact of circumstances and policy, and analyzes their historical significance for Russia and the Soviet Union, providing valuable insights for economic historians.

title: Drought and Civil War in Sub-Saharan Africa
abstract: In this paper, we show that drought has a positive effect on the incidence of civil war over the 1945-2005 period in Sub-Saharan Africa. We use the Palmer Drought Severity Index which is a richer measurement of drought than the measures used in the literature (rainfall and temperature) as it measures the accumulation of water in the soil in taking into account the temperature and the geological characteristics of the soil. We show that the risk of civil war increases by more than 42% from a “normal” climate to an “extremely drought” climate. Surprisingly, only 2.5% of this effect is channeled through economic growth.Climate Change, Drought, Civil War
fieldOfStudy: History, Climate Change, Drought, Civil War
summary: This paper investigates the positive effect of drought on civil war incidence in Sub-Saharan Africa between 1945 and 2005. The study employs the Palmer Drought Severity Index, a more comprehensive drought measurement accounting for soil water accumulation, temperature, and geological characteristics, unlike simpler rainfall and temperature metrics. Findings reveal that the risk of civil war increases by over 42% from a normal to an extremely drought-prone climate. Surprisingly, economic growth accounts for only 2.5% of this observed effect. Key terms include drought, civil war, climate change, and economic growth.

The OAH debuted their new Imperiled Promise report on NPS history practices (which Jake commented on last week). Kevin Levin participated with other Civil War folks on a Civil War Working Group discussing the course of the 150th and beyond. [excerpt

It discusses the OAH's "Imperiled Promise" report on NPS history practices and Kevin Levin's participation in a Civil War Working Group. The author explores innovative approaches to connect the Civil War to the American public, including a YouTube video series from Greater Washington National Parks that juxtaposes a modern soldier with historical sites, and considers finding deeper meaning through unconventional contextualization. title: The Economics of US Civil War Conscription
abstract: The US government had limited power during the Civil War, including an inability to tax income. Similar to conscription plans considered in the War of 1812, Civil War conscription was not intended to compel service, but was a second-best plan to shift the tax burden to state and local governments. The time allowed communities to provide volunteers after a federal call for enlistments, along with substitution and the payment of a fee to avoid service (commutation), meant few were actually drafted---about 2% of all who served. Commutation could have lowered social cost, but appears to have been a binding ceiling on the price of a substitute.
summary: This paper examines the economics of US Civil War conscription, arguing that it was a second-best solution to shift the tax burden to state and local governments, rather than to compel service. Due to provisions like substitution and commutation (payment to avoid service), only about 2% of those who served were actually drafted. The study suggests that while commutation could have lowered social costs, it acted as a binding ceiling on the price of a substitute. Keywords include conscription, substitutes, and commutation, which are important for understanding military recruitment and economic policy during wartime.

title: Richard D. Dunphy and The Prices and Prizes of War
abstract: Like many immigrants during the mid-nineteenth century, Irishman Richard D. Dunphy served his new country in the Civil War, albeit not entirely willingly. The wounds he sustained during the war were grave, including the loss of both arms. He received some reward for his sacrifice from his country: a monthly pension, a Medal of Honor, and a notability lacked by other faceless coal heavers. As with other great conflicts, the war played a pivotal role in the lives of its participants, especially in the case of Richard Dunphy. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History
summary: This blog post examines the experiences of Richard D. Dunphy, an Irish immigrant who served in the American Civil War, highlighting the profound impact of the conflict on his life. Despite grave wounds, including the loss of both arms, Dunphy received a monthly pension and the Medal of Honor, achieving a certain notability. The piece explores how his wartime sacrifices led to recognition and how his family continued a legacy of service, providing insights into the lasting personal and societal costs of war for immigrants in the mid-nineteenth century.

title: The Good, the Great, and the Ugly of Public History
abstract: My last post recounted some of my favorite takeaways from my Civil War road trip this summer. But this trip was about more than just mosquito bites and cheap donuts; it was the first time I ever visited a historical site as a student of public history. My first tour was with Elizabeth Smith ’17 at the Sunken Road at Fredericksburg. Elizabeth’s tour was unique in that she was able to connect the events that transpired along Marye’s Heights, a moderately nuanced subject, to President Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address, a very well-known subject. I was delighted to see this connection that appealed to a wide audience. For the hardcore Civil Warrior, Elizabeth’s accounts of the 5th New Hampshire and Cobb’s Georgia Legion gave the military historian exactly what he or she was looking for. Tying the mortality of the common soldier and the pathos of the war-torn nation that was so evident at Fredericksburg to the familiar and powerful Gettysburg Address gave the casual Civil War enthusiast something relatable (and perhaps it provided a new perspective to the hardened military historian as well). Her knowledge of her audience combined with her ability to connect broad themes to specifics and the importance of location demonstrated Elizabeth’s skill as a public historian [excerpt]

summary: This blog post examines the qualities of effective public history through the author's Civil War road trip experiences. It highlights two distinct tours: one at Fredericksburg, connecting specific battle events to the Gettysburg Address for broad appeal, and another at Cold Harbor, emphasizing accessibility and personal connection. The author evaluates tour guides' abilities to engage diverse audiences, provide accurate information, and contextualize historical sites, ultimately advocating for public historians who can balance factual detail with relatable narratives and audience understanding. Keywords: public history, Civil War, Fredericksburg, Gettysburg Address, Cold Harbor, historical interpretation.

title: Drought and Civil War in Sub-Saharan Africa
abstract: We show that civil war is strongly related to drought in sub-Saharan Africa. We consider the eect of variations in the Palmer Drought Severity Index (Palmer 1965) - a cumulative index that combines precipitation, temperature and the local characteristics of the soil - on the risk of civil war. While the recent, contentious debate on the link between climate and civil war has mainly focused on precipitation and temperature, without obtaining converging results, the Palmer index describes social exposure to water stress in a more ecient way. We show that it is a key factor of civil war in sub-Saharan Africa and that this result is robust to various specications and passes a series of sensitivity tests. Also, our results indicate that agriculture, ethnic diversity and institutional quality are important factors to link climate and civil war.
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between climate and civil war, focusing on sub-Saharan Africa. It utilizes the Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI), a cumulative measure of hydrological stress, arguing it is more effective than precipitation or temperature alone for describing social exposure to water stress. The study employs a large dataset and various sensitivity tests, including country fixed effects and alternative sample periods, to establish a robust link between drought and civil war in post-independence sub-Saharan African states. Key findings indicate that agriculture, ethnic diversity, and institutional quality are also important factors connecting climate and conflict. This research contributes to the debate on climate change and conflict.

title: Murder in Manassas: Mental Illness and Psychological Trauma After the Civil War
abstract: Following the American Civil War, the small railroad junction of Manassas, Virginia grew into one of the most prominent towns in the region with the help of town founder William S. Fewell and his family. In 1872, the youngest daughter of the prominent Fewell family was seduced and abducted by Prince Williams County’s Commonwealth Attorney and most prominent orator, James F. Clark without warning. Having just come home from three years of military service in the Civil War, witnessing the death of his twin brother as well as suffering for a year in Elmira Prison as a prisoner of war, Lucien N. Fewell walked into Clark’s jail and murdered his younger sister’s abductor. Acquitted of murder on the terms of mental illness, Lucien Fewell continued to live a life of violence caused by his traumatic experiences during the Civil War. Like many soldiers who came home from the Civil War, Lucien Fewell gives historians an insight into those who came home with combat-induced mental illnesses, as he came back from his military services a changed and violent man
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This paper examines the life of Lucien N. Fewell, focusing on how his traumatic experiences during the American Civil War, including witnessing his twin brother's death and suffering as a prisoner of war, led to severe mental illness and violent behavior. Following his sister's abduction, Fewell murdered her abductor and was acquitted on grounds of mental illness. His case provides historical insight into combat-induced psychological trauma among Civil War veterans, demonstrating the profound and lasting impact of warfare on individuals and society in the post-war period in Manassas, Virginia.

title: Food, Fuel and Fodder: Civil War Carbon Footprints
abstract: Thursday morning finds me presenting to a group of fellow NPS folks on the possibilities of the interpretive futures. So I\u27ve dragged out some older, weirder interpretive dreaming from a few years back. It\u27s something I worked up for my friend and boss David Larsen to prove that topics like Climate Change can be discussed from any perspective and in any context.   But this sort of dreaming can\u27t stay locked in drawers, left on the backs of envelopes and stuffed away in digital filing cabinets back at work. So here\u27s a peek at what I\u27m presenting. It\u27s a way of visualizing impacts, Civil War and otherwise, on the world around us. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Public History, Social History, United States History, Environmental History, Civil War Era Studies
summary: This presentation explores innovative ways to interpret the Civil War, specifically by connecting it to contemporary issues like climate change. The author, a National Park Service employee, aims to demonstrate that historical topics can be discussed from diverse perspectives and contexts. The work visualizes the environmental impacts of the Civil War, calculating the carbon footprint of transporting fodder for the Army of the Potomac's artillery. Using mid-19th century steam engine data, it quantifies coal consumption and CO2 emissions, revealing that the war's transport carbon cost for artillery feed was equivalent to only 48 hours of a modern coal-burning power plant's production. This highlights historical environmental impacts and offers a novel interpretive approach.

title: Students Shine a Light on Syrian Civil War
abstract: A course examining human behavior through the lens of the Syrian conflict inspires students to raise awareness on campus
summary: A Roger Williams University course on human behavior, viewed through the Syrian conflict, inspired students to organize a candlelight vigil. The vigil aimed to raise awareness about the struggles of Syrian refugees and foster discussion within the campus community. Students, including organizers Emma Gengo and Liz Sledge, sought to help peers digest global events and put the humanitarian crisis into perspective. The event concluded with a call for continued engagement and discussion through the “Quest for Refuge” series, emphasizing a human duty to acknowledge and address such struggles.

title: Review: Looming Civil War
abstract: In Looming Civil War, Phillips writes about the future, specifically, the one predicted by nineteenth-century Americans in the years preceding the Civil War. Challenging dominant narratives of the war, Phillips argues that nineteenth-century individuals were fully aware of a looming civil war and that many believed it would be a long, bloody, and disastrous conflict, not just a short excursion. As individuals looked to the uncertain future, they all made predictions unique to their race, religion, gender, and location. Some white southern elites saw the looming war as an Armageddon that would destroy civilized society, while abolitionists and slaves saw war as a harbinger of freedom. Phillips seamlessly blends these abstract conceptualizations of war with physical realities by using material culture as his driving impetus, illustrating how nineteenth-century Americans interacted with the physical world in a way that both illustrated and influenced their conceptions of the future. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Public History, United States History
summary: Phillips' "Looming Civil War" examines nineteenth-century American predictions of the Civil War, challenging the notion that its severity was unforeseen. The book argues that individuals anticipated a long, bloody conflict, with perceptions varying based on race, religion, gender, and location. White Southern elites envisioned Armageddon, while abolitionists and enslaved people saw a harbinger of freedom. Phillips integrates these abstract conceptualizations with physical realities, using material culture to illustrate how Americans' interactions with the physical world both shaped and reflected their understanding of the impending war. Key terms: Civil War, nineteenth-century America, material culture, historical predictions.

title: Competing Stories: The Gardner Saga Continues
abstract: In 1893, two Philadelphia doctors from the Mütter Museum sent surveys to Civil War amputee veterans in order to compile records on their war amputations circa thirty years after seeing combat. One of those surveys found its way into the hands of Clark Gardner, a fifty-four year old double amputee vet who served in the 10th New York Heavy Artillery. (An introduction to Garnder can be found here.) Gardner’s responses to the survey are quite compelling and provided vivid details about his war amputations, the healing processes, difficulties he encountered, and artificial limb usage. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, History of Science, Technology, and Medicine, United States History
summary: This article examines the case of Clark Gardner, a Civil War double amputee veteran, focusing on inconsistencies between his 1893 Mütter Museum amputation survey and his 1907 pension deposition. Doctors from Philadelphia's Mütter Museum surveyed Civil War amputee veterans to compile records on their war injuries. Gardner's vivid survey responses detailed his amputations, healing, difficulties, and artificial limb use. However, his later testimony contradicted the heroic battle wound narrative, suggesting his amputations stemmed from sickness, not combat, raising questions of pension fraud. This analysis highlights the complexities of historical records and veteran claims.

title: Guest Post: John Rambo fights the Civil War
abstract: Today we offer another of our “Guest Post Wednesday” extras, with some meditations on Rambo from Aaron Urbanski. Yeah, we’re not kidding... Rambo. Aaron is a graduate of the GMU American History Masters program and alumnus Ranger of the NPS. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Cultural History, Public History, Social History, United States History, Civil War Era Studies, Civil War Interpretation
summary:
This guest post by Aaron Urbanski from the National Park Service offers an unconventional meditation on the American Civil War, using the character of Rambo as a lens for interpretation. The author, a GMU American History Masters graduate, explores methods of connecting the Civil War to the American public, particularly focusing on memorialization and engagement. It proposes innovative approaches, like public transportation memorials, to help individuals find meaning in historical contexts during daily routines. The discussion emphasizes the importance of understanding numbers and incorporating unexpected elements to share history effectively, even humorously suggesting a 
Rambo-style
 act by a Civil War leader.

title: A Soldier and his Nurse: The Star-Crossed Tragedy of Frank and Arabella Barlow
abstract: This is not a love story ready-made for Hollywood. Rather, it is one more suited for a Shakespearean tragedy. Two newlyweds, on the day after their marriage, were separated by the call for troops in Mr. Lincoln’s War. As was true of so many Civil War couples, only one would survive the war. While you may be thinking to yourself that you’ve heard this story before (and perhaps many of you have), the tale of these two star-crossed lovers does not fit the typical narrative behind the vacant chair. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History, American Civil War
summary: This blog post recounts the tragic love story of Frank and Arabella Barlow, two newlyweds separated by the American Civil War. The narrative focuses on their star-crossed fate, where only one survived the conflict, departing from typical "vacant chair" stories. It highlights Arabella's role as a devoted nurse and Frank's eventual wish for a monument to loyal Civil War women, which was realized with the American Red Cross headquarters. The piece aims to provide a unique perspective on personal sacrifices during the war through the lens of this specific couple. Their story is presented as a Shakespearean tragedy rather than a Hollywood romance, emphasizing themes of love and loss.

title: The 2016 Fortenbaugh Lecture: Individual Responses to Lincoln’s Assassination
abstract:
Every year on November 19th, the anniversary of the Gettysburg Address, a distinguished scholar of the Civil War Era is invited to speak as part of the Robert Fortenbaugh Memorial Lecture and present an aspect of the Civil War in a format that the general public can understand. This year, the 55th annual Fortenbaugh Memorial Lecture was delivered by Dr. Martha Hodes of New York University. Dr. Hodes’ lecture was based on her book Mourning Lincoln and argued, based on personal primary sources from the immediate aftermath of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, that Americans’ responses were by no means consistent. Not everyone mourned, nor was everyone totally focused on the assassination, partly because there were differing visions for the nation’s future.
[excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Public History, United States History
summary: This document summarizes the 2016 Fortenbaugh Memorial Lecture, delivered by Dr. Martha Hodes of New York University, based on her book "Mourning Lincoln." The lecture argued, using personal primary sources from the immediate aftermath of Abraham Lincoln's assassination, that American responses were diverse and inconsistent. Not everyone mourned, and individuals held differing visions for the nation's future, preventing total focus on the assassination. Hodes' research emphasizes that sweeping generalizations about historical events, particularly concerning individual reactions, are often inaccurate. The lecture highlighted competing visions for the nation and the persistence of everyday life amidst a pivotal historical event, underscoring the lack of unanimity in response to Lincoln’s death.

title: POV: The controversy over Confederate Civil War monuments
summary: This article explores the controversy surrounding Confederate Civil War monuments, drawing on the author's expertise as an historian and preservationist. It emphasizes the power of historic sites to connect people to the past and foster critical thinking, while acknowledging the inherent problems with monuments associated with white supremacy. The author, having lived in Charlottesville, Virginia, critiques the notion of simply preserving all monuments and argues for the necessity of counter-monuments or the removal of racist constructions to reshape public spaces to reflect values of equity, inclusion, and democracy. This analysis contributes to debates on historical memory and public history.

title: Human Capital and Growth in the Post-Bellum South: A Separate but Unequal Story
abstract: This paper tests the importance of human capital in explaining convergence across states of the United States after 1880. Human capital levels are found to matter not only to a state's income level but also to its growth rate through technological diffusion. The South's low human capital levels immediately after the Civil War, combined with its active resistance in the Post-Bellum period to educating its population, both white and black, played an important role in reducing the speed of Southern conditional convergence toward the rest of the nation after the Civil War.
fieldOfStudy: History, Human Capital, Economic Growth, Convergence, Regional Analysis, U.S. Economic History, Southern U.S. Economic History, Racial Discrimination
summary: This paper investigates the role of human capital in explaining economic convergence among U.S. states from 1880 to 1950. It finds that human capital levels influence not only a state's income but also its growth rate through technological diffusion. A unique pattern in the agricultural South, characterized by reliance on work experience over formal education and racial discrimination in schooling, significantly lowered human capital accumulation for both Black and white populations. This low human capital, coupled with post-Civil War resistance to education, substantially reduced the speed of Southern conditional convergence towards the rest of the nation.

title: High stakes and low bars: How international recognition shapes the conduct of civil wars
abstract: When rebel groups engage incumbent governments in war for control of the state, questions of international recognition arise. International recognition determines which combatants can draw on state assets, receive overt military aid, and borrow as sovereigns—all of which can have profound consequences for the military balance during civil war. How do third-party states and international organizations determine whom to treat as a state's official government during civil war? Data from the sixty-one center-seeking wars initiated from 1945 to 2014 indicate that military victory is not a prerequisite for recognition. Instead, states generally rely on a simple test: control of the capital city. Seizing the capital does not foreshadow military victory. Civil wars often continue for many years after rebels take control and receive recognition. While geopolitical and economic motives outweigh the capital control test in a small number of important cases, combatants appear to anticipate that holding the capital will be sufficient for recognition. This expectation generates perverse incentives. In effect, the international community rewards combatants for capturing or holding, by any means necessary, an area with high concentrations of critical infrastructure and civilians. In the majority of cases where rebels contest the capital, more than half of its infrastructure is damaged or the majority of civilians are displaced (or both), likely fueling long-term state weakness
summary: This study investigates how international recognition shapes the conduct of civil wars, focusing on how third-party states and international organizations determine which combatant to recognize as a state's official government. Analyzing data from sixty-one center-seeking wars (1945-2014), the research finds that control of the capital city, rather than military victory, is the primary criterion for recognition. This incentivizes combatants to capture or hold capitals by any means, often resulting in significant damage to infrastructure and displacement of civilians, which fuels long-term state weakness. The paper suggests alternative recognition criteria, such as battlefield conduct, to improve outcomes during civil conflict.

title: The End is Near: The Civil War in 1864
abstract: In the minds of most Civil War lovers, the year 1864 marks the noticeable shift from a conciliatory war to a hard war. Most view it through the lens of Ulysses S. Grant’s Overland Campaign, through William Tecumseh Sherman’s March to the Sea, through the successes of the Union Army. After all, the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863 is seen as the ‘high tide of the Confederacy,’ marking the falling action point in the war when total Union victory became inevitable. But in actuality, 1864 was just as—if not more—critical to the outcome of the war than the prior three years. The changing character of the war in that year muddled who was actually succeeding, making clear winners and losers unknown. Additionally, Abraham Lincoln’s reelection hung in the balance; a presidential change-up would alter the nature of war, especially if George B. McClellan were victorious. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History, American Civil War
summary: This study challenges the conventional view of 1864 in the American Civil War as merely a period of inevitable Union victory following Gettysburg. It argues that 1864 was a critical year marked by a shift to a 'hard war' where clear winners and losers were obscured, and Abraham Lincoln's reelection hung in the balance, potentially altering the war's nature. The research highlights the uncertainty experienced by both soldiers and civilians, suggesting that decisive victories were absent and the war's conclusion remained ambiguous until 1865, thus urging a re-evaluation of historical hindsight.

title: Designing an interactive multimedia instructional environment: the civil war interactive
abstract: This article describes the rationales behind the design decisions made in creating The Civil War Interactive, an interactive multimedia instructional product based on Ken Burns''s film series The Civil War
summary: This article details the design rationales behind "The Civil War Interactive," an educational multimedia product. Based on Ken Burns's popular film series, the interactive environment aims to instruct users on the American Civil War. The design decisions consider how to effectively convey historical information through an interactive medium, building upon the widespread engagement generated by the original documentary. Key aspects include integrating multimedia elements and instructional strategies to enhance learning about this pivotal period in American history. The work emphasizes the challenges and considerations in developing engaging educational software from existing historical content.

title: Profiles in Patriotism: Muslims and the Civil War
abstract: While many minority groups have had their contributions and accomplishments during the Civil War recognized, one group of Americans has received little attention. Muslim Americans are rarely the focus of Civil War scholars and are typically viewed as a demographic relevant only to more modern history. This should not be the case. In fact, Muslim Americans have served in virtually every armed conflict in United States history and left their mark on every era, including the Civil War. A simple search using the Civil War Soldiers and Sailors System (CWSS) reveals several names associated with Islam, including two Mahomets, two Hasans, three Rahmans, three Alis, 17 Saids, and 58 Hassans. In his Muslim Veterans of American Wars, Amir N. Muhammad theorized that as many as 292 Muslim last names appear in muster roles. Additionally, as many as 15% of African slaves brought to America are believed to have practiced Islam. While these summary statistics provide an overview of the scope of Muslim American involvement in the Civil War Era, their personal stories truly show their importance in shaping America
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History, Public History
summary: This blog post argues that Muslim Americans played a significant but largely unrecognized role in the American Civil War, challenging the common perception that they are relevant only to modern history. It highlights that Muslim Americans served in various conflicts, including the Civil War, and provides statistical evidence from the Civil War Soldiers and Sailors System (CWSS) revealing numerous names associated with Islam. The author cites Amir N. Muhammad's theory of up to 292 Muslim last names in muster roles and notes that up to 15% of African slaves may have practiced Islam. This work emphasizes the importance of acknowledging these contributions for a complete understanding of American history.

title: Theatre of War: a witness to love, tragedy, and parody
abstract: Central to American nineteenth century life was the theater. As the fratricidal fighting of the American Civil War broke out and divided the nation, this centrality remained, and audiences crowded into the theaters. For both north and south, the theater provided an outlet through which Americans could enjoy plays, performances, music, and variety shows that appealed to all social classes of American society. However, in order to understand the operations of theater companies during the war itself, it is first essential to examine the state of the theater as a concept during the mid-nineteenth century, and in the pre-war years. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Theatre History, United States History
summary: This post examines the central role of theater in American life during the nineteenth century, particularly before and during the American Civil War. It explores how theater provided an essential outlet for entertainment across all social classes, offering plays, music, and variety shows. The discussion highlights the operations of theater companies, including benefit performances for actors, and the diverse types of theatrical entertainment available, from symphonies to minstrel shows. The article emphasizes the significant role of popular theater in presenting patriotic displays and spectacles during the war, using examples such as performances featuring "Liberty" and "Justice" to instill patriotic fervor.

title: Foreign Interventions and Abuse of Civilians during the Peruvian Civil War
abstract: The international community has a declared intention to protect innocent civilians from direct and deliberate violence in civil conflicts, but its track record of actually doing so is mixed. Using a new monthly time-series data set, we explore the factors associated with variations in the number of civilians killed or wounded by participants in the civil war in Peru during the 1980s and 1990s. We find that an increase in the level of abuse by one side is strongly associated with subsequent increases in the level of abuse by the other. Certain types of foreign intervention had a large and statistically significant impact on the level of abuse; some types of intervention raised the level of violence, but others reduced it.Peru, civil war, conflict, abuse against civilians
fieldOfStudy: History, civil war, conflict, abuse against civilians, foreign intervention
summary: This paper investigates the effectiveness of international efforts to protect civilians from violence in civil conflicts, focusing on the Peruvian civil war during the 1980s and 1990s. Utilizing a new monthly time-series dataset, the authors explore factors influencing the number of civilians killed or wounded. Key findings indicate a strong correlation where increased abuse by one side leads to subsequent increases by the other. Furthermore, certain types of foreign intervention significantly impacted violence levels, with some raising and others reducing abuse. This study provides insights into civil conflict dynamics, civilian protection, and the effects of foreign intervention in Peru.

title: Beyond Greed and Grievance: Feasibility and Civil War
abstract: A key distinction among theories of civil war is between those that are built upon motivation and those that are built upon feasibility. We analyze a comprehensive global sample of civil wars for the period 1965-2004 and subject the results to a range of robustness tests. The data constitute a substantial advance on previous work. We find that variables that are close proxies for feasibility have powerful consequences for the risk of a civil war. Our results substantiate the ’feasibility hypothesis’ that where civil war is feasible it will occur without reference to motivation.
fieldOfStudy: History, Political Science, Civil War Studies
summary: This study analyzes a global sample of civil wars from 1965-2004 to distinguish between motivation-driven and feasibility-driven theories of conflict. Employing extensive data and robustness tests, the research identifies powerful correlations between variables indicative of feasibility and the risk of civil war. The findings strongly support the 'feasibility hypothesis,' asserting that civil wars occur when feasible, independent of underlying motivations. This work advances previous empirical analyses by offering a comprehensive quantitative approach to understanding civil war determinants, emphasizing feasibility, conflict risk, and global civil war patterns.

title: Forever Free : It\u27s Deja Vu All Over Again
abstract: A friend and colleague has a great quip she uses when planning Civil War interpretation in the DC area.  Why,  she asks,  would a black single mother with two daughters come to this event? What\u27s here for her?  [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Cultural History, Public History, Social History, United States History, Civil War Era Studies, Civil War Interpretation
summary: This blog post by John M. Rudy examines the challenges of making Civil War interpretation relevant to a broader, more diverse American public, using a colleague's quip about engaging a Black single mother as a focal point. It argues against merely reaching traditional audiences and advocates for expanding the narrative's reach to ensure all Americans find meaning in the Civil War story. The author proposes a national signature event celebrating Emancipation and Lincoln's courage, ideally hosted by the National Park Service, to attract widespread media attention and increase visitor numbers, citing Gettysburg College's efforts as a positive example.

title: History is Good Drama: BBC’s “Copper”
abstract: BBC America’s programming covers a wide range of genres, presenting characters, and settings that appeal to viewers around the world. In 2012, BBC began airing Copper, a period drama set in the ethnically diverse, crime and disease-ridden Five Points neighborhood in New York City in the late-Civil War years. The title, taken from the slang term for a police officer, centers on police detective work in the rapidly growing urban center. The characterizations, as well as the situations presented are not far off from historical fact. For various reasons, many of the characters have returned to the Five Points, and their experiences in war have ended, though the war itself rages on. As a result, their attitudes take on an historical tone of post-Civil War society, though the show takes place in the late-war years of 1863 and 1864. This is not an anachronistic flaw in the show, but rather depicts the characters’ own struggles to carry on in American society through the late-war years now that they have returned from war, and that their combat experiences have come to an end. Therefore, the following questions arise: what post-Civil War themes does “Copper” depict for television audiences, and how does the show contribute to the surge of both print and mass media in relation to the American Civil War? In this segment, we will consider the themes found in the show in terms of the post-war sentiments expressed by characters. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, United States History, American Civil War
summary: This analysis examines BBC America's period drama "Copper," set in late-Civil War New York City's Five Points. The show explores post-Civil War themes and characters' struggles to adapt to civilian life after combat, despite the war still raging. The purpose is to investigate how "Copper" depicts these societal attitudes and contributes to modern mass media representations of the American Civil War. It considers the series' historical accuracy and its engagement with rapid social changes in diverse urban neighborhoods, appealing to both Civil War enthusiasts and general viewers.

title: Eritrean Refugees in Buffalo
abstract: Eritrea was once part of Ethiopia, but began a struggle for independence in the 1960s and finally became established as a separate country in 1993. The civil war that preceded the separation lasted for approximately 30 years, beginning while Eritrea was still considered part of Ethiopia and continued until 2000, even after independence was granted. Three waves of migration from Eritrea to the US occurred in the 1980s and 1990s, as refugees escaped the violent civil war, finding safety in refugee camps in surrounding countries, and then more recently as individuals (mostly men) sought to escape the mandatory national service. Despite the peace treaty with Ethiopia signed in 2000, there has been escalating tension along the border, along with discrimination against evangelical Christians and ethnic minority groups. The most common ethnic group in Eritrea is Tigrean
fieldOfStudy: History, Migration Studies, Eritrean Civil War
summary: This article examines the historical context of Eritrean independence and subsequent refugee migrations. It details Eritrea's struggle for independence from Ethiopia beginning in the 1960s, culminating in its establishment as a separate country in 1993, and the prolonged civil war until 2000. The study highlights three waves of Eritrean migration to the US, driven by the violent conflict and more recently by individuals escaping mandatory national service, also noting escalating border tensions and discrimination against evangelical Christians and ethnic minorities like the Tigrean group.

title: Unspeakable Suffering; Eloquent Explanations: National Civil War Medicine Museum’s 26th Annual Conference
abstract: On Friday, October 12th, 2018, the National Civil War Medicine Museum kicked off its 26th annual conference and began its three-day event with a series of lectures on topics ranging from Confederate medical practice to cultural understandings of cowardice. A series of unique lectures given by a professionally diverse cast of presenters illuminated the often-peripheral field of Civil War Medicine. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Public History, United States History, Civil War
summary: This paper summarizes the 26th annual conference of the National Civil War Medicine Museum, held in October 2018. The event featured diverse lectures exploring Civil War Medicine, encompassing topics from Confederate medical practices to cultural understandings of cowardice. Presenters utilized interdisciplinary methods, incorporating material culture, gender studies, and cultural history, which inspired attendees to reconsider their own research, particularly in curating a photography exhibit for the Civil War Institute. The conference highlighted the significant overlap between history, medicine, and science, offering new perspectives on a seemingly overpopulated field and encouraging groundbreaking scholarship.

title: To Begin the Nation Anew: Congress, Citizenship, and Civil Rights after the Civil War
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
summary: This article examines the revolutionary constitutionalism and new American federalism that Congress and Northern states sought to establish after the Civil War, specifically concerning citizenship and civil rights. It analyzes how, in the aftermath of the Dred Scott decision, Congress enacted measures like the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Amendments and the Civil Rights Act of 1866 to grant rights to Black Americans and centralize national authority. The paper argues that the Supreme Court, however, rejected this "revolutionary congressional Republican theory" in the 1870s, opting for a states' rights interpretation that limited federal enforcement authority and ultimately led to a "reactionary resurgence of states' rights," effectively undermining the gains of Reconstruction for Southern Black Americans. This analysis is relevant for understanding American constitutional history, federalism, and civil rights.

title: Dead is Dead: Why 20% Doesn\u27t Matter
abstract: Over at Cosmic America, Keith Harris beat me to the punch on this one. But Jake can attest to the fact that, since the  news  of the revision of Civil War dead up by 130,000 broke, I have been grumbling on and off
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Cultural History, Social History, Public History, United States History, Civil War Era Studies, Civil War Interpretation, Casualties
summary: John M. Rudy's blog post, "Dead is Dead: Why 20% Doesn't Matter," responds to the revision of Civil War casualty figures, which increased by 130,000. Rudy argues that while the statistical change is significant, the true understanding of the war's impact lies not in abstract numbers but in comprehending individual suffering. He uses vivid examples from Gettysburg to illustrate the personal tragedy behind each death, emphasizing that humanizing these experiences is crucial for connecting the Civil War to the American public and truly grasping the immense human cost.

title: Assessing Reconstruction: Did the South Undergo Revolutionary Change?
abstract: With the end of the Civil War, came a number of unanswered questions Reconstruction would attempt to answer for the South. While the South underwent economic, political and social changes for a short period, old traditions continued to persist resulting in racist sentiment
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, African American Studies, Cultural History, Military History, Political History, Race and Ethnicity, Social History, United States History
summary: This paper examines whether the South underwent revolutionary change during the Reconstruction era following the Civil War. It explores the economic, political, and social transformations that occurred for a brief period, ultimately arguing that old traditions and racist sentiments persisted despite these shifts. The analysis delves into the unanswered questions Reconstruction aimed to address and its long-term impact on Southern identity. Key methods involve historical assessment of primary and secondary sources. This study contributes to understanding post-Civil War American history, Southern culture, and the complexities of social change.

title: Beyond divide and rule: weak dictators, natural resources and civil conflict
abstract: We propose a model where an autocrat rules over an ethnically divided society. The dictator selects the tax rate over domestic production and the nation's natural resources to maximize his rents under the threat of a regime-switching revolution. We show that a weak ruler may let the country plunge in civil war to increase his personal rents. Inter-group fighting weakens potential opposition to the ruler, thereby allowing him to increase fiscal pressure. We show that the presence of natural resources exacerbatesthe incentives of the ruler to promote civil conflict for his own profit, especially if the resources are unequally distributed across ethnic groups. We validate the main predictions of the model using cross-country data over the period 1960-2007, and show that our empirical results are not likely to be driven by omitted observable determinants of civil war incidence or by unobservable country-specific heterogeneity.
summary: This study proposes a model where an autocrat in an ethnically divided society maximizes rents by setting tax rates on domestic production and natural resources, under the threat of revolution. The model demonstrates that a weak ruler may incite civil war to boost personal rents, as inter-group fighting weakens opposition, enabling increased fiscal pressure. The presence of natural resources, especially if unevenly distributed among ethnic groups, exacerbates the ruler's incentive to promote conflict. The model's predictions are validated using cross-country data from 1960-2007, showing robust empirical results not influenced by omitted variables or unobservable heterogeneity. Key concepts include autocracy, ethnic division, natural resources, civil conflict, and fiscal policy.

title: Russia’s home front, 1914-1922 : the economy
abstract:
This paper describes the main trends of the Russian economy

through the Great War (1914 to 1917), Civil War (1918 to 1921), and postwar

famine (1921 to 1922) for the general reader. During its Great War

mobilization the Russian economy declined, but no more than other

continental economies under similar pressures. In contrast, the Civil War

inflicted the greatest economic trauma that Russians suffered in the course

of the twentieth century. The paper identifies the main shocks in each period

evaluates the relative contributions of circumstances and policy, and sums up

their historical significance
publisher: Department of Economics, University of Warwick
summary: This paper analyzes the major economic trends in Russia during the Great War (1914-1917), Civil War (1918-1921), and postwar famine (1921-1922). It argues that while the Russian economy declined during World War I mobilization, it was comparable to other continental economies. However, the Civil War caused the most significant economic trauma of the 20th century. The study identifies key shocks in each period, evaluates the impact of circumstances versus policy, and discusses their historical significance, providing insights into Russia's economic history during these turbulent years. Key terms include Russian economy, Great War, Civil War, famine, economic trauma, and historical significance.

title: Confederate Memory
abstract: This year as a CWI Fellow, I’ve been doing a lot of research and thinking on Civil War memory, specifically that of Confederate memory. When doing this work, the question at the back of my mind is always: How should monuments, symbols, and other examples of Confederate memory be handled? This is a very difficult question, so up until now, I’ve left it alone, knowing that there would come a time in the future that I would sit down and wrestle with my conflicting opinions on the matter. A couple days ago, the Civil War Era Studies Department here at Gettysburg College sent out an email sharing the news that New Orleans had begun removing Confederate monuments and several other cities were thinking of doing the same. After reading this, I knew the time had come for me, and all of you, to join the discussion about Confederate Memory
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Public History, United States History
summary: This research explores the complex issue of Confederate memory, focusing on how monuments, symbols, and other representations of this historical period should be handled. Prompted by New Orleans' decision to remove Confederate monuments, the author delves into conflicting opinions surrounding their preservation or removal. The study encourages discussion on Civil War memory, its controversial symbols, and the ongoing debate about their place in public spaces, aiming to facilitate a dialogue on historical interpretation and public memorialization. Key themes include Confederate monuments, historical memory, public history, and the American Civil War.

title: The civil war
abstract: Elektronische Version der gedr. Ausg. 199
summary: This essay explores the competing identities of the American nation between the Revolution and the Civil War, arguing that these national identity struggles draw heavily on racial and sexual embodiments, even in discussions of seemingly unrelated institutions like the Declaration of Independence or the Bank of the United States. It traces the "miscegenated" nature of America's composite body, examining how authors like Mark Twain used metaphors of "monstrous birth" to imagine race. The analysis delves into literary and cultural texts, including theatrical adaptations of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," to reveal the pervasive anxieties and negotiations around race, gender, and national belonging during this tumultuous period, highlighting the role of cultural products in reflecting and shaping these complex identities.

title: The Forging of Freedom: Slave Refugee Camps in the Civil War: An Interview Amy Murrell Taylor
abstract: Today we are speaking with Amy Murrell Taylor, Associate Professor of History at the University of Kentucky. She is the author of Embattled Freedom: Journeys through the Civil War’s Slave Refugee Camps (UNC Press, 2018), as well as The Divided Family in Civil War America (UNC Press, 2005). Her research has been supported by fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities and the American Council of Learned Societies. Taylor has also served as a consultant for public history sites and is currently an editorial advisor for the Civil War Monitor magazine. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, Public History, United States History
summary:
This interview with Amy Murrell Taylor discusses her book, "Embattled Freedom: Journeys through the Civil War
						’s Slave Refugee Camps." Taylor explores the experiences of formerly enslaved people in Union-occupied camps during the Civil War, emphasizing the profound losses they faced even after emancipation due to the dismantling of these camps and the failure of land reform. The work highlights the central role of slavery in the war, the impact of African Americans on the Union war effort, and the inherent link between military history and emancipation, advocating for a revised public memory of this critical period in American history.

title: Arming of the U.S. Army During War 1861
abstract:
Grade Level: 9-12 
Lesson Length: 60 minutes
Learning Objectives:   The student will be able to identify the armament of the Union army at the beginning of the Civil War. The student will consider the preparedness of the Union and Confederate armies. The student compare and contrast prior knowledge about the Civil War to interpret historical documents. The student will be able to analyze and interpret a primary document
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History, Curriculum and Instruction
summary: This lesson plan, designed for 9th-12th grade students, focuses on the arming of the U.S. Army in 1861 during the American Civil War. Students will analyze primary documents, specifically "Illinois First Response to Civil War," to evaluate the Union army's preparedness and understand who was responsible for supplying uniforms and weapons. Key learning objectives include identifying Union armament, comparing Union and Confederate preparedness, and interpreting historical documents to discern the causes of confusion in early battles like the First Battle of Bull Run. The lesson culminates in an essay and exit ticket, fostering historical analysis skills.

title: Great War, Civil War, and Recovery: Russia’National Income, 1913 to 1928
abstract: The last remaining gap in the national accounts of Russia and the USSR in the twentieth century, 1913 to 1928, includes the Great War, the Civil War, and postwar recovery. Filling this gap, we find that the Russian economy did somewhat better in the Great War than was previously thought; in the Civil War it did correspondingly worse; war losses persisted into peacetime, and were not fully restored under the New Economic Policy. We compare this experience across regions and over time. The Great War and Civil War produced the deepest economic trauma of Russia’s troubled twentieth century.Civil War, GDP, Russia, Soviet Union, World War I
summary: This study addresses a gap in the national accounts of Russia and the USSR from 1913 to 1928, covering the Great War, Civil War, and postwar recovery. By filling this gap, the research reveals that the Russian economy performed better than previously believed during the Great War, but correspondingly worse during the Civil War. It also highlights that war losses persisted into peacetime and were not fully alleviated under the New Economic Policy. The paper compares these economic experiences across various regions and over time, concluding that the Great War and Civil War constituted Russia's most profound economic trauma of the twentieth century, with key terms including Civil War, GDP, Russia, Soviet Union, and World War I.

title: Special Collections Roadshow – Episode 9: Medical Kit
abstract: For our ninth episode we welcome our guest Dr. Ian Isherwood ’00 to talk about a Civil War medical kit and how to do research relating to Civil War medicine, as seen in the PBS series, Mercy Street. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, History of Science Technology and Medicine, Public History, Museum Studies
summary: This episode of the 'Special Collections Roadshow' features Dr. Ian Isherwood '00 discussing a Civil War medical kit and research methods for Civil War medicine, inspired by the PBS series 'Mercy Street.' Created by the Civil War Institute at Gettysburg College, the series highlights various artifacts from the college's special collections. The discussion provides insights into historical medical practices and the resources available for studying this period, including specific publications by Clements, Devine, Rutkow, and Schultz, alongside U.S. Army Medical Department manuals. This resource is valuable for historians and researchers of military and medical history.

title: Decolonizing civil war
abstract: This essay argues that there is a need to decolonize the genealogy of civil war. David Armitage’s new book brilliantly reveals civil war’s generative power in shaping European and North American conceptions of politics, revolution, and the laws of war. But to make sense of the discourse of civil war we also need to account for the constitutive exclusions of those whose struggles elite Europeans refused to recognize as “civil,” those not recognized as part of a common brotherhood or as co-belligerents. The absence/ presence of women, slaves, and barbarous armies is vital to the historical conception of civil war
publisher: University of Toronto, Faculty of Law
summary: This essay argues for a decolonized genealogy of civil war, building on David Armitage's work which reveals its power in shaping European and North American political and legal concepts. The author contends that understanding civil war discourse requires accounting for the historical exclusion of struggles by women, slaves, and

title: Theater of War: Combining entertainment and art
abstract: Did the theater work to benefit the causes for north or south, dependent upon region? Sautter stated that this phenomenon was less common than many might expect. Many actors stated their neutrality, or as one Civil War era actor said, “I am neither northerner nor southerner.” Still others simply responded to the war by leaving the country. One must consider the “clannish nature” of theater of the time in order to understand how actors could have taken the neutral role during a war of ideals: many actors were born into theater life, therefore did not grow up in any one city or region, and furthermore lived a life separate from the outside world where harsh realities allowed for the existence of slavery and social oppression. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Theatre History, United States History
summary: This article explores the role of theater during the American Civil War, challenging the common assumption that it primarily served partisan causes. It highlights that many actors maintained neutrality or even left the country due to the insular, "clannish nature" of theatrical life, as actors often lacked strong regional ties. While some performances fostered patriotism or offered satirical commentary, public sentiment and growing casualty lists increasingly made war a taboo subject, turning theater into a form of escapism rather than a direct reflection of conflict. The study uses insights from Richard Sautter's lecture on American theater during the Civil War.

title: Civil war: is it all about disease and xenophobia? A comment on Letendre, Fincher & Thornhill
abstract: Letendre, Fincher & Thornhill (2010) argue that pathogen intensity provides the ultimate explanation for why some countries are more prone to civil war than others. They argue that the economic and political factors highlighted in previous research on civil war are largely caused by underlying differences in pathogen intensity, and contend that disease proneness increases the risk of civil war through its effects on resource competition and xenophobia. They present empirical evidence that they interpret as consistent with their argument: a statistically significant correlation between pathogen intensity and civil war onset. In this comment, we raise concerns over their interpretation of the empirical evidence and their proposed causal mechanisms. We find that the data provide stronger evidence for the reverse causal relationship, namely that civil war causes disease to become more prevalent. This finding is consistent with the literatures on the public health effects of civil war as well as research on state capacity and public health.</jats:p
summary: This comment critically examines Letendre, Fincher & Thornhill's (2010) argument that pathogen intensity is the ultimate cause of civil war, influencing economic and political factors. Letendre et al. posited that disease proneness increases civil war risk through resource competition and xenophobia, presenting empirical evidence of a correlation between pathogen intensity and civil war onset. This study, however, challenges their interpretation and causal mechanisms, finding stronger evidence for the reverse: civil war causes an increase in disease prevalence. This finding aligns with research on the public health effects of conflict and state capacity.

title: “All May Visit the Big Camp”: Race and the Lessons of the Civil War at the 1913 Gettysburg Reunion
abstract: Shaping historical memory means extracting lessons from the past. Those lessons frame the debate about the nature of the present. Just months after the inauguration of Woodrow Wilson, the attention of most of the nation focused on the events scheduled to commemorate the semi-centennial of what was by then increasingly viewed as “the turning point” of the Civil War. The reunion at Gettysburg in 1913 constituted the contemporary public exegesis of the status of American memory of the Civil War. In this respect, the reunion in Gettysburg reflected the erasure of the legacy of emancipation and the unfulfilled promise of equality for African-Americans. Yet, almost all the public discourse at Gettysburg reflected no sense of disappointment; rather, the battle now represented a triumph of the American spirit. The presence of AfricanAmerican veterans would have complicated the message of white reconciliation at the reunion. Reckoning with the honorable service of black troops was not something mainstream American society felt comfortable with in 1913. Whether or not black veterans attended the fiftieth anniversary of Gettysburg is a small detail which illuminates a profoundly broader pair of subjects: the meaning of the Civil War and the nature of American race relations in 1913. In answering this question of black veterans at the Gettysburg reunion, the broader context of the organization and execution of the reunion, the lessons drawn from the ceremonies in Gettysburg, explicit discussions of race at the reunion and contemporary African-American perspectives must all be explored. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This paper examines the 1913 Gettysburg Reunion, analyzing how it shaped historical memory of the Civil War. It argues that the reunion, held months after Woodrow Wilson's inauguration, largely erased the legacy of emancipation and the unfulfilled promise of equality for African Americans, reflecting a white reconciliation narrative. The absence of African-American veterans and the broader context of race relations in 1913 are explored, revealing how mainstream society avoided acknowledging black troops' honorable service. The study considers the reunion's organization, lessons drawn from ceremonies, explicit discussions of race, and contemporary African-American perspectives to understand the meaning of the Civil War and racial dynamics of the era.

title: Civil War Summer
summary: This poem explores themes of violence, betrayal, and childhood experiences during a "Civil War Summer." It opens with a narrative of infidelity leading to a violent confrontation, followed by a lighter segment about bargain hunters. The core then shifts to a childhood friendship in Memphis, where a Northern child's persistent declaration of the South's defeat in the Civil War leads to teasing and ultimately a moment of shared discovery and vulnerability between the two boys, playfully connecting their personal history with the grander historical events.

title: UNH Web Site Generates Gifts of Civil War Artifacts
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
summary: This article highlights how the University of New Hampshire (UNH) Library's website has facilitated the acquisition of significant historical artifacts, particularly those related to the Civil War. The digital platform enables researchers, genealogists, and collectors worldwide to explore UNH's Special Collections and Archives, which include diverse materials such as Civil War artifacts, historical documents, photographs, and rare book collections. This online accessibility encourages donations and ensures important New Hampshire-related historical materials remain in public ownership and are easily discoverable. The initiative demonstrates technology's role in preserving and sharing history.

title: Civil War, Ethnicity, and the Migration of Skilled Labor
abstract: We investigate the impact of civil war on high skilled emigration rates to the OECD over the period 1985-2000. Controlling for economic and institutional characteristics of source countries, we find that civil war increases high skilled emigration by about 5 percent on the average. However, the nature of conflict matters: While brain drain from countries with ethnic conflict is about 6-8 percent greater on average than it is from countries without conflict, brain drain from countries with nonethnic conflict is less, and statistically insignificant. Duration also matters: Each additional year of ethnic conflict worsens the brain drain by between 0.4 and 1 percent, whereas the effect of an additional year of nonethnic conflict is small and insignificant.
fieldOfStudy: History, Migration Studies, Economics, Political Science
summary: This study examines the influence of civil war on high-skilled emigration to OECD countries from 1985 to 2000. Utilizing controls for economic and institutional factors in source nations, the research reveals that civil war, on average, escalates high-skilled emigration by approximately 5 percent. The nature and duration of conflict are critical; ethnic conflict significantly worsens brain drain (6-8% greater, 0.4-1% per additional year), while nonethnic conflict shows less and statistically insignificant impact. This research highlights the differentiated effects of conflict types on international migration patterns and brain drain.

title: The Rebel Flag: Offputting Symbol or Point of Pride?
abstract:
In 2004, Gettysburg College hosted an art exhibit by John Sims, a Florida based artist and ethnomathematician. The exhibit focused on varied recolored versions of the Confederate Flag. The press outrage was quick and damning. I should know, I was quoted in it (in the Civil War News).
Back in 2004, I called the exhibit,  sickening,  and condemned the college for,  trying to distance itself from the town by rejecting the Civil War past in which it is steeped.  I was wrong. I figured that out no sooner than passing through the doors of the art gallery and viewing the exhibit. Sims\u27 presentation was provocative and jarring, but had some of the most profound things to say about the Confederate Flag that I think can be said. It\u27s been six long years, my views have shifted and solidified, and I now look back on those words I spoke against Sims\u27 project in shame. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Cultural History, Public History, Social History, United States History
summary: This blog post reflects on a 2004 art exhibit by John Sims at Gettysburg College, which featured recolored versions of the Confederate Flag. Initially critical of the exhibit, the author, John M. Rudy, later re-evaluated his stance, recognizing the provocative display's profound commentary on the flag. The piece explores the evolving symbolism of the Confederate Flag, from its origins in the Civil War to its controversial use during the Jim Crow era and beyond. It critically examines how the flag became associated with hate speech and institutional segregation, questioning its contemporary display and its impact on visitors, particularly African Americans, at historical sites.

title: Two Steps Forward and One Step Back: An Assessment of How Uneven Economic Development Affects the Number of Civil Wars
abstract: The effects of economic development are enormously important in understanding the causes of civil war and the requirements for successful post-conflict reconstruction. In recent decades we have seen an increase in the number of civil wars because of a phenomenon known as the conflict trap. I question why we see an increase in civil wars and what role unstable economic development plays in contributing to the conflict trap. This paper offers evidence to support the hypothesis that uneven economic development increases the risk of multiple civil wars occurring in a short amount of time. Based on the results of testing my hypothesis I suggest that the conflict trap can be broken, and the risk of civil war decreased, when economic growth is stabilized. I suggest participation in the global economic community as a mechanism for stabilizing economic growth
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Peace and Conflict Studies, Political Science
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between unstable economic development and the increase in civil wars, particularly addressing the 'conflict trap' phenomenon. The author hypothesizes that uneven economic development heightens the risk of multiple civil wars within a short timeframe. The study provides evidence supporting this hypothesis and suggests that stabilizing economic growth, potentially through participation in the global economic community, can break the conflict trap and reduce civil war risks. Key themes include economic development, civil war, conflict trap, and global economics.

title: “Two Wars and the Long Twentieth Century:” A Response
abstract: Drew Gilpin Faust, president of Harvard University and renowned historian of the American Civil War, authored an article in the New Yorker recently entitled “Two Wars and the Long Twentieth Century.” Taken primarily from her remarks in the Rede Lecture delivered at the University of Cambridge earlier in 2015, Faust’s article takes advantage of the proximity of the anniversaries of the First World War and the American Civil War to advocate for a dialogue of greater continuity between the two conflicts. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Military History, United States History, Public History
summary: This article responds to Drew Gilpin Faust's "Two Wars and the Long Twentieth Century," originally a Rede Lecture and later published in the New Yorker. Faust advocates for a dialogue emphasizing continuity between the First World War and the American Civil War due to their anniversary proximity. The authors argue that Faust's comparisons are limited, particularly concerning the global impact of the First World War versus the American Civil War, and the profound, radical global changes the Great War ushered in, which truly shaped the twentieth century. They highlight technological differences, such as artillery, demonstrating the distinct industrial nature of the Great War. Key terms: American Civil War, First World War, twentieth century, historical comparison, global impact, military history.

title: Measuring the Economic Impact of Civil War
abstract: Civil wars impose substantial costs on the domestic economy. We empirically measure the economic impact of such internal wars. The paper contributes to the existing literature both theoretically and methodologically. First, it explores the economic channels through which civil war affects growth. Previous studies have shown the negative growth effects of civil wars. We go a step further by identifying the channels through which war strips a country of its growth potential. Our argument is that civil war negatively impacts private investment through the process of portfolio substitution. Methodologically, the paper improves on both the data and statistical models used in the existing literature. Our data set includes better measurements of the intensity and scope of civil war as well as new economic and political data for the 1990s. Moreover, using a multiple imputation technique, we minimize the estimation bias due to missing data. Finally, to improve the model, we apply fixed and random effects models to the panel data. The evidence gives strong support to our argument indicating that the driving force behind the negative effects of civil war on economic growth is a decrease in private investment.civil war, instability, economic growth, investment, fiscal balance
summary: This paper empirically measures the economic impact of civil wars, exploring the channels through which they affect economic growth. It argues that civil war negatively impacts private investment through portfolio substitution, stripping a country of its growth potential. Methodologically, the study improves on existing literature by utilizing better measurements of war intensity and scope, new economic and political data for the 1990s, and minimizing estimation bias with a multiple imputation technique. Fixed and random effects models are applied to panel data, providing strong support for the argument that decreased private investment drives the negative economic growth effects of civil war.

title: Revolution
abstract: This chapter compares the revolutions of 1789, 1848 and 1989 to examine the usefulness of the concepts of 'risk', and 'threat' in the development of revolutionary situations
summary: This chapter examines the revolutions of 1789, 1848, and 1989 to assess the utility of 'risk' and 'threat' concepts in understanding the development of revolutionary situations. Drawing on Victor Hugo's metaphor of revolutions as a subterranean force, the text explores the sense of brooding threat and powerlessness experienced by Europeans. It analyzes how underlying social and political factors contribute to revolutionary movements, emphasizing the deliberate and determined nature of these forces. The analysis helps in understanding historical events like the French Revolution and the fall of the Soviet Empire through the lens of perceived dangers.

title: University Scholar Series: Kim Komenich
abstract:
Revolution Revisited 
On March 21, 2012, SJSU Assistant Professor Kim Komenich spoke in the University Scholar Series hosted by Provost Ellen Junn at the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library. Kim Komenich worked for 30 years as a photojournalist for the San Francisco Chronicle and San Francisco Examiner. He was awarded the 1987 Pulitzer Prize in Spot News Photography for photographs of the Philippine Revolution he made while on assignment for the Examiner. Komenich’s current creative project, “Revolution Revisited,” is a 25th Anniversary look back at the 1986 Philippine “People Power” Revolution. In 2012, he will publish the book, Revolution Revisited, and a full-length documentary film by the same name.https://scholarworks.sjsu.edu/uss/1026/thumbnail.jp
summary: This document summarizes a talk by SJSU Assistant Professor Kim Komenich, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalist, on his project "Revolution Revisited." The project is a 25th-anniversary retrospective on the 1986 Philippine "People Power" Revolution, for which Komenich won his Pulitzer. He plans to publish a book and a full-length documentary film with the same title in 2012. The summary covers Komenich's career, the context of the Philippine Revolution, and the project's purpose and deliverables.

title: Staging Revolution: Form and Violence in La noche de los asesinos
abstract: Written within the first years of the Cuban revolution, José Triana’s La noche de los asesinos (1965) has traditionally been read as either a revolutionary or an antirevolutionary play. This article argues that more than its historical and political context, revolution constitutes La noche’s form. The concept of revolution as a violent, paradigm-shattering phenomenon relates to La noche’s shifting and unstable dramatic spaces. Triana creates a complex performative space that turns La noche into a dramaturgical exploration of revolution as violent change and transformation. Through Franz Fanon’s theoretical understanding of structural violence, this article ultimately investigates how La noche offers important insights into the experiential and emotional processes of the Cuban subject within the historical process of the revolution
