title: [Review of] Mariano Azuela. The Underdogs
abstract: The Underdogs (Los De Abajo) is a classic novel of the Mexican Revolution. The foreword briefly covers Mexican history, from Spanish Conquest to Independence to Revolution. Its purpose is to focus upon the main sociopolitical and economic problems of the Mexican Revolution
summary: The Underdogs (Los De Abajo) is a classic novel of the Mexican Revolution, exploring its sociopolitical and economic problems. This text also discusses a separate novel focusing on Rosalie's class consciousness and its impact on Elzina's doomed relationship with Jesse, highlighting themes of societal expectations and personal tragedy. Additionally, it introduces "The Way of a Peyote Roadman" by Silvester J. Brito, a controversial work blending folklore, anthropology, and personal experience, aiming to document the peyote ceremony and stir academic debate. Key themes include revolution, class, tragedy, peyote religion, and ethnographic study.

title: ‘A Very Hell of Horrors’? The Haitian Revolution and the Early Transatlantic Haitian Gothic
abstract: This article explores the Gothicisation of the Haitian Revolution in the transatlantic discourse during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. As it argues, the Gothic mode has to be understood as a reaction to the profound challenges that the Haitian Revolution posed to a transatlantic world built on the slave economy. Pro-slavery and pro-colonialist authors demonised this successful slave revolution and one of the first anti-colonial revolutions in modern history by resorting frequently to the ‘hegemonic Haitian Gothic.’ By contrast, early Haitian leaders and some British radicals appropriated this mode, turning it into the ideologically contrary ‘radical Haitian Gothic.
summary: This article examines the Gothicisation of the Haitian Revolution in transatlantic discourse during the late 18th and early 19th centuries. It argues that the Gothic mode emerged as a response to the profound challenges the revolution posed to the slave economy. Pro-slavery and pro-colonialist authors used a 'hegemonic Haitian Gothic' to demonize this successful slave and anti-colonial revolution. In contrast, early Haitian leaders and some British radicals appropriated this mode, transforming it into a 'radical Haitian Gothic' with ideologically opposing views. Keywords include Haitian Revolution, Gothic, transatlantic repercussions, proslavery, and radical antislavery.

title: Green revolution 2.0: a sustainable energy path
abstract: This repository item contains a single issue of Sustainable Development Insights, a series of short policy essays that began publishing in 2008 by the Boston University Frederick S. Pardee Center for the Study of the Longer-Range Future. The series seeks to promote a broad interdisciplinary dialogue on how to accelerate sustainable development at all levels.The Green Revolution in agriculture greatly increased crop yields and averted mass starvation, but it also turned small farms into factory farms that concentrated production in a few locations and reduced the diversity of crops. In this paper, Professor Nalin Kulatilaka, Co-Director of BU’s Clean Energy & Environmental Sustainability Initiative, calls for a Green Energy Revolution that decentralizes energy supplies through a smart electricity network. He argues that such a revolution could provide for a diversity of energy sources located closer to users, which in turn could shift consumption patterns, reduce losses and decrease overall energy demand. He concludes that shifting to such a system “will adopt clean energy technologies while fostering new businesses, creating new jobs and ultimately empowering society to reach new heights in energy conservation and sustainability“
publisher: Boston University Frederick S. Pardee Center for the Study of the Longer-Range Future
summary: This policy essay proposes a "Green Energy Revolution" to decentralize energy supplies through a smart electricity network, contrasting it with the Green Agricultural Revolution's concentration of production. The author argues this energy revolution would enable diverse energy sources closer to users, shift consumption patterns, reduce losses, and decrease overall energy demand. Such a system is projected to adopt clean energy technologies, foster new businesses, create jobs, and empower society toward energy conservation and sustainability. Key themes include sustainable development, smart grids, clean energy, and consumption reduction.

title:
On the existence of infinitely many closed geodesics on orbifolds of
  revolution
abstract:
Using the theory of geodesics on surfaces of revolution, we introduce the
period function. We use this as our main tool in showing that any
two-dimensional orbifold of revolution homeomorphic to S^2 must contain an
infinite number of geometrically distinct closed geodesics. Since any such
orbifold of revolution can be regarded as a topological two-sphere with metric
singularities, we will have extended Bangert's theorem on the existence of
infinitely many closed geodesics on any smooth Riemannian two-sphere. In
addition, we give an example of a two-sphere cone-manifold of revolution which
possesses a single closed geodesic, thus showing that Bangert's result does not
hold in the wider class of closed surfaces with cone manifold structures.Comment: 21 pages, 4 figures; for a PDF version see
  http://www.calpoly.edu/~jborzell/Publications/publications.htm
summary: This paper extends Bangert's theorem by demonstrating that any two-dimensional orbifold of revolution homeomorphic to S^2 must contain an infinite number of geometrically distinct closed geodesics. The authors introduce the period function, derived from the theory of geodesics on surfaces of revolution, as their primary tool. This work treats orbifolds of revolution as topological two-spheres with metric singularities. Conversely, an example of a two-sphere cone-manifold of revolution is provided that possesses only a single closed geodesic, illustrating that Bangert's result does not hold for the broader class of closed surfaces with cone manifold structures. Keywords: geodesics, orbifolds, surfaces of revolution, Bangert's theorem, cone manifolds.

title: The Rehnquist Revolution
abstract: [Excerpt]  When historians look back at the Rehnquist Court, without a doubt they will say that its greatest changes in constitutional law were in the area of federalism. Over the past decade, and particularly over the last five years, the Supreme Court has dramatically limited the scope of Congress’ powers and has greatly expanded the protection of state Sovereign Immunity. Virtually every area of law, criminal and civil, is touched by these changes. Since I began teaching constitutional law in 1980, the most significant differences in constitutional law are a result of the Supreme Court’s revival of federalism as a constraint on federal power
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
fieldOfStudy: History, Constitutional Law, Supreme Court of the United States
summary: This article examines the "Rehnquist Revolution" in constitutional law, focusing on the Supreme Court's dramatic shifts in federalism. It details how the Court significantly limited Congress's powers and expanded state sovereign immunity, impacting both criminal and civil law. The author, Erwin Chemerinsky, argues that these rulings, which invalidated important federal statutes on issues like gun control, gender-motivated violence, and environmental protection, represent a conservative policy choice with no apparent purpose beyond limiting federal power. The article concludes by suggesting that a future Court will likely reverse these decisions, restoring broader federal authority to address national problems.

title: The Antibiotic Revolution
abstract: In 1928, Alexander Fleming discovered Penicillin, which revolutionized the way infections were treated. This discovery was revolutionary because it impacted the scientific field, the medical field, the pharmaceutical industry, and all of humanity. Alexander Fleming’s discovery of Penicillin sparked the development of antibiotics, which has continued to save people’s lives since the revolution. Thomas Kuhn would qualify the discovery of Penicillin by Alexander Fleming as a revolution because it led to a paradigm shift. Prior to the discovery of Penicillin, patients died from trivial injuries and infections. Fleming’s discovery of Penicillin is revolutionary because it changed the worldview of the way doctors treat patients with infectious diseases; and as a result of the antibiotic revolution, individuals are not vulnerable to death by bacterial diseases
fieldOfStudy: History, Medical Sciences, Philosophy, Antibiotics, Scientific Revolutions
summary: This article examines Alexander Fleming's 1928 discovery of Penicillin as a revolutionary event that led to a paradigm shift in medicine, significantly impacting the scientific, medical, and pharmaceutical fields. Utilizing Thomas Kuhn's philosophy of science, the paper argues that Penicillin sparked the development of antibiotics, fundamentally changing the treatment of infectious diseases and saving countless lives. The discovery shifted the worldview of doctors, making individuals less vulnerable to bacterial diseases and establishing a new era in patient care.

title: Uneven and combined development: modernity, modernism, revolution
abstract: Trotsky’s theory of Uneven and Combined Development was born out of his experience of the Russian Revolution. To mark the centenary of the revolution, we are publishing a series of five pieces by Neil Davidson that explore the theory’s wider contribution to how we understand capitalist modernity. These articles show how ideas that began life in the revolution continue to inspire new ways of grasping the world, and that we are very much engaging in a living 21st century world when reflecting on the previous century. The series published here are extracts of his forthcoming book Violating all the Laws of History that will be published in the Haymarket Historical Materialism series in 2018
summary: This document explores Trotsky's theory of Uneven and Combined Development, stemming from his experiences during the Russian Revolution. It analyzes the theory's broader implications for understanding capitalist modernity, examining its classic forms, causes, consequences, and constraints, including capitalist industrialization, urbanization, and modernism. The analysis traces the theory's evolution and persistence, addressing new developments in urbanism and ideology, and applies it to contemporary China, focusing on internal migration, worker resistance, and state transformations. It concludes by emphasizing the theory's continued relevance in shaping revolutionary conjunctures in the 21st century.

title: Workers of the world, unite! Franchise extensions and the threat of revolution in Europe, 1820-1938
abstract: This paper tests the hypothesis that the extension of the voting franchise was caused by the threat of revolution, as suggested by Acemoglu and Robinson (2000). We approximate the threat of revolution in a given country by revolutionary events happening in neighboring countries. We investigate the relationship between this new measure of the threat of revolution and measures of suffrage reform in two samples of European countries covering the period from 1820 to 1938. We find strong support for the ‘threat of revolution theory’. We also find some evidence that war triggered suffrage reform, whereas ‘modernization theory’ receives little support.The extension of the voting franchise; democracy; threat of revolution; suffrage
summary: This paper investigates the hypothesis that the extension of the voting franchise was driven by the threat of revolution, building on Acemoglu and Robinson (2000). The authors approximate revolutionary threats by analyzing events in neighboring countries and examine this relationship with suffrage reform in European countries from 1820 to 1938. They find strong evidence supporting the 'threat of revolution theory' and some indication that war also triggered suffrage reform. However, 'modernization theory' receives little support. Key concepts include voting franchise extension, democracy, threat of revolution, and suffrage.

title: New classical/real business cycle macroeconomics. The anatomy of a revolution
abstract: The aim of the present paper is to assess the new classical/real business cycle revolution, which dethroned Keynesian macroeconomics. In its first part, I critically discuss the microfoundations requirement that constitutes a cornerstone of the new approach and suggest an alternative, softer, formulation of it. The conclusion of this discussion is that the new classical/real business cycle revolution marked a transition from a soft to a demanding understanding of the microfoundations requirement. In the second part of the paper, I present additional salient traits of the new classical and the real business cycle stages of the revolution. While each of these stages brought a specific contribution to the revolution, I emphasize the decisive role played by Kydland and Prescott in re-orienting the type of work in which macroeconomists were engaged. Finally, in part three, I ponder upon the causes of this revolution. After presenting and assessing Prescott’s and Lucas’s accounts of the factors which gave rise to the new approach, I venture into muddier waters by raising the question of whether a political agenda underpinned the NC/RBC revolution.
summary: This paper assesses the new classical/real business cycle revolution, which supplanted Keynesian macroeconomics. It critically examines the microfoundations requirement, proposing a softer alternative, and traces the revolution's evolution from a soft to a demanding understanding of this concept. The study highlights contributions from both new classical and real business cycle stages, emphasizing Kydland and Prescott's pivotal role in re-orienting macroeconomists' work. Finally, it explores the causes of this revolution, evaluating Prescott's and Lucas's accounts while also questioning whether a political agenda underpinned the NC/RBC revolution. Keywords: new classical macroeconomics, real business cycle, Keynesian macroeconomics, microfoundations, Kydland, Prescott, Lucas.

title: Diagrammatic Reasoning and Modelling in the Imagination: The Secret Weapons of the Scientific Revolution
abstract: Just before the Scientific Revolution, there was a "Mathematical Revolution", heavily based on geometrical and machine diagrams. The "faculty of imagination" (now called scientific visualization) was developed to allow 3D understanding of planetary motion, human anatomy and the workings of machines. 1543 saw the publication of the heavily geometrical work of Copernicus and Vesalius, as well as the first Italian translation of Euclid
fieldOfStudy: History of Science; Early Modern Science; History
summary: This article posits a "Mathematical Revolution" preceding the Scientific Revolution, driven by geometrical and machine diagrams and the development of "scientific visualization" for understanding complex systems. Focusing on the pivotal year 1543, it examines Copernicus's "De revolutionibus," Vesalius's "De humani corporis fabrica," and Tartaglia's Italian translation of Euclid. The authors argue that these works, though distinct in subject matter (physics, biology, geometry), share a common emphasis on diagrammatic reasoning and the necessary interrelations of spatial parts, moving beyond mere pictorial representation to enable profound scientific understanding.

title: The Possibility of a Green Revolution in Sub-Saharan Africa: Evidence from Kenya
abstract: It is widely believed that a Green Revolution similar to the one achieved in Asia is impossible in Sub-Saharan Africa. Although grain yields have been stagnant in this region, there are some signs of the intensification of farming systems in the face of growing population pressure on limited land resources. In this paper we focus on the new farming system based on the use of manure produced by dairy cows, which may be termed an â€œOrganic Green Revolution.â€ Using the farm household data collected from Kenya, this paper demonstrates that the Organic Green Revolution has a potential of doubling maize yields in highlands of Kenya.Green Revolution, Agricultural Revolution, Organic Green Revolution, dairy cows, manure, chemical fertilizer, maize yield, International Development,
fieldOfStudy: History, Green Revolution, Agricultural Revolution, Organic Green Revolution, International Development
summary: This paper challenges the belief that a Green Revolution is impossible in Sub-Saharan Africa by focusing on an "Organic Green Revolution" utilizing dairy cow manure. Analyzing farm household data from Kenya, the study demonstrates the potential to double maize yields in the Kenyan highlands. The research explores the intensification of farming systems amid population pressure on land resources, offering insights into sustainable agricultural development, agricultural revolution, and maize yield improvement through organic practices in the region.

title: Was there an ‘Industrious Revolution’ before the Industrial Revolution? An Empirical Exercise for England, c. 1300-1830
abstract: It is conventionally assumed that the pre-modern working year was fixed and that consumption varied with changes in wages and prices. This is challenged by the twin theories of the ‘industrious’ revolution and the consumer revolution, positing a longer working year as people earned surplus money to buy novel goods. In this study, we turn the conventional view on its head, fixing consumption rather than labour input. Specifically, we use a basket of basic consumption goods and compute the working year of rural and urban day labourers required to achieve that. By comparing with independent estimates of the actual working year, we find two ‘industrious’ revolutions among rural workers; both, however, are attributable to economic hardship, and we detect no signs of a consumer revolution. For urban labourers, by contrast, a growing gap between their actual working year and the work required to buy the basket provides great scope for a consumer revolution.Consumer Revolution; Cost-of-Living Index; Day Wages; ‘Industrious’ Revolution; Industrial Revolution; Labour Supply; Standard of Living
summary: This study challenges conventional assumptions about pre-modern working years and consumption patterns, using a basket of basic goods to compute the required working year for rural and urban day labourers from 1300-1830 in England. The authors identify two 'industrious' revolutions among rural workers, which they attribute to economic hardship rather than a 'consumer revolution'. In contrast, urban labourers experienced a growing gap between their actual and required working years, indicating potential for a consumer revolution. This research provides insights into the 'Industrious Revolution', 'Consumer Revolution', and living standards during the Industrial Revolution.

title: Orange Revolution: The Prehistory
publisher: Boston University Center for the Study of Conflict, Ideology, and Policy
summary: This perspective piece details the prehistory of Ukraine's 2004 Orange Revolution, where citizens peacefully protested a discredited presidential election result. The author describes how hundreds of thousands converged on Kyiv, adopting Viktor Yushchenko's campaign color and rejecting the government-backed candidate, Viktor Yanukovich. After 17 days of protest, the Supreme Court ordered a repeat run-off, leading to Yushchenko's victory and a significant shift in Ukraine's political and geographical orientation, demonstrating support for freedom and democracy. Keywords: Orange Revolution, Ukraine, Viktor Yushchenko, Viktor Yanukovich, presidential election, political protest, democracy.

title: The Sicilian revolution of 1848 as seen from Malta
abstract: Following the Sicilian revolution of 1848, many Italian intellectuals and political figures found refuge in Malta where they made use of the Freedom of the Press to divulge their message of unification to the mainland. Britain harboured hopes of seizing Sicily to counterbalance French expansion in the Mediterranean and tended to support the legitimate authority rather than separatist ideals. Maltese newspapers reflected these opposing ideas. By mid-1849 the revolution was dead.peer-reviewe
fieldOfStudy: History, Italian exiles, Freedom of the Press, Maltese newspapers
summary: This study examines the Sicilian Revolution of 1848 through the lens of Maltese newspapers, focusing on the role of Italian intellectuals and political figures who sought refuge in Malta. These exiles leveraged Malta's freedom of the press to disseminate their message of Italian unification to the mainland. The paper explores Britain's strategic interest in Sicily to counter French Mediterranean expansion, leading to a complex dynamic where Britain supported legitimate authority over separatist movements. Maltese newspapers served as a platform reflecting these conflicting viewpoints. The research highlights the influence of these publications in shaping public opinion and the ultimate demise of the revolution by mid-1849, despite the efforts of revolutionaries and a continuous influx of Italian refugees into Malta. Keywords: 1848 Sicilian revolution, Italian exiles, Freedom of the Press, Maltese newspapers.

title: Against “revolution” and “evolution”
abstract: Those standard historiographic themes of “evolution” and “revolution” need replacing. They perpetuate mid-Victorian scientists’ history of science. Historians’ history of science does well to take in the long run from the Greek and Hebrew heritages on, and to work at avoiding misleading anachronism and teleology. As an alternative to the usual “evo-revo” themes, a historiography of origins and species, of cosmologies (including microcosmogonies and macrocosmogonies) and ontologies, is developed here. The advantages of such a historiography are illustrated by looking briefly at a number of transitions the transition from Greek and Hebrew doctrines to their integrations by medieval authors; the transition from the Platonist, Aristotelian, Christian Aquinas to the Newtonian Buffon and to the no less Newtonian Lamarck; the departures the early Darwin made away from Lamarck’s and from Lyell’s views. Issues concerning historical thinking about nature, concerning essentialism and concerning classification are addressed in an attempt to challenge customary stereotypes. Questions about originality and influence are raised, especially concerning Darwin’s “tree of life” scheme. The broader historiography of Darwinian science as a social ideology, and as a “worldview,” is examined and the scope for revisions emphasised. Throughout, graduate students are encouraged to see this topic area not as worked out, but as full of opportunities for fresh contributions
fieldOfStudy: History of Science, Historiography, History of Biology
summary: This paper challenges the conventional historiographic themes of "evolution" and "revolution" in the history of science, arguing they perpetuate mid-Victorian scientific perspectives. It proposes an alternative historiography focused on origins and species, cosmologies, and ontologies, drawing from Greek and Hebrew heritages to avoid anachronism. The author illustrates this approach by examining transitions from medieval thought to Newtonian figures like Buffon and Lamarck, and Darwin's departures from their views, addressing issues of essentialism and classification. The study also investigates Darwinian science as a social ideology and worldview, encouraging fresh contributions from graduate students.

title: TRENDS REGARDING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE COMMERCIAL ACTIVITY IN ROMANIA
abstract: World economy is experiencing some important transformations, mainly due to the rapid evolution of the informational and communication technologies. In the last years, new technologies flooded the production processes. They have allowed the improvement of the processing and use of the economic information and the general accelaration of the economic flows. The technological revolution is presented in all its trade forms, either the wholesale trade or the retail trade. The technical progress interferes with the economic activity through the re-engineering of the production lines, the revolution in the field of building materials and store, shopping center, malls and industrial hall building, the considerably shorter time period these are being built and they become available for the commercial activity, the revolution in the field of supply, merchandise storage and manipulation, the appearance of different types of intelligent machineries and equipment, merchandise storage software improving the way the client is served at the counter. The industrial revolution determines a reorganization of the economic activity, a resetting of the trade economic activity by directing the trader towards the client using new commercial techniques and strategies.technology, technological revolution, technical progress, development, production, trade, improvement of the trade activity
summary: This article examines the significant transformations in the world economy, driven by rapid advancements in informational and communication technologies. It discusses how new technologies have permeated production processes, enhancing economic information processing and accelerating economic flows. The paper details how technical progress influences economic activity through re-engineering production lines, revolutionizing building materials and construction, shortening build times for commercial spaces, and innovating supply chain management and merchandise storage. It highlights the emergence of intelligent machinery and software, ultimately leading to a reorganization of economic activity and a client-focused approach in trade through new commercial techniques and strategies. Key terms include technology, technological revolution, production, and trade improvement.

title: "Revolution? What Revolution?" Successes and limits of computing technologies in philosophy and religion
abstract:
Computing technologies like other technological innovations in the modern West are inevitably introduced with the rhetoric of "revolution".  Especially during the 1980s (the PC revolution) and 1990s (the Internet and Web revolutions), enthusiasts insistently celebrated radical changesâ€” changes ostensibly inevitable and certainly as radical as those brought about by the invention of the printing press, if not the discovery of fire.\ud
	These enthusiasms now seem very "1990sâ€?â€”in part as the revolution stumbled with the dot.com failures and the devastating impacts of 9/11.  Moreover, as I will sketch out below, the patterns of diffusion and impact in philosophy and religion show both tremendous success, as certain revolutionary promises are indeed keptâ€”as well as (sometimes spectacular) failures. Perhaps we use revolutionary rhetoric less frequently because the revolution has indeed succeeded: computing technologies, and many of the powers and potentials they bring us as scholars and religionists have become so ubiquitous and normal that they no longer seem "revolutionary at all.  At the same time, many of the early hopes and promises instantiated in such specific projects as Artificial Intelligence and anticipations of virtual religious communities only have been dashed against the apparently intractable limits of even these most remarkable technologies.  While these failures are usually forgotten they leave in their wake a clearer sense of what these new technologies can, and cannot do
summary: This essay examines the "revolutionary" rhetoric surrounding computing technologies, particularly in the 1980s and 1990s (PC, Internet, and Web revolutions), and their actual impact on philosophy and religion. It argues that while some revolutionary promises were fulfilled, leading to ubiquitous technological integration, other hopes, like those for Artificial Intelligence or virtual religious communities, faced significant limitations. The paper sketches out the successes and failures in the diffusion and impact of these technologies, providing a clearer understanding of their capabilities and constraints, essential for scholars and religionists.

title: Revolution through electronic purchasing
abstract: Automation is finding its way in the world of purchasing. This development could evoke dramatic effects in the long term, not only on purchasing but even on the market place itself. Nowadays, EDI and CD-ROM are examples of automation applications that purchasing departments use frequently. Internet and other global communication systems are not yet perceived as major added value applications for purchasers. Nevertheless this medium could change purchasing in a revolutionary manner, provided that the information such global media present, is structured in an easily accessible way. At that point major elements of traditional purchasing will be automatically shifted to the end user. As a consequence the marketplace for these products will become completely transparent, creating a new fundamentally different reality. This will allow new competitors to enter and will demand new services to be rendered
fieldOfStudy: History, purchasing management, electronic purchasing, market transparency
summary: This article explores the transformative impact of automation, particularly electronic purchasing, on traditional purchasing practices and the marketplace. It discusses current applications like EDI and CD-ROM, and projects how the Internet, once information is structured accessibly, could revolutionize purchasing by shifting responsibilities to end-users. This shift is predicted to create a transparent market, fostering intense price competition, enabling new competitors, and demanding new logistical services. The paper concludes that this constitutes a fundamental revolution in the marketplace, necessitating adaptation from suppliers of standard products and the disappearance of traditional wholesalers.

title: The School Food Revolution: Public Food and the Challenge of Sustainable Development - Book Review
abstract:
The School Food Revolution is a timely book for a world of obesogenic food, a world of the fat poor in rich countries, and the hungry poor in poor countries. Worldwide, malnourishment is a marker of poverty. Readers impatient for the revolution are advised to go directly to Chapter 4 - School Food as Social Justice: The Quality Revolution in Rome.

Morgan and Sonnino report that “in Italy the public sector has been actively fighting against the generalized deterioration in the population’s nutritional habits”. They identify in Italy “the first organic school meals system”, “the first organic university canteen” and “an organic hospital menu”. They report Italian legislation that “establishes a direct and explicit link between organic and local food and public sector catering … This national law created a regulatory context that encouraged many municipalities to turn organic”
summary: This book review of "The School Food Revolution" by Kevin Morgan and Roberta Sonnino examines the global issue of obesogenic food environments and malnourishment, focusing on school food reform. The review highlights Italy's pioneering organic school meals system and legislation linking organic and local food to public catering. It discusses Rome's successful school food reforms, which improved children's health and supported local producers. The book also contrasts approaches in the UK and USA, and touches on the challenges in Africa, advocating for child engagement in food revolutions. Keywords include school food, organic food, sustainable development, public catering, and health.

title: Gaia: The Astrometry Revolution
abstract:
The power of micro-arcsecond ($\mu$as) astrometry is about to be unleashed.
ESA's Gaia mission, now headed towards the end of the first year of routine
science operations, will soon fulfil its promise for revolutionary science in
countless aspects of Galactic astronomy and astrophysics. The potential of Gaia
position measurements for important contributions to the astrophysics of
planetary systems is huge. We focus here on the expectations for detection and
improved characterization of 'young' planetary systems in the neighborhood of
the Sun using a combination of Gaia $\mu$as astrometry and direct imaging
techniques.Comment: 6 pages, 3 figures, to appear in the Proceedings of IAU Symposium 314
  'Young Stars & Planets Near the Sun', held on May 11-15 2015 in Atlanta (GA),
  USA (J. H. Kastner, B. Stelzer, & S. A. Metchev, eds.
summary: This paper highlights the revolutionary potential of micro-arcsecond astrometry from ESA's Gaia mission for galactic astronomy and astrophysics. The authors focus on its significant contributions to the astrophysics of planetary systems, particularly for detecting and characterizing 'young' planetary systems near the Sun. The methodology combines Gaia's high-precision astrometry with direct imaging techniques to achieve improved characterization. Key areas of application include planetary systems, astrometry, and numerical methods for analysis, promising advances in understanding stellar and planetary evolution.

title: Conforming polisher for aspheric surface of revolution  Patent
abstract: Conforming polisher for aspheric surfaces of revolution with inflatable tub
summary: This document describes a conforming polisher designed for aspheric surfaces of revolution, featuring an inflatable tube mechanism. The invention addresses the need for precision polishing without degrading surface contour accuracy, ensuring uniform pressure application. Key components include a body means with openings for polishing compound application, inflatable tube means for pressure variation, and a flexible rubber tubing secured by rigid shoes, often utilizing a pneumatic source. This apparatus facilitates the uniform polishing of aspheric surfaces, critical for applications requiring high optical precision. Keywords: aspheric surfaces, conforming polisher, inflatable tube, uniform pressure, optical polishing.

title: Identity crisis: how ideological and rhetorical failures cost Egyptians their revolution
abstract: Thesis (M.A.) University of Alaska Fairbanks, 2019The Egyptian uprising, which began on January 25, 2011, and ended on February 11, 2011, culminated in the ending of President Hosni Mubarak's 30-year reign as dictator.  After free elections in which the Muslim Brotherhood ascended to power in the country, they were ousted in a military coup d'état only one year after their ascension to power and were replaced by former military general Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi. The symptoms which led the country to rise up against Mubarak continue to exist under el-Sisi today, indicating that no revolution really took place. This paper answers the question, "why did the revolution fail?", offering a rhetorical reason for the revolution's failure. The uprisings, which were billed as decentralized, offer unique opportunities for analysis of rhetorical strategy. This paper uses the reconstitutive-discourse model, a critical model which examines a rhetor's reconstitution of their audience's character, to examine the rhetoric of three different parties in the revolution. First, it examines the rhetoric of all protestors irrespective of source via Twitter and on the ground protestors; next it looks at the rhetoric of Wael Ghonim, who is credited with instigating the uprisings, and Mohammed ElBaradei, an influential figure who became interim vice-president in the aftermath of the uprisings. The study found that first, the uprisings were not really decentralized and indeed has leaders. Further, rhetorical failures on the part of its leaders caused the uprisings to fail in their goal of democratic revolution
summary: This paper analyzes the failure of the 2011 Egyptian uprising, which ousted President Hosni Mubarak but did not lead to sustained democratic change, as the underlying societal issues persist under President el-Sisi. The study employs the reconstitutive-discourse model to examine the rhetoric of three key parties: anonymous protestors on Twitter and on the ground, Wael Ghonim, and Mohammed ElBaradei. Findings indicate that the uprisings were not truly decentralized, possessing identifiable leaders, and their rhetorical failures ultimately contributed to the revolution's inability to achieve its democratic goals.

title: Technological Breakthroughs and Productivity Growth
abstract: This study consists of an examination of productivity growth following three major technological breakthroughs: the steam power revolution, electrification and the ICT revolution. The distinction between sectors producing and sectors using the new technology is emphasized. A major finding for all breakthroughs is that there is a long lag from the time of the original invention until a substantial increase in the rate of productivity growth can be observed. There is also strong evidence of rapid price decreases for steam engines, electricity, electric motors and ICT products. However, there is no persuasive direct evidence that the steam engine producing industry and electric machinery had particularly high productivity growth rates. For the ICT revolution the highest productivity growth rates are found in the ICT-producing industries. We suggest that one explanation could be that hedonic price indexes are not used for the steam engine and the electric motor. Still, it is likely that the rate of technological development has been much more rapid during the ICT revolution compared to any of the previous breakthroughs.electrification; general purpose technologies; ICT revolution; productivity growth; steam power; Technological breakthroughs
fieldOfStudy: History, Electrification, General Purpose Technologies, ICT Revolution, Productivity Growth, Steam Power
summary: This study examines productivity growth following three major technological breakthroughs: the steam power revolution, electrification, and the ICT revolution. It emphasizes the distinction between sectors producing and using new technology, finding a long lag between invention and significant productivity growth. Evidence shows rapid price decreases for associated technologies. While ICT-producing industries exhibit high productivity growth, direct evidence is less persuasive for earlier breakthroughs. The authors suggest that hedonic price indexes may explain this discrepancy for steam engines and electric motors, concluding the ICT revolution's technological development rate likely surpasses previous breakthroughs.

title: Reclaiming Revolution: William Wells Brown's Irreducible Haitian Heroes
abstract: This article focuses on William Wells Brown's 1854 history of the Haitian Revolution
summary: This article analyzes William Wells Brown's 1854 lecture, "St. Domingo: Its Revolutions and its Patriots," contrasting his account of the Haitian Revolution with those in contemporary publications like *DeBow's Review* and *The Anti-Slavery Reporter*. The study argues that Brown's use of fragmented narratives, mirroring Haiti's multiple insurrections, offers a model for black revolutionary activity not confined to a single event or figure, but instead conceptualized as an international revolutionary continuum driven by black liberatory goals. This framework allows for re-examining events such as the American Revolution, the Haitian Revolution, and the American Civil War within a broader, interconnected revolutionary history.

title: The transition to a new economy after the Second Industrial Revolution
abstract: During the Second Industrial Revolution, 1860–1900, many new technologies, including electricity, were invented. After this revolution, however, several decades passed before these new technologies diffused and measured productivity growth increased. We build a quantitative model of technology diffusion which we use to study this transition to a new economy. We show that the model implies both slow diffusion and a delay in growth similar to that in the data. Our model casts doubt, however, on the conjecture that this experience is a useful parallel for understanding the productivity paradox following the Information Technology Revolution.
fieldOfStudy: History, Economics, Technology Diffusion, Industrial Revolution
summary: This paper develops a quantitative model of technology diffusion and growth to analyze the transition to new economies following technological revolutions. Focusing on the Second Industrial Revolution (1860-1900), the model explains the observed slow diffusion of new technologies, the delay in productivity growth, and ongoing investment in older technologies. By quantifying the learning process using U.S. manufacturing plant data, the authors demonstrate that the nature of transition depends on the amount of accumulated knowledge about old technologies. The findings suggest the experience of the Second Industrial Revolution may not be a direct parallel for the Information Technology Revolution due to varying historical contexts impacting diffusion and growth rates.

title: New Media and the Quality of Life
abstract: We are currently in the middle of a revolution. This revolution, sometimes called the digital revolution, is the revolutionary transformation brought about in the information and communication structure of society by the advent of the digital computer, with most of the major transformations having taken place in the past thirty years. Digital computing technology has generated the mainframe and personal computer, the multimedia computer, and computer networks. It has also transformed the telephone system and the monetary system, it is transforming all kinds of conventional products ranging from washing machines to automobiles, and it is on its way to change television as well. More than ever, contemporary society is an Information Society, in which the importance of information and communication is much greater than in past societies, and of which technologies that facilitate information and communication processes are a central societal feature. In this paper, I want to evaluate the implications of contemporary information and communication media for the quality of life, including both the new media from the digital revolution and the older media that still remain in use. My evaluation of contemporary media will proceed in three parts. In the section to follow, the benefits of contemporary media will be discussed, with special emphasis given to their immediate functional benefits. The section thereafter is devoted to a discussion of four potential threats posed by contemporary media. In a final major section, I look at the future of digital media and the possibilities available to us in shaping that future. A short concluding section ends the paper
summary: This paper evaluates the implications of contemporary information and communication media, stemming from the digital revolution, on the quality of life. It discusses both new digital media and older, still-used media. The evaluation proceeds in three parts: exploring immediate functional benefits, analyzing four potential threats posed by these media, and examining the future of digital media and possibilities for shaping it. This work highlights the societal transformation into an Information Society driven by digital computing technology and its pervasive influence on various systems and products. Keywords: digital revolution, information society, quality of life, communication media, digital media, technology, societal transformation.

title: 3. The Second Industrial Revolution
abstract: There is abundant evidence for the opinion that after about 1850 the Industrial Revolution entered upon a new phase in its development. Inventions occurred at a more rapid pace than ever before in history. (Between 1850 and 1914 there were more than fifty times as many patents issued in the Unites States as during the preceding sixty years.) Increasingly these inventions were the work of scientists and engineers working in the research laboratory rather than of self-taught craftsmen, as had often been the case in the eighteenth century. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, European History, History of Science, Technology, and Medicine
summary: This chapter discusses the "Second Industrial Revolution" which began around 1850, characterized by an accelerated pace of invention, increasingly driven by scientists and engineers in research laboratories rather than self-taught craftsmen. It examines England's prominent role as a global financial and trade center, its adoption of the gold standard, and its shift to a food-deficit nation reliant on imports. The text also covers England's promotion of free trade until roughly 1870, when other nations began implementing tariffs to protect their developing industries, signaling a changing global economic landscape. Keywords: Second Industrial Revolution, industrial development, inventions, economic liberalism, global trade, England, free trade, tariffs, gold standard.

title: Contraception - The Revolution that Failed
fieldOfStudy: History, Ethics, Medical Ethics, Family Planning
summary: This article, "Contraception - The Revolution that Failed" by Peter Brady, critically examines the historical development and efficacy of contraception, particularly focusing on Dr. John Rock's 1965 advocacy for the contraceptive pill as a natural and harmless method acceptable to Catholics. The author argues that despite early claims, doubts have emerged regarding the long-term safety and effectiveness of both the Pill and other artificial methods, including concerns about discontinuation rates and links to health issues like cancer. The paper suggests that the promised "revolution" in contraception has fallen short, prompting a re-evaluation of its societal and ethical implications, including its impact on family planning and abortion.

title: Impingement of Water Droplets on an Ellipsoid with Fineness Ratio 5 in Axisymmetric Flow
abstract: The presence of radomes and instruments that are sensitive to water films or ice formations in the nose section of all-weather aircraft and missiles necessitates a knowledge of the droplet impingement characteristics of bodies of revolution. Because it is possible to approximate many of these bodies with an ellipsoid of revolution, droplet trajectories about an ellipsoid of revolution with a fineness ratio of 5 were computed for incompressible axisymmetric air flow. From the computed droplet trajectories, the following impingement characteristics of the ellipsoid surface were obtained and are presented in terms of dimensionless parameters: (1) total rate of water impingement, (2) extent of droplet impingement zone, (3) distribution of impinging water, and (4) local rate of water impingement
summary: This technical note investigates droplet impingement characteristics on all-weather aircraft and missile nose sections, which often contain sensitive radomes and instruments susceptible to water or ice formation. The study computed droplet trajectories around an ellipsoid of revolution with a fineness ratio of 5, using incompressible axisymmetric airflow, to approximate real-world bodies. Key impingement characteristics, including total water impingement rate, impingement zone extent, water distribution, and local impingement rate, were obtained and presented as dimensionless parameters. This research provides crucial data for designing aircraft and missiles to mitigate adverse effects from water droplet impact and ice formation.

title: Adult longevity and economic take-off: from Malthus to Ben-Porath
abstract: We propose four arguments favoring the idea that medical effectiveness, adult longevity and height started to increase in Europe before the industrial revolution. This may have prompted households to increase their investment in human skills as a response to longer lives and initiated the transition from stagnation to growth.life expectancy, height, industrial revolution, human capital, adult mortality.
summary: This paper argues that medical effectiveness, adult longevity, and height in Europe began to improve before the Industrial Revolution. The authors propose four arguments supporting this idea. This pre-industrial improvement in living conditions may have motivated households to invest more in human capital due to longer lifespans, thereby initiating the shift from economic stagnation to growth. Key concepts explored include life expectancy, human capital, adult mortality, and the Industrial Revolution's role in economic development.

title: The future of shale
abstract: Master's Project (M.S.) University of Alaska Fairbanks, 2016This project examines the various drivers that led to the U.S. shale oil revolution in order to predict its place in the energy industry going forward and to analyze its effects on Alaska. The shale boom flooded the market with oil causing a dramatic decrease in crude oil prices in late 2014. With this price drop threatening to send Alaska into an economic recession, the future of shale should be of primary concern to all Alaskans as well as other entities that rely heavily on oil revenue. The primary driver leading to the shale revolution is technology. Advances in hydraulic fracturing, horizontal drilling, and 3D seismic mapping made producing shale oil and gas possible for the first time. New technologies like rotary steerable systems and measurements while drilling continue to make shale production more efficient, and technology will likely continue to improve. Infrastructure helps to explain why the shale revolution was mostly an American phenomenon. Many countries with shale formations have political infrastructure too unstable to risk shale investment. Capital infrastructure is a primary strength of the U.S. and also helps to explain why shale development didn't find its way up to Alaska despite having political stability. Financial infrastructure allowed oil companies to receive the funding necessary to quickly bring shale to the market. The final driver explored is crude oil prices. High oil prices helped spark the shale revolution, but with the recent price crash, there is uncertainty about its future. With production costs continually falling due to technology improvements and analysts predicting crude oil prices to stabilize above most project breakeven points, the future of shale looks bright.Introduction -- Shale & Alaska North Slope Crude Oil Prices -- Seeds of its own destruction? Technology -- Hydraulic Fracturing -- History of fracking -- Directional drilling -- History of drilling -- Benefits of directional drilling -- 3D seismic mapping -- Creating a shockwave -- Recording the data -- Interpreting the results -- The birth of a revolution -- Current/future developments -- Rotary steerable system -- Measurements while drilling -- Future developments. Infrastructure -- Political risk -- Financial markets -- Over investment -- Capital infrastructure. Crude prices -- The price crash -- Breakeven prices -- Future prices -- Alaska -- Conclusion -- Bibliography
fieldOfStudy: History, Energy Industry, Oil and Gas, Technology
summary: This project investigates the drivers of the U.S. shale oil revolution, aiming to forecast its future in the energy sector and analyze its impact on Alaska's oil-dependent economy. Key drivers include technological advancements such as hydraulic fracturing, horizontal drilling, and 3D seismic mapping, which have dramatically improved production efficiency. Infrastructure—political, capital, and financial—explains the revolution's American focus. High crude oil prices initially spurred growth, but a recent price crash created uncertainty. However, with falling production costs and anticipated price stabilization, the future of shale oil appears robust, profoundly affecting Alaska's economic outlook.

title: The Deleuzian Revolution: Ten Innovations in Difference and Repetition
abstract:
Difference and Repetition might be said to have brought about a Deleuzian Revolution in philosophy comparable to Kant’s Copernican Revolution. Kant had denounced the three great terminal points of traditional metaphysics – self, world and God – as transcendent illusions, and Deleuze pushes Kant’s revolution to its limit by positing a transcendental field that excludes the coherence of the self, world and God in favour of an immanent and differential plane of impersonal individuations and pre-individual singularities. In the process, he introduces numerous conceptual innovations into philosophy: the becoming of concepts; a transformation of the form of the question; an insistence that philosophy must start in the middle; an attempt to think in terms of multiplicities; the development of a new logic and a new metaphysics based on a concept of difference; a new conception of space as intensive rather than extensive; a conception of time as a pure and empty form; and an understanding of philosophy as a system in heterogenesis – that is, a system that entails a perpetual genesis of the heterogeneous, an incessant production of the new. 
          
          Keywords: concepts, becoming, multiplicity, singularity, the middle [au milieu], difference, intensity, time, system, the ne
summary: This paper examines Gilles Deleuze's "Deleuzian Revolution" in philosophy, comparing it to Kant's Copernican Revolution. Deleuze extends Kant's critique of traditional metaphysics by positing a transcendental field favoring immanent, differential planes of impersonal individuations and pre-individual singularities, thus excluding coherent self, world, and God. The author details ten conceptual innovations Deleuze introduces, including the becoming of concepts, a new logic based on difference, intensive space, time as pure form, and philosophy as a system in heterogenesis. Key concepts include multiplicity, singularity, intensity, and system.

title: The moral core of Judaism and Christianity: reclaiming the revolution
abstract: Reviewed Book: Maguire, Daniel C. The moral Core of Judaism and Christianity: reclaiming the revolution. Minneapolis: Augsburg Fortress, 1993
summary: This review examines Daniel C. Maguire's book, "The Moral Core of Judaism and Christianity: Reclaiming the Revolution," which explores theological and religious ethics amidst contemporary human challenges. Maguire critically reviews religion and delves into themes of justice, hope, truth, and peace, arguing that knowledge of God is inherently moral. The book is structured in two parts: "The Single Source of Morality and Religion" and "Scripting a New Humanity," offering an insightful perspective on moral and religious foundations for modern society.

title: From Tarde to Deleuze and Foucault: The Infinitesimal Revolution (Review)
abstract:
From Tarde to Deleuze and Foucault: The Infinitesimal Revolution
          
          ,Palgrave Macmillan: London, 2018; 154 pp.: ISBN 9783319551487
          
          Sergio Tonkonoff
summary: Sergio Tonkonoff's book, "From Tarde to Deleuze and Foucault: The Infinitesimal Revolution," explores the significant and often underappreciated influence of Gabriel Tarde on the philosophical development of Gilles Deleuze and Michel Foucault. The review highlights how Tarde's microsociological concepts, particularly his 'infinitesimal grammar,' profoundly shaped Deleuze's "Difference and Repetition" and his work on Foucault. Tonkonoff argues that Tarde offers a vital framework for understanding social life beyond traditional dichotomies (society/individual, structure/agency), advocating for an approach centered on lines, flows, and escapes, crucial for contemporary social theory and understanding concepts like machinic assemblages and contagion theory.

title: A Cubic Surface of Revolution
abstract:
We develop a direct and elementary (calculus-free) exposition of the famous
cubic surface of revolution x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz=1.12 pages. We have added a second

This paper offers a direct and elementary, calculus-free exposition of the cubic surface of revolution defined by the equation x
3 + y

Additionally, the paper includes two proofs for a special case of the Salmon-Cayley theorem concerning the twenty-seven lines on every cubic surface, explores singularities of cubic surfaces, and discusses the general problem of finding rational points on such surfaces. title: Secrecy in the American Revolution
abstract: This paper analyzes how the use of various cryptographic and cryptanalytic techniques affected the American Revolution. By examining specific instances of and each country\u27s general approaches to cryptography and cryptanalysis, it is determined that America\u27s use of these techniques provided the rising nation with a critical advantage over Great Britain that assisted in its victory
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This paper analyzes the impact of cryptographic and cryptanalytic techniques on the American Revolution, arguing that America's strategic use of these methods provided a critical advantage over Great Britain, contributing significantly to its victory. The study examines specific instances and general approaches to cryptography and cryptanalysis employed by both nations, highlighting how American efforts in cryptanalysis were pivotal. It emphasizes that continued use of cryptography in diplomatic communications offered the nascent nation a secure beginning. Keywords include cryptography, cryptanalysis, American Revolution, Great Britain, military communications, and diplomatic security.

title: The methodological 'revolution': caution accepted.
summary: This correspondence addresses the ongoing discussion regarding the 'overuse' of new methodological developments in epidemiology versus traditional, transparent methods. The authors, while acknowledging the need for caution, argue against completely disregarding technical advancements. They emphasize the importance of understanding the limitations of all methods, new and old, advocating for careful application. The text highlights the adoption of tools like Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) for presenting causality and suggests that new methods will find their place in the epidemiological toolbox once their added value is proven, contributing to advancements in causal inference and data analysis.

title: Reading and the digital revolution
abstract: Response to Maryanne Wolf's article in which she pondered the digital revolution’s potential to ‘unravel 5000 years of learning’ in relation to reading ('Will kids lose skill to think?', HSun, 20/10/07)
fieldOfStudy: History, Digital Revolution, Reading, Literacy, Education
summary: This article responds to Maryanne Wolf's concerns about the digital revolution potentially eroding traditional reading skills, arguing against an alarmist view that privileges print over digital literacies. The author posits that expertise in reading encompasses broad repertoires of practices for decoding, meaning-making, and critical understanding across all text types, regardless of mode. It highlights that children develop valuable skills through digital engagement, including navigating hyperlinks and multimodalities, which require different but equally important competencies compared to traditional print reading. The paper advocates for teaching that builds on children's existing literate experiences in both traditional and digital modes to ensure comprehensive literacy.

title: Green Revolution Counterfactuals
abstract: In this paper, we conduct two "counterfactual" simulations for the 30-year period 1970-2000-the first holding 1970 crop genetic improvements (CGI) constant and the second presuming the International Agricultural Research Center (IARC) system had not been built. Both these counterfactuals apply to developing countries only. The core estimates on which the counterfactuals are based include country fixed effects , and the key estimates are for the Dietary Energy Sufficiency (DES) equation. DES affects birth rates, death rates, child mortality rates and malnutrition rates, making it possible to "endogenize" population growth in developing countries, in the counterfactuals. Reduced DES levels (from reduced CGI contributions) will lead to more births, more deaths and more child deaths and higher levels of malnutrition. The key technology variables that determine DES are the number of agricultural scientists per million hectares of cropland, the average years of schooling of adult males (over 25), and the level of Green Revolution Modern Varieties (GRMV) adoption. Our results show striking contrasts between the historical record and the alternative counterfactuals. The worst outcome is that without any Green Revolution Technologies or an IARC system to support it, which results in holding technological advancements constant at the 1970 level is a marginal improvement, leading to much higher prices over time, as agricultural production struggles to keep up with food demand in those countries. The endogenous feedback effects of population show the importance of nutrition and education, and argue strongly in favor of those factors playing a significant role in the improvement of human well-being that has been observed since the start of the Green Revolution to present.Research and Development/Tech Change/Emerging Technologies,
summary: This paper conducts two counterfactual simulations for 1970-2000 in developing countries to assess the impact of crop genetic improvements (CGI) and the International Agricultural Research Center (IARC) system. It examines how holding 1970 CGI constant or presuming no IARC system affects Dietary Energy Sufficiency (DES), which in turn influences birth, death, child mortality, and malnutrition rates, thereby endogenizing population growth. Key technology variables include agricultural scientists, adult male schooling, and Green Revolution Modern Varieties (GRMV) adoption. Results reveal significant contrasts with historical records, demonstrating that without these advancements, agricultural production struggles, leading to higher prices and worsened human well-being, underscoring the importance of nutrition and education.

title: Act or Revolution? Yes, Please!
abstract: In the context of the current crisis of global capitalism, it is crucial to determine what is the state of Marxism. Certainly, it is true that in recent decades Marxism has suffered a notable series of attacks, but in no way may we conclude that for this reason Marxism no longer constitutes a legitimate political and intellectual option. As Perry Anderson fittingly pointed out, “to be defeated and to be bowed are not the same” (Anderson 2005: XVII). In permanent crisis and despite all adversities—Marxism persists. Thus, adopting the standpoint of an “intransigent realism” (Anderson 2000: 10) which makes possible “refusing any accommodation with the ruling system, and rejecting every piety and euphemism that would understate its power” (idem), it is valid to question if Marxism has theoretically and practically recovered from a crisis that was supposedly fatal. In fact, has Marxism been able to respond to the challenges posed by Post-Structuralism and 2 Postmodernist discourse? Has it repelled the attacks that were inherent in the postulates of the so-called Post-Marxism? As a part of a larger effort to answer these questions, this paper deals with the work of Slavoj Žižek. What distinguishes the Slovenian philosopher from other contemporary thinkers that try to normatively undertake a defense of Marxism is that he is not precisely a Marxist. Essentially, Žižek is part of the Lacanian left (Stravrakakis 2007). But at the same time he is a very distinctive Hegelian that belongs to the field of Materialist Theory of Subjectivity (Johnston 2008). Nevertheless, in recent years Žižek has showed increasing fidelity to the Idea of communism and the radical emancipatory politics. Within this context, he has strayed from his previous interests in the development of ideology critique and has carried out a noteworthy number of original contributions to both the vicissitudes of Marxist theory and the political practice that the times in which we live require.Fil: Roggerone, Santiago Martín. Universidad de Buenos Aires; Argentina. Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas; Argentin
publisher: University of Leeds. Institute of Communications Studies
summary:
This paper examines the contemporary state of Marxism amidst the crisis of global capitalism, asserting its persistence despite numerous attacks. It questions if Marxism has recovered from challenges posed by Post-Structuralism, Postmodernism, and Post-Marxism, adopting an "intransigent realism." The study focuses on Slavoj 

ži

žek's contributions, noting his unique position as a Hegelian belonging to Materialist Theory of Subjectivity, though not strictly a Marxist.
