title: The Fall of the House of Dixie: The Civil War and the Social Revolution that Transformed the South
abstract: This article reviews The Fall of the House of Dixie: The Civil War and the Social Revolution that Transformed the South (2013) by Bruce Levine
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Social History, United States History
summary: This article reviews Bruce Levine's 2013 book, "The Fall of the House of Dixie: The Civil War and the Social Revolution that Transformed the South." The review highlights Levine's compelling narrative, which incorporates diverse sources to explain how the Civil War dismantled the Confederacy's socio-economic structure and contextualizes the transformation of the South within Northern war aims. It also addresses the post-Civil War era, discussing how Southerners, despite rejoining the Union, sought to restore their social system, and Levine's argument that the war, as a "second American revolution," ultimately ended slavery and advanced liberty.

title: Economics need a scientific revolution
abstract:
I argue that the current financial crisis highlights the crucial need of a
change of mindset in economics and financial engineering, that should move away
from dogmatic axioms and focus more on data, orders of magnitudes, and
plausible, albeit non rigorous, arguments.Comment: An edited version of this essay appeared in Natur
summary: This essay argues that the current financial crisis necessitates a fundamental shift in the mindset of economics and financial engineering. The author proposes moving away from dogmatic axioms and embracing a more data-driven approach, focusing on orders of magnitude and plausible, non-rigorous arguments, similar to natural sciences. It critiques the disappointing quantitative success of economic sciences compared to physics and advocates for new tools from 'behavioral economists' and 'econophysicists,' along with improved regulation and scrutinizing financial products. The core message emphasizes a pragmatic, realistic representation of financial markets, prioritizing data over perfect equations and aesthetic axioms.

title: The Invention of Invention
abstract: This paper models an industrial revolution as a qualitative transition from a world where innovation is infrequent and haphazard to one where it is continuous and systematic. Pre-industrial innovation is treated as a social process where an individual's effectiveness as an innovator depends on the skills of other individuals in his social network. As technology improves, individuals invest more time in learning through social contact. This gradual increase in linkage formation leads to a sudden change in the size of knowledge networks from small, isolated clusters, to a large connected cluster spanning most of the economy, causing a sudden increase in the effectiveness of innovation - an industrial revolution. The predicted sequence of typical innovators - from gifted amateurs, to lucky amateurs, to professionals - is consistent with empirical evidence.Industrial revolution, social networks, innovation
summary: This paper models an industrial revolution as a qualitative shift from infrequent, haphazard innovation to continuous, systematic innovation. It treats pre-industrial innovation as a social process where an individual's effectiveness depends on their social network's skills. As technology advances, increased investment in learning through social contact leads to a sudden expansion of knowledge networks from isolated clusters to a large, connected cluster across the economy, triggering an industrial revolution. The model predicts a sequence of innovators—gifted amateurs, lucky amateurs, then professionals—consistent with empirical evidence, providing insights into economic development, social networks, and innovation.

title: Credit rationing and crowding out during the Industrial Revolution: Evidence from Hoare's Bank, 1702-1862
abstract: Crowding-out during the British Industrial Revolution has long been one of the leading explanations for slow growth during the Industrial Revolution, but little empirical evidence exists to support it. We argue that examinations of interest rates are fundamentally misguided, and that the eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century private loan market balanced through quantity rationing. Using a unique set of observations on lending volume at a London goldsmith bank, Hoare’s, we document the impact of wartime financing on private credit markets. We conclude that there is considerable evidence that government borrowing, especially during wartime, crowded out private credit.Credit rationing, Napoleonic wars, Industrial Revolution, technological change, crowding out
fieldOfStudy: History, Economic History, Financial History, Industrial Revolution, Crowding Out, Credit Rationing
summary: This study examines the long-debated 'crowding-out' effect during the British Industrial Revolution, which posits that government borrowing hindered private sector growth. Challenging traditional approaches focused on interest rates, the authors argue that the 18th- and early 19th-century private loan market operated through quantity rationing. By analyzing unique lending volume data from Hoare's, a London goldsmith bank, they document the substantial impact of wartime financing on private credit markets. The research concludes that significant evidence supports the idea that government borrowing, particularly during wartime, actively crowded out private credit, contributing to slower growth during this pivotal period.

title: The French Revolution and Codification: Comment on the Enlightenment, the French Revolution, and the Napoleonic Codes
fieldOfStudy: History, Law, French Revolution, Napoleonic Codes
summary: This commentary on Professor Berman's lectures, "The Enlightenment, the French Revolution, and the Napoleonic Codes," details the socio-political and economic climate in France leading up to the Revolution. It outlines key events from the Estates General meeting in 1789 and explores the core belief system embedded within the Revolution. The article also examines the legislative process, specifically the codification effort that culminated in the Napoleonic Codes, including the influence of Natural Law philosophy and its eventual exclusion from the final Civil Code, highlighting its inspirational role in the codification process. This piece serves as a historical analysis of the French Revolution's impact on legal codification.

title: "New Songs of the Battlefield": Songs and Memories of the Chinese Cultural Revolution
abstract: This dissertation focuses on a five-volume anthology of songs published from 1972 to 1976 known as "Zhandi Xinge," literally "New Songs of the Battlefield." The songs represent a significant portion of the limited musical expression during a period in China known as the Cultural Revolution (1966-76). Published and approved by the Chinese Communist Party, the anthology appeared at a time when artistic and musical activities were extremely restricted. The government utilized this particular musical form for multiple goals, including the propagation of political ideologies, stimulation of party support, and education of the masses. Based upon original research and personal interviews, the dissertation provides the first documentation and analysis of the anthology in any language. Analysis focuses on the official ideology as situated in its socio-historical context, and an examination of individual reception and memory. The study begins with an introduction to the Cultural Revolution period, followed by an investigation of the composition, editing, compilation, themes, texts, and musical characteristics of the anthology. The dissertation concludes with an analysis of the contemporary memory of Cultural Revolution songs while considering concepts of music, memory, and nostalgia. The analysis reveals that the major factors influencing how the music is remembered and who remembers it, is dependent upon a combination of features including music and memory, generational imprinting and changes in contemporary Chinese society
summary: This dissertation provides the first documentation and analysis of "Zhandi Xinge" ("New Songs of the Battlefield"), a five-volume anthology of songs published in China during the Cultural Revolution (1972-1976). It investigates how the Chinese Communist Party used these songs for political propagation, party support, and mass education during a period of restricted artistic expression. The study analyzes the anthology's composition, themes, texts, and musical characteristics within its socio-historical context, concluding with an examination of contemporary memory, music, and nostalgia related to these Cultural Revolution songs, highlighting generational imprinting and societal changes as key factors in their remembrance.

title: Impact of Interupted Education on Earnings: The Educational Cost of the Chinese Cultural revolution
abstract: Impact of school interruptions on earnings through lower subsequent educational attainment and lower quality of education is investigated using the Chinese Cultural Revolution as a natural experiment. During the Cultural Revolution, most schools in China stopped normal operation for 3 to 4 years, universities stopped normal student recruitment for an even longer period. Such large scale school interruptions reduced the opportunity of the cohort to obtain university degrees. We find that individuals who did not obtain a university degree becasue of the Cultural revolution on average lost 46 per cent of their potential earnings. In addition most of the cohort experienced missed or interrupted schooling, at a given level of education and we show that this reduced earnings of degree holders of the Cultural Revolution cohort by 7.3 per cent on average. The findings in this paper also indicate that the quality of schooling affected earnings of individuals in a non-linear way, that is, only missed schooling at junior and senior high level reduced subsequent earnings and it only reduced earnings of those with degrees.
summary: This paper investigates the impact of school interruptions during the Chinese Cultural Revolution on subsequent earnings, using it as a natural experiment. It examines how reduced educational attainment and lower quality of education affected individuals. Findings indicate that not obtaining a university degree due to the Revolution led to a 46% loss in potential earnings. Furthermore, missed or interrupted schooling reduced earnings for degree holders by 7.3%. The study also reveals a non-linear effect of schooling quality, where only missed junior and senior high schooling reduced earnings for degree holders, impacting labor market outcomes and educational costs.

title: Revolutionary change and structural breaks: A time series analysis of wages and commodity prices in Britain 1264-1913
abstract: In this paper we empirically test the hypothesis that economic revolutions are associated with structural breaks in historical economic data. A simple test for structural breaks in economic time series is applied to British wage and price data from the medieval to the modern period. Evidence for structural change is found in nearly half of the series studied -- suggesting that structural breaks are an intrinsic feature of such historic data. Structural changes are most closely linked to the Commercial Revolution followed by the Agricultural Revolution and the Industrial Revolution, with changes linked to an underlying process of price stabilisation as measured by a decrease in the long-term level of volatility.historical economics; economic revolutions; structural breaks; price stabilisation
fieldOfStudy: History, historical economics, economic revolutions, structural breaks, price stabilisation
summary: This paper empirically tests the hypothesis that economic revolutions correlate with structural breaks in historical economic data. Applying a simple structural break test to British wage and price data from the medieval to modern periods, the study finds evidence of structural change in nearly half of the series. These changes are most strongly linked to the Commercial, Agricultural, and Industrial Revolutions, and are associated with a process of price stabilization marked by decreased long-term volatility. This suggests structural breaks are intrinsic to historical economic datasets.

title: Keeping your head in a revolution
abstract: Explores new developments in information services
summary: This article explores the ongoing revolution in information services, arguing that many in the information world have yet to fully benefit from or adapt to these changes. It highlights the shift from scientists and engineers as initial drivers to users now demanding Internet-based information. The author emphasizes the need for information professionals to embrace change wholeheartedly, move beyond past paradigms, and actively lead the revolution, particularly by aligning with the public good in areas like copyright. Key themes include information revolution, digital transformation, library evolution, and the role of information professionals in adapting to new user expectations driven by electronic information access.

title: On the Geometry of Planar Domain Walls
abstract:
The Geometry of planar domain walls is studied. It is argued that the planar
walls indeed have plane symmetry. In the Minkowski coordinates the walls are
mapped into revolution paraboloids.Comment: 11 paghoj, Late
summary: This paper investigates the geometry of planar domain walls, arguing for their inherent plane symmetry. Using Minkowski coordinates, the walls are mapped into revolution paraboloids. This study builds on prior work concerning domain walls in the early universe, specifically Vilenkin's 1983 analytic solution with plane symmetry and subsequent explorations of spacetime global structure by Gibbons, Wang, and Letelier. The authors aim to further characterize these cosmic structures, noting the existence of horizons in spatial directions and issues of stability against fluid and scalar field perturbations.

title: The Third Industrial Revolution
abstract: The author examines periods of rapid technological change for coincidences of widening inequality and slowing productivity growth. He contends that while the introduction of technologies offers profits to investors and premiums for skilled workers, in the long run the rising tide of technological change lifts everybody's boat.Technology ; Productivity ; Income distribution
summary: This article examines the relationship between rapid technological change, income inequality, and productivity growth, focusing on periods like the Third Industrial Revolution. The author contends that while new technologies initially benefit investors and skilled workers, leading to widening inequality, the long-term effect is a broad improvement in living standards. The study connects the rate of technological progress with income inequality and productivity, suggesting that the significant learning costs associated with new technologies, such as information technologies, favor skilled labor, causing wage premiums to rise and increasing income inequality. However, this is presented as a transient phase before widespread societal benefits materialize. Keywords: technology, productivity, income distribution, industrial revolution, inequality.

title: The Spinning Jenny and the Guillotine: Technological Diffusion at the Time of Revolutions
abstract: Why was England the cradle of the Industrial Revolution? The present work shows that scale economies and demand, combined with the conditions of the relative prices of input factors, allow to provide a purely economic answer to this question. The labor-saving innovations of the Industrial Revolution were profitable only if, after their adoption, sales expanded enough to cover the upfront cost of capital. For some time, England was the only country in which sales exceeded the minimum threshold required to make adoption profitable. This fact is illustrated here by means of a detailed case study centered on the cotton industry and on the adoption of the spinning jenny in England and in France at the dawn of the Industrial Revolution. By then, the sufficiently large and relatively well-off English middle class could guarantee to cotton spinners a level of sales that was not viable in France, where income was lower and more concentrated in the hands of the upper classes.Industrial Revolution, income distribution, economies of scale, choice of technique, spinning jenny
summary: This work explores why England was the birthplace of the Industrial Revolution, arguing that a unique combination of scale economies and demand, alongside specific input factor prices, created favorable economic conditions. Labor-saving innovations like the spinning jenny were only profitable if sales expanded sufficiently to cover capital costs. England, unlike France, possessed a large and relatively prosperous middle class, ensuring a viable market size for cotton spinners. The study uses a detailed case study of the cotton industry and the adoption of the spinning jenny in England and France to illustrate this point, highlighting the roles of income distribution and market size.

title: Friedman and the Walrasian Equations of The Natural-Rate Counter-Revolution
abstract:
From the 1930s, economic controversy has been a tale of three cities (Chicago and the two Cambridges) and three General Theories. In the 1930s, there were, in addition to the General Theory of Employment (Keynesian Macroeconomics), two other revolutionary attempts to don the mantle of generality: the General Theory of Method (the formalist revolution, involving structural econometrics and Walrasian general equilibrium) and the General Theory of Value (organised around the concept of monopolistic, or imperfect, competition). The Keynesian and formalist general revolutions became symbiotic and dominated the post-war landscape of economists. In contrast, the monopolistic competition revolution did not readily lend itself to general equilibrium formalism and, so far, has yet to achieve its promise (Tinbergen 1967, 268).
ISBN: 033373045
summary: This chapter, from a 2000 book by Robert Leeson, explores the "natural-rate counter-revolution" in economics, focusing on the interplay between Friedman's ideas and Walrasian general equilibrium. It outlines three "General Theories" from the 1930s: Keynesian Macroeconomics, the formalist revolution (structural econometrics and Walrasian equilibrium), and monopolistic competition. The chapter argues that the Keynesian and formalist revolutions became symbiotic, dominating post-war economics, while monopolistic competition struggled to integrate with general equilibrium formalism. Key concepts include economic controversy, Walrasian equations, and the Chicago counter-revolution.

title: The unfinished global revolution: intellectuals and the new politics of international relations
abstract: More than a decade after the revolutions of 1989, we can see these as a high point of a new, worldwide and increasingly global wave of democratic revolution and counter-revolution. Violent struggles between the political forces unleashed have produced genocidal wars and stimulated global state formation. These developments present concerned citizens and students of international relations and politics with new challenges. This article criticizes two trends in the responses of political intellectuals in the West: the ‘new anarchism’ of some critical thinkers in the academic discipline of international relations, and ‘yesterday's radicalism’ which has led some left-wing critics to revive the defence of sovereignty for repressive and genocidal non-Western states. The lecture concludes by outlining an alternative ‘new politics’ of international relation
summary: This article examines the global wave of democratic revolution and counter-revolution ignited by the 1989 revolutions, leading to genocidal wars and global state formation. It criticizes two Western intellectual responses: the 'new anarchism' in international relations and 'yesterday's radicalism' which defends sovereignty for repressive non-Western states. The author proposes an alternative 'new politics' of international relations, highlighting the urgent challenge for citizens and scholars to address global revolutionary dynamics to prevent further conflict and promote responsible international governance. Keywords: democratic revolution, counter-revolution, international relations, political intellectuals, sovereignty, global politics.

title: Income inequality, redistribution and democratization
abstract: We consider that in a society, there are conflicts of income redistribution between the rich (class) and the poor (one), and the extent of income inequality s conflict between these two groups in the society, bringing to a revolution aimed for more redistribution. In our model, we assume that there are two types of poor: weak and strong. The difference between the weak type and the strong type is that the later can win through a revolution, but the former can not. However, this is the private information of the poor and is not observed by the rich. When income inequality increases, with this asymmetry of information, the weak type of the poor is more likely to attempt a revolution. As a result, larger inequality results in higher probability of democratization.Democratization
summary: This paper examines the conflict of income redistribution between the rich and the poor, and how income inequality can lead to revolution and democratization. The model posits two types of poor individuals: weak and strong, with only the latter capable of winning a revolution. This information asymmetry, where the rich are unaware of the poor's strength, leads the weak poor to initiate revolutions as inequality rises. Consequently, the study claims that higher income inequality increases the probability of democratization. Key concepts include income inequality, redistribution, revolution, democratization, and information asymmetry.

title: Sociology and postcolonialism: another 'missing' revolution?
abstract: Sociology is usually represented as having emerged alongside European modernity. The latter is frequently understood as sociology's special object with sociology itself a distinctively modern form of explanation. The period of sociology's disciplinary formation was also the heyday of European colonialism, yet the colonial relationship did not figure in the development of sociological understandings. While the recent emergence of postcolonialism appears to have initiated a reconsideration of understandings of modernity, with the development of theories of multiple modernities, I suggest that this engagement is more an attempt at recuperating the transformative aspect of postcolonialism than engaging with its critiques. In setting out the challenge of postcolonialism to dominant sociological accounts, I also address `missing feminist/queer revolutions', suggesting that by engaging with postcolonialism there is the potential to transform sociological understandings by opening up a dialogue beyond the simple pluralism of identity claims
summary: This paper critically examines the conventional representation of sociology as a discipline born alongside European modernity, arguing that its disciplinary formation overlooked the colonial relationship despite its contemporary prominence. The author contends that postcolonialism's engagement with theories of multiple modernities often recuperates rather than critiques, and proposes that a genuine engagement with postcolonialism, alongside "missing feminist/queer revolutions," can transform sociological understandings by fostering dialogue beyond simple identity pluralism. Key terms include sociology, postcolonialism, European modernity, colonialism, feminist theory, and queer theory.

title: Determinants of Protests: Longitudinal Evidence from Ukraine’s Orange Revolution
abstract: This paper is the first study that analyzes the drivers of political protest using longitudinal data from a critical revolution that changed –at least temporarily– the political landscape in a transition country. We make use of a rich dataset consisting of panel data collected before and after the so called “Orange” revolution in Ukraine. Our empirical approach tackles two different –and equally interesting– features of the revolution: the determinants of participation (both in the protests and counter-protests) and the “selection” of participants into different levels of involvement (i.e. intensity of participation). We consider different drivers of participation, from traditional proxies for opportunities and grievances, but we also analyze the role of political and economic preferences, risk tolerance, life satisfaction, and indicators of network connectivity. What emerges from this study is a more nuanced pattern of participation that does not link uniquely to a single theoretical model.
summary: This study analyzes the drivers of political protest using longitudinal panel data from Ukraine's "Orange" revolution. The authors investigate determinants of participation in both protests and counter-protests, and the intensity of involvement. They consider traditional factors like opportunities and grievances, alongside political and economic preferences, risk tolerance, life satisfaction, and network connectivity. The key finding is a nuanced pattern of participation that defies linkage to a single theoretical model. This research offers insights into revolutionary dynamics and social mobilization.

title: Transforming vocational learning: a cultural revolution?
publisher: Great Britain. Office for Standards in Education
summary: This speech by David Bell, Her Majesty's Chief Inspector of Schools, delivered at the CRAC Conference in 2004, emphasizes the critical importance of vocational learning and skills in preparing young people for a rapidly changing global workforce. Bell advocates for a broad and balanced curriculum that includes vocational relevance, arguing that a highly educated, skilled, and adaptable workforce is essential for national prosperity. The speech calls for greater collaboration between the business community and the education system to champion vocational education and support teachers in developing enterprising young people. It acknowledges an ongoing transformation in vocational education but highlights the need to overcome issues of parity with general education.

title: Buckling of shells of revolution with various wall constructions.  Volume 1 - Numerical results
abstract: Numerical results of buckling of shells of revolution for computer progra
summary: This volume presents numerical results concerning the buckling of shells of revolution with various wall constructions, serving as the first part of a three-volume final report. The study investigates critical axial loads for different shell geometries, including cones and spherical segments, under varying support conditions such as edge rings and internal stiffening. Key analyses involve examining the influence of parameters like ring thickness and the number of mesh points on buckling behavior. The findings provide insights into structural stability and inform engineering design for aerospace applications, particularly for spacecraft components and other thin-walled structures.

title: NASA Educational Briefs for the Classroom. Orbits of Bodies in Space
abstract: The difference between an orbit and a revolution is explained and it is shown why space shuttle Columbia's period of revolution was longer than its orbital period. Parameters of orbits examined include apoapsis, periapsis, apogee, perigee, aphelion, perihelion, orbital plane, and inclination. Orbit velocity and duration, Newton's law of gravitation, and Kepler's three laws of motion are considered. The principles involved in geostationary satellites are also explored
fieldOfStudy: Astronomy, Orbital Mechanics, Physics, Spacecraft Engineering
summary: This document clarifies the distinction between an orbit and a revolution, explaining why space shuttle Columbia's revolution period exceeded its orbital period. It defines key orbital parameters such as apoapsis, periapsis, apogee, perigee, aphelion, perihelion, orbital plane, and inclination. The text also delves into orbit velocity, duration, Newton's law of gravitation, and Kepler's three laws of motion, exploring the principles governing geostationary satellites. These concepts are crucial for understanding celestial mechanics and spacecraft trajectories.

title: The Urgent Need for an Academic Revolution: From Knowledge to Wisdom,
abstract: At present the basic intellectual aim of academic inquiry is to improve knowledge. Much of the structure, the whole character, of academic inquiry, in universities all over the world, is shaped by the adoption of this as the basic intellectual aim. But, judged from the standpoint of making a contribution to human welfare, academic inquiry of this type is damagingly irrational. Three of four of the most elementary rules of rational problem-solving are violated. A revolution in the aims and methods of academic inquiry is needed so that the basic aim becomes to promote wisdom, conceived of as the capacity to realize what is of value, for oneself and others, thus including knowledge and technological know-how, but much else besides. This urgently needed revolution would affect every branch and aspect of the academic enterprise
fieldOfStudy: History, Academic Inquiry, Philosophy of Science
summary: This paper argues that the current intellectual aim of academic inquiry, focused on improving knowledge, is damagingly irrational and fails to contribute optimally to human welfare. It claims that academic inquiry violates fundamental rules of rational problem-solving. The author proposes an urgent revolution in academic aims and methods, advocating for a shift from knowledge acquisition to the promotion of 'wisdom' – defined as the capacity to realize what is of value for oneself and others, encompassing knowledge, technological know-how, and more. This revolution is presented as essential to address grave global problems.

title: In brief...Cotton and Cars: the Huge Gains from Process Innovation
abstract: New inventions are good for economic growth, but equally important are improvements in the way we make things - what's known as process innovation. Tim Leunig and Joachim Voth measure the impact of two such innovations - mechanical cotton spinning and the motorcar assembly line - on the world's material wellbeing.Process innovations, new goods, welfare, consumer surplus, mechanisation, mass production, automobiles, cotton, industrial revolution, second industrial revolution
fieldOfStudy: History, Economics, Industrial Revolution, Mass Production
summary: This article investigates the significant impact of process innovations on material wellbeing, arguing that improvements in manufacturing methods are as crucial for economic growth as new inventions. Focusing on mechanical cotton spinning and the motorcar assembly line, the authors measure how these innovations transformed luxury items into everyday consumables, leading to substantial price declines and increased consumer welfare. The study highlights that making existing goods cheaper profoundly raises living standards, contributing significantly to societal prosperity and economic history.

title: Gravitational and Harmonic Oscillator Potentials on Surfaces of Revolution
abstract: In this paper, we consider the motion of a particle on a surface of revolution under the influence of a central force field. We prove that there are at most two analytic central potentials for which all the bounded, nonsingular orbits are closed and that there are exactly two on some surfaces with constant Gaussian curvature. The two potentials leading to closed orbits are suitable generalizations of the gravitational and harmonic oscillator potential. We also show that there could be surfaces admitting only one potential that leads to closed orbits. In this case, the potential is a generalized harmonic oscillator. In the special case of surfaces of revolution with constant Gaussian curvature, we prove a generalization of the well-known Bertrand theorem
summary: This paper investigates the motion of a particle on a surface of revolution under a central force field, proving that at most two analytic central potentials lead to closed, bounded, nonsingular orbits. Specifically, on surfaces with constant Gaussian curvature, exactly two such potentials exist, generalizing the gravitational and harmonic oscillator potentials. The study also shows that some surfaces may admit only one potential leading to closed orbits, which is a generalized harmonic oscillator. The authors present a generalization of the Bertrand theorem for surfaces of revolution with constant Gaussian curvature, contributing to the field of classical mechanics and differential geometry.

title: Reconstruction as a Pure Bourgeois Revolution
abstract: The years between 1865 and 1877, which form the period in American history known as Reconstruction, compose a sort of coda to the traumatic opera of the American Civil War of 1861–65. Reconstruction embraces the twelve years of active effort to rebuild the American Union, though in some sense (because Reconstruction had no official starting or ending date) aspects of it spluttered on well into the 1890s. I use the word spluttered deliberately, because Reconstruction is also the ugly duckling of American history in the eyes of many American historians, and something the public considers vaguely awful if it thinks of it at all. Absent from Reconstruction are the conflict and the personalities that make the Civil War so colorful; it also lacks the climactic battles and dissipates into a confusing and wearisome tale of lost opportunities, squalid victories, and embarrassing defeats. It was, proclaimed one veteran of the Army of Northern Virginia, “not peace established in power, but captured in shame; not throned on high by willing witnesses, but pinned to the earth by imperial steel—the peace of the bayonet.” In many cases, especially for those who regard Reconstruction as an unrelieved misery, almost the worst thing that can be said about someone is that they were prominent in Reconstruction
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, United States History, Civil War Era Studies
summary: This article examines the period of American history known as Reconstruction (1865-1877), often viewed negatively due to its perceived lack of dramatic conflict and personalities, and its conclusion in "squalid victories" and "embarrassing defeats." The author argues that Reconstruction can be interpreted as a pure bourgeois revolution, despite its often-maligned status. It focuses on the efforts to rebuild the American Union post-Civil War, analyzing the societal and political shifts. The text suggests that the era's complexities and outcomes serve as a warning against Whiggish assumptions about liberal democracy's inevitability, highlighting the oscillation between desires for stability and desires for mobility, liberty, and profit.

title: Collective invention during the British Industrial Revolution: the case of the Cornish pumping engine
abstract: pump enigine, industrial revolution, collective invention
fieldOfStudy: History, Economic History, Innovation Studies, Technological Change
summary: This paper investigates collective invention settings, where competing firms share technological knowledge, as a crucial source of innovation during the early phases of industrialization, a topic often overlooked in literature focusing on the patent system. It details the Cornish mining district as one such setting, examining the economic and technical circumstances that fostered its emergence and analyzing its impact on the rate of technological innovation. Key areas of focus include incremental innovation, patents, collective invention, and steam engines, particularly the Cornish pumping engine.

title: The Digital Revolution and Higher Education
abstract: Presents survey findings about the views of college presidents and the public on the value of, prevalence of, and experience with online learning, as well as the role of the Internet and related technologies in education and prospects for future growth
fieldOfStudy: History, Higher Education, Online Learning, Digital Revolution
summary: This report presents findings from two Pew Research Center surveys conducted in spring 2011, examining the perceptions of college presidents and the general public regarding online learning. It explores their views on the educational value, prevalence, and experience with online courses, as well as the broader role of the internet and related technologies in higher education. Key findings reveal a difference in opinion between the public and college presidents on the value of online courses. The study employed telephone and online survey methodologies, providing insights into educational trends and technology integration in academia.

title: Digital Television: Has the Revolution Stalled?
abstract: When digital television technology first hit the scene it garnered great excitement, with its promise of movie theater picture and sound on a fraction of the bandwidth of analog. A plan was implemented to transition from the current analog broadcasting system to a digital system effective December 23, 2006. As we reach the half point of this plan, the furor begins to die as the realities of the difficult change sink in
summary: This article examines the stalled transition from analog to digital television (DTV) broadcasting, initially promised to deliver movie-quality picture and sound with reduced bandwidth. Despite a plan for a full transition by December 23, 2006, the reality of implementing this complex change has dampened initial excitement. The paper explores the history and immense technological possibilities of DTV, including broadcast of theater-quality media, multicasting, and data communication capabilities. It also touches upon the motivations stemming from analog broadcasting history and the establishment of technical standards by the National Television Systems Committee (NTSC).

title: Materials science and the sensor revolution
abstract:
For the past decade, we have been investigating strategies to develop

ways to provide chemical sensing platforms capable of long-term

deployment in remote locations1-3. This key objective has been driven by

the emergence of ubiquitous digital communications and the associated

potential for widely deployed wireless sensor networks (WSNs).

Understandably, in these early days of WSNs, deployments have been

based on very reliable sensors, such as thermistors, accelerometers, flow

meters, photodetectors, and digital cameras. Biosensors and chemical

sensors (bio/chemo-sensors) are largely missing from this rapidly

developing field, despite the obvious value offered by an ability to measure

molecular targets at multiple locations in real-time. Interestingly, while

this paper is focused on the issues with respect to wide area sensing of

the environment, the core challenge is essentially the same for long-term

implantable bio/chemo-sensors4, i.e.; how to maintain the integrity of the

analytical method at a remote, inaccessible location
fieldOfStudy: History, chemical sensing, wireless sensor networks
summary: This paper investigates strategies for developing long-term deployable chemical sensing platforms, focusing on their integration into wireless sensor networks (WSNs). The core challenge addressed is maintaining the integrity of analytical methods in remote or inaccessible locations for both wide-area environmental sensing and implantable biosensors/chemosensors. While early WSNs rely on robust sensors like thermistors and accelerometers, the authors highlight the absence of bio/chemo-sensors despite their value in real-time molecular target measurement. The study aims to overcome technical barriers for widespread deployment of advanced chemical sensing.

title: Technological Revolutions and Economic Growth:The �Age of Steam� Reconsidered
abstract: revolution, economic growth, steam, technological
summary: This paper reconsiders the "Age of Steam" within the context of technological revolutions and their impact on economic growth. It explores the historical development and adoption of steam engine technology, analyzing its role in driving industrial and economic transformation. The authors investigate how steam power acted as a general purpose technology, influencing various sectors and contributing to sustained economic expansion. Key findings emphasize the complex interplay between technological innovation, industrial organization, and long-term economic development. This study is crucial for understanding the dynamics of technological change and its macroeconomic implications.

title: From iron to aggregates
abstract:
One hundred and seventy-five years ago the supply of iron ore and coal were vital to

maintain growth during the latter stages of the Industrial Revolution and the need for these

minerals contributed to the founding of the British Geological Survey
summary: This document highlights the British Geological Survey's ongoing commitment to understanding and mapping the UK's mineral resources, a priority since its founding during the Industrial Revolution due to the demand for iron ore and coal. It emphasizes the increasing pressure on land from population growth, threatening future mineral supply security. The BGS provides detailed mineral resource maps and digital data for England, Wales, and central Scotland, built on 1:50,000 scale digital geological maps (DigMapGB). Criteria for defining resources include physical/chemical suitability and historical industry presence, utilizing desk studies, existing literature, BGS datasets, and stakeholder consultations to inform planning and ensure future supply management.

title: Science, Bourgeois Dignity, and the Industrial Revolution
abstract: What happened to make for the factor of 16 were new ideas, what Mokyr calls “industrial Enlightenment.” But the Scientific Revolution did not suffice. Non-Europeans like the Chinese outstripped the West in science until quite late. Britain did not lead in science---yet clearly did in technology. Indeed, applied technology depended on science only a little even in 1900.scientific revolution, science, technology, industrial enlightenment, applied technology
summary: This paper argues that the Industrial Revolution, characterized by a "factor of 16" growth, stemmed from new ideas, or "industrial Enlightenment," rather than solely from the Scientific Revolution. It highlights that non-Europeans initially outpaced the West in science and that Britain's technological leadership did not heavily depend on scientific advancements, even by 1900. The work, part of "The Bourgeois Era," proposes that increased dignity and liberty for the bourgeoisie and their innovations, rather than other factors, drove modern economic growth and benefited the poor. Key concepts include industrial enlightenment, Scientific Revolution, applied technology, and economic growth.

title: The dictator’s dilemma: the role of social media in revolutions
abstract: This paper develops a revolution model incorporating the effects of social media. It is seen that social media changes the outcomes of traditional revolution models due its effects on the cost/benefit analysis of would-be participants. The paper also considers various strategies for the dictator to stop the revolution in light of social media. Finally, the paper offers extensions and different ways to evaluate the effectiveness of social media in a revolution.•Introduction: So, you want to be a dictator? These days, it is tougher to lead an authoritarian regime in the face of democratic ideals, free speech and globalized media. Look to the Arab Spring, the inspiration for this paper, as an example of dictators overthrown by these modern forces. Rebels mobilized in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya against longstanding dictators to achieve a self-determined life. This paper hopes to find ways to help you, the would-be dictator, stay in power. In order to do this, the paper will explore and model the factors that encourage the overthrow of a dictator and hence inform how the dictator can rebuff any rebellions before they start.All revolutions differ; perhaps, however, modern and future revolutions have fundamentally changed due to the internet and social media. The greatest problem for would-be revolutionaries is organization. Social media helps overcome collective action problems by dissemination of information to organize people. Facebook and Twitter brought people to Tahrir Square in Egypt to protest Hosni Mubarek because they were inspired by posted messages and videos. Wael Gholim created a Facebook page “We Are All Khaled Saeed” that created an online arena for people to share their discontent. When the page called for protests on January 25th, hundreds of thousands mobilized.Social media has also changed the effectiveness of the dictator’s methods to quell a revolution. In the past, a dictator could kill a dissident to silence him while only angering a few close relatives and friends. Today, as in the case of Khaled Saeed, the deceased can become a rallying cry for thousands and his message quickly spread. The dictator’s action, while silencing one, angers thousands. Since the revolutionaries’ tactics have changed, perhaps the dictators need to as well. In some Asian countries, authoritarian regimes restrict internet access such as China’s “great firewall”. Pakistan has decided to build its own web wall to partially block users from certain websites while North Korea effectively does not have internet.  Restricting the internet involves a trade-off between the internet’s efficiency gains and the possibility of social unrest.Of course, there is always the good old-fashioned bribe. The problem is enforcing the bribe. Hopefully, the bribe is not taken and then used against the dictator. Instead of a cash bribe, the dictator could employ or create governmental positions for his opposition. This co-option of leading revolutionaries may help kill a revolution before it starts.  Perhaps the best method of keeping a revolution at bay is to make the people happier by governing better.The dictator has many choices to stop a revolution; some more effective than others. In order to examine the dictator’s choices, a revolution model needs to be constructed
fieldOfStudy: History, Political Science, Social Media Studies
summary: This paper develops a revolution model that integrates the role of social media, examining its impact on the cost/benefit analysis for potential participants. It analyzes how social media alters outcomes in traditional revolution scenarios and explores various strategies dictators can employ to counter revolutions in the digital age. The study also proposes extensions and methods for evaluating social media's effectiveness in revolutionary movements, drawing inspiration from events like the Arab Spring where platforms like Facebook and Twitter facilitated organization and dissemination of information, helping overcome collective action problems.

title: Jesuit response to the communication revolution
abstract: This essay will consider both. In order to offer a context, it begins with a review of the impact of the communication revolution on our individual and collective lives. Communication, the process of exchanging information and influence, occurs through interpersonal methods or through the mass media. However, recent technological advances lead me to focus more on mass communication
summary: This essay reviews the impact of the communication revolution on individual and collective lives, focusing on mass communication due to recent technological advances. It explores how Jesuits, as consumers and communicators of media, respond to this pervasive influence. The paper discusses the inescapable nature of media consumption and the challenges faced by religious communication, such as liturgy competing with television. It serves as a context for understanding Jesuit perspectives on the evolving media landscape.

title: Spacetime Slices and Surfaces of Revolution
abstract:
Under certain conditions, a $(1+1)$-dimensional slice $\hat{g}$ of a
spherically symmetric black hole spacetime can be equivariantly embedded in
$(2+1)$-dimensional Minkowski space. The embedding depends on a real parameter
that corresponds physically to the surface gravity $\kappa$ of the black hole
horizon.
  Under conditions that turn out to be closely related, a real surface that
possesses rotational symmetry can be equivariantly embedded in 3-dimensional
Euclidean space. The embedding does not obviously depend on a parameter.
However, the Gaussian curvature is given by a simple formula: If the metric is
written $g = \phi(r)^{-1} dr^2 + \phi(r) d\theta^2$, then
$\K_g=-{1/2}\phi''(r)$.
  This note shows that metrics $g$ and $\hat{g}$ occur in dual pairs, and that
the embeddings described above are orthogonal facets of a single phenomenon. In
particular, the metrics and their respective embeddings differ by a Wick
rotation that preserves the ambient symmetry.
  Consequently, the embedding of $g$ depends on a real parameter. The ambient
space is not smooth, and $\kappa$ is inversely proportional to the cone angle
at the axis of rotation. Further, the Gaussian curvature of $\hat{g}$ is given
by a simple formula that seems not to be widely known.Comment: 15 pages, added reference
summary: This paper demonstrates that specific $(1+1)$-dimensional slices of spherically symmetric black hole spacetimes and rotationally symmetric real surfaces, which are typically embedded in higher-dimensional Minkowski and Euclidean spaces respectively, are orthogonal facets of a single phenomenon. The authors show that these metrics form dual pairs, related by a Wick rotation that preserves ambient symmetry. Consequently, the embedding of the real surface also depends on a real parameter, where the surface gravity of the black hole horizon is inversely proportional to the cone angle of the ambient space. The study also provides a simplified formula for the Gaussian curvature of the black hole spacetime slice, which can be useful in general relativity and differential geometry.

title: Mayakovsky’s Bedbug: Revolution, Time and Utopia
abstract: The article was submitted on 25.04.2017.In Russia, the very idea of a Communist revolution – from 1905 onwards – meant both hope and dread. This attitude is quite clearly shown in a very significant part of the Russian literary process, from 1908 to the beginning of the Stalin era. An obvious thread, in fact, connects Aleksandr Bogdanov (Red Star, 1908), Evgeny Zamyatin (We, 1921) and Vladimir Mayakovsky (The Bedbug, 1929): the growing awareness that the Communist revolution, as Lenin had conceived it, was little more than a model and that a model could not describe – much less forecast – a complex reality (a complex system) like a social and political one. As a result of this awareness, hope and a dark prophecy (Bogdanov) slowly turn into despair (Mayakovsky). The model is subsumed by Vladimir Mayakovsky’s dystopian satire of The Bedbug and The Bathhouse which propose a new paradigm of dystopia: a bottleneck in the flow of the information produced by blind adherence to a preconceived project that prevents the discovery and the implementation of la volonté générale in so complex a system as human society.Для периода господства революционных идей в России начала XX в. были характерны противоречивые настроения надежды и страха. Это ярко проявлялось и во многих произведениях русской литературы, начиная с 1908 г. и вплоть до сталинской эпохи. Такие представления были связующей нитью для творчества Александра Богданова (Красная Звезда, 1908), Евгения Замятина (Мы, 1921) и Владимира Маяковского (Клоп, 1929): по их изменениям можно проследить то, как в сознании людей росло убеждение, что коммунистическая революция – всего лишь абстрактная модель. А модель не может описать и, тем более, предсказать сложную реальность, включающую в себя социальную и политическую системы. Из осознания этого факта, по мнению автора, и происходит мрачное пророчество А. Богданова (соединенное с надеждой), которое затем перерастает в отчаяние у В. Маяковского. Эта модель представлена в сатире Маяковского – в «Клопе» и «Бане», в которых возникает новая парадигма антиутопии: информационная ограниченность, вызванная слепым следованием заранее заданному замыслу, препятствует открытию и внедрению volonté générale (всеобщей воли как результата ограничения людьми своих прав) в такой сложной системе как человеческое общество
summary:
This article explores the evolving perception of the Communist revolution in Russian literature from 1908 to the early Stalin era, focusing on works by Aleksandr Bogdanov, Evgeny Zamyatin, and Vladimir Mayakovsky. It argues that initially, the revolution evoked both hope and dread, but authors increasingly recognized Lenin's conception as an inadequate model for complex social and political realities. The study traces this awareness from Bogdanov's dark prophecy to Mayakovsky's despair, particularly through his dystopian satires "The Bedbug" and "The Bathhouse." These works present a new paradigm of dystopia: an informational bottleneck caused by rigid adherence to a preconceived project, hindering the implementation of the "volont
		générale" in human society. Key themes include revolution, utopianism, dystopia, and the limitations of theoretical models.

title: Scriptural Justification for the American Revolution
abstract: This thesis will seek to examine the intention of the Founding Fathers regarding their decision to break from England in what became the American Revolution. On July 4th, 1776, fifty-five men gathered to sign the defining document of their cause – the Declaration of Independence. As the document presents the climactic argument against the English crown, this thesis will seek to analyze its writers’ intentions, presuppositions, and rationalizations. Ultimately, this thesis will demonstrate that the Founders not only sought biblical justification for their actions and opinions, but followed the letter of biblical and common law in order to please both their Creator and their consciences
fieldOfStudy: History, American Revolution, Founding Fathers, Declaration of Independence, Biblical Law, Common Law, Political Theory
summary: This thesis examines the Founding Fathers' intentions in breaking from England during the American Revolution, specifically analyzing the Declaration of Independence. It explores the writers' presuppositions and rationalizations, arguing that the Founders sought biblical justification for their actions. The study demonstrates their adherence to biblical and common law, aiming to reconcile their decisions with their Creator and consciences. Key methods involve analyzing primary documents and historical philosophies concerning civil disobedience, just war theory, and the role of government. This work is relevant for understanding the ideological underpinnings of American independence and the interplay of religion and politics in its formation.

title: The Physician and the Sexual Revolution
summary: This article, "The Physician and the Sexual Revolution," by Max Levin, M.D., examines the impact of the sexual revolution on medical practice, particularly concerning emotional conflicts and guidance sought by individuals. The author advocates for premarital chastity as an ideal for young unmarried women, emphasizing the greater emotional investment girls typically have in love and marriage. Levin argues against a "debased conception of sex" and stresses the physician's obligation to teach real values and the beauty of sex, despite potential accusations of speaking like religious figures. Keywords: sexual revolution, physician's role, premarital chastity, emotional conflicts, human values, sex education.

title: Geodesics on an ellipsoid of revolution
abstract:
Algorithms for the computation of the forward and inverse geodesic problems
for an ellipsoid of revolution are derived. These are accurate to better than
15 nm when applied to the terrestrial ellipsoids. The solutions of other
problems involving geodesics (triangulation, projections, maritime boundaries,
and polygonal areas) are investigated.Comment: LaTex, 29 pages, 16 figures. Supplementary material is available at
  http://geographiclib.sourceforge.net/geod.htm
summary: This paper presents algorithms for computing forward and inverse geodesic problems on an ellipsoid of revolution, achieving accuracy better than 15 nm for terrestrial ellipsoids. The research investigates solutions for various geodesic-related problems including triangulation, map projections, maritime boundaries, and polygonal area calculations. It defines geodesics as natural "straight lines" or paths of minimum curvature on the Earth's surface. The study is relevant for fields requiring precise geodetic computations and numerical methods for spatial analysis. Key aspects include geometrical geodesy, map projections, and numerical methods.

title: A spatial revolution continues in Oakland
abstract: The article describes the purpose-built young adult space in Oakland Public Library\u27s (OPL) 81st Avenue Branch in California. Launched on January 29, 2011, the space emphasizes the library\u27s dedication to young adult literature. The space expands the library\u27s commitment to public space equity for teenagers as well as contributes to the facility\u27s revolution in serving young adult readers. An overview of the planning process involved in the construction of the space.
summary: This article describes the creation of a dedicated young adult space at the Oakland Public Library's 81st Avenue Branch, launched in January 2011. The purpose-built area underscores the library's commitment to young adult literature and public space equity for teenagers, marking a significant development in serving this demographic. The text provides an overview of the planning process involved in constructing this innovative library space, highlighting its contribution to a "spatial revolution" in Oakland public libraries. Keywords include young adult library services, public libraries, space planning, and teen services.

title: Serhii Yefremov: Epitome of the Ukrainian Revolution
abstract: Yefremov’s personal characteristics exemplify the characteristic features of the Ukrainian revolution. He was an argumentative, pugnacious man, and the revolution was characterized by infighting. He was an institution builder, and that’s a key element of the Ukrainian revolution. He was ideologically an advocate of Ukrainian identity (sooner than social rights or state building) and that too was a feature of the Ukrainian revolution. His diaries and ego writing offer a variety of evidence of these aspects of his personality
summary:
This study examines Serhii Yefremov's personal characteristics as emblematic of the Ukrainian Revolution's defining features. The research highlights Yefremov's argumentative nature, mirroring the revolution's infighting, and his role as an institution builder, a crucial aspect of the movement. It further explores his ideological advocacy for Ukrainian identity over social rights or state-building, another prominent revolutionary trait. Utilizing his diaries and other personal writings, the paper provides evidence for these facets of his personality, offering insights into his significant contributions to Ukrainian political and cultural life during the 1917
V21 period. Keywords include Serhii Yefremov, Ukrainian Revolution, diary, and memoirs.

title: The invention of ancient Israel: the silencing of Palestinian history
abstract: Whitelam, Keith W. The invention of ancient Israel: the silencing of Palestinian history. London: Routledge, 1996
summary: This monograph by Keith W. Whitelam critically examines the historical delineation of ancient Israel, arguing it is a scholarly invention driven by biases towards biblical and Christian preoccupations, and the modern state of Israel. The author contends that this invention has effectively silenced the true history of Palestine. The review encourages readers to consider the subtle biases in all historical writing and reconstruction. It highlights how Whitelam's work, though focused on a specific region, raises broader methodological questions about marginalized or misrepresented peoples, urging a re-examination of other silenced histories.

title: A History of Dystonia: Ancient to Modern
abstract: Before 1911, when Hermann Oppenheim introduced the term dystonia, this movement disorder lacked a unifying descriptor. While words like epilepsy, apoplexy, and palsy have had their meanings since antiquity, references to dystonia are much harder to identify in historical documents. Torticollis is an exception, although there is difficulty distinguishing dystonic torticollis from congenital muscular torticollis. There are, nevertheless, possible representations of dystonia in literature and visual art from the pre-modern world. Eighteenth century systematic nosologists such as Linnaeus, de Sauvages, and Cullen had attempted to classify some spasmodic conditions, including torticollis. But only after Charcot's contributions to clinical neuroscience were the various forms of generalized and focal dystonia clearly delineated. They were categorized as névroses: Charcot's term for conditions without an identifiable neuroanatomical cause. For a time thereafter, psychoanalytic models of dystonia based on Freud's ideas about unconscious conflicts transduced into physical symptoms were ascendant, although there was always a dissenting “organic” school. With the rise of subspecialization in movement disorders during the 1970s, the pendulum swung strongly back toward organic causation. David Marsden's clinical and electrophysiological research on the adult-onset focal dystonias was particularly important in establishing a physical basis for these disorders. We are still in a period of “living history” of dystonia, with much yet to be understood about pathophysiology. Rigidly dualistic models have crumbled in the face of evidence of electrophysiological and psychopathological overlap between organic and functional dystonia. More flexible biopsychosocial frameworks may address the demand for new diagnostic and therapeutic rationales
summary: This review explores the historical understanding of dystonia, a movement disorder whose unifying descriptor was only introduced by Hermann Oppenheim in 1911. The authors trace possible references to dystonia in pre-modern literature and art, alongside early attempts at classification by 18th-century nosologists. They highlight Charcot's delineation of generalized and focal dystonias, initially categorized as "névroses," and the subsequent rise and fall of psychoanalytic models. The shift towards organic causation with David Marsden's research in the 1970s is discussed. The paper concludes by noting the ongoing understanding of dystonia's pathophysiology and the need for biopsychosocial frameworks given the overlap between organic and functional dystonia.

title: The history of ancient Palestine from the palaeolithic period to Alexander\u27s conquest
abstract: Reviewed Book: Ahlström, Gösta  Werner. The history of ancient Palestine from the palaeolithic period to Alexander\u27s conquest. Minneapolis: Augsburg Fortress; Sheffield: JSOT Press, 1993
summary: This review examines Gösta Werner Ahlström's monumental posthumous work, "The History of Ancient Palestine from the Palaeolithic Period to Alexander's Conquest." The book offers a comprehensive history of Palestine and its neighbors, spanning from prehistoric times to the Persian Period. Authored by a philologically-trained scholar who embraced archaeology later in his career, it covers methodological introductions, the land's geography, and various historical epochs. While highly recommended as a resource for further research, the reviewer notes minor inconsistencies and factual details, suggesting its use to supplement more standard presentations of ancient Israelite history.

title: Oyster shells as history books
abstract: [FIRST PARAGRAPH] A collaborative project was established in 2002 that has brought together geochemistry and archaeology in order to investigate environmental change and the harvesting strategies of ancient peoples. The objectives of this study are to decipher the life history and environmental information contained in shells of the European oyster, Ostrea edulis, by analyzing geochemical variations along shell growth. This approach provides an independent measure of age and season of death, as well as a record of environmental change in temperature and salinity through the life of the oyster. By understanding the life history and environmental records contained in modern oyster shells, we can analyze shells from archaeological sites to gain an historical perspective of harvesting practices and environmental change in ancient shellfisheries
summary: This collaborative project, established in 2002, integrates geochemistry and archaeology to investigate ancient environmental change and harvesting strategies. The study aims to decipher the life history and environmental information from European oyster (Ostrea edulis) shells by analyzing geochemical variations. This method provides independent measures of age, season of death, temperature, and salinity throughout the oyster's life. Understanding modern oyster shells allows for analyzing archaeological shells to gain historical perspectives on harvesting practices and environmental shifts in ancient shellfisheries, contributing to knowledge on environmental reconstruction and human-environment interactions.

title: Astrophysics: Most distant cosmic blast seen
abstract:
The most distant -ray burst yet sighted is the earliest astronomical object
ever observed in cosmic history. This ancient beacon offers a glimpse of the
little-known cosmic dark ages.Comment: Published in Nature News & View
summary: This paper highlights the discovery of GRB 090423, the most distant gamma-ray burst ever observed, representing the earliest astronomical object in cosmic history. Researchers Tanvir et al. and Salvaterra et al. measured a concordant redshift of approximately 8.2 by observing its fading afterglow, offering a unique glimpse into the poorly understood cosmic dark ages. The findings extend the redshift record beyond galaxies and quasars, providing critical insights into the early Universe's expansion and re-ionization process. This discovery is pivotal for understanding the conditions and events occurring roughly 630 million years after the Big Bang.

title: Determining how atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations have changed during the history of the Earth
abstract: The reconstruction of ancient atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations is essential to understanding the history of the Earth and life. It is also an important guide to identifying the sensitivity of the Earth system to this greenhouse gas and, therefore, constraining its future impact on climate. However, determining the concentration of CO2 in ancient atmospheres is a challenging endeavour requiring the application of state-of-the-art analytical chemistry to geological materials, underpinned by an understanding of photosynthesis and biochemistry. It is truly an interdisciplinary challenge
summary: This article discusses the critical importance of reconstructing ancient atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentrations to comprehend Earth's history and life, and to predict future climate impacts. It emphasizes that determining past CO2 levels is an interdisciplinary challenge, requiring advanced analytical chemistry applied to geological materials, alongside an understanding of photosynthesis and biochemistry. The authors highlight its role as a guide for identifying the Earth system's sensitivity to this greenhouse gas. This research is vital for climate modeling and historical environmental science.

title: Engineering of Ancient Greece
abstract: STEP Category: Education AbroadMy STEP project will be a two-week education abroad trip to Greece with a one-week class on campus in May 2019. The education abroad program, “Engineering of Ancient Greece” is through the Office of International Affairs at OSU. From May 6-10, I will be participating in the on-campus course, ENGR 5797.18, which explores the engineering wonders of Ancient Greece and the construction methods that were used. May 12-23 will be spent in-country, traveling to various islands and cities throughout Greece, exploring the temples and ruins while experiencing the modern Greek culture. The goal of the program is for students to learn the importance of iconic engineering sites and their construction methods. In addition to this, students get to explore a combination of ancient and modern Greek cultures and how the nation has been impacted by history. I have always wanted to travel to Greece, to visit Athens and the Parthenon, and to study the ancient Greek civilizations. My goal for this trip is to increase my global awareness by learning about and engaging with a new culture. I also want to increase my understanding of engineering by studying its beginnings in Greece and learning the tools and methods they used. To prepare for the trip and experience, I am learning some of the history of Greece and basic Greek phrases. Besides being an engineering student, I am also a Classical Humanities minor, studying Greek civilization. I think that this program will be a great way to merge my two courses of study and enrich my academic experience at OSU.The Ohio State University Second-year Transformational Experience Program (STEP)Academic Major: Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineerin
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient History, Engineering, Classical Humanities
summary: This STEP project involved a two-week education abroad trip to Greece, complemented by a one-week on-campus course, "Engineering of Ancient Greece." The student, an Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering major and Classical Humanities minor, aimed to increase global awareness and understanding of engineering by exploring ancient Greek construction methods and historical sites. Key activities included studying the Sanctuary at Delphi, visiting Athens (Parthenon, Acropolis, Olympic Stadium), and experiencing modern Greek culture through traditional meals and dances. The program successfully merged academic interests, providing a deeper appreciation for ancient and modern civilizations and engineering marvels.

title: Ethnography and Ancient History
