summary: This presentation challenges the common historical portrayal of Black people as lacking civilization. By leveraging historical arts, scriptures, world leader utterances, and archaeological findings, it aims to demonstrate that Black civilizations, such as the Nubian Empire (Sudan) and Kemet (Egypt), were among the greatest, oldest, and most inventive, flourishing for centuries before European invasions. The work highlights achievements like advanced craftsmanship and vast wealth, questioning why these significant contributions were neglected or altered in historical narratives following invasions. Key themes include ancient Black civilizations, historical revisionism, and African empires.

title: Вивчення давньої історії України в період романтизму: історіографічні та джерелознавчі питання
abstract:
Розглядається доробок романтизму в царині давньої історії. Висвітлюється пріоритетна проблематика наукових студій істориків-романтиків. Аналізується їхній внесок у розробку української історії стародавньої доби.The author considers the contribution of Romanticism into ancient history,

reveals the priority problems of the historian-romantics’ scientific studies,

analyses their role in the development of Ukrainian history in ancient times
summary: This study examines the significant contributions of Romanticism to the field of ancient history, focusing on the priority research areas undertaken by Romantic historians. It analyzes their crucial role in shaping and developing the understanding of Ukrainian history during ancient times, highlighting specific problems and perspectives championed by this movement. Key themes include historical methodology, ancient Ukrainian history, and the intellectual legacy of Romantic-era historians.

title: The African origins of Greek philosophy: Ancient Egypt in retrospect
abstract: The demand of philosophizing in Africa has faced a history of criticism that has been particularly Eurocentric and strongly biased. However, that trend is changing with the emergence of core philosophical thinking in Africa.  This paper is an attempt to articulate a singular issue in this evolution— the originality of African philosophy, through ancient Egypt and its influence on Greek philosophy. The paper sets about this task by first exposing the historical debate on the early beginnings of the philosophical enterprise, with a view to establishing the possibility of philosophical influences in Africa.It then goes ahead to posit the three hypotheses that link Greek philosophy to have developed from the cultural materiality of Ancient Egypt, and the Eurocentric travesty of history in recognizing influences of philosophy as from Europe alone, apart from Egypt
summary: This paper addresses the historical criticism and Eurocentric bias against African philosophizing, arguing for the originality of African philosophy. It explores the influence of Ancient Egypt on Greek philosophy, asserting that Greek philosophical thought developed from Egyptian cultural materiality. The study exposes the historical debate on philosophy's origins, positing three hypotheses that link Greek philosophy to Ancient Egypt and challenging the Eurocentric narrative that solely attributes philosophical influences to Europe. Key concepts include African philosophy, Ancient Egypt, Greek philosophy, Eurocentrism, and colonialism.

title: Population history from the Neolithic to present on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia: an ancient DNA perspective
abstract: Recent ancient DNA studies of western Eurasia have revealed a dynamic history of admixture, with evidence for major migrations during the Neolithic and Bronze Age. The population of the Mediterranean island of Sardinia has been notable in these studies –} Neolithic individuals from mainland Europe cluster more closely with Sardinian individuals than with all other present-day Europeans. The current model to explain this result is that Sardinia received an initial influx of Neolithic ancestry and then remained relatively isolated from expansions in the later Neolithic and Bronze Age that took place in continental Europe. To test this model, we generated genome-wide capture data (approximately 1.2 million variants) for 43 ancient Sardinian individuals spanning the Neolithic through the Bronze Age, including individuals from Sardinia{’}s Nuragic culture, which is known for the construction of numerous large stone towers throughout the island. We analyze these new samples in the context of previously generated genome-wide ancient DNA data from 972 ancient individuals across western Eurasia and whole-genome sequence data from approximately 1,500 modern individuals from Sardinia. The ancient Sardinian individuals show a strong affinity to western Mediterranean Neolithic populations and we infer a high degree of genetic continuity on the island from the Neolithic (around fifth millennium BCE) through the Nuragic period (second millennium BCE). In particular, during the Bronze Age in Sardinia, we do not find significant levels of the {“}Steppe{” ancestry that was spreading in many other parts of Europe at that time. We also characterize subsequent genetic influx between the Nuragic period and the present. We detect novel, modest signals of admixture between 1,000 BCE and present-day, from ancestry sources in the eastern and northern Mediterranean. Within Sardinia, we confirm that populations from the more geographically isolated mountainous provinces have experienced elevated levels of genetic drift and that northern and southwestern regions of the island received more gene flow from outside Sardinia. Overall, our genetic analysis sheds new light on the origin of Neolithic settlement on Sardinia, reinforces models of genetic continuity on the island, and provides enhanced power to detect post-Bronze-Age gene flow. Together, these findings offer a refined demographic model for future medical genetic studies in Sardinia
fieldOfStudy: History, Genetics, Population History, Ancient DNA
summary: This study investigated the genetic history of Sardinia from the Neolithic to the present using genome-wide capture data from 43 ancient Sardinian individuals and comparative analyses with ancient and modern DNA data. The research aimed to test the model of early Neolithic influx and subsequent isolation for Sardinia's population. Key findings indicate strong genetic continuity on the island from the Neolithic through the Bronze Age, with no significant 'Steppe' ancestry influx during the Bronze Age, unlike many parts of continental Europe. The study also characterized modest post-Bronze Age admixture from Eastern and Northern Mediterranean sources, and identified elevated genetic drift in isolated mountainous regions within Sardinia. These results refine the demographic model for future medical genetic studies.

title: Rome’s urban history inferred from Pb-contaminated waters trapped in its ancient harbor basins
abstract: Heavy metals from urban runoff preserved in sedimentary deposits record long-term economic and industrial development via the expansion and contraction of a city’s infrastructure. Lead concentrations and isotopic compositions measured in the sediments of the harbor of Ostia—Rome’s first harbor—show that lead pipes used in the water supply networks of Rome and Ostia were the only source of radiogenic Pb, which, in geologically young central Italy, is the hallmark of urban pollution. High-resolution geochemical, isotopic, and 14C analyses of a sedimentary core from Ostia harbor have allowed us to date the commissioning of Rome’s lead pipe water distribution system to around the second century BC, considerably later than Rome’s first aqueduct built in the late fourth century BC. Even more significantly, the isotopic record of Pb pollution proves to be an unparalleled proxy for tracking the urban development of ancient Rome over more than a millennium, providing a semiquantitative record of the water system’s initial expansion, its later neglect, probably during the civil wars of the first century BC, and its peaking in extent during the relative stability of the early high Imperial period. This core record fills the gap in the system’s history before the appearance of more detailed literary and inscriptional evidence from the late first century BC onward. It also preserves evidence of the changes in the dynamics of the Tiber River that accompanied the construction of Rome’s artificial port, Portus, during the first and second centuries AD
summary: This study analyzes heavy metal concentrations and lead isotopic compositions in sedimentary deposits from Ostia harbor to reconstruct Rome's urban and industrial development. Utilizing high-resolution geochemical, isotopic, and 14C analyses of a core, the research dates the commissioning of Rome's lead pipe water distribution system to the second century BC, later than previously thought. Lead pollution serves as an unparalleled proxy for tracking ancient Rome's urban development over a millennium, detailing the water system's expansion, neglect during civil wars, and peak during the early Imperial period, filling historical gaps before literary evidence became available.

title: Coptic SCRIPTORIUM: Digitizing a Corpus for Interdisciplinary Research in Ancient Egyptian
abstract: Coptic, having evolved from the language of the hieroglyphs of the pharaonic era, represents the last phase of the Egyptian language and is pivotal for a wide range of disciplines, such as linguistics, biblical studies, the history of Christianity, Egyptology, and ancient history. The Coptic language has proven essential for the decipherment and continued study of Ancient Egyptian and is of major interest for Afro-Asiatic linguistics and Coptic linguistics in its own right. Coptic manuscripts are sources for biblical and extra-biblical texts and document ancient and Christian history. Coptic SCRIPTORIUM will advance knowledge in these fields by increasing access to now largely inaccessible texts of historical, religious, and linguistic significance. The project designs digital tools and methodologies and applies them to literary texts, creating a rich open-access corpus
fieldOfStudy: History, Linguistics, Biblical Studies, Egyptology, Ancient History
summary: Coptic SCRIPTORIUM is a project dedicated to advancing knowledge in linguistics, biblical studies, the history of Christianity, Egyptology, and ancient history by increasing access to historically, religiously, and linguistically significant Coptic texts. The project designs and applies digital tools and methodologies to literary texts, creating a rich, open-access corpus. This initiative supports the continued study of Ancient Egyptian, Afro-Asiatic linguistics, and Coptic linguistics, and provides crucial sources for biblical and extra-biblical texts, documenting ancient and Christian history through Coptic manuscripts. Key methods include data modeling, data curation, and developing a searchable database and computational tools for text annotation.

title: Weimar Jewish Chic: Jewish Women and Fashion in 1920s Germany
abstract: This volume presents papers delivered at the 24th Annual Klutznick-Harris Symposium, held at Creighton University in October 2011. The contributors look at all aspects of the intimate relationship between Jews and clothing, through case studies from ancient, medieval, recent, and contemporary history. Papers explore topics ranging from Jewish leadership in the textile industry, through the art of fashion in nineteenth century Vienna, to the use of clothing as a badge of ethnic identity, in both secular and religious contexts. Dr. Kerry Wallach\u27s chapter examines the uniquely Jewish engagement with fashion and attire in Weimar, Germany
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This volume, from the 24th Annual Klutznick-Harris Symposium, explores the multifaceted relationship between Jewish communities and clothing across ancient, medieval, and modern history. It presents case studies examining Jewish leadership in the textile industry, the evolution of fashion in 19th-century Vienna, and the role of attire in expressing ethnic identity, both secular and religious. A specific chapter by Dr. Kerry Wallach investigates Jewish engagement with fashion in Weimar, Germany, offering insights into cultural practices and the socio-economic aspects of dress within Jewish populations.

title:
Statistical physics and stromatolite growth: new perspectives on an
  ancient dilemma
abstract:
This paper outlines our recent attempts to model the growth and form of
microbialites from the perspective of the statistical physics of evolving
surfaces. Microbialites arise from the environmental interactions of microbial
communities (microbial mats). The mats evolve over time to form internally
laminated organosedimentary structures (stromatolites). Modern day
stromatolites exist in only a few locations, whereas ancient stromatolitic
microbialites were the only form of life for much of the Earth's history. They
existed in a wide variety of growth forms, ranging from almost perfect cones to
branched columnar structures. The coniform structures are central to the heated
debate on the oldest evidence of life. We proposed a biotic model which
considers the relationship between upward growth of a phototropic or
phototactic biofilm and mineral accretion normal to the surface. These
processes are sufficient to account for the growth and form of many ancient
stromatolities. These include domical stromatolites and coniform structures
with thickened apical zones typical of Conophyton. More angular coniform
structures, similar to the stromatolites claimed as the oldest macroscopic
evidence of life, form when the photic effects dominate over mineral accretion.Comment: 8 pages, 3 figures. To be published in Proceedings of StatPhys-Taiwan
  2004: Biologically Motivated Statistical Physics and Related Problems, 22-26
  June 200
summary: This paper investigates the growth and form of microbialites, specifically stromatolites, from the perspective of statistical physics and evolving surfaces. The authors propose a biotic model that links the upward growth of phototropic/phototactic biofilms with mineral accretion to explain various ancient stromatolite forms, including domical and coniform structures like Conophyton. The study suggests that the balance between photic effects and mineral accretion dictates the resulting morphology, with photic dominance leading to more angular coniform structures. This research contributes to understanding the oldest evidence of life and the physical mechanisms driving microbialite development.

title: Submission or Subversion: Women with Shaved Hair in Media
abstract: “It is quite obvious that the shaving of heads fundamentally damages the physical and moral integrity of those people for whom it was intended,” Fabrice Virgili asserts in his book Shorn Women: Gender and Punishment in Liberation France (135). For centuries, hair has been held as a standard of feminine beauty, therefore a lack of it has a long and storied history as well. Records of head shaving as a form of punishment for women can be traced back to Ancient Greek and Roman times. Shaving a woman’s head was a sign of sin and shame, and stripped them of their femininity and identity
summary: This paper examines the historical and cultural significance of head shaving as a form of punishment for women, tracing its origins from Ancient Greek and Roman times to its modern portrayal in media. Drawing on Fabrice Virgili's "Shorn Women," it highlights how hair has historically represented feminine beauty and identity, making its removal a profound act of dehumanization and shame. The study explores the damaging impact on women's physical and moral integrity, analyzing how this practice strips individuals of their femininity and identity, and its enduring presence as a symbol of sin and punishment across various cultural contexts.

title:
Joint assembly and genetic mapping of the Atlantic horseshoe crab genome
  reveals ancient whole genome duplication
abstract:
Horseshoe crabs are marine arthropods with a fossil record extending back
approximately 450 million years. They exhibit remarkable morphological
stability over their long evolutionary history, retaining a number of ancestral
arthropod traits, and are often cited as examples of "living fossils." As
arthropods, they belong to the Ecdysozoa}, an ancient super-phylum whose
sequenced genomes (including insects and nematodes) have thus far shown more
divergence from the ancestral pattern of eumetazoan genome organization than
cnidarians, deuterostomes, and lophotrochozoans. However, much of ecdysozoan
diversity remains unrepresented in comparative genomic analyses. Here we use a
new strategy of combined de novo assembly and genetic mapping to examine the
chromosome-scale genome organization of the Atlantic horseshoe crab Limulus
polyphemus. We constructed a genetic linkage map of this 2.7 Gbp genome by
sequencing the nuclear DNA of 34 wild-collected, full-sibling embryos and their
parents at a mean redundancy of 1.1x per sample. The map includes 84,307
sequence markers and 5,775 candidate conserved protein coding genes. Comparison
to other metazoan genomes shows that the L. polyphemus genome preserves
ancestral bilaterian linkage groups, and that a common ancestor of modern
horseshoe crabs underwent one or more ancient whole genome duplications (WGDs)
~ 300 MYA, followed by extensive chromosome fusion
summary: This study examines the chromosome-scale genome organization of the Atlantic horseshoe crab, Limulus polyphemus, a marine arthropod exhibiting remarkable morphological stability and often cited as a "living fossil." Using a novel strategy combining de novo assembly and genetic mapping, researchers constructed a genetic linkage map from 34 wild-collected full-sibling embryos and their parents. The findings reveal that the L. polyphemus genome preserves ancestral bilaterian linkage groups and experienced one or more ancient whole genome duplications approximately 300 million years ago, followed by extensive chromosome fusion. These results contribute to comparative genomic analyses, particularly within Ecdysozoa. Keywords: horseshoe crab, Limulus polyphemus, genome organization, whole genome duplication, genetic linkage mapping, Ecdysozoa.

title: TOPONIMYS WITH ANCIENT TURK ORIGINS IN THE BALKANS
abstract: One of the sources dealing with the ancient Turkic history are toponyms.Toponymic investigations show that most of the ancient geographical names whichhave spread in Eurosia, in Central Asia, from North Africa, to Eastern Turkistaneven in Siberia and these names were formed before Roman and Byzantine periods.So development of toponymic investigations, study of the history of Turkic peoplesand scientific investigation of existing geographical names which keep the historyof Turkic peoples have great significance
summary: This study investigates toponyms as a crucial source for understanding ancient Turkic history, particularly focusing on their origins and distribution across Eurasia, Central Asia, North Africa, and Eastern Turkistan, predating Roman and Byzantine periods. The research specifically examines the Balkans, identifying numerous geographical names derived from ancient Turkic ethnonyms, such as Astipos/Astepe/Ishtip, Izletdere, Vardar, and Tatarli kariyesi. These toponymic investigations illuminate the early settlement patterns of Turkic tribes and are significant for studying their ethnogenesis, mythology, religion, and socio-philosophical views, particularly in the context of the Ottoman Empire.

title: [Review of] Miriam Makeba and James Hall. Makeba: My Story
abstract: Like much of her music, Miriam Makeba\u27s autobiography is both personal and political. As it details the story of a young girl\u27s coming of age and search for identity, it simultaneously records the history of a country struggling for independence. In the prologue, Makeba compares herself to a South African bird soaring above the horror of apartheid (aparthood) which was instituted in 1947. As she recounts the details of war and injustice in direct, understated, idiom-filled prose, and as she intertwines details of ancient customs with the realities of modern technology, Makeba suggests that music best expresses the tragic subject of the inner exile of the South African people
summary: Miriam Makeba's autobiography, "Makeba: My Story," intertwines her personal journey of identity with South Africa's struggle for independence. Born in 1932, Makeba, an exiled political dissident, vividly portrays the impact of apartheid, instituted in 1947, through her direct, idiom-filled prose. She employs music to convey the "inner exile" of her people and offers an anthropological and historical overview of South African changes and customs, comparing herself to a bird soaring above apartheid's horrors. The book serves as a readable account of war, injustice, ancient traditions, and modern technology. Keywords: Miriam Makeba, autobiography, South Africa, apartheid, political dissident, identity, history, music.

title: Historical Poetics : Chronotopes in "Leucippe and Clitophon" and "Tom Jones"
abstract: This paper forms part of a larger, ongoing project, to investigate how certain narrative possibilities that seem to have crystallized for the first time in the ancient Greek novel have proved persistent and productive over time, undergoing subtle transformations during formative later periods in the history of the genre, notably the twelfth century (simultaneously in Old French and in Byzantine Greek) and the eighteenth (the time when, according to a narrower definition, the novel is said to originate). For the present, my more limited aim is to revisit the two main essays in which Bakhtin’s theory of the chronotope (and of the “historical poetics” of the novel) are developed, and to extrapolate what seem to me to the most significant and productive lines of his approach, both in general, and with specific reference to the ancient Greek novel. I will then attempt simultaneously to apply and to modify Bakhtin’s model, in the light of a reading of Achilles Tatius’ Leucippe and Clitophon and with reference to previous critiques. The final part of the paper examines how this approach can be productive for a reading of a much later text, often regarded as “foundational” for the modern development of the genre, especially in English, Fielding’s Tom Jones (1749)
summary:
This paper investigates the persistent and productive narrative possibilities originating in the ancient Greek novel, tracing their subtle transformations through later periods, specifically the twelfth and eighteenth centuries. The author revisits Bakhtin's theory of the chronotope and "historical poetics" to extrapolate key lines of his approach, applying and modifying the model with reference to Achilles Tatius’ 

Leucippe and Clitophon and previous critiques. The study concludes by examining the approach's productivity for understanding Fielding’s Tom Jones (1749), a foundational text for the modern novel. Keywords: ancient Greek novel, narrative theory, Bakhtin, chronotope, Achilles Tatius, Fielding, Tom Jones.

title: Subject review report: University of Nottingham; classics and ancient history
publisher: Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
summary: This report details a subject review of Classics and Ancient History at the University of Nottingham in October 2000, conducted by the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA). The review's purpose was to assess educational quality, provide public information, and encourage improvements. The method involved evaluating the department against its stated aims and objectives, highlighting successful recruitment, good progression and completion rates, and an exemplary record in fostering student development. Excellent library resources, a collaborative ethos, and robust quality management systems were also noted, demonstrating effective self-evaluation leading to continuous improvements in educational quality.

title: A complete ancient RNA genome : identification, reconstruction and evolutionary history of archaeological Barley Stripe Mosaic Virus
abstract: The origins of many plant diseases appear to be recent and associated with the rise of domestication, the spread of agriculture or recent global movements of crops. Distinguishing between these possibilities is problematic because of the difficulty of determining rates of molecular evolution over short time frames. Heterochronous approaches using recent and historical samples show that plant viruses exhibit highly variable and often rapid rates of molecular evolution. The accuracy of estimated evolution rates and age of origin can be greatly improved with the inclusion of older molecular data from archaeological material. Here we present the first reconstruction of an archaeological RNA genome, which is of Barley Stripe Mosaic Virus (BSMV) isolated from barley grain ~750 years of age. Phylogenetic analysis of BSMV that includes this genome indicates the divergence of BSMV and its closest relative prior to this time, most likely around 2000 years ago. However, exclusion of the archaeological data results in an apparently much more recent origin of the virus that postdates even the archaeological sample. We conclude that this viral lineage originated in the Near East or North Africa, and spread to North America and East Asia with their hosts along historical trade routes
fieldOfStudy: History, Archaeology, Molecular Evolution, Plant Pathology
summary: This study addresses the problematic determination of plant disease origins by employing heterochronous approaches and ancient molecular data. Researchers successfully reconstructed the first archaeological RNA genome of Barley Stripe Mosaic Virus (BSMV) from ~750-year-old barley grain. Phylogenetic analysis, including this ancient genome, indicates BSMV diverged from its closest relative approximately 2000 years ago, suggesting an older origin than analyses excluding archaeological data. This viral lineage likely originated in the Near East or North Africa and spread globally with host plants along historical trade routes, impacting plant pathology and molecular evolution studies.

title: HOW EUROPEAN HISTORIANS IN THE NINETEENTH AND EARLY TWENTIETH CENTURIES TOLD THE HISTORY OF HUMAN MASS MIGRATIONS OR VÖLKERWANDERUNGEN
abstract: Historians’ interest in the history of human migrations is not limited to recent years. Migrations had already figured as explanatory factors in connection with cultural and historical change in the work of classical and ancient studies scholars of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. In the writings of these scholars, migrations acted as historical landmarks or epochal thresholds and played a key role in the construction of geo‐historical areas. This model has been called “migrationism” and cannot be explained simply on the basis of the history of individual disciplines, but must be seen in its complex interaction with scientific and historical contexts. However, “migrationism” does not relate to fixed political and scientific positions or movements. For this reason, it cannot be explained adequately by using a historically or ideologically based approach. Relying on narratological approaches, this article examines migration narratives that historians of this period used to explain the rise and fall of ancient civilizations. Referring to contemporary historiographical representations of the ancient Near East, it distinguishes three main narratives that are still common today: narratives of foundation, narratives of destruction, and narratives of mixtures. In this sense, analyzing older migration narratives helps us to sharpen the critical view on the genealogy of our own views on the history—and present—of human migrations
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient History, Historiography, Migration Studies
summary: This article examines the historical concept of "migrationism" as an explanatory factor in cultural and historical change, particularly in the works of late nineteenth and early twentieth-century classical and ancient studies scholars. It argues that migration narratives were central to constructing geo-historical areas and explaining the rise and fall of ancient civilizations. Employing narratological approaches, the study distinguishes three main narratives—foundation, destruction, and mixtures—still prevalent today. Analyzing these older migration narratives provides a critical perspective on the genealogy of contemporary views on human migration, highlighting their enduring influence on historiography.

title: Searchin’ His Eyes, Lookin’ for Traces: Piri Reis’ World Map of 1513 & its Islamic Iconographic Connections (A Reading Through Bagdat 334 and Proust)
abstract: The remnant of the 1513 world map of the Ottoman corsair (and later admiral) Muhiddin Piri, a.k.a. Piri Reis, with its focus on the Atlantic and the New World can be ranked as one of the most famous and controversial maps in the annals of the history of cartography. Following its discovery at Topkapi Palace in 1929, this early modern Ottoman map has raised baffling questions regarding its fons et origo. Some scholars posited ancient sea kings or aliens from outer space as the original creators; while the influence of Columbus’ own map and early Renaissance cartographers tantalized others. One question that remains unanswered is how Islamic cartography influenced Piri Reis’ work. This paper presents hitherto unnoticed iconographical connections between the classical Islamic mapping tradition and the Piri Reis map
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Islamic World and Near East History
summary: This paper investigates the 1513 world map by Ottoman corsair Piri Reis, a historically famous and controversial cartographic work focusing on the Atlantic and New World. Discovered in 1929, its origins have been debated, with theories ranging from ancient sea kings to the influence of Columbus and Renaissance cartographers. The study specifically addresses the overlooked question of Islamic cartography's influence on Piri Reis's work. It aims to reveal previously unnoticed iconographical connections between the classical Islamic mapping tradition and the Piri Reis map, contributing to a deeper understanding of its complex genesis. Keywords: Piri Reis, World Map of 1513, Ottoman Cartography, Islamic Cartography, Islamic Wondrous Tradition, Islamic Manuscript Illumination.

title: Unexpected understorey community development after 30 years in ancient and post-agricultural forests
abstract:
1. Land-use change is considered one of the most radical and extensive disturbances that have influenced plant distributions and diversity patterns in forest understorey communities in much of Europe and eastern North America. In forests growing on former agricultural land, local species diversity and community differentiation among sites are generally reduced compared to ancient forests (i.e. forests with no historical record of agriculture). Yet, no study has determined how the compositional differences created by former land use change over time as the forest sites recover from former agricultural use.
2. Here we resurveyed 78 vegetation plots (half of the plots in ancient and half in post-agricultural forest) to demonstrate how three decades of forest development have changed the compositional differences between post-agricultural and ancient forest sites. The impact of land-use history and survey date was tested on two measures of species diversity and two measure of community divergence.
3. The data indicate that the imprint of former agricultural land use persisted over time, yet not through compositional stability. Parallel and strong vegetation shifts occurred in both ancient and post-agricultural forest: the species diversity decreased and local species cover strongly diverged, which indicates community drift. The observed understorey changes did thus not support the commonly accepted model of community development in post-agricultural forests, i.e. the diversity did not increase and the vegetation did not become more similar to the ancient forest vegetation over time. The changes in species composition were associated with an increase of common, competitive species at the expense of ancient forest indicator species. The source populations of ancient forest species have been gradually depleted, so the recovery of post-agricultural forests becomes even more precarious.
4. Synthesis. While land-use history is likely to persist as the primary predictor of local species diversity and community divergence, other environmental drivers may additionally structure forest understorey communities and lead to biotic impoverishment and pervasive species reordering on the time scale of only decades
fieldOfStudy: History, Forest Ecology, Plant Diversity, Land Use Change
summary: This study investigated how land-use change, specifically former agricultural use, impacts forest understorey plant distributions and diversity over time. Researchers resurveyed 78 vegetation plots in both ancient and post-agricultural forests over three decades, analyzing species diversity and community divergence. The findings reveal that the imprint of past agriculture persisted, contrary to expectations of recovery and increased diversity. Instead, both forest types experienced parallel vegetation shifts, with decreased species diversity and increased community drift, favoring common, competitive species over ancient forest indicators. This suggests that the recovery of post-agricultural forests is becoming more challenging due to the depletion of ancient forest species.

title:
Ancient mythological images and their interpretation:

an introduction to iconology, semiotics and image studies in classical art history
abstract:
When we try to make sense of pictures, what do we gain when we use a particular method - and what might we be missing or even losing? Empirical experimentation on three types of mythological imagery - a Classical Greek pot, a frieze from Hellenistic Pergamon and a second-century CE Roman sarcophagus - enables Katharina Lorenz to demonstrate how theoretical approaches to images (specifically, iconology, semiotics, and image studies) impact the meanings we elicit from Greek and Roman art. A guide to Classical images of myth, and also a critical history of Classical archaeology's attempts to give meaning to pictures, this book establishes a dialogue with the wider field of art history and proposes a new framework for the study of ancient visual culture. It will be essential reading not just for students of classical art history and archaeology, but for anyone interested in the possibilities - and the history - of studying visual culture.



This book:

- Proposes a new framework for the study of (ancient) visual culture based on engagement with Greek and Roman mythological imagery, appealing to those seeking to better their understanding of Greek and Roman cultural history.



- Relates historiography and method development in Classical archaeology and ancient art history to the art history of more modern periods, and will therefore be of interest to readers interested in the Classical world and those concerned with more recent historical periods.



- Tracks intellectual developments in different contexts and carves out their similarities and differences, speaking to readers from different intellectual backgrounds and familiarising them with broader developments in western European art history
summary: This book, by Katharina Lorenz, critically examines how theoretical approaches such as iconology, semiotics, and image studies influence the interpretation of Greek and Roman mythological imagery. Through empirical experimentation on Classical Greek pots, Hellenistic friezes, and Roman sarcophagi, it demonstrates the impact of different methods on meaning elicitation. The work proposes a new framework for studying ancient visual culture, serving as both a guide to Classical myth images and a critical history of Classical archaeology's interpretive attempts. It aims to foster dialogue within art history and is essential for students of classical art history, archaeology, and visual culture.

title: Review of periodical articles
abstract: One of the attractions of medieval urban history is the fact that major conceptual problems in the field continue to be debated. In a stimulating review article by J.H. Mundy, ’Philip Jones and the medieval Italian city-state‘, J. of European Economic History, 28 (1999), 185–200, one distinguished scholar is taxed for holding views now dismissed by some, but of which he is by no means a unique surviving representative. One of these views assumes a clear distinction between the antique city, supposedly a bureaucratic centre with limited economic functions, and the medieval city, as the home of industrious artisans and nascent capitalism. The image of the non-profit-making ancient town may be overly indebted to the nature of the literary sources and to the prevalent interests of classicists; but, although many would now agree that both the elements in the above equation need qualifying, a more focused comparison is presently lacking, and a fine book is still waiting to be written on the transition from the ancient world to the middle ages in urban history
summary: This review article examines the ongoing debates within medieval urban history, specifically focusing on the distinction between antique and medieval cities as presented in J.H. Mundy's review of Philip Jones' work. It critiques the assumption of the ancient city as purely bureaucratic versus the medieval city as a hub of economic activity and nascent capitalism, suggesting this view may be influenced by literary sources. The authors argue for a more focused comparison and call for a new book addressing the transition in urban history from the ancient to the middle ages, highlighting conceptual problems and historical interpretation.

title: Ancient Wisdom? What we think we know about supporting families during Positive Behaviour Support
abstract: What do practitioners of positive behaviour support know about supporting families effectively? This paper reviews the experiences we might relegate as ancient history, arguing ancient insights are often wisdo
summary: This paper, a personal perspective by Tony Osgood, explores the effectiveness of positive behaviour support (PBS) in assisting families, drawing parallels with "ancient wisdom." It critiques the limitations of centralized, nomothetic paradigms in addressing individual needs within large systems, emphasizing the challenges faced by practitioners in delivering personalized support due to rigid pathways and a focus on easily collectible metrics over quality of outcomes. The author advocates for more idiographic solutions to individual issues in learning and service delivery within the context of intellectual and developmental disabilities.

title: Ancient history: GCSE subject content: February 2016
summary: This document outlines the GCSE subject content for Ancient History, aiming to enable students to study ancient societies within their broader historical context. It emphasizes developing critical thinking skills, evaluating literary and material evidence, and understanding the legacy of the ancient world. Key objectives include extending knowledge of military, political, religious, social, and cultural aspects, analyzing sources for reliability and context, and constructing evidence-based arguments. The content covers historical knowledge, understanding, and methodological approaches crucial for studying ancient events and cultures.

title: KOI-3158: The oldest known system of terrestrial-size planets
abstract:
The first discoveries of exoplanets around Sun-like stars have fueled efforts
to find ever smaller worlds evocative of Earth and other terrestrial planets in
the Solar System. While gas-giant planets appear to form preferentially around
metal-rich stars, small planets (with radii less than four Earth radii) can
form under a wide range of metallicities. This implies that small, including
Earth-size, planets may have readily formed at earlier epochs in the Universe's
history when metals were far less abundant. We report Kepler spacecraft
observations of KOI-3158, a metal-poor Sun-like star from the old population of
the Galactic thick disk, which hosts five planets with sizes between Mercury
and Venus. We used asteroseismology to directly measure a precise age of
11.2+/-1.0 Gyr for the host star, indicating that KOI-3158 formed when the
Universe was less than 20% of its current age and making it the oldest known
system of terrestrial-size planets. We thus show that Earth-size planets have
formed throughout most of the Universe's 13.8-billion-year history, providing
scope for the existence of ancient life in the Galaxy.Comment: Submitted to EPJ Web of Conferences, to appear in the Proceedings of
  the 3rd CoRoT Symposium, Kepler KASC7 joint meeting; 4 pages, 1 figur
summary: This research reports on Kepler spacecraft observations of KOI-3158, a metal-poor Sun-like star in the Galactic thick disk, hosting five planets sized between Mercury and Venus. Using asteroseismology, the study precisely measured the host star's age at 11.2 +/-1.0 Gyr, making it the oldest known system of terrestrial-size planets. This finding indicates that Earth-size planets formed early and consistently throughout the Universe's 13.8-billion-year history, suggesting the potential for ancient life in the Galaxy. The paper highlights the significance of the Kepler mission's photometry in this discovery.

title: Discovering commercial hospitality in ancient Rome
abstract: Commercial hospitality in Ancient Rome, argues Kevin O'Gorman, was complex and sophisticated. He is concerned that over-reliance on the surviving texts can lead to confusion: it is important to examine physical historical sites, like Pompeii, to get a sense of how these establishments worked, and to investigate them within a context of what we know about hospitality throughout history
summary: This paper investigates commercial hospitality in Ancient Rome, asserting its complex and sophisticated nature. The author, Kevin O'Gorman, argues against an over-reliance on surviving texts, emphasizing the importance of examining physical historical sites like Pompeii. This approach helps contextualize ancient Roman hospitality within broader historical understandings. Key methods include archaeological site analysis and interdisciplinary historical comparison to better understand these establishments and their societal function. This research contributes to the fields of ancient history, hospitality studies, and archaeology, providing insights into Roman society and its economic structures.

title: Historiografi Antik dan Historiografi Kristen
abstract: Human being is a historical being. In the history the details of life and their struggle is expressed. For the people who believe in God, faith is a fundamental part in their life. The faith is experienced in the history and therefore the faithful see the history as an implementation of divine providence. Accordingly, explaining the history is an important task. The writers of the ancient history use the literary genres such as historiography, chronography and biography. In ancient christianity, the historical writers give a new meaning to the existing literatures. Their authority is not based on the divine inspiration but on the truth about salvific eschatological event. Eusebius is one of the pioneers of the ecclesiastical historiography. In the history of the Church it is the Divine Providence who guides and decides the course of all events to their ultimate purpose namely to prepare the Kingdom of God. Thus the history of the Church is a divine-spiritual history. Nowadays, the influence of Greek and Roman philosophers and famous writers is well observed especially in political theology. This new history is presented with the documentation which was unusual for the history of politics, but which was common in polemical works and biography
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient History, Christian History, Theology
summary: This article explores the concept of humanity as a historical being, focusing on the role of faith and divine providence in shaping historical understanding, particularly within ancient Christianity. It examines how ancient historical writers utilized literary genres like historiography, chronography, and biography, and how early Christian authors, such as Eusebius, redefined these forms. The study emphasizes that ecclesiastical historiography, guided by Divine Providence, aims to prepare for the Kingdom of God, making it a divine-spiritual history. It also notes the influence of Greek and Roman philosophers on political theology and the use of unique documentation in this new historical presentation. Keywords include historiography, ancient Christianity, Eusebius, and divine providence.

title: Sobre lo griego y lo bárbaro
abstract: The self-definition of ancient empires is based on the strong conviction of being God’s chosen one. In this way, Greeks, Persians, Assyrians, Sumerians, Indians, Hebrews and Egyptians built their religions, rituals, thought and wisdom. Greece was not the creator of the xenophobic idea consisted in refusing systematicly stranger modes of life; in oriental vocabularies we could find a lot of words to refer non-local traditions. Various questions rise about the relationship between Greece and other ancient people. Are the difference only on religious stuff? What was the global meaning of ritual characters in each ancient mediterranean-oriental land? How each ancient culture/ empire/people/land abstract identity was built? What happens with ancient History of European Culture? Exists any relationship between the “Culture” (greeks) and “other” European barbarians
summary: This abstract examines the self-definition of ancient empires, founded on the conviction of being a "chosen people." It highlights how Greeks, Persians, Assyrians, Sumerians, Indians, Hebrews, and Egyptians developed their religions, rituals, and thought based on this belief. The study challenges the notion that Greece originated xenophobia, noting that other ancient oriental languages also contained terms for "non-local" traditions. The article raises questions about the differences beyond religion between Greece and other ancient Mediterranean-Oriental cultures, the global meaning of rituals, and how each ancient society constructed its abstract identity, particularly regarding the relationship between Greeks and other European "barbarians."

title: Boechari, Melacak Sejarah Kuno Indonesia Lewat Prasasti/Tracing Ancient Indonesian History Through Inscriptions; Kumpulan Tulisan/Writings Of Boechari.
summary: This book review celebrates a collection of essays by the late Professor M. Boechari, a prominent Indonesian epigraphist and ancient historian. The compilation, "Tracing ancient Indonesian history through inscriptions," offers a valuable addition to studies on the ancient history of Island Southeast Asia. Boechari's distinguished career involved teaching and research at various Indonesian universities and archaeological services, contributing to major projects like the restoration of Borobudur and Majapahit. The review highlights Boechari's extensive work, making his insights accessible for researchers interested in Indonesian archaeology and epigraphy.

title: Review: Amidst ancient monuments: The administrative history of Mound City Group National Monument/Hopewell Culture National Historical Park, Ohio Ron Cockrell
abstract: Book review of: Amidst ancient monuments: The administrative history of Mound City Group National Monument/Hopewell Culture National Historical Park, Ohio by Ron Cockrel
summary: This book review examines Ron Cockrel's "Amidst Ancient Monuments," an administrative history of Mound City Group National Monument/Hopewell Culture National Historical Park. The review discusses Stephen Mather's and Horace Albright's foundational roles in the National Park Service, particularly Albright's leadership during Mather's absences and his authorship of the "Lane letter." It acknowledges some factual errors in Cockrel's manuscript, stemming from the passage of time. The review highlights the complex interplay of personalities, external events, and local institutions that shaped the park's history, noting the near "disestablishment" of Mound City Group in the 1940s. It emphasizes the broader significance of local struggles in cultural resource preservation, despite some minor criticisms regarding photos.

title: The antiquities collection, Department of Classics and Ancient History, University of Queensland
authors: University of Queensland. Department of Classics and Ancient History
summary: This volume presents the Antiquities Collection of the Department of Classics and Ancient History, University of Queensland, established in 1963. It catalogues various ancient artifacts, including pottery, figurines, lamps, glassware, metalwork, bricks, tiles, architectural decorations, stone sculpture, mosaics, and cylinder seals. The collection serves as an important resource for teaching and research in classical studies and ancient history, documenting the acquisition and types of items held, providing context for the study of ancient Greece, Italy, and the Near East.

title: Adapting to New Contexts. Cuneiform in Anatolia
abstract: This article focuses on cuneiform and scribal education in Anatolia. It attempts to trace some of the developments in the corpus of knowledge and training when it let the confines of its initial area of relevance and was received in Anatolia by the Hittites and to draw inferences about the semiotic and sociological context of the wholesale import of a large-scale technocratic apparatus from one culture into another. It discusses the institutional and social context of scribal education in Old Babylonian Mesopotamia and suggests that class composition among the Anatolian elite was not necessarily the same as that in Mesopotamia
summary: This article explores the transmission of cuneiform and scribal education from Mesopotamia to Anatolia, focusing on its reception by the Hittites. It examines how this large-scale technocratic apparatus was imported from one culture to another, analyzing the semiotic and sociological implications. The study discusses the institutional and social context of scribal training in Old Babylonian Mesopotamia and posits that the class composition of the Anatolian elite might have differed from that in Mesopotamia. Key terms include cuneiform, scribal education, Anatolia, Hittites, Mesopotamia, and cultural transmission.

title: Linking Letters: Translating Ancient History into Medieval Romance
abstract:
In his prologue to the late fourteenth-century romance, the Destruction of Troy, John
Clerk of Whalley negotiates between his roles as translator, historian and alliterative
poet to introduce his account of the fall of Troy for medieval English readers.
Professing to tell the true story of Britain’s ancient ancestors, he invokes the fiction
of translatio imperii, in which the power of empire passes from Troy to Rome to
Britain. According to Clerk, his translation of Guido delle Colonne’s Historia
destructionis Troiae provides vernacular readers access to historical truth that had not
previously been available to them. Clerk’s assumption of Guido’s history separates
his romance from the historiographic tradition of the vastly influential Geoffrey of
Monmouth, whose Historia regum Britannie celebrates Britain’s Trojan ancestry and
promises future glory to the Britons. Rather than venerate Troy as a font of imperial
power, Guido condemns the martial policy of the Trojans that causes their defeat,
characterizing Troy as a tainted origin of Western civilization. By comparing Clerk’s
text with another translation of Guido’s Historia, John Lydgate’s Troy Book, I argue
that Clerk’s translational method, which he calls a ‘linking of letters’, reflects a
commitment to connecting a destructive past with an English present
summary: This essay analyzes John Clerk of Whalley's prologue to his late fourteenth-century romance, "The Destruction of Troy." Clerk, acting as translator, historian, and poet, introduces the fall of Troy to medieval English readers. He employs the "translatio imperii" fiction, claiming imperial power passed from Troy to Rome to Britain. The study compares Clerk's translation of Guido delle Colonne's "Historia destructionis Troiae" with John Lydgate's "Troy Book." The author argues that Clerk's translational method, termed a 'linking of letters,' aimed to connect a destructive ancient past with the English present, differentiating his work from Geoffrey of Monmouth's celebratory historiography.

title: Ancient History for Beginners
summary: This text explores the historical debate surrounding potential Buddhist influences on Catholic Church customs, particularly noting similarities explained by some as "diabolical imitation." It references Hildreth's observations and Mr. Haas's continuation, which cites Professor Rudolf Seydel's work on the subject, while also acknowledging the challenge of finding evidence of Buddhism in early Christian literature before Clement of Alexandria. The latter part of the text shifts to an analysis of two philosophical poems by Goethe, "One and All" and "Bequest," highlighting their contrasting views on existence and eternity, and how Goethe's initial "Nirvana" mood in "One and All" was often misunderstood.

title: The Storm-Gods of the Ancient Near East: Summary, Synthesis, Recent Studies. Part II
abstract: In many regions of the ancient Near East, not least in Upper Mesopotamia, Syria and Anatolia where agriculture relied mainly on rainfall, storm-gods ranked among the most prominent gods in the local panthea or were even regarded as divine kings, ruling over the gods and bestowing kingship on the human ruler. While the Babylonian and Assyrian storm-god never held the highest position among the gods, he too belongs to the group of 'great gods' through most periods of Mesopotamian history. Given the many cultural contacts and the longevity of traditions in the ancient Near East only a study that takes into account all relevant periods, regions and text-groups can further our understanding of the different ancient Near Eastern storm-gods. The study Wettergottgestalten Mesopotamiens und Nordsyriens by the present author (2001) tried to tackle the problems involved, basing itself primarily on the textual record and excluding the genuinely Anatolian storm-gods from the study. Given the lack of handbooks, concordances and thesauri in our field, the book is necessarily heavily burdened with materials collected for the first time. Despite comprehensive indices, the long lists and footnotes as well as the lack of an overall synthesis make the study not easily accessible, especially outside the German-speaking community. In 2003 Alberto Green published a comprehensive monograph entitled The Storm-God in the Ancient Near East whose aims are more ambitious than those of Wettergottgestalten: All regions of the ancient Near East—including a chapter on Yahwe as a storm-god—are taken into account, and both textual and iconographic sources are given equal space. Unfortunately this book, which was apparently finished and submitted to the publisher before Wettergottgestalten came to its author's attention, suffers from some serious flaws with regard to methodology, philology and the interpretation of texts and images. In presenting the following succinct overview I take the opportunity to make up for the missing synthesis in Wettergottgestalten and to provide some additions and corrections where necessary. It is hoped that this synthesis can also serve as a response to the history of ancient Near Eastern storm-gods as outlined by A. Green
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient Near Eastern Studies, Religious Studies
summary: This study provides a summary and synthesis of storm-gods in the ancient Near East, drawing upon the author's previous work "Wettergottgestalten Mesopotamiens und Nordsyriens" (2001) and critiquing Alberto Green's "The Storm-God in the Ancient Near East" (2003). The purpose is to address the lack of synthesis in earlier studies and offer corrections, additions, and a response to Green's outline of storm-god history. Key topics include the prominence of storm-gods in Upper Mesopotamia, Syria, and Anatolia, their position in local panthea, and textual and iconographic sources. This aims to enhance understanding of ancient Near Eastern storm-gods and related traditions.

title: 2. Meaning as a Problem in Contemporary Religious Thought
abstract: To judge from the public voice and countenance of religion in America at least, there is a preoccupation in religion with happiness at the expense of meaning. But between the two poles of happiness and meaning there is considerable distance. This chapter accepts the problem of meaning as more urgent than the problem of happiness. For over against the hopeful prescriptions for the integration of the personality and of social life through religion there stands the experience of disintegration of the structure of past confidence. Desperately, theologians wrestle with ancient symbols to wrest from them new significance or reference, or attempt to revivify their lost meaning and powers of evocation. In these critical times theological thought attempts to referee the contest between the lost soul and the powerful chaos of world history. In an intellectual landscape scarred by war, diplomatic failure, economic uncertainty, and a wide variety of psychic traumata, theologians probe the private egos, society, and even language itself to reestablish meaning. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Religious Thought, Theology, Philosophy of Religion
summary: This chapter argues that religion in America prioritizes happiness over meaning, and it considers meaning a more urgent problem, especially amidst societal and personal disintegration. The authors explore how theologians grapple with ancient symbols, attempting to revive their significance in a world scarred by war and uncertainty. They examine existentialist approaches to meaning from thinkers like Karl Barth and Martin Buber, who emphasize given truth or relational discovery. The chapter also discusses analytical philosophy's engagement with religious language (e.g., Ian Ramsey) and Paul Tillich's comprehensive view of man's religious status, culminating with Charles Hartshorne's unifying framework for human experience.

title: Acceptance through Restriction: Male Homosexuality in Ancient Athens
summary: This journal article explores the complex topic of male homosexuality in ancient Athens, challenging modern understandings of sexuality by analyzing historical perspectives on acceptance through restriction. It also touches upon the Gold Rush era in California history, specifically examining the overlooked issue of Indian prostitution and the varied circumstances surrounding it, distinguishing it from rape and forced concubinage. The text highlights how these historical contexts offer crucial insights into societal norms and individual experiences related to sexuality and exploitation across different cultures and time periods.

title: The ancient, the medieval and the modern in a Greek-English Lexicon or : how to get your daily ‘bread’ in Greek through the ages
abstract: This chapter discusses theoretical and methodological aspects of Greek lexicography with particular reference to LSJ. Special attention is given to the question whether the online LSJ should incorporate information about Medieval and Modern Greek to elucidate the meaning and further development of Ancient Greek words. By way of illustration, the chapter studies in great detail the evolution of various words for ‘bread’ in the history of the Greek language from Ancient to Moder
summary: This chapter explores theoretical and methodological aspects of Greek lexicography, specifically concerning the Liddell and Scott Lexicon (LSJ). It addresses whether the online LSJ should integrate information from Medieval and Modern Greek to clarify Ancient Greek word meanings and their subsequent evolution. The study illustrates this by examining the historical development of various Greek words for "bread" across different linguistic periods. Key methods involve analyzing lexical changes and considering cultural influences on word usage, aiming to enhance the comprehensive understanding of Greek vocabulary through the ages, especially for semantic search applications.

title: About ancient history of gold: gold in Galicia
abstract:

summary: This study examines the historical significance and decline of gold mining in Galicia, Spain, from ancient times to the modern era. Early Mediterranean cultures highly valued gold, with Galicia supplying demand until the fall of Rome. The loss of organized administration under the Suevi led to a centuries-long decline, further impacted by invasions and American gold imports. Although late 19th and early 20th-century recovery attempts failed, current research by companies like ITGE and ADARO indicates renewed interest. The paper also characterizes primary gold deposits in Galicia, providing data for each. Keywords: gold mining, Galicia, ancient history, Roman Empire, mineral resources, geological surveys, economic history.

title: Following the rivers: historical reconstruction of California voles Microtus californicus (Rodentia: Cricetidae) in the deserts of eastern California
abstract: The California vole, Microtus californicus, restricted to habitat patches where water is available nearly year-round, is a remnant of the mesic history of the southern Great Basin and Mojave deserts of eastern California. The history of voles in this region is a model for species-edge population dynamics through periods of climatic change. We sampled voles from the eastern deserts of California and examined variation in the mitochondrial cytb gene, three nuclear intron regions, and across 12 nuclear microsatellite markers. Samples are allocated to two mitochondrial clades: one associated with southern California and the other with central and northern California. The limited mtDNA structure largely recovers the geographical distribution, replicated by both nuclear introns and microsatellites. The most remote population, Microtus californicus scirpensis at Tecopa near Death Valley, was the most distinct. This population shares microsatellite alleles with both mtDNA clades, and both its northern clade nuclear introns and southern clade mtDNA sequences support a hybrid origin for this endangered population. The overall patterns support two major invasions into the desert through an ancient system of riparian corridors along streams and lake margins during the latter part of the Pleistocene followed by local in situ divergence subsequent to late Pleistocene and Holocene drying events. Changes in current water resource use could easily remove California voles from parts of the desert landscape
fieldOfStudy: History, Evolutionary Biology, Zoology, Ecology, Genetics
summary: This study reconstructs the historical population dynamics of the California vole (Microtus californicus) in the southern Great Basin and Mojave deserts, examining its adaptation to climatic changes. Researchers analyzed mitochondrial cytb gene, nuclear intron regions, and microsatellite markers from voles in eastern California. Findings revealed two mitochondrial clades and supported a hybrid origin for the distinct, endangered Tecopa population. The overall patterns suggest two major Pleistocene invasions into the desert via riparian corridors, followed by local divergence during later drying events. The research highlights the vulnerability of these voles to current water resource changes.

title: Wales, the Enlightenment and the New British History
abstract: There is no electronic version of this article.PostprintPeer reviewe
summary: This article evaluates the impact and limitations of "new British history," particularly its influence on understanding the Enlightenment period in Wales. It discusses how scholars like Lewis Namier, Herbert Butterfield, and John Pocock challenged traditional Anglocentric historical narratives, advocating for an Atlantic archipelago perspective. While acknowledging the new British history's success in dismantling Anglocentric biases and promoting a more complex, multi-cultural approach, the paper argues it shouldn't fully replace national historical understandings. It highlights how the British Enlightenment, once reductively studied as "Augustan England," now incorporates diverse, often blurring, elements of rational and irrational, progressive and antiquarian thought, especially within the Anglo-Welsh experience.

title: The Work of Tragic Productions: Towards a New History of Drama as Labor Culture
abstract: Preliminary analysis of the representation of laborers in Greek tragedy and satyr drama
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient Greek Drama, Labor Culture
summary: This study analyzes the representation of laborers in Greek tragedy and satyr drama, arguing that modern critical inquiry, focused on figures like Oedipus and Antigone, has created a structured silence around class relations. It critiques the adoption of these figures as paradigms, which often reduces tragedy to a tool for representing the ancient Greek polis and addressing modern political problems. The paper aims to develop a new history of drama as labor culture, shedding light on the overlooked social and economic aspects of ancient Greek theatrical productions and the working class within them, providing a fresh perspective on tragic texts.

title: Night at the museum: Contribution of small RNA from historical herbarium specimens in the reconstruction of evolutionary histories of geminiviruses
abstract: Emerging infectious diseases of plants, almost half of which are caused by viruses, are recognized as a growing threat to global food security. However, little is known about the evolutionary processes and ecological factors that underlie the emergence and success of viruses that have caused past epidemics. With technological advances in the field of ancient DNA and RNA, it is now possible to sequence historical viral genomes, which provides us direct access to the dimension of time in evolutionary studies. Herbarium collections are an enormous source of dated, identified and well-preserved material that can be used to elucidate the emergence and evolutionary history of viral plant pathogens. Geminiviruses are responsible for many of the emerging plant diseases worldwide with a major economic impact on food crops such as cassava, which are a vital source of dietary calories in many sub-Saharan African countries. Their high potential for evolution, with high rates of mutation and recombination, makes such viruses an ideal model for understanding the epidemiological and evolutionary processes associated with viral emergence. Our proof of concept study investigated whether small interfering RNA (siRNA) can be used to reconstruct a complete geminivirus DNA genome from a herbarium sample despite the existence of post-mortem nucleic acid damage. Using a metagenomics approach based on the high-throughput sequencing of siRNA, we obtained a siRNA database from cassava leaf samples presenting typical symptoms of cassava mosaic disease that were collected in 1928 from Madagascar and 1968 from Cameroon, and then stored in the National Museum of Natural History herbarium in Paris. Our preliminary results demonstrate our ability to reconstruct the almost complete sequence of bipartite begomoviruses in particular from a 90-year-old herbarium specimen. These sequences are now used in phylogenetic, comparative genomic and phylogeographic studies to elucidate the emergence and evolutionary history of this important crop pathogen
summary: This study explored using small interfering RNA (siRNA) from herbarium samples to reconstruct historical viral genomes, addressing the growing threat of emerging plant infectious diseases to global food security. Focusing on geminiviruses, significant crop pathogens, researchers used a metagenomics approach with high-throughput siRNA sequencing from cassava leaf samples collected in 1928 and 1968. They successfully reconstructed nearly complete bipartite begomovirus sequences from a 90-year-old specimen, demonstrating the potential of ancient RNA technology to elucidate the emergence and evolutionary history of plant pathogens through phylogenetic, comparative genomic, and phylogeographic studies.

title: Believable conversational agents for teaching ancient history and culture in 3D virtual worlds
abstract:
University of Technology, Sydney. Faculty of Engineering and Information Technology.This thesis introduces believable conversational agents as an engaging and motivational learning tool for teaching ancient history and culture in virtual worlds.
Traditional approaches are lacking engagement, interactivity and socialisation, features that are of tremendous importance to modern students (digital natives). At the same time, modern 3D visualisations primarily focus on the design side of the given space and neglect the actual inhabitants of these ancient places. As a consequence, in such historical or cultural 3D visualisations it is difficult to engage the students in the learning process and to keep track of students' learning progress. Furthermore, this approach neglects the knowledge carriers (inhabitants of the ancient site) which are an important part of a particular culture and played an important role in significant historical events.
Embodied conversational agents envisaged by this thesis for teaching ancient history and culture must be believable as they act in highly dynamic and heterogeneous environments such as 3D Virtual Worlds with both human and autonomous agent participants. In these virtual environments participants behave autonomously and frequently interact with each other and with software agents. Therefore, embodied conversational agents must know their surroundings, be aware of their own state in the virtual environment and possess a detailed knowledge of their own interactions as well as the interactions of other participants. We label such agent abilities as "awareness believability" and develop the necessary theoretical background and the formalisation of this concept. We also discuss the I2B (Interactive, Intelligent and Believable) framework that implements awareness believability using the combination of the Virtual Institutions technology, the AIML engine and the visualisation layer of Virtual Worlds.
Through a detailed literature review on virtual agents' believability we identified the ability to continuously learn new conversational skills as another important aspect of being believable. Thus, this thesis also explains how AIML specific rules and virtual agents' interactions with subject matter experts help to dynamically improve the conversational corpus of virtual agents via imitation learning.
To validate the impact of supplying agents with awareness believability we conducted a number of case studies specific to the domain of ancient history and culture. The studies confirmed that the identified awareness features are indeed making the agents perceived as more believable. Furthermore, the studies provide important evidence in favour of using virtual agents for improving the knowledge of students in the domain of ancient history and culture
fieldOfStudy: History, Virtual Agents, Ancient History, Conversational Agents, Virtual Worlds
summary: This thesis introduces believable conversational agents as engaging and motivational tools for teaching ancient history and culture in 3D virtual worlds. Addressing limitations of traditional methods, the research proposes and formalizes "awareness believability" for agents operating in dynamic virtual environments. It discusses the I2B (Interactive, Intelligent and Believable) framework, which integrates Virtual Institutions, the AIML engine, and Virtual Worlds for implementation. The study also explores improving agents' conversational skills through imitation learning. Case studies confirmed that awareness features enhance agent believability and support their effectiveness in improving students' knowledge of ancient history and culture, focusing on interactive learning and socialisation.

title: Judean Pillar Figurines and Ethnic Identity in the Shadow of Assyria
abstract: An examination of Judean Pillar Figurines in relation to cultural discourse and identity construction in the late Iron-Age Levan
summary: This article examines Judean Pillar Figurines (JPFs) from the late Iron Age Levant, which are considered uniquely Judean artifacts. It surveys scholarly discussions focusing on their representation and use, contributing to debates about Asherah/asherah in monarchic Judah. The study aims to understand the popularity of JPFs in the 8th and 7th centuries BCE by drawing on Antonio Gramsci's concepts of cultural hegemony and ideology. It suggests JPFs were part of a complex cultural discourse, resisting, adopting, and fusing ideologies, and highlights the multifaceted impact of Assyrian imperialism on Judean culture and ethnic identity.

title: The status of linear "B" in the history of Ancient Greek
fieldOfStudy: History, Linguistics, Ancient Greek, Linear B, Phonology
summary: This study aims to summarize the phonological changes from Indo-European into the Attic dialect of Ancient Greek (circa 200 BC) and to position Minoan (Mycenaean) Linear B Greek within this chronology. The authors order these changes chronologically, acknowledging that alterations within each stage might be simultaneous. The methodology involves detailing specific phonetic shifts across various stages, such as the purported reflexes of laryngeals and their transformations into different Greek vowel sounds. Key findings include a detailed timeline of linguistic evolution and the integration of Linear B's characteristics into this developmental framework. This research provides insights into historical linguistics and the evolution of Greek dialects.

title: The Logic of Time: from Aristotle to Computer Science
abstract:
Charla tipo conferencia-seminario dada para alumnos de un másterThis short course will explore that continuous thread which connects the discussion about time in philosophy with the modern use of temporal logic in computer science. It will go through the history of temporal logic to show how ideas developed by ancient and medieval philosophy have been rediscovered in modern times and applied to solve relevant problems in computer science.
Part 1: An historical perspective on temporal logic
• Synthesis: the nature of time is a central issue of classical and medieval phylosophy • Downfall: in the Renaissance the subject loses interest and is removed from the philo-
sophical discussion • Rediscovery: in the 19th and 20th centory temporal logic become a central issue again
Part 2: Time in Computer Science
• Algorithms, states and computations • Imperative programs and Reactive programs • Temporal Logic for Computer Science: CTL and LTL • The satisfiability problem • The model checking problemUniversidad de Málaga. Campus de Excelencia Internacional Andalucía Tech
summary: This short course explores the historical and modern connections between philosophical discussions of time and the application of temporal logic in computer science. It traces the evolution of temporal logic from ancient and medieval philosophy, through a period of decline in the Renaissance, to its rediscovery and central role in the 19th and 20th centuries. The course also delves into temporal logic's use in computer science, covering topics like algorithms, imperative and reactive programs, CTL and LTL, and the satisfiability and model checking problems. This offers insights into philosophy of time and formal logic.

title: Nationalization of Antiquities: Threats to Human Heritage Posed by Equating Modern Nations with Ancient Counterparts
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
fieldOfStudy: History, Classical Archaeology and Art History
summary: This thesis examines the "Nationalization of Antiquities," exploring the threats to human heritage that arise from equating modern nations with their ancient predecessors. It defines antiquities broadly and investigates how nationalistic interpretations can lead to contested ownership and cultural appropriation of historical artifacts. The study analyzes the implications of such nationalization on the preservation and accessibility of ancient objects, highlighting potential conflicts and the loss of universal human heritage. Key concepts include cultural heritage, nationalism, artifact repatriation, and the definition of antiquities.

title: Interrogation of modern and ancient genomes reveals the complex domestic history of cattle
abstract:
The analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear DNA sequence polymorphisms from modern cattle populations has had a profound impact on our understanding of the events surrounding the domestication of cattle. From these studies, it has been possible to distinguish between pre- and post-domestic genetic differentiation, supporting previous assertions from archaeological studies and, in some cases, revealing novel aspects of the demographic history of cattle.

Analyses of genetic material retrieved from the remains of extinct ancestral wild cattle have also added valuable layers of information pertaining to cattle domestic origins; however, information from these investigations have, in general, been limited to small, variable portions of the mitochondrial genome owing to technical challenges associated with the retrieval and amplification of ancient DNA.

In recent years, however, new high-throughput, massively parallel genomics technology platforms, such as single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping arrays and next-generation sequencing (NGS), have provided a new impetus to the studies of genetic variation in extant and ancient cattle.

Arrays of SNP have facilitated high-resolution genetic surveys of global cattle populations and detection of ancient and recent genomic selective sweeps. Next-generation sequencing analyses of modern and ancient cattle hold great promise for identifying and cataloging of pre- and post-domestication patterns of genomic variation and correlating this with natural and artificial selection processes
authors: Bovine Genome Sequencing and Analysis Consortium
summary: This paper reviews how mitochondrial and nuclear DNA sequencing from modern and ancient cattle populations has advanced our understanding of cattle domestication. Early studies distinguished pre- and post-domestic genetic differentiation, supported by archaeological findings. While ancient DNA analysis was initially limited by technical challenges, new high-throughput genomics technologies like SNP arrays and next-generation sequencing now enable high-resolution genetic surveys.
