These methods facilitate the detection of genomic selective sweeps and the cataloging of pre- and post-domestication genomic variation, correlating it with natural and artificial selection processes, revealing the complex domestic history of cattle.

title: Pico della Mirandola and the Presocratics
abstract: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463-1494) decided to study all the ancient and medieval schools of philosophy, including the Pre-Socratics, in order to broaden his scope. Pico showed interest in ancient monists. He commented that only Xenophanes’ One is the One simply, while Parmenides’ One is not the absolute One, but the oneness of Being. Melissus’ One is in extreme correspondence to that of Xenophanes. As for Xenophanes, Pico seems to have fallen victim of ancient sources, who referred to Xenophanes and Parmenides as members of the Eleatic “tribe”. In the case of Parmenides Pico draws mainly on the Platonic dialogues Parmenides and Sophist and not on intermediaries such as the Neoplatonists and other commentators. Despite of Pico’s knowledge of Empedocles’ philosophy, it is worth noticing that Pico was also strongly influenced by the medieval kabbalistic literature and the pseudo Empedocles. While Neoplatonists, such as Proclus, commented Empedocles and interpreted him according to the Neoplatonic spectrum, Pico’s appreciation of the philosophy of Empedocles was mediated through Arab and Jewish mysticism. Pico counted among his sources the Pre-Socratics, but the way he read them was not always direct and consistent. He intentionally chose to interpret them through the spectrum of intermediaries such as the ancient Commentators, the Neoplatonists, the Arabs and Jews mystics
fieldOfStudy: History, Philosophy, Ancient Philosophy, Medieval Philosophy, Renaissance Philosophy
summary: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's study of ancient and medieval philosophy, including the Pre-Socratics, aimed to broaden his intellectual scope. He explored ancient monists, noting distinctions between Xenophanes' absolute One and Parmenides' oneness of Being. Pico's interpretation of these philosophers was often mediated, influenced by ancient sources mistakenly linking Xenophanes and Parmenides to the Eleatic school, and by medieval Kabbalistic and Arab/Jewish mystical literature in his appreciation of Empedocles. This study highlights Pico's synthetic approach, drawing on diverse intermediaries rather than direct engagement with original texts, to understand foundational philosophical concepts like monism and being.

title: The ancient lunar crust, Apollo 17 region
abstract: The Apollo 17 highland collection is dominated by fragment-laden melt rocks, generally thought to represent impact melt from the Serenitatis basin-forming impact. Fortunately for our understanding of the lunar crust, the melt rocks contain unmelted clasts of preexisting rocks. Similar ancient rocks are also found in the regolith; most are probably clasts eroded out of melt rocks. The ancient rocks can be divided into groups by age, composition, and history. Oldest are plutonic igneous rocks, representing the magmatic components of the ancient crust. The younger are granulitic breccias, which are thoroughly recrystallized rocks of diverse parentages. The youngest are KREEPy basalts and felsites, products of relatively evolved magmas. Some characteristics of each group are given
summary: This document explores the geological setting and compositional analysis of the Apollo 17 landing site, focusing on the highland collection dominated by fragment-laden melt rocks from the Serenitatis basin-forming impact. It categorizes ancient lunar rocks into plutonic igneous rocks, granulitic breccias, and KREEPy basalts/felsites based on age, composition, and history. The text also discusses the potential impact of the Imbrium Basin event on the Sculptured Hills and describes spectroscopic measurements and spectral/chemical correlations used to estimate key element concentrations like Fe, Ti, Al, and Mg in Apollo 17 soil samples.

title: Review of Walter Scheidel (ed.), The Cambridge Companion to the Roman Economy (2012)
summary: This review analyzes Walter Scheidel's "The Cambridge Companion to the Roman Economy," a collection exploring the similarities and differences between ancient and modern economies. It highlights the long-standing debate among ancient historians and classical archaeologists regarding the 'foreignness' or 'otherness' of ancient Greek and Roman economies, especially since M.I. Finley's 1973 work. The Companion integrates new archaeological sources and interdisciplinary theories (economics, demography, ecology) to invigorate discussions on Roman economic history. It emphasizes the historical specificity of the Roman economy, particularly the rural-urban divide and elite entitlement, offering a stimulating introduction to current research and debates for students and scholars interested in ancient economic history and pre-modern societies.

title: Classics Department Newsletter 2017-18
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Classics, Ancient Philosophy, Greek, Roman
summary: This newsletter, published by the Classics Department at Gettysburg College for the 2017-2018 academic year, provides updates on departmental activities. It includes notes from the department chair, faculty news such as the retirement of Carolyn Snively and the welcome of Katheryn Whitcomb, and information on prizes and awards. The newsletter also features alumni news, highlighting career changes and personal milestones, and encourages past students to submit their own updates for future editions. Keywords include Classics, Ancient Philosophy, Greek, and Roman.

title: From Document to History: Introduction
summary: This introduction to "From Document to History: Epigraphic Insights into the Greco-Roman World" outlines a collection of papers exploring the historical significance of epigraphy. The volume, organized chronologically and regionally, not thematically or linguistically, presents new research on inscriptions from Classical and Hellenistic Greece, covering topics such as war orphans, quarries, fortifications, grants of isopoliteia, and new Hellenistic inscriptions. It emphasizes drawing historical insights from ancient texts rather than focusing solely on linguistic divisions, offering a fresh perspective on the polyglot ancient Mediterranean world.

title: The image of an instrument: bells as represented by inscriptions in the Quan Song wen 全宋文
summary: This paper examines the perception and cultural significance of bells during the Song dynasty (960-1279), a period marked by a strong interest in ancient music and archaeology. Drawing on approximately 70 texts from the Quan Song wen, the study reveals diverse engagements with bells beyond mere listening, including composing inscriptions and collecting. It explores how ancient bell culture was integrated with Song dynasty bell production and the instrument's role within a Buddhist context. This research contributes to understanding the multifaceted history of craft, music, power relations, and religious culture through the lens of bells, bell inscriptions, and elite culture.

title: Two inscribed documents of the Athenian Empire: the Chalkis decree and the tribute reassessment decree
abstract: This paper discusses two important inscriptions for the history of the Athenian Empire, the Chalkis decree of 446/5 (or 424/3?) BC (IG I3 40) and the tribute reassessment decree (“Thoudippos’ decree”) of 425/4 BC (IG I3 71). Based on English translations of the most up-to-date and authoritative Greek texts, the paper sets out to explain the inscriptions in historical context, without assuming prior knowledge of ancient Greek or of the history of Athens and the Athenian Empire. To help the reader new to the study of Athenian inscriptions, the Paper includes an introduction to inscribed Athenian decrees of the fifth century BC. This paper will be useful for researchers, teachers and learners of Greek History at University level, but is also designed to help 6th-form teachers and students in the UK with the study of these two inscriptions, which are set as source material for the “Relations between Greek states and between Greek and non-Greek states, 492-404 BC” period study under the OCR specification for A-level Ancient History (H407, for first assessment in 2019; LACTOR4 1.78 and 138). Note: minor corrections were incorporated on 28 June 2017
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient History, Greek History, Athenian Empire
summary: This paper analyzes two pivotal inscriptions for the Athenian Empire: the Chalkis decree (446/5 or 424/3? BC) and the tribute reassessment decree of Thoudippos (425/4 BC). It aims to explain these documents within their historical context, providing English translations of authoritative Greek texts. The paper includes an introduction to fifth-century BC Athenian inscribed decrees, making it accessible to those without prior knowledge of ancient Greek or Athenian history. This work is designed for university-level researchers, teachers, and students of Greek History, as well as UK A-level Ancient History students studying Greek state relations.

title: Suggestions for the Teaching of History and Civics in the High School
authors: The University of Texas at Austin
publisher: 'The University of Texas at Austin, Bureau of Economic Geology'
summary: This bulletin provides revised suggestions for teaching history and civics in high schools, originally authored by A. C. Krey and updated by the University of Texas School of History faculty. It outlines curriculum recommendations, such as dedicating two years to General History (Ancient, Medieval, and Modern) if limited, and includes an extensive bibliography largely compiled by Herbert Keller. The resource aims to guide educators on structuring history and civics courses, emphasizing the importance of these subjects for informed citizenship and the preservation of democratic government. Key topics include historical periods, pedagogical approaches, and relevant educational materials.

title: Artefacts and Errors: Acknowledging Issues of Representation in the Digital: Imaging of Ancient Texts
abstract:
It is assumed, in palaeography, papyrology and epigraphy, that a certain amount of

uncertainty is inherent in the reading of damaged and abraded texts. Yet we have

not really grappled with the fact that, nowadays, as many scholars tend to deal with

digital images of texts, rather than handling the texts themselves, the procedures for

creating digital images of texts can insert further uncertainty into the representation

of the text created. Technical distortions can lead to the unintentional introduction

of ‘artefacts’ into images, which can have an effect on the resulting representation. If

we cannot trust our digital surrogates of texts, can we trust the readings from them?

How do scholars acknowledge the quality of digitised images of texts? Furthermore,

this leads us to the type of discussions of representation that have been present in

Classical texts since Plato: digitisation can be considered as an alternative form of

representation, bringing to the modern debate of the use of digital technology in Classics

the familiar theories of mimesis (imitation) and ekphrasis (description): the conversion

of visual evidence into explicit descriptions of that information, stored in computer

files in distinct linguistic terms, with all the difficulties of conversion understood in the

ekphratic process. The community has not yet considered what becoming dependent

on digital texts means for the field, both in practical and theoretical terms. Issues of

quality, copying, representation, and substance should be part of our dialogue when

we consult digital surrogates of documentary material, yet we are just constructing

understandings of what it means to rely on virtual representations of artefacts. It is

necessary to relate our understandings of uncertainty in palaeography and epigraphy

to our understanding of the mechanics of visualization employed by digital imaging

techniques, if we are to fully understand the impact that these will have
summary: This paper addresses the inherent uncertainty in reading damaged ancient texts, especially when relying on digital images rather than physical artifacts. It highlights how digital imaging procedures can introduce technical distortions and 'artefacts,' questioning the trustworthiness of readings derived from digital surrogates. The author explores the philosophical implications of digital representation in Classics, drawing parallels with Platonic theories of mimesis and ekphrasis, and emphasizes the need for palaeography and epigraphy to integrate understandings of digital visualization mechanics. Key issues discussed include quality, copying, representation, and the substantive impact of digital dependence in textual scholarship and semantic search.

title: Examination of Human Skeletal Remains and Artifacts from el-Qantir, Egypt
summary: This study examines human skeletal remains and artifacts discovered in a common grave on the outskirts of el-Qantir, Egypt. The excavation uncovered a human skeleton, a mummified cat, and a vase from the First Intermediate Period of the Eleventh Dynasty. Based on similar findings and carbon dating, all items were determined to be approximately 4060 years old. The research integrates Egyptian history to interpret cultural aspects of the burial, the human skeleton's middle socioeconomic class, the religious role of the cat, and the human's natural cause of death. The skeletal remains are identified as those of a male.

title: Artemis: Depictions of Form and Femininity in Sculpture
abstract: Grecian sculpture has been the subject of investigation for centuries. More recently, however, emphasis in the field of Art History on the politics of gender and sexuality portrayal have opened new avenues for investigation of those old statues. In depicting gender, Ancient Greek statuary can veer towards the non-binary, with the most striking examples being works depicting Hermaphroditos and ‘his’ bodily form. Yet even within the binary, there are complications. Depictions of the goddess Artemis are chief among these complications of the binary, with even more contradiction, subtext, and varied interpretation than representations of Amazons. The numerous ways Artemis has been portrayed over the years highlight her multifarious aspects, but often paint a contradictory portrait of her femininity. Is she the wild mother? The asexual huntress? Or is she a tempting virgin, whose purity is at risk? Depictions of her in sculptural form, deliberately composed, offer answers. Though as separate depictions they sometimes contradict one another, as a whole, they reveal just how Artemis the female was thought of
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque Art and Architecture, Sculpture
summary: This paper investigates the portrayal of femininity and gender in Ancient Greek statuary, specifically focusing on the goddess Artemis. It explores how Grecian sculpture, through deliberate compositions, depicts Artemis in various, often contradictory, ways—as a wild mother, an asexual huntress, or a vulnerable virgin. The study analyzes these multifaceted representations to understand how Artemis's female form was conceived and presented within the context of art history's emphasis on gender and sexuality politics, offering insights into the complexities of binary and non-binary depictions in ancient art. Keywords: Ancient Greek sculpture, Artemis, gender portrayal, femininity, art history, classical studies.

title: В. В. Латышев: опыт каталогизации крымских эпиграфических памятников
abstract:
Рассмотрен вклад выдающегося российского антиковеда Василия Васильевича Латышева (1855–1921) в изучение античного периода истории Крыма, систематизацию и публикацию эпиграфических памятников. Проанализирована роль В. В. Латышева в изучении древней и средневековой истории Крыма, в особенности, источниковой базы исследования.Розглянуто внесок видатного російського вченого Василя Васильовича Латишева

(1855–1921) у вивчення античного періоду історії Криму, систематизацію і публікацію епіграфічних пам'яток. Репрезентовано внесок В. В. Латишева у вивчення давньої та середньовічної історії Криму, особливо, джерельної бази дослідження.The article describes the contribution of the prominent Russian antiquity scientist Vasily

Latyshev (1855-1921) to the studing of the ancient period of the history of the Crimea,

organizing and publishing epigraphic monuments. In this paper the role of

V.V. Latyshev in the studing of ancient and medieval history of the Crimea, in particular,

the source base of the study. It is emphasized that published monuments epigraphic is the

most fundamental body of published written sources on the history of the ancient period

of the Crimea to the present time. It is noted that due to methodological assistance provided

by the local research scientist forces has been tremendous progress in the studying

of the ancient monuments in Kerch museum (K.E. Dumberg, V.V. Shkorpil) and Chersonese

(K.K. Kosciusko-Valyuzhinich, L.A. Moses), there have been numerous publications

of local regional specialists dedicated to exploring and transcripts of the Crimean

inscriptions (K.K. Kosciusko-Valyuzhinich, V.V. Shkorpil). Based on the studing of V.V.

Latyshev correspondence it is shown that an important form of the Crimean study activities

were his constant contact with local and regional specialists of Crimean studies and

scientists from other research centers
publisher: Центр пам’яткознавства НАН України і Українського товариства охорони пам’яток історії та культури
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient History, Archaeology, Epigraphy, Crimean Studies
summary: This article examines the significant contributions of Vasily Latyshev (1855-1921), a distinguished Russian antiquity scholar, to the study of Crimea's ancient and medieval history. The research focuses on his role in systematizing and publishing epigraphic monuments, which are highlighted as fundamental written sources for the ancient Crimean period. The study analyzes Latyshev's methodological assistance to local researchers in Kerch and Chersonese, facilitating progress in monument studies and numerous publications of Crimean inscriptions. It also reveals, through Latyshev's correspondence, his crucial contacts with regional specialists and scientists from other research centers, emphasizing collaborative efforts in Crimean studies.

title: Learning from Jesus’ Wife: What Does Forgery Have to Do with the Digital Humanities?
abstract: McGrath’s chapter on the so-called Gospel of Jesus’ Wife sets aside as settled the question of the papyrus’ authenticity, and explores instead what we can learn about the Digital Humanities and scholarly interaction in a digital era from the way the discussions and investigations of that work unfolded, and how issues that arose were handled. As news of purported new finds can spread around the globe instantaneously facilitated by current technology and social media, how can academics utilize similar technology to evaluate authenticity, but even more importantly, inform the broader public about the importance of provenance, and the need for skepticism towards finds that appear via the antiquities market
summary: McGrath's chapter explores the implications of the "Gospel of Jesus' Wife" papyrus controversy for Digital Humanities and scholarly interaction in the digital age. It analyzes how discussions and investigations surrounding the papyrus unfolded, addressing issues that arose in disseminating and evaluating authenticity in an era of instantaneous global news spread via technology and social media. The work highlights the role of academics in using technology not only to assess authenticity but also to educate the public about the importance of provenance and skepticism towards finds from the antiquities market, promoting critical engagement with digital scholarship and ancient manuscripts.

title: Functional Skills Support Programme: Developing functional skills in history
abstract:
This booklet is part of "... a series of 11 booklets which helps schools to implement functional skills across the curriculum. The booklets illustrate how functional skills can be applied and developed in different subjects and contexts, supporting achievement at Key Stage 3 and Key Stage 4.



Each booklet contains an introduction to functional skills for subject teachers, three practical planning examples with links to related websites and resources, a process for planning and a list of additional resources to support the teaching and learning of functional skills." - The National Strategies website
summary: This booklet, part of a series for schools, aims to help subject teachers implement and develop functional skills across the curriculum, specifically within history at Key Stages 3 and 4. It provides an introduction to functional skills for history teachers, three practical planning examples related to the industrial revolution and suffragettes, links to websites and resources, and a process for planning. The guide focuses on integrating essential skills into history lessons to support overall achievement. Key topics include curriculum development, educational planning, and skill integration in secondary education.

title: Different Clusters of Text from Ancient China, Different Mathematical Ontologies
abstract: Sources attesting to mathematical activities in ancient China form at least four distinct clusters of texts, bespeaking at least four different—though overlapping—ways of practicing mathematics. I will focus on two such sets of documents: the canons that in the seventh century constituted one of the two curricula taught in the Imperial “School of Mathematics,” and manuscripts recently excavated from tombs sealed in the last centuries BCE. I will argue that these two sets of documents testify to two different ways of practicing mathematics, which related to different material practices. Accordingly, we can perceive that mathematical objects were shaped and explored in different ways, with significant consequences for the knowledge produced
fieldOfStudy: History of Mathematics, Sinology, Ancient History
summary: This paper examines mathematical activities in ancient China, focusing on two distinct sets of documents: canons from the 7th-century Imperial School of Mathematics and manuscripts excavated from tombs sealed in the last centuries BCE. The author argues these documents reveal two different ways of practicing mathematics, linked to diverse material practices. Consequently, mathematical objects were shaped and explored in varied ways, impacting the knowledge produced. Keywords include arithmetical operations, history of mathematics in China, practices, terminology, and ontological assumptions, providing valuable insights for semantic search in the history of mathematics.

title: A survey of the coverage, use and application of ancient woodland indicator lists in the UK
abstract: This report presents the results of a survey into the current use of ancient woodland indicator species lists in the UK. The idea of using species particularly vascular plants as indicators of ancient woodlands can be dated back to the 1970s and the work of Peterken. Since then a wide number of lists of Ancient Woodland Indicators (AWIs)have been produced, some based on expert opinions, some utilising field surveys, others adapted from existing lists. Recently developed lists, e.g. the lists for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have been based on either robust reviews of existing lists, and/or expert opinion and/or field surveys and statistical analysis. Concerns however have been expressed regarding the use of lists and these concerns appear to be supported by the uncritical use of indicator species in recent planning inquiries, e.g. not recognising that indicators are indicators and considering them to be the key value of a woodland. A survey was undertaken of relevant individuals working in biological record centres, local authorities and key agencies across the UK. The survey sought to identify what lists of Ancient Woodland Indicators are currently in use, where possible to determine the methods used in developing these lists. The survey also sought to assess the awareness of ancient woodland indicator lists and review the ways in which these were used. A total of 419 questionnaires were sent out; a response rate of 11% was obtained. Follow up phone conversations were held with key individuals involved in developing ancient woodland indicator lists. Responses were received from all counties excluding: Buckinghamshire, Cheshire, Essex, Huntingdonshire, Middlesex, Northamptonshire, Staffordshire, Wiltshire and Worcestershire. In addition, the Lancashire respondent stated there was no AWI list for Lancashire. The key findings of the survey were: • There is a wide variety of lists of Ancient Woodland Indicators lists available covering most of the UK. • Most individuals using indicator lists are unaware of the methods used to produce the lists and therefore of their robustness. Some key stakeholders are unaware of the existence of indicator lists in their area. • Attitudes to ancient woodland indicator lists are variable, as is their use. • Few lists use species thresholds or weightings in determining whether a site is ancient, several lists are currently under review. • There are over 200 species listed on the various Ancient Woodland Indicators lists, few species are common to more than a quarter of the lists
summary: This report surveys the use of ancient woodland indicator species lists in the UK, building on work dating back to the 1970s by Peterken. It identifies various lists, their development methods (expert opinion, field surveys, statistical analysis), and assesses awareness and application among professionals in biological record centers, local authorities, and key agencies. Findings reveal a wide variety of lists, often with users unaware of their methodological robustness, and inconsistent attitudes and applications. The survey highlights that few lists employ species thresholds or weightings, with over 200 species listed across various UK AWIs, but few are common to more than a quarter of them. This study provides valuable insights into the current landscape of ancient woodland conservation.

title: An Environmental History of Medieval Europe by Richard C. Hoffman
abstract: Review of Richard C. Hoffman\u27s An Environmental History of Medieval Europe
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Environmental History, European History, Social History
summary: This article presents a review of Richard C. Hoffman's "An Environmental History of Medieval Europe." The reviewer praises the book as fascinating, prompting readers to reconsider the origins of food, the image of medieval peasants, and the names of natural features. The work highlights a civilization controlled by powerful elites whose interests dictated actions, often at the expense of others or the environment. The reviewer suggests that while interdisciplinary, the book could further benefit from an international and plurilingual approach, emphasizing the ongoing relevance of its themes to contemporary power dynamics.

title: The origins of intensive marine fishing in medieval Europe: the English evidence
abstract: The catastrophic impact of fishing pressure on species such as cod and herring is well documented. However, the antiquity of their intensive exploitation has not been established. Systematic catch statistics are only available for ca. 100 years, but large-scale fishing industries existed in medieval Europe and the expansion of cod fishing from the fourteenth century (first in Iceland, then in Newfoundland) played an important role in the European colonization of the Northwest Atlantic. History has demonstrated the scale of these late medieval and post-medieval fisheries, but only archaeology can illuminate earlier practices. Zooarchaeological evidence shows that the clearest changes in marine fishing in England between AD 600 and 1600 occurred rapidly around AD 1000 and involved large increases in catches of herring and cod. Surprisingly, this revolution predated the documented post-medieval expansion of England's sea fisheries and coincided with the Medieval Warm Period-when natural herring and cod productivity was probably low in the North Sea. This counterintuitive discovery can be explained by the concurrent rise of urbanism and human impacts on freshwater ecosystems. The search for 'pristine' baselines regarding marine ecosystems will thus need to employ medieval palaeoecological proxies in addition to recent fisheries data and early modern historical records
summary: This study investigates the origins of intensive marine fishing in medieval Europe, focusing on English evidence. While historical records for catch statistics are limited to the last century, archaeological findings reveal significant increases in herring and cod catches around AD 1000 in England. This period predates the documented post-medieval expansion of sea fisheries and surprisingly coincided with the Medieval Warm Period, a time of potentially low natural fish productivity. The authors propose that the rise of urbanism and human impacts on freshwater ecosystems explain this counterintuitive trend. This research highlights the need for medieval paleoecological proxies alongside modern data to establish 'pristine' baselines for marine ecosystems.

title: Medieval Christian Dualist Perceptions and Conceptions of Biblical Paradise
abstract:
The article intends to draw attention to some of the most significant and telling appropriations
of traditional themes of Biblical paradise in medieval Christian dualism (namely, Paulicianism,
Bogomilism and related groups in Eastern Christendom and Catharism in Western Christendom) and initiate discussion on the important but presently not always explicable problem of their theological and literary provenance. The significance of this problematic is highlighted by the increasing amount of direct and indirect evidence of the role played by a number of early Jewish and Christian
pseudepigraphic works in the formation of medieval Christian dualist cosmogonic, cosmological, satanological,
Christological and biblical history traditions. The preliminary survey of medieval dualist
conceptions of biblical Paradise shows also once more that the doctrinal evidence for Bogomilism
and Catharism is too complex and polyvalent to be defined or ignored apriori as representing medieval
heresiological constructs drawing on earlier heresiological texts and stereotypes. The material examined in the article shows that the text-critical treatment of the primary sources to first establish
the most plausible literary and theological provenance of the respective teachings attributed to medieval
Christian dualist groups or individuals still remains indispensable to the study of medieval heresy and needs to precede the application of models and approaches drawn from contemporary
anthropological and sociological theory to the source material
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Religious Studies, Theology
summary: This article explores the appropriations of Biblical paradise themes within medieval Christian dualism, specifically in Paulicianism, Bogomilism, and Catharism. It aims to initiate discussion on their theological and literary provenance, highlighting the influence of early Jewish and Christian pseudepigraphic works on dualist cosmogonic, cosmological, satanological, and Christological traditions. The preliminary survey reveals the complexity of doctrinal evidence for Bogomilism and Catharism, suggesting they are not merely heresiological constructs. The study emphasizes the necessity of text-critical treatment of primary sources to establish the provenance of these teachings before applying contemporary anthropological and sociological theories to medieval heresy.

title: The Dies Irae ( Day of Wrath ) and Totentanz ( Dance of Death ): Medieval Themes Revisited in 19th Century Music and Culture
abstract: During the pivotal November 2002 football game of Arkansas vs. Georgia in the SEC conference championship, the Georgia marching band struck up their defensive rallying song. Instead of a typical  defense  song, the band played an excerpt of the Gregorian Sequence Dies Irae ( Day of Wrath\u27\u27) from the Roman Catholic Requiem Mass. Drastically dissociated from its original medieval milieu, this musical Sequence still manages to elicit the same effect of fear and foreboding nearly a thousand years later. Precisely because of its deep musical and cultural roots, the Dies Irae occupies a significant place in history, closely intertwined from early on with the medieval folk motif Totentanz ( Dance of Death ), widely depicted in medieval art, and dramatically revived in 19th century music, art, and literature. This multi-disciplinary study focuses on the history of art and music of these two medieval themes during their development, and then moves on to study them in 19th century culture. Specifically, the manipulation of the original Gregorian chant and the incorporation of the idea of a medieval dance are analyzed in the music of Hector Berlioz, Franz Liszt, and Camille Saint-Saens. Numerous other contextual links are explored as well, such as Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Victor Hugo, Henri Cazalis, William Blake, and Alfred Rethel, all of whom created 19th century artistic or literary masterpieces derived from the thematic seeds of the Dies Irae and the Totentanz. Although neither of these ideas endured in their original form during the Romantic era, the inherently compelling nature of these themes that center on the macabre but inevitable end of life captivated the Romantic geniuses and continue to intrigue us to this day
summary: This multidisciplinary study explores the history of the medieval themes "Dies Irae" (Day of Wrath) and "Totentanz" (Dance of Death) and their revival in 19th-century culture, specifically in music, art, and literature. The research analyzes the manipulation of the Gregorian chant and the incorporation of the medieval dance concept in compositions by Hector Berlioz, Franz Liszt, and Camille Saint-Saëns. It also examines contextual links with figures like Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and Victor Hugo, demonstrating how these macabre but compelling themes captivated Romantic artists and continue to intrigue audiences.

title: The fortunes of Arthur: Malory to Milton
abstract: This chapter follows the fortunes of Arthur as a figure contested and celebrated in equal measure between Malory's Morte Darthur (1485), and Milton's History of Britain (1670). Malory depicted the French wars under the guise of Arthur's sixth-century campaign against Rome, and Arthur was key to medieval and Renaissance representations of sovereignty and resistance. One critical view suggests that by the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries Arthur became an inconvenient myth, retaining poetic and propagandistic potential but scoffed at by serious scholars. The Reformation and the rise of antiquarianism engendered suspicion of medieval sources, and Arthur and Brutus were undone by the rise of Anglo-Saxon studies. Yet Arthur maintained momentum even as myth morphed from history to poetry, and writers such as Sidney, Spenser, and Shakespeare still found purchase in the legend. Looked at closely, Milton's disparaging of Arthur appears less absolute, refashioning as it does Malory's Arthurian political allegory
summary: This chapter examines how Arthur's figure was both contested and celebrated in Malory's Morte Darthur (1485) and Milton's History of Britain (1670). It explores how Arthur, initially central to medieval and Renaissance representations of sovereignty, faced skepticism from scholars during the Reformation and the rise of antiquarianism due to suspicions of medieval sources and the emergence of Anglo-Saxon studies. Despite this, Arthur maintained significance as a myth, influencing writers like Sidney, Spenser, and Shakespeare. The analysis reveals Milton's seemingly disparaging view of Arthur to be less absolute, as he refashioned Malory's Arthurian political allegory. Keywords: Arthur, Malory, Milton, Morte Darthur, History of Britain, medieval history, Renaissance literature, political allegory.

title: Sons, apprentices and successors in late medieval and early modern London: the transmission of skills and work opportunities
abstract: Book synopsis: The existence and changing of generations in family life, business and politics was a central feature of towns as well as rural societies in earlier times. Even so, it remains understudied by urban historians of the pre-modern period. This book aims to fill some of this gap, containing twelve studies of generations in late medieval and early modern European towns, ranging from the Mediterranean to the Nordic countries, with a time-span from the fourteenth to the early nineteenth century. Dealing with topics like succession and inheritance, family consciousness, as well as relations and conflicts within and between generations, the articles demonstrate the importance and potential of generational studies on pre-modern towns. The book will appeal to anyone who takes an interest in urban social and cultural history, legal and family history in medieval and early modern times
fieldOfStudy: History, Urban History, Family History, Legal History
summary: This book explores the understudied role of generations in late medieval and early modern European towns, aiming to fill a gap in urban history. Comprising twelve studies from the 14th to the early 19th century, it examines topics such as succession, inheritance, family consciousness, and intergenerational relations and conflicts. The articles demonstrate the importance of generational studies for understanding pre-modern urban societies. This research is relevant to urban social and cultural history, legal history, and family history in medieval and early modern times, with a focus on skill transmission and work opportunities.

title: “Of the Ruin and Conquest of Britain”:  The Anglo-Saxon Transformation of the British Isles
abstract: The history of Britain after the collapse of the Western Roman Empire has traditionally been perceived as one of invasion and domination at the hands of Germanic peoples most commonly known as the Angles, Saxons, and Jutes. Though this is the narrative presented by medieval authors, current archaeology suggests that the settlement of Germanic peoples in Britain was peaceful and characterized by cohabitation and acculturation. Further examination and contextualization of the most nearly-contemporary sources reveal discrepancies of chronology and causation which indicate that medieval authors constructed their accounts based not upon an understanding of any Anglo-Saxon invasion but rather upon a narrative constructed from their contemporary cultural landscape
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This study re-examines the traditional narrative of post-Roman Britain, which often portrays the era as one of Germanic invasion and domination by the Angles, Saxons, and Jutes. Challenging medieval authors' accounts, current archaeological evidence suggests a more peaceful settlement, characterized by cohabitation and acculturation. The research contextualizes contemporary sources to reveal chronological and causal discrepancies, indicating that medieval histories were constructed based on contemporary cultural landscapes rather than actual Anglo-Saxon invasions, thus questioning the historicity of a violent conquest.

title: History : a medieval multiverse.
summary: This research paper explores an unusual approach to cosmology by collaborating on the subject with a medieval master. The authors investigate the consequences of the interaction between historical intellectual frameworks and modern cosmological concepts, specifically examining a "medieval multiverse" model. They use convergent simulations to represent a Grosseteste universe with nine perfected spheres, exploring regions of stability in opacity, lumen intensity, and transparency space. Key findings include the stalling of the perfection process when the model attempts to generate a tenth sphere, offering insights into the cosmological ideas of Robert Grosseteste and their modern interpretations. This interdisciplinary study bridges history, cosmology, and medieval philosophy.

title: Reformist hagiography : the life of St Roding of Beaulieu and the struggle for power in early eleventh-Century Lotharingia
abstract: This paper explores an example of ‘reformist’ hagiographic production in early eleventh-century Lotharingia by focusing on the Life of St Roding of Beaulieu, a small monastery in the diocese of Verdun. Until recently, this text was interpreted exclusively in terms of the scant information it provides on this institution’s early medieval history and in terms of its ideological message regarding monastic discipline and leadership. By integrating the redaction of this text into the then-current regional geography and political context, this paper proposes a new approach to its interpretation and to the understanding of Beaulieu’s ‘monastic reform’ in general. Close analysis of the narrative reveals that its redaction was inspired by specific issues relating to local and regional politics in the mid-1010s, and that parts of the institution’s recent history were allegorically veiled behind the portrayal of Roding. However, rapid changes in power relationships rendered those aspects of the text outdated within a few years. This raises significant questions regarding the long-term relevance of such hidden stories and the degree to which their various ideological, political and other messages remained accessible to medieval audiences
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Monasticism, Hagiography, Political History
summary: This paper re-examines the "Life of St Roding of Beaulieu," a reformist hagiographic text from early eleventh-century Lotharingia, challenging previous interpretations focused solely on institutional history and monastic ideology. By integrating the text's redaction into its regional political and geographical context, the author proposes a new understanding of Beaulieu's monastic reform. Close narrative analysis reveals that the text was inspired by specific local and regional political issues in the mid-1010s, with parts of the institution's recent history allegorically veiled behind Roding's portrayal. However, rapid shifts in power dynamics quickly rendered these hidden narratives outdated, raising questions about their long-term relevance and accessibility to medieval audiences.

title: ‘The Military Mirror of Kai’: Swordsmanship and a Medieval Text in Early Modern Japan
abstract: Swordsmanship emerged as a new field of knowledge in early modern Japan (1600–1868), a time of relative peace. During the most violent periods of Japanese history, the latter half of the medieval period (1185–1600), samurai conducted warfare mostly on horseback, using the bow and arrow, or by leading massive armies filled with soldiers who used pikes, halberds, and even firearms. In this paper, I will trace the origins of early modern swordsmanship to the late 16th century during the transition between the medieval and early modern periods, when teachers of swordsmanship and their sword ‘styles’ first appeared in texts. Of these texts I will focus on ‘The Military Mirror of Kai’, purportedly written during the late 16th century, and a widely-read text among samurai of the early modern period. A mix of fact and fiction, the ‘Mirror’ became a source of fantasy and inspiration for samurai and non-samurai alike. It is also the earliest source of writing about swordsmanship, which was influenced by, and grew alongside, other medieval cultural arts such as Noh theater and tea ceremony
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Japanese History, Swordsmanship
summary: This paper traces the origins of early modern Japanese swordsmanship (1600–1868) to the late 16th century, a period of transition following medieval warfare. It specifically examines "The Military Mirror of Kai," a significant text from the late 16th century, widely read by samurai. This text, a blend of fact and fiction, served as a source of inspiration and is the earliest written account of swordsmanship, influenced by other medieval arts like Noh theater and tea ceremony. The research highlights the evolution of swordsmanship and its cultural integration in early modern Japan.

title: Review of periodical articles
abstract: [First Paragraph] There is only one true city, wrote St Augustine, and it is not of this world. The pessimistic Christian response to the fall of Rome in AD 410, epitomized in Augustine's City of God, affected the development of the later medieval city to a degree which has yet, even now, to be fully appreciated. In the Christian city of the Middle Ages the divinity was normally confined to the sanctuaries of his churches, whose topographical prominence and harmonious proportions made manifest an otherwise hidden spiritual order. Outside the cloister gates, disorder reigned: a general lack of planning revealed the meaninglessness of the outward, secular life. This dichotomy between an inner world of spirit and a public world of transient matter was embodied in the recurrent tensions between spiritual and secular space which ran as a motif throughout the history of medieval towns. Modern studies which have emphasized (not, of course, without reason) the secular political and economic power of ecclesiastical institutions in the medieval city have perhaps distracted attention unduly from the real differences of ethos which, within the town, distinguished religious space from that of the surrounding lay world
summary: This paper examines the influence of St. Augustine's pessimistic Christian response to the fall of Rome (AD 410) on the development of the medieval city. It highlights the dichotomy between the sacred, ordered space within churches and the perceived disorder of the secular urban environment. The study critiques modern interpretations that overemphasize the secular power of ecclesiastical institutions, arguing for a renewed focus on the distinct ethos separating religious from lay spaces in medieval towns. This historical analysis provides insights into the enduring tensions between spiritual and secular life in urban settings.

title: 1. Prelude to Reform
abstract: The more immediate background for the Age of Reformation includes factors which precede Luther by a Century and more. While the reformers themselves felt that these factors had roots in first century Christian history and literature, more directly relevant to the movement were political, social, and economic changes which produced severe tensions in the late medieval world. Some of these contributed significantly to the Protestant upheaval. Still more important, however, were diverse streams of religious ferment, such as late medieval scholasticism, mysticism, humanism, heretical propaganda , and anti-clericalism, which flowed toward a junction in the Reformation. While it must be insisted that it took dynamic personalities to trigger this movement, we must remember that these great figures were influenced by the ideas of their environment. These earlier streams of ferment may properly be called the prelude to reform. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Cultural History, History of Christianity, History of Religion
summary: The Age of Reformation was preceded by political, social, and economic changes that created severe tensions in the late medieval world, alongside diverse religious movements like scholasticism, mysticism, humanism, and anti-clericalism. These factors converged to influence dynamic figures who triggered the Protestant upheaval. The movement primarily focused on fundamental religious questions concerning salvation and the relationship between God and man, reflecting a return to and concern with the experience of salvation. This paper examines the prelude to reform and the complex nature of the Reformation, emphasizing its religious core rather than solely moral reforms.

title: Entrevista a Martin Aurell : diálogo sobre Nobleza, Matrimonio e Historiografía
abstract: Aprovechando la edición catalana de su obra Les noces du comle realizamos una entrevista al prestigioso medievalista Martin Aurell, catedrático de historia medieval en la universidad de Poitiers. A lo largo de sus respuestas, se detiene sobre problemas de historia catalana, nobleza, espiritualidad e historiografía medievalEnjoying the opportunity provided by the Catalán edition of his work Les noces du comte, we interviewed the prestigious medievalist Martin Aurell, chair of Medieval History at he University of Poitiers. His responses to our questions touch on problems of Catalan history, the nobiliti, spirituality and medieval historiography
summary: This document presents an interview with prestigious medievalist Martin Aurell, Chair of Medieval History at the University of Poitiers, conducted on the occasion of the Catalan edition of his work "Les noces du comte". Aurell's responses explore key topics in Catalan history, nobility, spirituality, and medieval historiography. The discussion provides insights into these historical and societal aspects, offering valuable perspectives from a leading scholar in the field. Keywords include nobility, marriage, spirituality, and historiography.

title: A small intruder. A Medieval marble winged lion from Ravello
abstract: An image of a 12th century marble winged lion was provocatively included among the slides accompanying a lecture by the author at a recent conference at the American Academy in Rome to illustrate Umberto Scerrato’s work on Islamic archaeology and art history in Italy. The lion, in fact, was never published by Scerrato, but it and a winged bull, both once featuring as ornaments on the “Moresque Fountain” in Ravello (originally from a medieval building most likely from Ravello itself), are the subject of this brief article. They are of undeniable Islamic taste
summary:
This article discusses a 12th-century marble winged lion and a winged bull, previously adorning the 

"Moresque Fountain" in Ravello, Italy. These sculptures, of undeniable Islamic taste, were never published by Umberto Scerrato but were presented at a conference illustrating his work on Islamic archaeology and art history in Italy. The study examines their provenance, likely from a medieval building in Ravello, and their significance within the context of Norman period Islamic contacts in Italy. Keywords: Ravello, marble sculptures, Norman period, Islamic contacts.

title: And We cast upon his throne a mere body: A Historiographical Reading of Q. 38:34
abstract: This paper focuses on Q. 38:34 from the perspective of early and medieval works of Islamic historiography and collections of tales of the prophets: the early tenth century works of 'Umara b. Wathima and Tabari, the eleventh century Tales of the Prophets by Tha'labi, the twelfth century folkloric collection of Kisa'i, along with Ibn 'Asakir's History of Damascus, the thirteenth century world history by Ibn al-Athir, and the fourteenth century historiographical work by Ibn Kathir. These various works are viewed not as any particular stage in the development of a genre, but as variations on a (Qur'anic) theme, and the avenue of medieval historiographers and storytellers is utilised as a bridge to explore various possible interpretations of the Qur'anic passage. Historiographers and storytellers provide us with an illustration of how lessons of admonition implied in the Qur'anic text were perceived in medieval Islamic society. They also, as will become clear, provide a picture of Solomon that is consistent with the Qur'anic figure as a whole
summary: This paper analyzes Qur'anic passage 38:34 concerning the figure of Solomon, using early and medieval Islamic historiography and collections of tales of the prophets. Examining works by 'Umara b. Wathima, Tabari, Tha'labi, Kisa'i, Ibn 'Asakir, Ibn al-Athir, and Ibn Kathir, the study explores various interpretations of the Qur'anic text. These historical and narrative accounts illuminate how the admonitory lessons embedded in the Qur'an were perceived in medieval Islamic society, providing a consistent portrayal of Solomon across different sources. The research aims to bridge medieval perspectives with modern understanding of this significant religious figure.

title: Mittelalterliche deutsche Handschriften in Rumänien : Erschließung, Katalogisierung und Verwertung für eine regional orientierte Literaturgeschichte (Eine Projektidee)
abstract: The present essay outlines a project, which aims to catalogue and tap the potential of medieval German manuscripts in the collections of both church and secular libraries and archives in Romania. The project complements current efforts to catalogue and explore medieval German manuscripts in Eastern European countries. At the same time, the project prepares the ground for a regionally oriented literary history of Transylvania. Here, too, the aim is to build on current trends in medieval German studies in particular. Instead of a concept of literary history based almost exclusively on individual authors and their work, these trends advocate a literary historiography that turns to regional factors and manuscript transmission in describing literary activity in a particular area
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval German Studies, Literary History
summary: This essay outlines a project to catalogue and leverage medieval German manuscripts held in church and secular libraries and archives across Romania. The initiative complements existing efforts to explore similar manuscripts in Eastern European countries and lays the groundwork for a regionally-focused literary history of Transylvania. Moving beyond author-centric approaches, the project advocates for a literary historiography that emphasizes regional factors and manuscript transmission in describing literary activity. Key aspects include exploring manuscript collections, cataloging, and contributing to Transylvanian literary history based on regional manuscript evidence.

title: A People’s History of Christianity, vol. 4
abstract: Title: A People’s History of Christianity, vol. 4; Author: Daniel E. Bornstein, ed. Medieval Christianity; Publisher: Minneapolis, Minnesota: Fortress Press, 2009; ISBN: 978080063414
summary: This book review examines "A People's History of Christianity, vol. 4: Medieval Christianity," edited by Daniel E. Bornstein, part of a monumental seven-volume series. The review praises the series' comprehensive scope, covering two millennia of Christian history from its Jewish origins to global Christianity. It highlights Bornstein's volume for bringing to life various elements of medieval Christianity, focusing on the daily lives of ordinary people rather than abstract theological ideas or prominent figures. The reviewer recommends the entire series as essential for scholars in the field, suggesting future paperback editions and a concise one-volume summary to enhance accessibility for wider use in "History of Christianity" courses. Key topics include medieval Christianity, people's history, church history, and everyday life.

title: Medieval church history and queer ministry: using the historical imaginary to build theological community
abstract:
<p>“A woman who takes up devilish ways and plays a male role in coupling with

another woman is most vile in My sight, and so is she who subjects herself to

such a one in this evil deed…..”1</p>



<p>This statement, made by Hildegard of Bingen is representative of much of the vitriol the

medieval church liked to produce in response to same sex sexual activity. Indeed, even for

as innovative (and on occasions heretical) an author as Hildegard there was neither space

nor any evidence of her desire to do other than uphold traditional approaches to two

women having sex.2 In the face of such prejudice it is hard not to wonder whether the

medieval church has anything positive to offer the queer ecclesial community. Of course, by

implication this quote suggests that queer folk existed in the distant past and are not just a

figment of our fertile (if not furtive), libidinous, post‐modernist imaginations. Indeed, this

quote indicates the existence of not only woman to woman sex, but also role playing of a

type that sounds (comfortingly or disquieteningly dependent on your personal view point)

like the butch/femme dichotomy. Obviously, this is a translation from Latin and linguistically

at least, conveys an inherently post‐medieval reading of the text. However, it is hard to

know how a literal interpretation of this particular text would differ. It clearly implies same

sex coupling.</p>



<p>In this paper I wish to elaborate on why and how medieval church history can be used to

benefit of the queer community and those whom identify as its ministers. To do this, I have

broken the paper into three key areas: firstly, theoretical frameworks; secondly, the

practical implications of these frameworks for queer ministry; and thirdly, a case study of

using the historical imaginary and what it suggests as areas for exploration in queer

theology.</p&gt
fieldOfStudy: History, Queer Theology, Medieval Church History
summary: This paper investigates how medieval church history, despite its historical prejudice against same-sex relationships, can positively inform and benefit the queer ecclesial community and its ministers. Drawing on Hildegard of Bingen's condemnation of same-sex sexual activity, the author argues that such historical vitriol ironically confirms the existence of queer individuals and role-playing in the past. The paper is structured into three sections: theoretical frameworks, practical implications for queer ministry, and a case study exploring the historical imaginary in queer theology. This research highlights the utility of historical analysis for contemporary theological community building concerning LGBTQ+ issues.

title: Early Medieval World (Chapter 2 of World History, A Short, Visual Introduction)
abstract: The fifth through the tenth centuries was a period of significant transformation for Europe. As a result of the Germanic invasions and the collapse of the economy, the last Roman Emperor in the West, Romulus Augustulus (475-76), was deposed in 476. The Eastern Roman or Byzantine Empire would continue in a much-truncated form until the Ottoman Turks conquered Constantinople in 1453. Not only did the Germanic tribes continue their expansion into the Roman territories in the fourth and fifth centuries, the Arabs conquered substantial territory in the seventh and eighth, and Viking, Magyar, and Arab attacks tore apart Europe in the ninth and tenth. All these groups added to the mix of cultures that created the medieval world
summary: This chapter examines the significant transformations in Europe from the fifth to the tenth centuries, a period marked by Germanic invasions, economic collapse, and the deposition of the last Western Roman Emperor, Romulus Augustulus, in 476. It explores the continued presence of the Byzantine Empire and the impact of further territorial conquests by Arabs, Vikings, and Magyars, which collectively shaped the cultural landscape of the medieval world. The text emphasizes how these interactions laid a firm foundation for the High Middle Ages, highlighting the growth of economies and the preservation of heritage through monarchical emphasis on education.

title: Literatura e História na Educação Medieval
abstract: Trata este artigo de uma análise da literatura medieval como linguagens que, expressando um período da história, são extremamente reveladoras da vida e da educação dos homens, em uma sociedade marcada pelo sinete da Igreja Católica. É por todas as formas e modalidades de linguagem que apreendemos o longo caminhar da Humanidade na construção da História. Neste caso, trataremos de textos da literatura medieval oriundos de diversos extratos da sociedade feudal como expressões das possibilidades pedagógicas de formação do homem nessa sociedade.The current article presents an analysis of medieval literature, as languages that express a period in the history and thus reveal real life and education in a society characterized by the Catholic church seal. Through all forms and modalities of language that we learnt the long development of humanity in the history construction and in this case, we will deal with texts of medieval literature from several extracts of feudal society as expressions of pedagogical possibilities of human development in such a society
summary: This article analyzes medieval literature as a powerful lens into the life and education of people in a society profoundly influenced by the Catholic Church. It explores various forms and modalities of language within medieval texts, drawn from different segments of feudal society. The purpose is to reveal the pedagogical possibilities for human development during this historical period, emphasizing how literature expresses the era and its educational practices. Key themes include medieval literature, history, education, language, and society.

title: Gay in the Sasanian period: some preliminary notes on its circular urban plan
abstract: This paper examines the Sasanian allegedly circular city of Gay, in the region of Isfahan. Material traces of the city have unfortunately been lost so we are forced to rely on Islamic literary sources alone. After an introduction discussing some aspects of the history of Gay, such as its foundation and possible founder, an attempt shall be made to reconstruct its layout according to the information available in medieval sources and through a comparison with the most renowned Sasanian circular city, Ardashīr Xwarrah/Fīrūzābād. Some hypotheses shall be advanced which aim to investigate new interesting features of the plan of Gay, in particular its connection with Sasanian astronomical beliefs
summary: This paper examines the allegedly circular Sasanian city of Gay in Isfahan, relying on Islamic literary sources due to the loss of material traces. It reconstructs Gay's layout by analyzing medieval texts and comparing it to Ardashir Xwarrah/Firuzabad, another renowned Sasanian circular city. The study also proposes hypotheses regarding Gay's urban plan, particularly its connection with Sasanian astronomical beliefs. Keywords include Iran, Isfahan, Sasanians circular city, and literary sources.

title: Ethnicity and the Writing of Medieval Scottish history
abstract: Historians have long tended to define medieval Scottish society in terms of interactions between ethnic groups. This approach was developed over the course of the long nineteenth century, a formative period for the study of medieval Scotland. At that time, many scholars based their analysis upon scientific principles, long since debunked, which held that medieval 'peoples' could only be understood in terms of 'full ethnic packages'. This approach was combined with a positivist historical narrative that defined Germanic Anglo-Saxons and Normans as the harbingers of advances of Civilisation. While the prejudices of that era have largely faded away, the modern discipline still relies all too often on a dualistic ethnic framework. This is particularly evident in a structure of periodisation that draws a clear line between the 'Celtic' eleventh century and the 'Norman' twelfth. Furthermore, dualistic oppositions based on ethnicity continue, particularly in discussions of the law, kingship, lordship and religion
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Scottish History, Historiography, Ethnicity, Cultural Studies
summary: This study examines the long-standing tendency in medieval Scottish historiography to define society through ethnic interactions, an approach rooted in nineteenth-century "scientific" and positivist narratives. These historical perspectives, now largely debunked, defined 'peoples' via 'full ethnic packages' and viewed Germanic Anglo-Saxons and Normans as catalysts for civilization. Despite the fading of overt prejudices, the modern discipline still frequently employs a dualistic ethnic framework, evident in periodization that differentiates a 'Celtic' eleventh century from a 'Norman' twelfth, and in discussions of law, kingship, lordship, and religion. The paper critiques the persistent reliance on these dualistic ethnic oppositions in the study of medieval Scotland.

title: What Has History to Do with Philosophy? Insights from the Medieval Contemplative Tradition
abstract: This paper highlights the corrective and complementary role that historically informed philosophy can play in contemporary discussions. What it takes for an experience to count as genuinely mystical has been the source of significant controversy; most current philosophical definitions of ‘mystical experience’ exclude embodied, non-unitive states -- but, in so doing, they exclude the majority of reported mystical experiences. I use a re- examination of the full range of reported medieval mystical experiences (both in the apophatic tradition, which excludes or denigrates embodied states, and in the affective tradition, which treats such states as fully mystical) to demonstrate how a better understanding of the historical medieval mystic tradition can serve as a valuable complement to ongoing philosophical discussions of religious and mystical experience
fieldOfStudy: History, Philosophy, Medieval Contemplative Tradition, Mystical Experience
summary: This paper argues for the corrective and complementary role of historically informed philosophy in contemporary discussions, particularly concerning the definition of "mystical experience." It critiques current philosophical definitions that exclude embodied, non-unitive states, thereby overlooking most reported mystical experiences. By re-examining medieval mystical traditions, including both apophatic and affective approaches, the author demonstrates how a deeper understanding of historical contexts can enrich ongoing philosophical debates on religious and mystical experience, offering valuable insights for semantic search into medieval mysticism and philosophy.

title: The emergence of mercantilism as a reaction against Muslim power: some of the evidences from history
abstract: In the early modern period, changing attitude of Medieval Europe towards trade as an outcome of encounter with Muslim scholars and rulers and consequently emergence of 'mercantilism' was a turning point in the history of economic thought. The paper documents evidences which prove that initially mercantilism was a reaction against Muslim powers. In the rise of mercantilism, discovery of the New World is considered a significant factor. The main objective before explorers and pioneers of mercantilism was to strengthen their governments through the acquisition of precious metal to regain the Holy Places, defeat the enemy, check the expanding power of Muslim rivals and spread Christianity. However, later it ended up in an effective economic movement.Mercantilism; History of Economic Thought; Medieval Economic History.
fieldOfStudy: History, Mercantilism, Economic Thought, Medieval Economic History
summary: This paper examines the emergence of mercantilism in early modern Europe, arguing it initially developed as a reaction against Muslim powers, significantly influenced by Medieval Europe's changing attitudes towards trade after encounters with Muslim scholars and rulers. It documents evidence suggesting that the primary objective of mercantilist pioneers, alongside the discovery of the New World, was to acquire precious metals to strengthen governments, regain Holy Places, defeat Muslim rivals, and spread Christianity, ultimately evolving into an effective economic movement. Key concepts include the history of economic thought and medieval economic history.

title: Newton Hall and the cruck buildings of North West England
abstract:
This study is an introduction to the archaeology and history of Newton Hall, Hyde, in Tameside. As a timber-framed cruck building from the late medieval period it is one of the oldest homes in North West England, and was one of the first such buildings to be restored for future generations in the 1960s. This study looks at Newton Hall

and its place within the cruck-framed building tradition

of the region, providing an overview of the development of the site and its regional importance. 95 cruck buildings are analysed within the Manchester city region, including their status, plan-form and construction details, and the study is illustrated with 122 colour plates and line drawings
publisher: Centre for Applied Archaeology, University of Salford
fieldOfStudy: History, Archaeology, Architectural History, Medieval Studies
summary: This study introduces the archaeology and history of Newton Hall, Hyde, a significant late medieval timber-framed cruck building in North West England. It examines Newton Hall's role within the regional cruck-framed building tradition and provides an overview of its development and importance. The research analyzes 95 cruck buildings in the Manchester city region, detailing their status, plan-form, and construction. Illustrated with numerous color plates and line drawings, this work contributes to the understanding of historical architecture and early domestic structures in the Tameside Borough.

title: La biblioteca digital de textos del español antiguo (BiDTEA)
abstract: El artículo ofrece una descripción pormenorizada de la historia, características de funcionamiento y contenidos de la Biblioteca Digital de Textos del Español Antiguo (BiDTEA) preparada por el Hispanic Seminary of Medieval Studies. BiDTEA ofrece acceso interactivo a transcripciones semi-paleográficas de testimonios concretos de obras producidas en el periodo medieval, una serie de índices (alfabético, frecuencia, alfabético inverso) yconcordancias en formato KWIC.The article offers a detailed description of the history, operating characteristics, and contents of the Biblioteca Digital de Textos del Español Antiguo (BiDTEA) prepared by the Hispanic Seminary of Medieval Studies. BiDTEA offers interactive access to semi-paleographical transcriptions of texts produced during the medieval period, a series of indices (alphabetic, frequency, reverse alphabetic), and KWIC concordances
fieldOfStudy: History, Digital Humanities, Medieval Studies, Philology
summary: This article details the history, operational features, and content of the Biblioteca Digital de Textos del Español Antiguo (BiDTEA), developed by the Hispanic Seminary of Medieval Studies. BiDTEA provides interactive access to semi-paleographical transcriptions of medieval Spanish texts, along with various indices (alphabetic, frequency, reverse alphabetic) and KWIC concordances. It serves as a crucial digital resource for researchers studying Old Castilian and Medieval Spanish, facilitating corpus analysis and historical linguistic investigations. The resource aims to preserve and make accessible valuable historical linguistic data.

title: Social change, ecology and climate in 20th-century Greenland
abstract: Two great transitions, from seal hunting to cod fishing, then from cod fishing to shrimp, affected population centers of southwest Greenland during the20th century. These economic transitions reflected large-scale shifts in the underlying marine ecosystems, driven by interactions between climate and human resource use. The combination of climatic variation and fishing pressure, for example, proved fatal to west Greenland\u27s cod fishery. We examine the history of these transitions, using data down to the level of individual municipalities. At this level,the uneven social consequences of environmental change show clearly: some places gained, while others lost. Developments in 20th-century Greenland resemble patterns of human-environment interactions in the medieval Norse settlements, suggesting some general propositions relevant to the human dimensions of climatic change
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
summary: This study examines two major economic transitions in southwest Greenland during the 20th century: from seal hunting to cod fishing, and then to shrimp fishing. These shifts reflect large-scale marine ecosystem changes, influenced by climate and human resource use, which proved fatal to the cod fishery. By analyzing data down to individual municipalities, the research highlights the uneven social consequences of environmental change. The observed human-environment interactions in 20th-century Greenland mirror patterns from medieval Norse settlements, offering general propositions for understanding the human dimensions of climatic change and ecological shifts.

title: RECEPCJA ŚREDNIOWIECZNYCH MOTYWÓW W ŚWIECIE GWIEZDNYCH WOJEN
abstract: The paper makes up an attempt to systematize and occasionally verify the views on the medieval motifs which were to be used while creating the world of Star Wars. The synchronic method applied in various publications lies behind opinions according to which the inspiration here included: Arthurian legends, the medieval concept of minne, visions of hell, the history and tradition of the Knights Templar, as well as the samurai in feudal Japan. These opinions cannot be regarded as entirely grounded. The remarks on the reception of some motifs related to the samurai or the Knights Templar seem justified as well as the plot of courtly love and the medieval image of hell. However, insistent juxtaposing, among others, of the individual stages of the lives of the saga’s main characters with the fortunes of king Arthur is controversial.The paper makes up an attempt to systematize and occasionally verify the views on the medieval motifs which were to be used while creating the world of Star Wars. The synchronic method applied in various publications lies behind opinions according to which the inspiration here included: Arthurian legends, the medieval concept of minne, visions of hell, the history and tradition of the Knights Templar, as well as the samurai in feudal Japan. These opinions cannot be regarded as entirely grounded. The remarks on the reception of some motifs related to the samurai or the Knights Templar seem justified as well as the plot of courtly love and the medieval image of hell. However, insistent juxtaposing, among others, of the individual stages of the lives of the saga’s main characters with the fortunes of king Arthur is controversial
fieldOfStudy: History, Star Wars, Middle Ages, Arthurian legends, image of hell, warriors
summary: This paper systematizes and verifies views on medieval motifs influencing the creation of Star Wars. It examines proposed inspirations such as Arthurian legends, the medieval concept of minne, visions of hell, the Knights Templar, and feudal Japanese samurai. The authors find reception of samurai and Knights Templar motifs, courtly love, and the medieval image of hell justified. However, drawing direct parallels between the lives of Star Wars characters and King Arthur's fortunes is deemed controversial. The study aims to clarify the extent to which these medieval elements genuinely shaped the saga's world.

title: The Orality of a Silent Age: The Place of Orality in Medieval Studies
abstract: 'The Orality of a Silent Age: The Place of Orality in Medieval Studies' uses a brief survey of current work on Old English poetry as the point of departure for arguing that although useful, the concepts of orality and literacy have, in medieval studies, been extended further beyond their literal referents of spoken and written communication than is heuristically useful. Recent emphasis on literate methods and contexts for the writing of our surviving Anglo-Saxon poetry, in contradistinction to the previous emphasis on oral ones, provides the basis for this criticism. Despite a significant amount of revisionist work, the concept of orality remains something of a vortex into which a range of only party related issues have been sucked: authorial originality/communal property; impromptu composition/meditated composition; authorial and audience alienation/immediacy. The relevance of orality to these issues is not in dispute; the problem is that they do not vary along specifically oral/literate axes. The article suggests that this is symptomatic of a wider modernist discourse in medieval studies whereby modern, literate society is (implicitly) contrasted with medieval, oral society: the extension of the orality/literacy axis beyond its literal reference has to some extent facilitated the perpetuation of an earlier contrast between primitivity and modernity which deserves still to be questioned and disputed. Pruning back our conceptions of the oral and the literate to their stricter denotations, we might hope to see more clearly what areas of medieval studies would benefit from alternative interpretations
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Studies, Orality and Literacy
summary: This article, "The Orality of a Silent Age: The Place of Orality in Medieval Studies," critically examines the concepts of orality and literacy within medieval studies, arguing they have been overextended beyond their literal meanings. Using Old English poetry as a case study, the author contends that while useful, the emphasis on these concepts has perpetuated a problematic contrast between primitivity and modernity. The article suggests that pruning these conceptions to their stricter denotations would allow for clearer alternative interpretations in medieval studies, particularly concerning issues like authorial originality, composition methods, and audience immediacy.

title: Трубізький форпост
abstract: Автор досліджує проблеми середньовічної історії України, розкриває питання порубіжної землі.The author envisages the problems of medieval history of Ukraine, covers the problems of boundary land
summary: This article explores the medieval history of Ukraine, focusing on the development and significance of the Pereyaslav fortress as a borderland stronghold. The study examines the reconstruction of ancient fortifications in 1585 by Kyiv voivode Kostiantyn Vasyl Ostrozkyi, who recognized the city's strategic importance for potash extraction and saltpeter production. The Pereyaslav fortress, strategically located between the Alt and Trubezh rivers, integrated traditional Old Rus' wooden-earthen defenses with elements of a bastion system. Subsequent reinforcements by Janusz Ostrozkyi and Janusz Zaslavskyi in the early 17th century further enhanced its protective capabilities. The fortress complex, spanning 1500 meters, housed the voivode's residence, a gunpowder depot, potash storage, provisions, and military arsenal, defended by mercenary garrisons. Keywords: medieval history, Ukraine, Pereyaslav fortress, bastion system, borderland, fortification.

title: Rubricating History in Late Medieval France
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, French Manuscripts, Paleography
