summary: This essay examines the role and function of rubrics in late medieval French manuscripts, focusing on historical texts like the "Grandes Chroniques de France" and "Chroniques" of Jean Froissart. It investigates why rubrics became a standard feature in textual production during the 14th and 15th centuries in France, analyzing their purpose for both authors and readers. The study also explores the specific practices involved in the rubrication process within manuscript production, highlighting the variation in paratextual systems across different textual traditions.

title: Reflections on the Asiatic Mode of Production in India
summary: This essay critically examines the historiographical debates surrounding Karl Marx's concept of the 'Asiatic Mode of Production' (AMP) and its applicability to pre-colonial, pre-capitalist societies, particularly in India. Motivated by frustrations with extreme polarity in historical discourse, the paper delves into longstanding discussions among South Asian historians regarding Marx's periodisation method and the definition of 'feudalism' in an Indian context. It compares and contrasts the AMP and feudalism, highlighting their perceived similarities and fundamental differences, drawing upon significant works like 'The Feudalism Debate'. This work seeks to advance the understanding of historical social formations and class development in South Asia.

title: British economic growth : 1270 - 1870
abstract:
We provide annual estimates of GDP for England between 1270 and 1700 and 

for Great Britain between 1700 and 1870, constructed from the output side. The GDP 

data are combined with population estimates to calculate GDP per capita. We find 

English per capita income growth of 0.20 per cent per annum between 1270 and 1700, 

although growth was episodic, with the strongest growth during the Black Death crisis of 

the fourteenth century and in the second half of the seventeenth century. For the period 

1700-1870, we find British per capita income growth of 0.48 per cent, broadly in line 

with the widely accepted Crafts/Harley estimates. This modest trend growth in per capita 

income since 1270 suggests that, working back from the present, living standards in the 

late medieval period were well above “bare bones subsistence”. This can be reconciled 

with modest levels of kilocalorie consumption per head because of the very large share of 

pastoral production in agriculture
publisher: Department of Economics, University of Warwick
summary: This study presents annual GDP estimates for England (1270-1700) and Great Britain (1700-1870) using an output-side construction, combined with population data to derive GDP per capita. Key findings indicate an English per capita income growth of 0.20% per annum between 1270-1700, with episodic increases during the Black Death and in the late seventeenth century. For 1700-1870, British per capita income grew at 0.48%, aligning with existing estimates. The research suggests that late medieval living standards were above "bare bones subsistence," reconciled by a significant share of pastoral production in agriculture. These findings are crucial for understanding long-term economic history and historical living standards.

title: Theorica et Practica: Historical Epistemology and the Re-Visioning of Thirteenth and Fourteenth-Century Medicine
abstract: Positivist medical historians, guided by the savoir of modern western biomedicine, have long depicted medieval medicine as an aberration along the continuum of scientific and medical progress. Historical epistemology, founded in the ideas of Cavailles, Foucault, Davidson, and Hacking, however, allows the historian to disrupt this false continuum and to unchain medieval medicine from modern medicine. Postmodernist approaches, such as those sourced in Lyotard, Barthes, and Derrida, allow the historian to further deconstruct medieval and modern medical discourse, revealing a multitude of narrative lenses spinning around biomedical and biocultural strands. In liberating these two medical systems and setting them within the distinct historical and epistemological contexts that both shaped and were shaped by them, the historian can revision the theories, practices, and culture of medieval medicine without having to anachronistically justify them according to modern medical discourse
summary: This article challenges positivist medical historians' depiction of medieval medicine as an aberration by employing historical epistemology and postmodernist approaches. Drawing on thinkers like Foucault, Davidson, Lyotard, and Derrida, the author aims to disrupt the false continuum between medieval and modern medicine. The methodology involves deconstructing existing medical discourse to reveal diverse narrative lenses around biomedical and biocultural strands. The main claim is that by setting these two medical systems within their distinct historical and epistemological contexts, historians can re-vision medieval medicine's theories, practices, and culture without anachronistically justifying them through modern medical discourse, ultimately liberating medieval medicine from modern medical hegemony.

title: The statutes of Iona : the archipelagic context
abstract: In recent decades, understanding of the historical development of Britain and Ireland has benefited significantly from the adoption of integrated approaches to the history of Britain and Ireland. While traditional national histories laid the foundation, the new British and Irish historiography has teased out many of the nuances arising from the interaction between the three kingdoms or four nations of Britain and Ireland. This approach has produced much scholarly work for both the medieval and early modern periods, although modern historians are still grappling with attempts to write a genuinely British history.1 For the early modern period in particular, the "three kingdoms" debate of the seventeenth century has advanced awareness of the complexity of regal union and the problems associated with one king ruling three distinct kingdoms. It is within this wider British context that James VI and I's efforts to integrate his three kingdoms need to be viewed. Although James's "earnist dispositioun to perfyte that Union"- brought about by his succession to the English throne on 1603-was thwarted by both the English and Scottish parliaments, James could not afford to govern either kingdom in isolation
summary: This paper examines the historical development of Britain and Ireland, emphasizing integrated approaches to historiography. It highlights how the "three kingdoms" debate of the seventeenth century advanced understanding of regal union complexities. Focusing on James VI and I's efforts to integrate his kingdoms, the study analyzes the Statutes of Iona and their impact on clan society, specifically landholding and tenant relations. The author argues that James, through conciliation with the Hebridean elite, aimed to align the Highlands with Scotland, demonstrating a traditional Stuart monarchical approach rather than solely punitive measures. Keywords: British and Irish history, historiography, James VI and I, Statutes of Iona, clan society, regal union.

title: Reseñas
abstract: Index de l'obra ressenyada: Linda KALOF, ed., A Cultural History of the Human Body in the Medieval Age. Oxford and New York: Berg, 2010 (hardback). London : Bloomsbury, 2014 (new edition)
fieldOfStudy: History of the Body, Medieval History
summary: This review critically examines "A Cultural History of the Human Body in the Medieval Age," edited by Linda Kalof, the second volume in a six-volume series. The series aims to consolidate recent scholarship on the history of the body and establish it as a distinct sub-discipline within History. The review highlights the book's success in providing a comprehensive survey of key topics, prominent scholars, and contemporary research in medieval body studies. It identifies the book as an accessible and essential reference for students and educators in medieval medicine and cultural history. The text also explores the body's role in individual identity and social constructs within medieval literature.

title: Decline and decadence in Iraq and Syria after the age of Avicenna? : ʿAbd al-Laṭīf al-Baghdādī (1162–1231) between myth and history
abstract:
‘Abd al-Laṭīf al-Baghdādī’s (d. 1231) work Book of the Two Pieces of Advice (Kitāb al Nasīḥatayn) challenges the idea that Islamic medicine declined after the twelfth century AD. Moreover, it offers some interesting insights into the social history of medicine. ‘Abd al-Laṭīf advocated using the framework of Greek medical epistemology to criticize the rationalist physicians of his day; he argued that female and itinerant practitioners, relying on experience, were superior to some rationalists. He lambasted contemporaneous medical education because it

put too much faith in a restricted number of textbooks such as the Canon by Ibn Sīnā (Avicenna, d. 1037) or imperfect abridgments
fieldOfStudy: History of Medicine, Medieval History, Islamic Studies
summary: 'Abd al-Laṭīf al-Baghdādī’s (d. 1231) work, Kitāb al Nasīḥatayn, challenges the conventional narrative of Islamic medicine's decline post-12th century, while also providing unique insights into the social history of medicine. Al-Baghdādī criticized contemporary rationalist physicians for over-reliance on limited textbooks like Avicenna's Canon. He championed female and itinerant practitioners, arguing their experiential knowledge was superior to that of some rationalists. This study examines his perspective to re-evaluate the historical progression and social dynamics within medieval Islamic medicine, emphasizing the diversity of medical practice and thought.

title: Medieval property investors, ca. 1300-1500
abstract: This paper utilises a dataset of freehold land and property transactions from medieval England to highlight the growing commercialisation of the economy.  By drawing on the legal records we are able to demonstrate that the medieval real estate market provided the opportunity for investors to profit. Careful analysis of the data provides evidence of group purchases, multiple transactions and investors buying outside of their own locality. The identification of these ‘investors’ and their buying behaviours, set within the context of the English medieval economy, contributes to the early commercialisation debate
summary: This paper investigates the growing commercialisation of the medieval English economy by analyzing a dataset of freehold land and property transactions from approximately 1300-1500. Utilizing legal records, the study demonstrates that the medieval real estate market presented profit opportunities for investors. Key findings include evidence of group purchases, multiple transactions, and investors acquiring property outside their local area. The identification of these 'investors' and their buying behaviors contributes significantly to the early commercialisation debate within the context of the English medieval economy. Keywords: medieval England, real estate, commercialisation, property investors, economic history.

title: Introduction
summary: This book explores medieval 'occasional rites' beyond the mass and office, such as baptism, burial, feast ceremonies, consecrations, and legal actions. It aims to address the infrequent university teaching of medieval liturgy despite renewed interest. The contributors, primarily medieval historians rather than liturgists, investigate these rituals as evidence for understanding medieval history, particularly how they involved and adapted for the laity. The book highlights the dynamic nature of medieval liturgy and its potential for improving our understanding of the Middle Ages.

title: Cultural contacts and ethnic origins in Viking Age Wales and northern Britain: the case of Albanus, Britain's first inhabitant and Scottish ancestor
abstract: Albanus, an eponymous ancestor for the kingdom of Alba, provides an example of the extent to which the creation of an ethnic identity was accompanied by new ideas about origins, which replaced previous accounts. Through an analysis of the Historia Brittonum’s textual tradition and Welsh knowledge of early Roman history and medieval ethnic groups, this article establishes that Albanus was added to the Historia Brittonum in the late ninth or early tenth century as an ancestral figure for the new kingdom of Alba in northern Britain. This was potentially a result of shared political situations in Gwynedd, Alba (formerly Pictland) and Strathclyde in relation to Scandinavian power at this time, which encouraged contacts and the spread of Alba-based ideology to Gwynedd. The later development of this idea and its significance in Alba itself, Geoffrey of Monmouth's account and English claims to supremacy over Scotland are also traced
summary: This article explores the creation of ethnic identity through new ideas about origins, focusing on Albanus, an eponymous ancestor for the kingdom of Alba. By analyzing the Historia Brittonum's textual tradition and Welsh knowledge of Roman history and medieval ethnic groups, the study establishes that Albanus was added to Historia Brittonum in the late ninth or early tenth century as an ancestral figure for the new kingdom of Alba. This addition may stem from shared political situations in Gwynedd, Alba, and Strathclyde during the Viking Age, encouraging contacts and the spread of Alba-based ideology. The paper also traces the later development of this idea and its significance in Alba, Geoffrey of Monmouth's account, and English claims to Scottish supremacy, highlighting the ongoing formation of ethnic origin accounts.

title: She Shall Be Saved in Childbearing: Submission, Contemplation of Conception, and Annunciation Imagery in the Books of Hours of Two Late Medieval Noblewomen
abstract: The role of the Book of Hours in female lay devotional life during the late Middle Ages has been investigated and analyzed by many scholars and art historians over the course of the past century. The general consensus has been that semi-literate medieval women valued these books greatly as instructional manuals on how to attain salvation, using the images contained within as spiritual aids meant to encourage individual contemplation and pious recitation. Prayers for mediation, protection, and guidance featured prominently within these books and many historians of both genders have come to the conclusion that Books of Hours were a source of comfort and spiritual nourishment for women living in a male-dominated and male-oriented world. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Women's History, History of Religion
summary: This study investigates the role of Books of Hours in the devotional lives of late medieval noblewomen, focusing on themes of submission, conception, and Annunciation imagery. Challenging traditional views that these books were solely instructional manuals for salvation, the analysis considers how images and prayers also supported dynastic and familial aspirations. By examining historical perspectives and specific examples like Jeanne d'Evreux, the paper argues that Books of Hours served as unique devotional guides, encouraging pious and obedient lives in pursuit of various forms of salvation beyond individual redemption. Key concepts include medieval women, lay devotion, religious imagery, and societal roles.

title: Is “Race” Modern? Disambiguating the Question
abstract: Race theorists have been unable to reach a consensus regarding the basic historical question, “is ‘race’ modern?” I argue that this is partly because the question itself is ambiguous. There is not really one question that race scholars are answering, but at least six. First, is the concept of race modern? Second, is there a modern concept of race that is distinct from earlier race concepts? Third, are “races” themselves modern? Fourth, are racialized groups modern? Fifth, are the means and methods associated with racialization modern? And sixth, are the meanings attached to racialized traits modern? Because these questions have different answers, the debate about the historical origins of “race” cannot be resolved unless they are distinguished. I will explain the ways in which “race” is and is not modern by answering these questions, thereby offering a resolution to a seemingly intractable problem
summary: This paper addresses the long-standing debate among race theorists about whether "race" is a modern phenomenon. The author argues that the lack of consensus stems from the ambiguity of the question itself, which encompasses at least six distinct inquiries: the modernity of the concept of race, the existence of a distinct modern race concept, the modernity of "races" themselves, racialized groups, means of racialization, and meanings of racialized traits. By distinguishing and answering these specific questions, the study aims to provide a clear resolution to the complex historical origins of race, offering insights into racial formation and periodization. The research contributes to understanding the history of race and racialized groups.

title: Review Of  The Medieval Spains  By B. F. Reilly
summary: This work presents a review of B. F. Reilly's "The Medieval Spains," offering a comprehensive overview of medieval Iberian history. The reviewer, Stephen P. Bensch, highlights Reilly's work as a reliable guide for American and English students exploring the diverse aspects of Spanish history, particularly moving beyond a narrow focus on the Catholic Monarchs. The review also touches on the transformation of medieval Galicia in the 12th and 13th centuries, driven by agricultural improvements and land control by nobles and the church, with land exploitation often managed through the "foro" contract.

title: Marion most bold : feminine transgression in the greenwood
abstract: In my project, I focus on the role and depiction of women found in the Robin Hood greenwood: specifically, those of Maid Marian. Maid Marian rarely appears in early Robin Hood texts, and especially not in a capacity in which she herself speaks, so it is striking that today she has become almost as synonymous with the greenwood in Robin Hood tales as the man himself. Indeed, one of the rare instances in which Marian plays a lead role occurs in the seventeenth-century ballad “Robin Hood and Maid Marian,” which appears in only one manuscript, after the original Robin Hood ballads of the Middle Ages, and does not seem to have been popular. This seventeenth-century ballad allots Maid Marian an agency typically reserved only for Robin’s merry men. Though I agree that Marian exhibits certain transgressive behaviors, especially in “Robin Hood and Maid Marian,” by the end of Robin Hood texts—medieval, early modern, or otherwise—though the space of the greenwood allows a certain level of freedom for the men in the texts, the “good” women in the Robin Hood texts remain noble ladies who still act as they ought to even though they live outside the confines of civilized society. The same social rules of urban society continue to apply to them, and even in the few cases where the women get to demonstrate more traditionally masculine qualities, they still must end up back in their proper role at the end of the Robin Hood ballad or play.Englis
summary: This project examines the evolving role and portrayal of Maid Marian in Robin Hood narratives, focusing on her infrequent appearance and limited voice in early texts versus her later prominence. It specifically analyzes the seventeenth-century ballad “Robin Hood and Maid Marian,” where Marian exhibits unusual agency. Despite instances of transgressive behavior, particularly in this ballad, the study argues that throughout medieval and early modern Robin Hood texts, even women granted some freedom in the greenwood ultimately revert to traditional societal roles, maintaining their status as noble ladies despite their outlaw setting. Keywords: Maid Marian, Robin Hood, greenwood, medieval literature, ballad, gender roles, feminine transgression.

title:
The Medieval Inquisition: Scale-free Networks and the Suppression of
  Heresy
abstract:
Qualitative evidence suggests that heresy within the medieval Catholic Church
had many of the characteristics of a scale-free network. From the perspective
of the Church, heresy can be seen as a virus. The virus persisted for long
periods of time, breaking out again even when the Church believed it to have
been eradicated. A principal mechanism of heresy was through a small number of
individuals with very large numbers of social contacts.
  Initial attempts by the Inquisition to suppress the virus by general
persecution, or even mass slaughtering, of populations thought to harbour the
"disease" failed. Gradually, however, the Inquisition learned about the nature
of the social networks by which heresy both spread and persisted. Eventually, a
policy of targeting key individuals was implemented, which proved to be much
more successful.Comment: 12 page
summary: This study analyzes heresy within the medieval Catholic Church as a scale-free network, akin to a persistent virus. It suggests that heresy spread through a small number of influential individuals with extensive social contacts. Early attempts by the Inquisition to suppress heresy through general persecution failed. However, the Inquisition eventually learned the nature of these social networks and adopted a more successful strategy of targeting key individuals. This research offers insights into historical epidemiology, social network dynamics, and the effectiveness of targeted suppression policies against societal 'viruses'.

title: A középkori Székelyföld  =  The Medieval Székelys (Hungarian minority group in Eastern Transylvania, Romania)
abstract: A pályázat a középkori Székelyföld történetének és régészetének monografikus igényű kutatására vállalkozott. A munka három témakör köré csoportosult:   I. Egy, a közelmúltban feltárt, rendkívül gazdag leletanyagot rejtő, 15-16. századi székelykeresztúri udvarház monografikus feldolgozása elkészült és 2008-ban nyomtatásban megjelent. A monográfia az udvarházak és ezek leletei, különösképpen kályhacsempéi és tüzelőberendezései elemzésén túlmenően a középkori székelyföldi nemesség kérdését is áttekintette. E témakörben külön tanulmány is készült. A székelyföldi várakról és védelmi célra felhasznált barlangokról több tanulmány is megjelent (Sófalvi András, Székelyudvarhely).  II. A késő középkori, kora újkori csíksomlyói ferences kolostorra vonatkozó kéziratos források (oklevelek, számadáskönyvek és leltárak, elbeszélő források) kiadása már a sajtó alá rendezéshez közeledik (Muckenhaupt Erzsébet, Csíkszereda).  III. A pályázat alapvető célját képező, a a középkori Székelyföld régészetét és történetét felölelő monográfia kézirata három részből áll: 1) több fejezetre oszló történeti-régészeti összefoglalás, terjedelmes illusztrációs anyaggal (Benkő Elek); 2) a székelyföldi középkori állatcsontanyag vizsgálata és értékelése (Gál Erika, Budapest); 3) A középkori Székelyföld embertani anyagának teljességre törekvő feldolgozása (Fóthi Erzsébet, Bernert Zsolt, Hajdu Tamás, Budapest). A kötet legfontosabb megállapításai magyarul, illetve németül külön is megjelentek (Benkő Elek).  |  The project aspired to process the medieval history and archaeology of the Szekler Region in eastern Transylvania. The major themes were assembled in three fields:   I. Working up a medieval manor house excavated in the last years at Cristuru Secuiesc, a monograph was published in 2008, which inclused, in addition to the treatment of different types of manor houses and their findings  a  survey on medieval nobility of the Szekler Region. About medieval castles and caves converted to defensive purposes several publications were elaborated (András  Sófalvi).  II. The transcript and annotation of late medieval and early modern written sources (documents, accounts, consriptions and chronicles) of the franciscan friary of Csíksomlyó is in the final stage before publication (Erzsébet Muckenhaupt).  III. The manuscript of a comprehensive book about the history and archaeology of the Szekler Region contains threee great parts: 1) a large study, divided into several chapters  on different historical and archaeological problems from the the much-disputed issues of the early history and 'origin' of the Szeklers untill the 16th-17th centuries, including an instructive case study of  sedes (village law court) Aranyos (Elek Benkő), 2) the working up of animal bones of medieval villages, market-towns, castles and manor houses (Erika Gál) and 3) the analysis of the complete medieval anthropological material of the Szekler Region (Erzsébet Fóthi, Zsolt Bernert, Tamás Hajdu)
summary: This project aimed to comprehensively research the medieval history and archaeology of the Szekler Region, eastern Transylvania, building on previous OTKA projects. It involved three main areas: a monograph on a 15th-16th century manor house in Cristuru Secuiesc, including analysis of nobility, castles, and defensive caves; the transcription and annotation of late medieval and early modern written sources for the Csíksomlyó Franciscan friary; and a comprehensive book on Szekler history and archaeology, incorporating natural sciences, zooarchaeology, and anthropological analysis. The work included museum research, new excavation summaries, and surveying fortifications and churches.

title: VI. Renaissance Humanism
abstract: Between the end of the High Middle Ages (about 1350) and the Protestant Reformation in the sixteenth century, the character of Western Civilization was profoundly altered. Earlier chapters have already told how most institutions and values characteristic of the High Middle Ages began to disintegrate. Meanwhile, other institutions and ideas, many of which we think of as modern, gradually came to the fore. The intensification of this process of transition from medieval to modern is called the Renaissance. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This chapter examines Renaissance Humanism, a period from the late High Middle Ages (circa 1350) to the 16th-century Protestant Reformation, marking a profound transition in Western Civilization. It explores how medieval institutions and values began to decline while modern ideas emerged, leading to significant cultural alterations. The text highlights how the Renaissance, while building upon medieval foundations, introduced new and vital elements, emphasizing the dynamic interplay of conflicting societal aspects like individualism, change, and realism, and how each age uniquely balanced these forces. Keywords: Renaissance, Humanism, Western Civilization, Middle Ages, Protestant Reformation, cultural history, medieval institutions.

title: Passion and Conflict: Medieval Islamic Views of the West
abstract: This article analyzes the representation of al-Andalus and North Africa in medieval Islamic maps from the eleventh to the fifteenth centuries. In contrast to other maps of the Mediterranean, which display a veneer of harmony and balance, the image of the Maghrib is by deliberate design one of conflict and confusion; of love and hate; of male vs. female; of desire vs rejection. This paper interprets and explains the reasons behind the unusual depiction of Andalus and the Maghrib by medieval Islamic cartographers. In addition, this article develops a new methodology of interpreting medieval Islamic maps employing a deconstruction of the forms through an analysis of different levels of gaze. The analysis unfolds into the use of erotic and nostalgic Hispano-Arabic poetry as a lens of interpretation for Islamic maps
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Islamic World and Near East History, Medieval Studies, Cartography
summary: This article examines the portrayal of al-Andalus and North Africa in medieval Islamic maps spanning the eleventh to fifteenth centuries. It highlights a deliberate depiction of conflict, confusion, love, and hate in the Maghrib, contrasting with the harmony often found in other Mediterranean maps. The paper interprets the reasons for this unusual cartographic representation using a new methodology that deconstructs forms through analyzing different levels of gaze. It further employs erotic and nostalgic Hispano-Arabic poetry as an interpretive lens for these Islamic maps, offering insights into medieval Islamic views of the West.

title: Gerald of Wales and Competing Interpretations of the Welsh Middle Ages c. 1870-1910
summary: This article examines the shift in conceptualizing Welsh medieval history from approximately 1870-1910. Initially dominated by antiquarian and mythic approaches, the field transitioned towards source-based, narrative syntheses, reflecting a broader European trend in national history-writing. The study highlights how interpretations of Gerald of Wales and his 'Description of Wales' were shaped by competing scholarly outlooks and political agendas of leading historians, despite the era being considered the genesis of modern historical method. It cautions against over-reliance on perceived objectivity and emphasizes the enduring influence of worldview and bias in historical interpretation, offering insights for contemporary scholars.

title: The Thousand-Year Spiritual Tradition of Lesnovo Monastery in Macedonia
abstract: Through the rich Christian tradition in Macedonia from the early Christian, medieval and up to the modern period numerous churches and monasteries were built, where all forms of development of spiritual and cultural life took place. A historically remarkable location is Lesnovo Monastery, which has survived until today during almost one thousand years of spiritual and cultural tradition in Macedonia. The oldest indirect and legendary sources point to the conclusion that the original construction of the monastic church in Lesnovo should be moved to the period of the eleventh century, when from 1018 onwards, after the fall of Samuil\u27s Slavic reign on the territory of Macedonia, the Byzantine state, political, and church protectorate was restored. As a consequence of the resistance to the restored Byzantine spiritual protectorate and the suppression of the established Slavic church tradition in this northeastern part of Macedonia, the anachoretic monasticism was revived, and as a reflection of the rising cult to the venerable hermit, St. Gavril of Lesnovo, the Lesnovo monastery was also affirmed. Its history directly reflects all the forms of spiritual and cultural tradition in Macedonia. In 2017, when the jubilee, the fiftieth anniversary of the restoration of the autocephaly of the Ohrid Archbishopric (1967-2017) as the Macedonian Orthodox Church - Ohrid Archbishopric is celebrated, the former abbot of the Lesnovo monastery Father Gabriel of Mt. Athos and Bishop of Velika was canonized as a saint (†12 January 1990). This blessed Christian act enriched the 10-century long spiritual tradition of the Lesnovo Monastery with the glory and honor of the holy Archangels Michael and Gabriel, of the venerable hermit Gavril of Lesnovo and of the Holy Bishop of Velika, the venerable Gavril Svetogorac (of Lesnovo)
fieldOfStudy: History, Christianity, Eastern European Studies, Religious History, Macedonian Orthodox Church
summary: This article explores the thousand-year spiritual and cultural tradition of Lesnovo Monastery in Macedonia, highlighting its historical significance from the 11th century to the modern period. It discusses the monastery's origins amidst Byzantine spiritual protectorate and the revival of anachoretic monasticism, particularly the cult of St. Gavril of Lesnovo. The paper also details the 2017 canonization of Father Gabriel of Mt. Athos and Bishop of Velika, formally linked to the fiftieth anniversary of the restoration of the Ohrid Archbishopric. This act further enriched the monastery's enduring spiritual heritage, honoring its patron saints and revered figures.

title: The audience for Old English texts: Ælfric, rhetoric and ‘the edification of the simple’
abstract: There is a persistent view that Old English texts were mostly written to be read or heard by people with no knowledge of Latin, or little understanding of it, especially the laity. This is not surprising because it is what the texts themselves tend to say. In this article I argue that these statements about audience reflect two rhetorical devices and should not be understood literally. This has implications for our understanding of the reasons why writers chose to use Old English and their attitudes towards translation of various kinds into the vernacular
summary: This article challenges the persistent view that Old English texts were primarily written for a lay audience with limited Latin knowledge. The author argues that statements within these texts about their audience should be interpreted as rhetorical devices rather than literal accounts. This re-evaluation has significant implications for understanding the motivations behind writers' use of Old English and their approaches to vernacular translation. By exploring figures like Ælfric and scholarly perspectives, the research sheds light on the confidence Anglo-Saxon writers had in Old English as a medium for scholarly and religious discourse, on par with Latin, influencing our understanding of medieval literature and language.

title: Warriors, heroes and companions: negotiating masculinity in Viking-Age England
abstract:
Detailed analysis of the construction of gender identities has transformed our understanding of many aspects of early

medieval society, yet the study of the Vikings in Britain has largely remained immune to this branch of scholarship. In

responding to this lacuna, this paper examines the gendered dimension of the funerary record of the Scandinavians

in England in the ninth and tenth centuries, and suggests that the emphasis on masculine display, in both the burial

and the sculptural record, is not merely a quirk of survival, but rather it has much to reveal about the negotiation of

lordship in the context of conquest and settlement
summary: This paper addresses a scholarly gap by analyzing the gendered dimensions of Scandinavian funerary records in ninth and tenth-century England, a period of Viking conquest and settlement. It argues that the prominent display of masculinity in both burial practices and sculptural artifacts is not coincidental. Instead, this emphasis offers crucial insights into how lordship was negotiated and expressed during this transformative era, challenging prior understandings of early medieval society. The study focuses on gender identities, funerary archaeology, Viking Age, and the socio-political dynamics of masculinity in historical contexts.

title: La Història Militar de la Corona d’Aragó a la Baixa Edat Mitjana: passat present i futur
abstract: La història militar de la Corona d’Aragó començà quan els reis d’Aragó escrigueren les seves cròniques i els seus documents, i diversos historiadores basaren les seves recerques en aquestes fonts. Quan les noves tendències historiogràfiques desenvolupades a mitjan segle XX arribaren a Espanya, la història militar de l’Edat Mitjana va quedar marginada. Aquest article mostra la manera com  aquest problema afectà la recerca històrica sobre la Corona d’Aragó a l’Edat Mitjana, i com la disciplina s’està recuperant lentament per a esdevenir un nou i interessant enfocament per al medievalisme.The military history of the Aragon medieval Crown began when the kings of Aragon wrote their chronicles and records, and several historians developed their research on these sources. When the historiographical tendencies developed from the middle of the XXth century arrived in Spain, the military history of the Middle Ages became marginalized. This paper shows the way this problem affected the historical research on the Aragon medieval Crown, and how the discipline is slowly recovering and becoming an interesting new focus for medieval research
summary: This article examines the marginalization and subsequent slow recovery of military history research concerning the Crown of Aragon in the Middle Ages. Historically, this field relied on chronicles and records by Aragonese kings and was later affected by new historiographical trends from the mid-20th century, which led to its decline. The paper highlights how this issue impacted historical research and argues for its renewed significance as an interesting new focus within medieval studies. Keywords: Military history, Middle Ages, historiography, Crown of Aragon.

title: 3. Bonaventura and Medieval Mysticism
abstract: Throughout the whole history of religious experience there have been two supplementary emphases, the rational and the non-rational, which have vied with each other for men\u27s allegiance. The Thomistic synthesis, with its stress on reason and how reason could prove the existence of God, was thought by many, including St. Bonaventura (1221-1274), to press too far the rational side of religion and thus to detract from the other side, which emphasizes the free g~it of faith, intuitive insight, and mystical experience. This rational emphasis, thought Bonaventura, could lead to intellectual pride and arrogance. It could also lead to a minimizing of that aspect of God which his Augustinian and Neoplatonic leanings led him to stress: the absolute sovereignty of God. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This chapter examines the historical tension between rational and non-rational approaches to religious experience, focusing on Bonaventura's critique of Thomistic rationalism. Bonaventura, influenced by Augustinian and Neoplatonic thought, emphasized the free gift of faith, intuitive insight, and mystical experience, contrasting with the reliance on reason to prove God's existence. The work explores how Bonaventura's views, particularly in "The Journey of the Mind to God," highlight aspects of religious experience beyond rationality, while also stressing his adherence to orthodox Church teachings. It discusses the potential for intellectual pride in rationalism and the dangers of mystics straying from ecclesiastical discipline, contributing to the understanding of religious diversity in the High Middle Ages.

title: Custom in context : Medieval and Early Modern Scotland and England
abstract: Studying custom and its context gives unique insights into relations of property, production and law in a society. The first part of the article discusses meaning in Scotland, focusing on ‘custom as normative practice, custom as unwritten law, and custom in opposition to law’. The second seeks to demonstrate (using evidence focusing principally on landholding) that custom as legal currency was more restricted for Scots than English. The third sets out the implications for continuity of landholding and for agrarian change in the Highlands of Scotland, an area where custom might be thought strong. The fourth deals with the differential legal development of Scotland and England between the twelfth and eighteenth centuries and its effects on social and tenurial relationships. A final section suggests why custom mattered more as a resource to the English, the domains in which it was important to Scots and the implications for understanding the comparative development of the two societies since the Middle Ages.PostprintPeer reviewe
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Legal History, Social History
summary: This article investigates the role of custom in shaping property, production, and law in Scotland and England from the medieval to early modern periods. It explores custom as normative practice, unwritten law, and in opposition to formal law, particularly focusing on landholding. The study demonstrates that custom held more restricted legal currency in Scotland compared to England, examining the implications for landholding continuity and agrarian change in the Scottish Highlands. It also analyzes the differential legal development between the two nations and its effects on social and tenurial relationships, concluding with why custom was a more significant resource for the English.

title: Back from Shingly: revisiting the premodern history of Jews in Kerala
abstract: Jewish history in Kerala is based on sources mainly from the colonial period onward and mostly in European languages, failing to account for the premodern history of Jews in Kerala. These early modern sources are based on oral traditions of Paradeśi Jews in Cochin, who view the majority of Kerala Jews as inferior. Consequently, the premodern history of Kerala Jews remains untold, despite the existence of premodern sources that undermine unsupported notions about the premodern history of Kerala Jews—a Jewish ‘ur-settlement’ called Shingly in Kodungallur and a centuries-old isolation from world Jewry. This article reconstructs Jewish history in premodern Kerala solely based on premodern travelogues and literature on the one hand and on historical documents in Old Malayalam, Hebrew and Judeo-Arabic on the other hand. Sources of the early modern period are then examined for tracing the origins of the Shingly myth, arguing that the incorporation of the Shingly legend into the historiography of Kerala Jews was affected by contacts with European Jews in the Age of Discoveries rather than being a reflection of historical events
summary: This article reconstructs the premodern history of Jews in Kerala, challenging previous accounts largely based on colonial-era European sources and oral traditions of Paradeśi Jews. It argues that these earlier narratives often overlooked or misrepresented the premodern period, particularly the unsupported notions of a Jewish 'ur-settlement' called Shingly and centuries of isolation from world Jewry. The research meticulously analyzes premodern travelogues, literature, and historical documents in Old Malayalam, Hebrew, and Judeo-Arabic. It further examines early modern sources to trace the origins of the Shingly myth, suggesting its integration into historiography was influenced by European Jewish contacts during the Age of Discoveries, rather than historical events. Keywords: Jewish history, Kerala, premodern, Shingly myth, Paradeśi Jews, historical reconstruction.

title: Hospitaller activities in medieval Malta
abstract: The Medieval Period in the Mediterranean World is generaly considered to cover a period of about a thousand years, and is considered to initiate with the end of the Roman era heralded by the division of the Roman Empure into two parts between the sons of Theodosius in AD 395. It ended with the advent of the Renaissance movement of the fifteenth century. This period in Malta was to see the Islands come under the influence of the Byzantine Empire encompassing the period prior to the ninth century; the Arab dominance starting in AD 870 and lasting until their formal expulsion in the mid-13th century; and the Latin phase of the late 13th century to the early 16th century when the islands were ceded to the Order of St. John of Jerusalem. The documentary sources dated to before the 14th century are rather scanty and often limited to ecclesiastical and political matters. A number of extant documents relate to medical matters, particularly with the setting up and management of hospital services and with matters relating to the affairs of hospitaller orders having links to the Maltese Islands.peer-reviewe
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Malta, Medical History
summary: This article explores hospitaller activities in medieval Malta, a period spanning from the 4th to the 15th century, marked by Byzantine, Arab, and Latin influences. It focuses on the establishment and management of hospital services and the affairs of hospitaller orders linked to the Maltese Islands. While early documentary sources are scarce and primarily cover ecclesiastical and political matters, a significant number of extant documents relate to medical matters. The study utilizes these documents to trace the historical development of healthcare provisions during these varied epochs. This historical perspective sheds light on the evolution of medical practices and institutions in Malta through medieval times.

title: Tolkien, Eucatastrophe, and the Re-Creation of Medieval Legend
abstract: Using comparative literary analysis, this essay examines three case studies from J.R.R. Tolkien’s oeuvre, in which Tolkien practiced eucatastrophic rewriting: his folk-tale, “Sellic Spell,” in which he re-creates the Old English poem Beowulf; his poem, “Princess Mee,” in which he re-envisions aspects of the myth of Narcissus and the Middle English dream vision poem, Pearl; and the character of Éowyn from The Lord of the Rings, in which he re-imagines the fate of Brynhild, a shield-maiden and valkyrie from Norse legend. In each case, Tolkien rewrites the original so that sorrow is transformed into happiness in Tolkien’s new versions. As part of the analysis of these transformations, this essay also considers a possible personal motivation as well as a larger purpose behind Tolkien’s artistic choices: his relationship to his beloved wife, Edith, and a desire to convey to others the hope he found in his own Christian faith
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Studies, Modern Literature, Reading and Language, Translation Studies
summary: This essay employs comparative literary analysis to explore J.R.R. Tolkien's practice of eucatastrophic rewriting across three works: "Sellic Spell" (re-creating Beowulf), "Princess Mee" (re-envisioning Narcissus and Pearl), and the character Éowyn from The Lord of the Rings (re-imagining Brynhild). The study details how Tolkien transforms sorrow into happiness in his retellings. It also considers potential motivations for his artistic choices, including his relationship with his wife Edith and a desire to convey Christian hope. Key themes include medieval legend, literary transformation, and mythological re-creation.

title: Science in Theology : Studies in the Interaction Between Late Medieval Natural Philosophy, Logic, and Theology
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Intellectual History, Theology, Philosophy
summary: This thesis explores the interaction between late medieval natural philosophy, logic, and theology, focusing on Roger Roseth's Lectura super Sententias. The study aims to make Roseth's text accessible and to trace the close relationship between late medieval theology and the arts faculties. It argues against a "nonstandard logic of faith" interpretation of Roseth's solutions to Trinitarian paralogisms, demonstrating that his logical rules apply equally to philosophical problems like those in Platonic metaphysics. The work includes three research papers and a critical edition of questions 3, 4, and 5 from Roseth's Lectura, based on all extant manuscripts.

title: When did Robert of Torigni first receive Henry of Huntingdon’s Historia Anglorum, and why does it matter?
summary: This article aims to clarify the precise timeline of Robert of Torigni's access to Henry of Huntingdon's *Historia Anglorum* (HA), a matter previously debated chronologically among historians. The study investigates whether Robert received the HA manuscript in 1139 or later, when Henry's work had expanded. By analyzing the dynamics of their intertextual relationship and the communication channels between the two medieval historians, the research offers an innovative lens for understanding similar textual interactions and contexts. Key methods involve detailed chronological analysis and manuscript study to establish the exact moment of transmission and its broader historical significance beyond just these two works.

title: Arts
abstract: For historians of medieval Iberian art and architecture, María Rosa Menocal’s most important legacy lies in her work’s normalization of a culturally decentralized, multidisciplinary frame through which medieval visual objects became part of a broadly shared network of cultural production that was unrestricted by firm boundaries between particular polities or “faith groups.” While Menocal was not the first to advance such an approach, her persuasive promotion of it in works such as The Ornament of the World and the co-authored The Arts of Intimacy dovetailed closely with concurrent trends within the discipline of art history: new attentiveness to the variability of the Iberian cultural economy; a renewed concern with questions of reception and meaning; revived emphasis on close, contextual readings; and an openness to extra-disciplinary methodologies. The conceptual and disciplinary flexibility that Menocal’s work encouraged now lies at the very heart of current work on Iberian visual culture
fieldOfStudy: History, Art History, Medieval Studies, Iberian Studies
summary:
This article examines the enduring legacy of Mar
ía Rosa Menocal in the historiography of medieval Iberian art and architecture. It highlights how Menocal's work normalized a culturally decentralized, multidisciplinary framework, viewing medieval visual objects within a shared network of cultural production beyond rigid political or religious boundaries. Her persuasive promotion of this approach, notably in "The Ornament of the World" and "The Arts of Intimacy," aligned with art history trends emphasizing Iberian cultural economy, reception, meaning, contextual readings, and interdisciplinary methodologies. Menocal's conceptual and disciplinary flexibility remains central to contemporary scholarship on Iberian visual culture.

title: The role of zooarchaeology in the interpretation of socioeconomic status: a discussion with reference to Medieval Europe
abstract: Social inequality is ubiquitous in human society, and the concept of social standing has been of fundamental importance throughout time (Price and Feinman 1995). The inference of social status has encountered problems in many areas of archaeology (see Orser 1990; Grenville 1997), and the use of zooarchaeology as part of an integrated approach may contribute to our understanding of important issues (Crabtree 1990). This paper reviews the various criteria used to infer socioeconomic status from faunal assemblages, taking examples from a variety of contexts, but concentrating primarily on medieval Europe, and England in particular. The problems associated with the application of zooarchaeological methods to this sphere of research are discussed, and some possible solutions proposed. It is suggested that zooarchaeology can play an important role in answering questions relating to socioeconomic standing, provided that it forms part of a wider archaeological strategy
summary: This paper explores the utility of zooarchaeology in inferring socioeconomic status within archaeological contexts, particularly focusing on medieval Europe and England. It reviews various criteria used to deduce status from faunal assemblages, discusses the challenges associated with applying zooarchaeological methods in this research area, and proposes potential solutions. The study suggests that zooarchaeology can significantly contribute to understanding socioeconomic standing when integrated into a broader archaeological strategy, addressing the ubiquitous issue of social inequality in human societies.

title: "After his death great tribulation came to Italy…" Dynastic politics and aristocratic factions after the death of Louis II, c.870-c.890
abstract: PostprintPeer reviewe
summary: This article re-evaluates the political landscape of Italy following the death of Emperor Louis II (875), challenging the traditional view of a simple decline in royal authority. It argues that the factionalism dominating Italian politics during this period was not merely due to disruptive aristocratic power but was significantly shaped by fluctuating patterns of royal patronage. The study emphasizes that dynastic and aristocratic politics remained intimately linked within a Carolingian framework until 888, after which the struggle for kingship between native competitors marked a true breach. The authors contend that kings always mattered in early medieval politics, advocating for a re-evaluation of Italian political history during this era. Key terms include Louis II, Italy, Carolingians, dynastic politics, aristocratic factions, and medieval history.

title: The trust: the invention of the uses and the Franciscan influence in England
summary: This paper investigates prominent theories concerning the genesis of the English trust device during the Middle Ages. It specifically focuses on the contribution of the Franciscans to the development of the 'use.' The author argues for a more thorough examination of Franciscan influence, particularly in light of continental debates surrounding apostolic poverty and church property. Key aspects include the origins of the trust, the invention of uses, Franciscan influence in England, and the interplay of religious and legal concepts in medieval common law. The study aims to enrich understanding of this fundamental legal instrument's historical evolution.

title: Analogy, Semantics, and Hermeneutics: The “Concept versus Judgment” Critique of Cajetan’s De Nominum Analogia
abstract: Page range: 241-26
summary: This article examines twentieth-century criticisms of Cajetan's theory of analogy in "De Nominum Analogia," which argue that medieval Aristotelian semantic assumptions regarding discrete 'concepts' and propositional meaning are inadequate for complex human discourse. The author argues that these criticisms are unfounded when considering Cajetan's semantic principles and hermeneutic practice. The study defends Cajetan's work and clarifies philosophical alternatives within the traditional Aristotelian semantic framework, concluding that Cajetan's approach, while conceptualist and compositionalist, is also organicist, where the meaning of parts is determined by interpretation and contextual attention.

title: Narcissus in Queer Time
abstract: Queer temporality has been studied in relation to the Middle Ages as a means of questioning the prevailing historiography for other modes of connection to the past, such as embodied or affective. Conversely, the other branch of queer temporality has been primarily interested in how queer lifestyles today disrupt the heteronormative plan laid out by society. Joining these modes, Gower’s revision of Narcissus questions our notions of historiography through showing us an example of a queer, transgender character and his struggles with heteronormative expectations—demonstrating that the medieval is not so disconnected from the modern
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Studies, English Language and Literature
summary: This article explores queer temporality in relation to the Middle Ages, challenging traditional historiography by examining alternative modes of connecting to the past. It bridges the study of queer temporality as it relates to historical contexts and contemporary queer lifestyles by analyzing Gower

title: 'Als Ich Kan': Flanders and the work of William Morris
summary: This article challenges the prevailing idea that William Morris lacked knowledge of Flemish, suggesting he possessed at least a passing understanding of Dutch. It examines Morris's poem "Mine and Thine" from his collection "Poems by the Way" (1891), which is subtitled "From a Flemish poem of the fourteenth century." The author argues that Morris used medieval Flemish texts as inspiration for this socialist poem, advocating for communal sharing and the abolition of concepts like "mine" and "thine" to solve global problems. The analysis highlights Morris's engagement with Flemish culture and its influence on his work.

title: 50 Years of Archaeology in the University of Łódź - Summary
abstract: Zadanie pt. „Digitalizacja i udostępnienie w Cyfrowym Repozytorium Uniwersytetu Łódzkiego kolekcji czasopism naukowych wydawanych przez Uniwersytet Łódzki” nr 885/P-DUN/2014  dofinansowane zostało ze środków MNiSW w ramach działalności upowszechniającej naukę
summary:
This document summarizes 50 years of archaeology at the University of 

Łódź, marking the 1995 anniversary of the Chair of Archaeology's establishment, co-founded by Professor Konrad Jażdżewski. It traces the evolution of archaeological institutions in 

Łódź, highlighting research and didactic achievements, including studies on armaments and military service in the Middle Ages. The paper also acknowledges the contributions of key figures like Professor Andrzej Nadolski and the vital role of the Student Science Circle. Annexes provide a comprehensive list of graduates and staff, showcasing the institution's academic impact and legacy.

title: EDV – Italian Medieval Epigraphy in the Vernacular. Some Editorial Problems Discussed,
abstract:
EDV (Epigraphic Database Vernacular) is a database collecting the

vernacular inscriptions produced in Italy from the late Medieval to the Early Modern

Age, and is a part of the EAGLE and IDEA projects. The present contribution illustrates

the criteria used for the description and indexing of all inscriptions that record public

script in language(s) other than Latin. The material is very varied as regards language,

script, provenance, support and function. The author discusses briefly the editorial

criteria that may prove most appropriate for its publication
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Epigraphy, Romance Linguistics, Digital Humanities, Palaeography
summary: This contribution describes the Epigraphic Database Vernacular (EDV), a database collecting vernacular inscriptions produced in Italy from the late Medieval to the Early Modern Age, as part of the EAGLE and IDEA projects. It details the criteria for describing and indexing public script inscriptions in languages other than Latin, noting the material's diversity in language, script, provenance, support, and function. The author also discusses appropriate editorial criteria for its publication, serving as a valuable resource for medieval epigraphy, Romance linguistics, palaeography, and digital humanities.

title: Many Hands Without Design:The Evolution of a Medieval Prophetic Text
summary: This article reconstructs the pre-manuscript history of the Sibylla Tiburtina, a late antique prophetic text widely disseminated after c.1000. It challenges the prevailing belief that a single intelligence structured the Latin text to a single meaning in the eleventh century. By identifying early medieval interpolations, the article offers a new account of the work's textual development before 1000. This suggests the Ottonian Sibyl had a less distinct moment of creation than usually assumed, being a product of independent interpolators adding to its late antique core over a long period without a common purpose. Keywords: Sibylla Tiburtina, Prophecy, Ottonians, Last Emperor, Aistulf, Apocalypticism, Oracle of Baalbek.

title: 8. The Gothic Cathedral
abstract: The Gothic cathedral, like the Summa of Aquinas, the University of Paris, and the Christendom of Innocent III, stands as one of the major expressions of the spirit of the High Middle Ages. The word  Gothic,  coined by the Renaissance as a term of disparagement, has come recently to have more favorable and appreciative connotations. Such a reevaluation may be due not only to the better perspective that a longer period of time offers us, but also to a deeper understanding of the cultural role of artistic and spiritual symbolism. The artistic expression of the Middle Ages found its supreme embodiment in the architecture of the Gothic cathedral. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance and Baroque Art and Architecture, Architectural History and Criticism, History of Christianity, History of Religion
summary: The Gothic cathedral is explored as a key expression of the High Middle Ages, alongside figures like Aquinas and institutions like the University of Paris. Initially a term of disparagement, "Gothic" now holds appreciative connotations, a shift attributed to historical perspective and a deeper understanding of cultural and spiritual symbolism. The text details the architectural innovations of Gothic cathedrals, such as flying buttresses and gargoyles, which allowed for immense height and structural integrity. These structures, often called "houses of God," symbolized a spiritual aspiration towards the divine, showcasing medieval ingenuity in materials, engineering, and finance, resulting in unique architectural masterpieces across France.

title: Social capital and collusion: the case of merchant guilds
abstract:
Merchant guilds have been portrayed as ‘social networks’ that generated beneficial ‘social capital’ by sustaining
 shared norms, effectively transmitting information, and successfully undertaking collective action. This social capital, it is claimed, 
 benefited society as a whole by enabling rulers to commit to providing a secure trading environment for alien merchants. But 
 was this really the case? We develop a new model of the emergence, rise and eventual decline of European merchant guilds 
 which explores the collusive relationship between rulers and guilds, and calls into question the prevailing positive view of merchant guilds. 
 We then confront the model’s predictions with the available historical data. The empirical evidence strongly support our model and 
 refutes existing theories. Our findings show that merchant guilds used their social capital for socially harmful as well as beneficial ends
summary: This study develops a new model to challenge the prevailing positive view of European merchant guilds. Historically portrayed as beneficial 'social networks' generating 'social capital' that aided societal well-being by securing trade environments, this research argues for a collusive relationship between rulers and guilds. The model's predictions, supported by historical data, demonstrate that merchant guilds leveraged their social capital for both beneficial and harmful ends, refuting existing theories. Key terms include merchant guild, collusion, social capital, and social networks.

title: The Question of the Plurality of Definitions in two Medieval Commentaries on Aristotle’s Topics
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient and Medieval Philosophy, Intellectual History
summary: This document, from the Moscow International Conference on Aristotle (October 2016), explores the enduring legacies of Aristotle as a constitutive element of European rationality. Specifically, it examines the reception of Aristotle's theory of definition, particularly the question of the plurality of definitions, within medieval commentaries from the Latin 13th and 14th centuries. It references passages from Aristotle's Topics and delves into the interpretations by figures such as John Buridan, engaging with the epistemological problems inherent in Aristotle's concept of definition and its influence on later philosophical thought.

title: Review of \u3cem\u3eNature and Scripture in the Abrahamic Religions: Up to 1700\u3c/em\u3e
summary: This is a review of "Nature and Scripture in the Abrahamic Religions: Up to 1700," a two-volume anthology stemming from a 2005 workshop. The collection, featuring essays from historians of interpretation of the Hebrew Bible, Christian, and Islamic traditions, explores the hermeneutical relationship between the study of nature and sacred texts across these religions. It highlights the complex, interdisciplinary nature of the topic, noting the extensive research still needed and suggesting areas for future scholarly inquiry. The review recommends the book for academic libraries and graduate students specializing in theological studies, medieval history, and the philosophy of science.

title: Legal Nationalism:Lord Cooper, Legal History and Comparative Law
summary: This paper examines the concept of 'legal nationalism' through the work of Lord Cooper, focusing on his contributions to Scottish legal history and comparative law. It explores how Cooper's medieval research provided insights into the development of Scots law from the twelfth century, emphasizing its positioning as a Civilian or mixed system. The study analyzes the historical and comparative foundations of Cooper's ideology, particularly his role in the Cooper-Smith ideology, and its implications for Scottish legal nationalism. Keywords: legal nationalism, Lord Cooper, Scots Law, legal history, comparative law, Civilian system.

title: Interview whith Martin Aurell : dialogues aboul Nohility. Manage and Historiograpy
abstract: Aprovechando la edición catalana de su obra Les noces du comle  realizamos una entrevista al prestigioso medievalista Martin Aurell,  catedrático de historia medieval en la universidad de Poitiers.  A lo  largo de sus respuestas, se detiene sobre problemas de historia  catalana, nobleza, espiritualidad e historiografía medieval.Enjoying the opportunity provided by the Catalán edition of his work Les  noces du comte, we interviewed the prestigious medievalist Martin  Aurell, chair of Medieval History at he University of Poitiers.  His  responses to our questions touch on problems of Catalan history, the  nobiliti, spirituality and medieval historiography
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval History, Nobleza, Mujer, Matrimonio, Espiritualidad, Historiografía, New Medievalism
summary: This interview with medievalist Martin Aurell, Chair of Medieval History at the University of Poitiers, discusses his work and insights, particularly in the context of the Catalan edition of his book "Les noces du comte". Aurell's responses delve into key areas such as Catalan history, the medieval nobility, spirituality, and medieval historiography. The discussion aims to provide a deeper understanding of these intertwined themes as approached by a leading scholar in the field, offering valuable perspectives for researchers interested in medieval studies, social structures, and historical interpretation.

title: Early estate structures in Cumbria and Lancashire
summary: This paper examines the concept of 'multiple estates' in Cumbria and Lancashire, England, asserting their significance as a key regional estate structure. It synthesizes previous scholarship from Jolliffe, Barrow, Winchester, Lewis, and Phythian-Adams, highlighting arguments for Celtic roots and pre-Viking continuity in estate frameworks, while also acknowledging cautions regarding the antiquity of post-Norman Conquest records. The study emphasizes the multiple estate model's importance for understanding long-term continuities in settlement history, particularly the enduring nature of cores, peripheries, boundaries, and the links binding communities into larger territorial patterns.

title: Common Medieval Pigments
abstract: This paper discusses the pigments used in medieval manuscripts. Specific types of pigments that are examined are earths, minerals, manufactured, and organics. It also focuses on both destructive and non-destructive methods for identifying medieval pigments
summary: This paper provides an introduction to the common medieval palette used in illuminated manuscripts before 1500, focusing on the pigments from earths, minerals, manufactured sources, and organics. It discusses both destructive and non-destructive methods for identifying these medieval pigments, encouraging further research into non-destructive techniques. The work highlights the brilliant colors in medieval art, derived from simple elements like clay, natural minerals, and insects, emphasizing their significance in illuminating medieval minds and embellishing content. Keywords: medieval manuscripts, pigments, illumination, medieval art, pigment identification, non-destructive methods.

title: Christian Moral Decline:A New Context for the Sibylla Tiburtina (Ms Escorial &.I.3)
summary: This paper re-examines the Sibylla Tiburtina, a popular and influential medieval apocalyptic text, focusing on its theme of Christian moral decline. While previous scholarship has often emphasized Reichseschatologie and fears of Muslims, this analysis argues that the Tiburtina's portrayal of societal moral decay provided a significant, independent reason for its widespread circulation and translation, even before the mid-eleventh century. The study highlights the complex, variegated nature of medieval eschatological thought, suggesting that different 'flavors' of apocalypticism existed, influenced by factors like the perceived imminence of the end and the identities of good and evil actors.

title: The Wool Trade in English Medieval History
summary: This work, comprising the Ford Lectures by Eileen Power, examines the integral role of the wool trade in English medieval society. It challenges the conventional view of the Middle Ages as solely a period of natural economy and self-sufficiency, instead emphasizing the sophisticated economic structures. The book covers sheep farming, wool production, the trade's development and organization, taxation policies (including the 'maltote'), and the staple system. A significant focus is on the impact of the wool trade on the English middle classes, revealing their economic dynamism and influence on constitutional and financial crises of the fourteenth century. Keywords: medieval history, economic history, wool trade, England, Middle Ages, taxation, staple system, middle classes.

title: Institute of Historical Research Newsletter, Spring Term 2006
abstract: The IHR produces a termly newsletter, which gives details of seminars and conferences and other historical news. This is the newsletter for the spring term 2006
summary: This newsletter from the Institute of Historical Research (IHR) for Spring 2006 details recent activities and upcoming events. A highlight was the celebration marking the IHR Appeal reaching its £10 million target, emphasizing the institute's vital role for historians globally and the need for continued donations to sustain projects and foster future creativity. The publication also expresses gratitude to all supporters and announces various historical seminars and lectures, including topics on legal history, customary law, and the Old Bailey Bar. These lectures are open to the public and offer CPD accreditation for legal professionals.

title: Scottish Burgh Record Scholarship c. 1830-1880
publisher: AHRC Centre for Scottish and Irish Studies
summary: This book section, "Scottish Burgh Record Scholarship c. 1830-1880," examines the evolution and significance of scholarly engagement with Scottish burgh records during a pivotal period. It traces the initial efforts by groups like the Maitland Club to publish extracts from these historical documents, highlighting the motivations and perceived value of such undertakings for understanding Scottish history, local antiquities, manners, customs, and the progress of civilization. The work likely discusses key figures, methodologies, and the impact of these publications on historical scholarship, revealing how archival research contributed to the broader narrative of Scottish identity and development. The text provides valuable insights into early 19th-century historical practices and the use of primary sources.

title: Review Of  Stained Glass Before 1700 In American Collections: New England And New York (Corpus Vitrearum Checklist I)  Edited By M.H. Caviness
summary: This review evaluates "Stained Glass Before 1700 In American Collections: New England And New York (Corpus Vitrearum Checklist I)" edited by M.H. Caviness. The work serves as a valuable checklist for students of medieval and Renaissance art history, facilitating scholarship on the origins, patrons, makers, and programs of these stained glass panels. Additionally, it provides insights into the commerce of artifacts in the early twentieth century, revealing patterns in collector tastes, motivations, and dealer practices within the burgeoning market for medieval antiquities. This resource advances the study of medieval art and its historical context.

title: Paintings and their implicit presuppositions: High Renaissance and Mannerism
abstract:
All art historians who are interested in questions of "styles" or "schools" agree in identifying a High Renaissance school of Italian

painting. There is, however, a disagreement, which has seemed nonterminating, regarding Mannerism: Is it another distinct school or

is it merely a late development of the Renaissance school? We believe that this disagreement can be terminated by distinguishing questions of

fact about paintings from questions about the definitions of schools.  To this end we have had two representative subsets of paintings--one

earlier, one later--rated on four of the dimensions of implicit presuppositions that we have introduced in other Working Papers. When

the paintings are scaled in this way a very distinct profile emerges for the earlier, or Renaissance, paintings. In contrast, the later, or

Mannerist, paintings are so heterogeneous that we conclude that they are best described as deviations from the Renaissance profile, rather

than a separate school. These results are not unimportant--at least for art historians. But they are more important methodologically

inasmuch as the procedures applied here can be used in classifying and distinguishing from one another all kind of cultural products
fieldOfStudy: History, Art History, Italian Painting, Mannerism, Renaissance, Art Styles
summary: This paper addresses the long-standing art historical debate regarding Mannerism, specifically whether it constitutes a distinct school of Italian painting or a late development of the High Renaissance. The authors propose resolving this disagreement by differentiating factual questions about paintings from definitional questions about schools. They rated two subsets of paintings, an earlier Renaissance group and a later Mannerist group, on four dimensions of implicit presuppositions. Their findings indicate a distinct profile for Renaissance paintings, while Mannerist paintings are highly heterogeneous, suggesting they are better described as deviations from the Renaissance profile rather than a separate school. This methodological approach can be broadly applied to classify other cultural products.

title: The Spiritual Nature of the Italian Renaissance
abstract: This study seeks to investigate the influence of faith in the emergence and development of the Italian Renaissance, in both the artwork and writing of the major artists and thinkers of the day, and the impact that new expressions of faith had on the viewing public. While the Renaissance is often labeled as a secular movement by modern scholars, this interpretation  is largely due to the political motives of the Medici family who dominated Florence as the center of this artistic rebirth, on and off again throughout the period. On close examination, the philosophical and creative undercurrents of the movement were much more complex. The thinkers of the era would often place Greco-Roman philosophers in the context of their Christian era and use their wisdom in addition to, rather than superseding, church and biblical authority, embracing figures like Virgil and Augustine in concert rather than opposition.  These Christian humanists saw their work as a way to engage humanity in a quest for knowledge in ever expanding ways, but still with an undercurrent of reflection on the role of the divine. Spiritual inquiries of Dante, Lorenzo Valla, and Petrarch in written works are similarly manifested in the visual arts by Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo Buonarotti, and Raphael Sanzio. These ‘big three’ painters of the Renaissance portrayed their individual Christian ideas through their own writings, sketchbooks, and all forms of artistic expressions, many of which are evaluated in this paper. Finally, the transition of art to a scale inviting the viewer to experience it personally marked a vital change. The shift from divine proportions to more naturalistic and relatable art also logically harmonizes with the mindset of the broader Renaissance movement. This paper seeks to examine the depth and complexity of key Renaissance figures and how concepts of Christian faith and spirituality translated into their works
summary: This study explores the profound influence of Christian faith on the Italian Renaissance, challenging the modern secular interpretation often attributed to Medici political motives. It investigates how major artists and thinkers like Dante, Petrarch, Leonardo da Vinci, and Michelangelo integrated Greco-Roman philosophy with Christian theology, viewing their work as a spiritual quest for knowledge. The paper examines their written and visual expressions of faith, highlighting the transition from divine proportions to more naturalistic art as harmonizing with the broader Renaissance movement. It emphasizes the depth and complexity of how Christian concepts translated into their works, impacting the viewing public and encouraging personal experience.

title: Animal Bodies, Renaissance Culture by Karen Raber
abstract: Chad Weidner reviews Animal Bodies, Renaissance Culture by Karen Raber
fieldOfStudy: History, Critical and Cultural Studies, English Language and Literature, European Languages and Societies, Modern Literature, Nature and Society Relations
summary: Chad Weidner reviews Karen Raber's "Animal Bodies, Renaissance Culture," a significant contribution to material ecocriticism and animal studies. The book explores human attitudes towards animals in the early modern period, connecting historical perspectives to contemporary discussions. Weidner praises Raber's work for raising new questions about the human-animal relationship, especially within Renaissance culture, and its relevance to understanding nonhuman creatures. He notes the limitations of materialist scholarship in addressing aesthetic and imaginative qualities, and the inherent incompleteness of human understanding of animal consciousness.

title: Butterflies and Rebirth
abstract: During the Renaissance, collectors saw Morpho butterflies as beautiful, elegant, and rare creatures. Their exotic origin and sophistication made these fascinating creatures the subjects of scientific observation, decoration, and symbolism. Butterflies of the Morpho genus include a wide variety of marvelous, striking, and beautiful species. Home to South and Central America, Morpho butterflies thrive in the rainforests of Nicaragua, Colombia, and Venezuela. When Renaissance Europeans began exploring American rainforests, they were quickly captivated by these butterflies. Morphos feature vivid blue coloration and iridescence on the dorsal side of their wings as well as a yellow-brown coloration on the other side. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Art History, Renaissance, Natural History, Entomology
summary: This student research paper examines the perception and cultural significance of Morpho butterflies during the Renaissance. It details how these exotic creatures, originating from South and Central American rainforests, captivated European collectors due to their beauty, rarity, and vivid iridescent blue coloration. The paper explores their role in scientific observation, decoration, and symbolism, highlighting their integration into art and natural history collections of the period.
