It references specific displays and artworks, such as those by Merian, to illustrate how these insects were showcased and studied, reflecting Renaissance interests in nature and artifice.

title: Sound
abstract:
Sound, basically characterized as air in motion
since ancient Greece, has been at the core of the
theories of many philosophers, as well as musicians,
poets, scientists, and theologians. Under
the auspices of Hellenic thought, Renaissance
scholars tried to define what sound is,
unveiling its vibrating forces to understand its
ability to shake the human body and soul. In
such a way, the ever-present metaphors of harmony
were much more than mere imagined,
unreal thoughts: through them, Renaissance
humanists shaped, organized, and understood
the structure and passions of the world itself.Este trabajo forma parte del proyecto de investigación “La obra musical renacentista: fundamentos, repertorios y prácticas” HAR 2015-70181-P (MINECO/FEDER, UE
fieldOfStudy: History, Renaissance Studies, History of Science, Music History, Philosophy
summary: This paper explores the Renaissance understanding of sound, moving beyond its ancient Greek characterization as air in motion. It investigates how Renaissance scholars, influenced by Hellenic thought, sought to define sound, unveiling its vibrating forces and its profound impact on the human body and soul. The study emphasizes the significance of harmony metaphors, arguing that these were not merely abstract concepts but fundamental tools through which humanists structured and comprehended the world and its passions. This historical perspective sheds light on the interplay between philosophy, science, and music during the Renaissance.

title: Illuminating Luke: the infancy narrative in Italian Renaissance painting
abstract: Title: Illuminating Luke: the infancy narrative in Italian Renaissance painting. Author: Hornik, Heidi J Illuminating Luke 164 p. Publisher: Harrisburg : Trinity, 2003
fieldOfStudy: Art History, Biblical Studies, Renaissance Painting
summary: This book review analyzes "Illuminating Luke: The Infancy Narrative in Italian Renaissance Painting" by Mikeal C. Parsons and Heidi J. Hornik. The work explores the intersection of visual arts and theology, focusing on four Italian Renaissance paintings depicting scenes from Luke's Gospel. These include Leonardo da Vinci's "The Annunciation," Jacopo Pontormo's "The Visitation," Domenico Ghirlandaio's "The Nativity and Adoration of the Shepherds," and Ambrogio Lorenzetti's "The Presentation in the Temple." The review highlights the collaboration between a biblical scholar and an art historian in interpreting these significant religious artworks within their theological and liturgical contexts, emphasizing their historical and artistic value.

title: Toward a Library Renaissance
abstract: For centuries, librarians have tried to safeguard information, sometimes in the face of destruction. Think of the great Library of Alexandria, the burning of which symbolizes the irretrievable loss of knowledge. Think also of Umberto Eco\u27s novel, The Name of the Rose, and the (fictitious) 14th-century story about the search for a  lost  volume of Aristotle that no one is allowed to read—but yet must be preserved—because it might reveal that Jesus could and did laugh, contrary to the death-obsessed zeitgeist of the time. Fast-forward to the age of the internet, when some fear libraries are again being destroyed and many ask:  Who wants libraries when you have Google?  This is not an easy question to address but one need not yield to pessimism. This paper argues that identifiable trends direct to a promising future: in light of these, one should be able to circumscribe plausible scenarios. Approaches to strategic planning that count on ownership should make a big difference and point to desirable skills for librarians. If they also invest in resilience and give unequivocal attention to branding, libraries can enjoy a renaissance
summary: This paper argues for a promising future for libraries, contending that despite fears of their destruction in the internet age, identifiable trends point toward a renaissance. The author proposes strategic planning centered on ownership, resilience, and strong branding to ensure libraries remain vital. The discussion highlights historical efforts by librarians to safeguard information, drawing parallels with the Library of Alexandria and Umberto Eco's "The Name of the Rose" to emphasize the enduring importance of knowledge preservation. Key strategies for librarians include acquiring desirable skills and focusing on strategic investment.

title: Bhangra: Mystics, music and migration
abstract:
Bhangra: Mystics, Music and Migration explores the origins of this folk song and dance from the Panjab in South Asia and its development into part of modern British culture in the hybrid soundscape of British Bhangra and beyond.



 

This book originated in academic research and the Heritage-lottery funded Bhangra Renaissance project. Through ethnographic research, oral history interviews, performances, photography, story-telling and community activity it celebrates the past contribution of all those involved in Bhangra.





This ground-breaking work provides an in-depth history of the spiritualism of performance and song, and an overview of the artists involved in influencing its development, as well as contemporaries leading the way of Bhangra’s renaissance amongst the South Asian diaspora in the UK and around the world
summary: This book, "Bhangra: Mystics, Music and Migration," explores the origins of Bhangra, a folk song and dance from the Panjab in South Asia, and its evolution into a part of modern British culture. Based on academic research and the "Bhangra Renaissance project," it uses ethnographic research, oral history, performances, and community activities to provide an in-depth history of its spiritualism and the artists influencing its development within the South Asian diaspora. The work uniquely examines Bhangra beyond textual analysis, proposing its roots in faith-based social groups and spiritual networks across mystical Hinduism, Sikhism, and Sufi Islam, contributing to studies of hybrid cultural formations and migration.

title: 2. The Renaissance of Northern Europe
abstract: The Renaissance north of the Alps was akin to the Italian Renaissance, but it appeared later and developed distinctive features of its own. It had a dual origin in infection and invention. Infection was the result of the brisk traffic of merchants, scholars, princes, soldiers, Churchmen, and artists which passed between Italy and the North, carrying tidings of the new developments in Rome, Florence, Venice, and Milan. In addition, northern Europeans hit on ideas of their own. Since they, like the Italians, were experiencing the growth of trade, urban life, and the centralized state, their response to these events was related to that of the Italians under similar conditions. However, Frenchmen, Germans, Netherlanders, and Englishmen worked with native materials and therefore did not reproduce the Italian scene exactly. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Cultural History, Economic History, European History
summary: This text examines the Northern European Renaissance, highlighting its distinct characteristics compared to its Italian counterpart. It asserts a dual origin of 'infection' from Italian developments and indigenous 'invention' rooted in shared societal changes like trade growth and centralized states. The study describes how northern Europeans, utilizing native materials, adapted these influences without exact reproduction, showcasing unique artistic and cultural expressions such as the Rabelaisian naturalism and the sober portraiture of Dürer and Holbein. The authors analyze the evolution and eventual decline of this period, concluding around the late sixteenth century as its defining features became less novel. Key terms: Northern European Renaissance, Italian Renaissance, cultural diffusion, art history, societal change.

title: Medical Crises and Moral Renaissance
summary: This paper argues that contemporary medicine, facing crises like AIDS and indigent care, should prompt practitioners to reconsider classic transcending virtues and remember medicine as a sacred trust. The author contends that ethical clinical practice requires mercy, justice, and fidelity, potentially restoring medicine to a "priestly profession" dedicated to sacred oaths rather than arrogance and accumulation. It explores historical precedents from Amos, Luke, and Roman writings emphasizing patient-focused ethics. The core purpose is to advocate for a moral renaissance in medicine through rediscovered virtues amidst modern challenges.

title: Fellowship, Service, and the \u27Spirit of Adventure\u27: The Religious Society of Friends and the Outdoors Movement in Britain, C. 1900-1950
abstract: This article considers the involvement of members of the Religious Society of Friends in various manifestations of the outdoors movement in early twentieth-century Britain. It examines the Edwardian \u27Quaker tramps\u27 and their role in the \u27Quaker renaissance\u27, and goes on to consider the influence of Friends in organisations such as the Holiday Fellowship and the Youth Hostels Association, as well as interwar Quaker mountaineers. It argues that, while the outdoor activities of the Quaker renaissance were essentially internal to the Religious Society of Friends, a wider conception of social service took Quakers beyond the boundaries of the Society in the interwar period, resulting in a more profound influence on the outdoors movement. These activities of Friends were associated with the promotion of the \u27social gospel\u27, and represented a significant strand of Quaker service in the first half of the twentieth century
fieldOfStudy: History, Christian Denominations and Sects, History of Christianity
summary: This article examines the involvement of members of the Religious Society of Friends in Britain's early twentieth-century outdoors movement, particularly from 1900-1950. It investigates the Edwardian 'Quaker tramps' and their role in the 'Quaker renaissance,' and Friends' influence on organizations like the Holiday Fellowship and Youth Hostels Association, as well as interwar Quaker mountaineers. The study argues that while early outdoor activities were internal to the Religious Society of Friends, a broader social service vision led Quakers beyond society boundaries in the interwar period, significantly influencing the outdoors movement. These activities promoted the 'social gospel' and represented a crucial aspect of Quaker service during the first half of the twentieth century.

title: [Review of] Langston Hughes. The Big Sea: An Autobiography
abstract: In the last ten years a number of critical studies on the Harlem Renaissance have been published, and these in turn have sparked a revival of interest in the cultural, political, and social activities that took place during the ten-year period in Afroamerican history between 1919 and 1929. There is a renewed interest in the life and writings of Renaissance figures such as Arna Bontemps, Countee Cullen, Zora Neale Hurston, Nella Larson, Claude McKay, and Langston Hughes. Hence many of their autobiographies, first published in the 1930s and 1940s, are being reissued in response to the demand for more information on the era when  the Negro was in vogue.  This latest edition of Hughes\u27s first autobiography The Big Sea is part of this larger revival and follows very closely behind the reprint of his contemporary Zora Neale Hurston\u27s Dust Tracks on a Road (University of Illinois Press, 1986)
summary: This text reviews the reissue of Langston Hughes's autobiography, "The Big Sea," amidst a renewed scholarly and public interest in the Harlem Renaissance (1919-1929). The book is presented as an insightful study of the era by a contemporary participant, though critics note its lack of personal revelation from Hughes himself. The revival includes reissues of works by other Renaissance figures like Zora Neale Hurston, reflecting a demand for information on this culturally significant period in Afroamerican history. The document also briefly discusses a separate work, "The Color of God," which aims to foster black self-worth but struggles with abstract theological discourse for the average layperson, suggesting a need for concrete examples of African contributions to Christianity.

title: Venice in the East: Renaissance Crete and Cyprus
abstract: This music bears witness to how ancient Greek and Latin liturgical traditions were richly embellished during the Renaissance on the islands of Crete and Cyprus, all within the shared cultural space of Venetian rule. First performed by Cappella Romana at the Early Music Festival in Utrecht (Netherlands)
summary: This music collection explores the rich embellishment of ancient Greek and Latin liturgical traditions during the Renaissance, specifically within Crete and Cyprus under Venetian rule. It features compositions from the Byzantine and Venetian Commemorations of the Paschal Triduum, including works by Johannes de Quadris, Alberto Castellani, and Manuel Gazēs the Lampadarios. The collection highlights the cultural intersection of Byzantine chant and Latin sacred music, providing insights into the musical practices of these Mediterranean islands during a significant historical period, and is useful for research on Renaissance music and liturgical studies.

title: Fides et ratio in the renaissance
fieldOfStudy: History, Renaissance Philosophy, Philosophy of Religion
summary: This book review discusses Paul Richard Blum's 'Philosophy of Religion in the Renaissance,' which defines philosophy of religion as "theology for non-believers" and examines the dialectical relationship between theology, philosophy, and religion from the 14th to 16th centuries. Blum argues this dynamic is a key achievement of Renaissance thought, exploring how philosophical projects rationalized revelation. The review highlights the book's comprehensive portrayal of Renaissance intellectual endeavors but suggests it overlooks the non-conflictual, hierarchical, and symbiotic articulations between these disciplines prevalent in classical Latin Christianity, where philosophy served to complement theological truth. Key concepts include Fides et Ratio, Renaissance philosophy, and philosophy of religion.

title: Commemorating the Sack of Rome (1527) : antiquity and authority in Renaissance poetic calendars
summary: This document presents an accepted manuscript from the University of Warwick Research Archive Portal (WRAP), detailing conditions for open access and reuse of research. It outlines copyright, moral rights, and permissions for personal research, educational, or not-for-profit purposes, requiring appropriate citation. The text primarily comprises a comprehensive bibliography of academic works, focusing on Renaissance studies, classical literature (especially Ovid's Fasti), and early modern European history. Keywords include Renaissance, Ovid, Fasti, Neo-Latin Studies, Early Modern France, Augustus, and Roman history.

title: Reflections on morality in Renaissance thought
abstract: We can read about the morality of that time in works by authors who describe or criticize the conduct and activity of the members of those classes taking the lead in the morality of that time. Thus, we can find a lot of information about ancient Greece and its morality in Plato’s presentation of Socrates, Peter Abelard presenting the Middle Ages, Erasmus of Rotterdam, Niccolo Machiavelli, Baldesar Castiglione, but even also Slovak authors such as Martin Rakovský and Juraj Koppay presenting very interesting contemporary facts about the Renaissance
summary:
This study explores the evolution of morality across different historical periods, focusing on how societal classes, estates, and groups influenced moral norms. It examines insights from ancient Greece (Plato's Socrates), the Middle Ages (Peter Abelard), and the Renaissance, particularly through the works of Erasmus of Rotterdam, Niccolo Machiavelli, Baldesar Castiglione, and Slovak authors like Martin Rakovsk
n

y and Juraj Koppay. The paper aims to delineate the sources and criticisms of moral conduct during these eras, providing a comprehensive overview of historical moral thought.

title: The French Renaissance in prints [Review]
abstract: Patricia Emison\u27s review of a book edited by Karen Jacobso
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
fieldOfStudy: Art History, Renaissance Studies, Music History
summary: This document is a review by Patricia Emison of Karen Jacobson's book, "The French Renaissance in Prints, from the Bibliothèque Nationale de France." It discusses the book's content, focusing on the French Renaissance and printmaking, and also covers aspects of Monteverdi's biography and musical works, including his service to the Gonzaga and as maestro di cappella of S. Marco in Venice. The review examines Monteverdi's madrigal books, sacred collections, stage works, and his controversy with Giovanni Maria Artusi, providing a reconstruction of each work's historical context.

title: East Midlands urban action plan 2005-2011
abstract: This is the second urban action plan (UAP) for the East Midlands. The plan sets out a framework for urban renaissance in the East Midlands and provides a delivery plan that includes significant schemes in the priority urban areas that will influence the transormation of urban areas and contribute to the region's economic development
summary: This document outlines the second Urban Action Plan (UAP) for the East Midlands, serving as a framework for urban renaissance and economic development from 2005-2011. Developed by the East Midlands Urban Partnership Group, it details significant schemes for priority urban areas, aiming to transform these regions. Key sections include strategic context, lessons learned from the first UAP, current economic conditions, thematic priorities, and a comprehensive delivery plan. Appendices provide supporting details, relevant strategies, economic statistics, and an evidence base summary. The plan emphasizes localized retail planning and a broad consultation approach.

title: 16th Century Antiphon
abstract: The Renaissance era, which spanned from the 14th century until the 16th century, served as a transitional period. Considered to be a period of rebirth, the Renaissance commenced a revival in culture, literature, and the arts throughout Europe. The 16th century antiphon not only signifies that music was indeed an important aspect during the Renaissance, but is also tangible evidence that choral music, and more specifically Gregorian chant, were prominent forms of musical expression
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance and Baroque Art and Architecture, Fine Arts, Intellectual History
summary: This paper examines the significance of the 16th-century antiphon within the context of the Renaissance era, spanning from the 14th to the 16th century. It argues that the antiphon serves as tangible evidence of the crucial role of music, particularly choral music and Gregorian chant, as prominent forms of musical expression during this period of cultural, literary, and artistic rebirth in Europe. The study highlights the transition experienced during the Renaissance and its revival of various art forms.

title: Retelling Orpheus: Orpheus in the Renaissance
abstract:
This paper examines the importance of the Orpheus myth during the English Renaissance. The
Orpheus myth was one of the most common mythic intertexts of the period due to the fact
that we could see the very story of Orpheus as being imbedded within the idea of the
Renaissance itself. The main ambition of the Renaissance humanist was to bring the literature
of the ancients back to life via the means of education. In other words, they attempted to bring
the dead back to life and Orpheus serves as an embodiment of this ambition due to his ability
to bring inanimate objects to life and in his journey to the underworld to rescue Eurydice. We
find many different aspects of the Orpheus myth dealt with in Renaissance writing, for
example Orpheus as poet, Orpheus as lover and the death of Orpheus being some of the key
focal points. This paper, however, will focus specifically on the role of Orpheus as Poet as, due
to the Renaissance love for art, rhetoric and eloquence, this seems to be the most popular
dimension of the Orpheus myth at that time. We will see how Renaissance writers reinterpret
the story of Orpheus, as originally told by Ovid and Virgil, in the Metamorphoses and the
Georgics respectively, to show Orpheus as not only as being an archetypal poet but in fact the
very first poet whose art is not only responsible for the civilisation of man, but also for the
creation of a “Golden Age” in Renaissance England
publisher: Department of Studies in Drama and Pre-1800 English Literature, University of Łódź
fieldOfStudy: History, English Renaissance, Orpheus Myth, Literary Studies
summary: This paper investigates the significance of the Orpheus myth during the English Renaissance, noting its prevalence as a mythic intertext reflective of the period's humanist ambition to revive ancient literature through education. Focusing on Orpheus as Poet, the study explores how Renaissance writers, reinterpreting Ovid and Virgil, depicted Orpheus not merely as an archetypal poet but as the primal poet whose art fostered civilization and ushered in a 'Golden Age' in Renaissance England. Key aspects include Orpheus's ability to bring life, his journey to the underworld, and his representation as poet and lover in Renaissance literature.

title: The Confucian Renaissance in the Sung dynasty
abstract: Thesis (Ph.D.)--Boston Universit
summary: This doctoral thesis, "The Confucian Renaissance in the Sung Dynasty" by John C. Ferguson (1902), examines the revival and re-establishment of Confucian doctrines as the central philosophy and standard for character in China during the Sung Dynasty. It draws parallels between the influence of Chu Hsi on Confucianism and Luther's impact on Christianity in Europe, asserting that the Confucian Renaissance was completed by solidifying the Sages' teachings. The study highlights the ceremonial veneration of Confucius in imperial schools and across the Empire, emphasizing his role as "The Teacher." Key concepts include Confucianism, Sung Dynasty, Chu Hsi, Chinese philosophy, and cultural revival.

title: Exciting Developments in Hadron Spectroscopy
abstract:
There has been a renaissance in hadron spectroscopy during the last couple of
years. Long lost states have been tracked down. Unexpected states are showing
up all over, and numerous measurements with unprecedented precision are being
reported. A review is presented.Comment: 11 pages, 10 figures, plenary talk contributed to XI International
  Conference On Hadron Spectroscopy (HADRON05), 21-26 Aug 2005, Rio de Janeiro,
  Brazi
fieldOfStudy: Physics and Astronomy, Hadron Spectroscopy, Quantum Chromodynamics
summary: This review presents exciting developments in hadron spectroscopy, a field experiencing a significant renaissance. It highlights the tracking down of long-lost states, the emergence of unexpected states, and numerous measurements reported with unprecedented precision. The study emphasizes heavy quark spectroscopy, particularly charmonium and bottomonium states, as an optimal approach for studying Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). Key methods involve analyzing relativistic effects and utilizing perturbative techniques. The review discusses recent genuine discoveries and important precision measurements, underscoring the ongoing surprises within heavy-quark spectroscopy.

title: Quartz and Prehnite: Minerals during the Renaissance
abstract: Minerals were displayed in wonder rooms for their beauty and used by apothecaries for their medical properties and artists, for sculptures and pigments. Minerals during the Renaissance were collected and displayed in wonder rooms to illustrate the beauty of nature. Humanists would have categorized minerals by their external qualities- color, transparency, form, luster, and smell. Over time, geologists continue to study these external qualities when they are first analyzing minerals, and the internal properties. Today the six major factors in identifying minerals are cleavage, the tendency of minerals to break into flat surfaces; color; crystal form or how the form of the mineral changes as the mineral crystallizes; hardness, the resistance to scratching to measure its strength; luster, the light reflection; and streak, the color of the streak left when a mineral is grinded on porcelain. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque Art and Architecture, Fine Arts, History of Science, Technology, Medicine, Industrial and Product Design, Intellectual History
summary: This student research paper examines the collection and display of minerals during the Renaissance, highlighting their multifaceted roles in wonder rooms, apothecary practices, and artistic endeavors. It traces the historical categorization of minerals by humanists based on external qualities like color and transparency, contrasting it with modern geological identification methods. The study details six major factors used today for mineral identification: cleavage, color, crystal form, hardness, luster, and streak. This exploration provides insights into the historical perception and scientific understanding of minerals from the Renaissance to the present, focusing on their aesthetic, medicinal, and practical applications.

title: The renaissance of the theatre of memory
abstract: Giulio Camillo (1480 - 1544) was as well-known in his era as Bill Gates is now. Just like Gates he cherished a vision of a universal Storage and Retrieval System, and just like Microsoft Windows, his ‘Theatre of the Memory’ was, despite constant revision, never completed. Camillo’s legendary Theatre of Memory remained only a fragment, its benefits only an option for the future. When it was finished, the user - so he predicted - would have access to the knowledge of the whole universe. On account of his promising invention, Camillo’s contemporaries called him ‘the divine’. For others, like Erasmus or the Parisian scholars, he was just a ‘quack’, but also this only shows that his reception was as strong as is the case with the computer gurus of our days. Still, Camillo was forgotten immediately after his death. No trace is left of his spectacular databank - except a short treatise which he dictated on his deathbed and which was formulated in the future tense: ‘L’Idea del Theatro’ (1550). ..
summary: This article explores the historical figure of Giulio Camillo (1480-1544) and his uncompleted 'Theatre of Memory,' a visionary universal Storage and Retrieval System. Despite its legendary status and Camillo's contemporary fame, the project remained a fragment, with its full benefits unrealized. The paper details how Camillo was largely forgotten after his death, only to be rediscovered and celebrated in the computer age due to renewed interest in his concepts of information storage and retrieval. It highlights how modern artists and scholars are reinterpreting Camillo's ideas using computer simulation and VR technologies, questioning future information staging based on his work. Keywords: Giulio Camillo, Theatre of Memory, Storage and Retrieval Systems, Renaissance, computer age, information science, artificial memory, VR.

title: Skeletons In the Closet
abstract: Among the collections cabinets of the Renaissance, fish, in the forms of naturalia and artificialia, can be widely found. They were sought after for their beauty as well as their relation to the natural world. In the famous frontispiece to Ferrante Imperato’s Dell’historia naturale (1599), fish of varying kinds are hung against and atop the ceiling on either side of a large alligator. They are mixed between an assortment of crustaceans and shells, also sea creatures, including the prized nautilus shell found so abundantly in Renaissance culture. As seen in this frontispiece, fish could be found as decoration in collection cabinets, featured creatures of study in natural history books, and the subject of paintings. The cabinet here at Gettysburg features fish in those two forms of naturalia and artificilia to properly emulate the era. A skeleton of the Gar fish is displayed alongside the skeleton of a Perch. Each representing two sides of the commercial spectrum. Paired with the skeletons are prints of copper engravings done by Mark Catesby (1682-1749) from the second volume of his book The Natural History of Carolina, Florida, and the Bahama Islands (1754).[excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This paper explores the role of fish, as both naturalia and artificialia, within Renaissance collections cabinets, drawing on examples like Ferrante Imperato's Dell'historia naturale (1599). It highlights how fish were valued for their aesthetic appeal and connection to the natural world, appearing as decorations, subjects of study in natural history books, and in paintings. The Gettysburg cabinet emulates this era by displaying Gar and Perch fish skeletons, representing different commercial values, alongside copper engravings by Mark Catesby from The Natural History of Carolina, Florida, and the Bahama Islands (1754). This study provides insight into Renaissance collecting practices and the representation of nature.

title: Small Asian Wonders
abstract: As curiosity grew in the Renaissance, so did the scope of collections of wonders. The Cricket Cage, Jade Screen, and Iron Dragon are three examples of rare collection items from the Far East. While these three east Asian small wonders may have been commonplace in their country of origin, they were considered marvelous to the collectors of Europe who had never seen objects such as these produced in their own countries. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History of Science, Technology, and Medicine, Art and Art History, Intellectual History
summary: This paper examines how the scope of collections of wonders expanded during the Renaissance, fueled by growing European curiosity. It focuses on three specific East Asian artifacts—the Cricket Cage, Jade Screen, and Iron Dragon—which, though common in their places of origin, were considered marvelous novelties by European collectors. The study explores the cultural perception and significance of these 'small Asian wonders' within the context of early modern European art and intellectual history, highlighting how such items contributed to the evolving understanding of nature and artifice.

title: Boston University Symphony Orchestra, December 13, 1994
abstract: This is the concert program of the Boston University Symphony Orchestra performance on Tuesday, December 13, 1994 at 8:00 p.m., at the Tsai Performance Center, 685 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts. Works performed were Celebration by Theodore Antoniou, Renaissance Concerto for Flute and Orchestra by Lukas Foss, and Symphony No. 1 in C minor, Op. 68 by Johannes Brahms. The program featured Theodore Antoniou's "Celebration" (U.S. Premiere), Lukas Foss's "Renaissance Concerto for Flute and Orchestra" with flutist Marya Martin, and Johannes Brahms's "Symphony No. 1 in C minor, Op. 68." Lukas Foss conducted the orchestra. The document includes detailed program notes for "Celebration," discussing its purpose of celebrating Greek-American friendship and its virtuostic character exploring new orchestrational and instrumental techniques. This historical record offers insights into classical music performances and repertoire.

title: Marriage from Renaissance to Reformation: Two Florentine Moralists
summary: This study examines the evolving views on marriage by comparing the teachings of two influential Florentine moralists, St. Antonino (1389-1459) and Peter Martyr Vermigli (1499-1562), whose lives spanned a century between the Renaissance and Reformation eras. It explores how attitudes and practices regarding this central social institution shifted, highlighting that such changes often originate from economic and cultural causes at a microscopic level. The analysis delves into their specific teachings to illuminate broader societal transformations in marriage, sex, and family during a period of significant historical upheaval.

title: What is event led regeneration?  Are we confusing terminology or will London 2012 be the first Games to truly benefit the local existing population?
abstract:
The term regeneration means keeping the locality available for the same social classes and improving the infrastructure for their benefit, however examination of previous games including Barcelona 1992 and Sydney 2000 has shown evidence of renaissance, referring to ‘upgrading’ the social structure of the area. The property prices in both cities rose as a result of the hosting of the games for both home owners and renters thus changing the social structure of the areas in questions. This term, renaissance, was used by Mace et al, (2007) in their paper about the urban changes to east Manchester. 



A further term called social rejuvenation is more appropriate because it implies an intervention in the continuing decline of as area without specifying for whom the improvements are intended  thus allowing the market forces to determine the social makeup, and therefore avoiding accusations of letting the locals down through unfulfilled promises. 



This paper examines in detail both Sydney 2000 and Barcelona 1996 Olympic Games organisers’ strategies in developing their cities in order to host their respective games and in doing so the effects these plans had on the demographic structure of the local populations. Lessons learned are then made into recommendations for London 2012 where already communities are being displaced and the social structure is in danger of changing, with the promised ‘regeneration’ of East London  (ODA, 2005) therefore never materialising
summary: This paper examines the terminology and effects of event-led regeneration, particularly in the context of Olympic Games. It contrasts "regeneration" (keeping social classes and improving infrastructure) with "renaissance" (upgrading social structure through rising property prices) and proposes "social rejuvenation" as a more appropriate term, implying intervention without specifying beneficiaries. The study analyzes the strategies of the Sydney 2000 and Barcelona 1992 Olympic Games organizers and their demographic impacts, offering recommendations for London 2012 to prevent displacement and ensure true community benefit, rather than simply extending gentrification. Key entities include Olympic Games, urban regeneration, gentrification, social impact, and community development.

title: The Plains of Mars, European War Prints, 1500-1825
abstract: Over fifty original prints by renowned artists from the sixteenth through the early nineteenth century, including Albrecht Dürer, Lucas Cranach, Théodore Géricault, and Francisco de Goya, among many others, are featured inThe Plains of Mars: European War Prints, 1500-1825. On loan from the Sarah Campbell Blaffer Foundation at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, the works of art included in this exhibition examine the topics of war and peace, propaganda, heroism, brutal conflicts, and the harrowing aftermath of battle. Spanning from the Renaissance to the Romantic periods and encompassing a wide geographic scope including Italy, Germany, France, Spain, the Low Countries, England, and North America, the prints depict triumphant Renaissance soldiers, devastating scenes of violence, and satirical caricatures of political figures. Also on display is Goya’s compelling “Disasters of War” series, completed in response to the brutality of the Spanish War of Independence. Goya’s prints serve as a powerful testament to the horrors faced by both soldiers and civilians. Under the direction of Professor Felicia Else and Shannon Egan, Melissa Casale ‘19 and Bailey Harper ‘19 have researched and written didactic labels, catalogue essays, and created an interactive digital interface to complement the exhibition. Together, Melissa and Bailey will lead public tours of the exhibition. A Gallery Talk by Prof. Peter Carmichael will draw connections between the depictions of warfare on view in the Gallery with representations of the American Civil War. James Clifton, Director of the Sarah Campbell Blaffer Foundation at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, will be delivering a lecture in conjunction with the exhibition. Dr. Clifton, who also serves as curator of Renaissance and Baroque painting at MFAH, curated the exhibition in its first iteration and wrote the exhibition catalogue (published by Yale University Press). Dr. Clifton’s lecture not only will provide an overview of the exhibition, but also will focus on the concept of “mediated war.” A full-color catalogue with images and essays by Bailey Harper ’19 and Melissa Casale ’19, under the supervision of Profs. Felicia Else and Shannon Egan, is planned to accompany the exhibition.https://cupola.gettysburg.edu/artcatalogs/1028/thumbnail.jp
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Art History, Renaissance, Baroque Art, European History
summary: This exhibition, "The Plains of Mars: European War Prints, 1500-1825," showcases over fifty original prints by artists like Dürer, Cranach, Géricault, and Goya. On loan from the Sarah Campbell Blaffer Foundation, these works explore themes of war, peace, propaganda, heroism, and the aftermath of battle from the Renaissance to the Romantic periods. The exhibition includes Goya's "Disasters of War" series and is complemented by didactic labels, catalogue essays, and an interactive digital interface researched by Melissa Casale and Bailey Harper. Public tours, lectures, and a gallery talk further enhance the understanding of European war prints and their historical context.

title: Crocodiles - the Singular Beast in the Renaissance Cabinet
abstract: Stuffed crocodiles often predominated many famous cabinets, hanging in the center of the ceiling. Crocodilians are the largest reptiles and the largest predator that spends time on land. They have existed for about 240 million years, and today there are 23 species of crocodilians in total, categorized in three families: 13 species of crocodiles, two species of alligators, and six species of caimans. Archaeologists found a “Supercroc” fossil as long as 40 feet (12 meters) and weighting 17,500 pounds in Niger. They believe that the crocodile lived alongside dinosaurs about 100 million years ago. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque Art and Architecture, Fine Arts, History of Science Technology and Medicine, Intellectual History
summary: This paper explores the prominent role of stuffed crocodiles in Renaissance cabinets of curiosities, often displayed as central, wondrous exhibits. It highlights crocodilians' ancient lineage, diverse species, and imposing physical characteristics, noting their significance in both natural history and artistic representation during the Renaissance period. The study examines how collectors appreciated various aspects of crocodilians, which continue to fascinate modern biologists, maintaining their mysterious and wondrous status from the Renaissance to the present day. This work connects historical art and science through the enduring intrigue of these large reptiles.

title: [Review of] Cary D. Wintz. Black Culture and the Harlem Renaissance
abstract: In 1925 Professor Alain Locke argued in The New Negro that the Negro was  moving forward under the control largely of his own objectives ...  which were  none other than the ideals of American institutions and democracy.  This allowed for blacks everywhere to be called  New Negroes  but nowhere were there as many New Negroes as in Harlem. The activities of these people in politics, arts, literature, music and the like between World War I and the Depression Era came to be called the Harlem Renaissance
fieldOfStudy: History, American literature, African American studies
summary: This review examines Cary D. Wintz's "Black Culture and the Harlem Renaissance," which focuses on the Harlem Renaissance as a literary and intellectual movement between World War I and the Depression Era. The book, while presented as a specialized treatment of black culture, primarily explores well-known topics and writers of the period. The reviewer notes that Alain Locke's 1925 argument in "The New Negro" positioned Black Americans as advancing under their own objectives, aligning with American democratic ideals, especially evident in Harlem. The review critically assesses the book's title and suggests older, finer works exist for students interested in the Harlem Renaissance writers and their historical groundwork for contemporary African American literature.

title: Alliances and treaties: co-operation in war and peace
abstract:
This article explores how the use of alliances and treaties changed

along with the developments in the European international order in the

modern era. Fundamentally, European international relations

remained based on an "anarchic" system of competing sovereign states.

Yet the evolution of concepts of international law from the Renaissance

onwards and the impact of cultural, political, and social developments

has encouraged a use of treaties and alliances that has moved

European politics fitfully towards a "constitutional" solution, while

never fully embracing such a model
summary: This article investigates the evolving role of alliances and treaties within the European international order from the Renaissance to the modern era. It examines how, despite a persistent "anarchic" system of sovereign states, the development of international law and broader cultural, political, and social changes have gradually pushed European politics towards a "constitutional" framework, albeit without fully adopting it. The text highlights the shift in cooperative mechanisms in war and peace, exploring concepts like international relations, state systems, and peace conferences.

title: \u27For a few days we would be residents in Africa : Jessie Redmon Fausct\u27s  Dark Algiers the White\u27\u27
abstract: American scholarship on the Harlem Renaissance has, until recently, been strongly U.S.-centric, but the work of many of the important writers of the New Negro-era has an international dimension, as writers attempted to place the African American struggle for political and civil rights and cultural authority in larger, often global, contexts. Recent scholarship has revealed that the term,  Harlem Renaissance,  used as a rubric to characterize the flowering of black culture-building and political activism in the first years of the 20th century is something of a misnomer
fieldOfStudy: History, African American Studies, Literary Criticism
summary: This scholarship re-evaluates the U.S.-centric understanding of the Harlem Renaissance, arguing that many New Negro-era writers engaged with international dimensions, positioning the African American struggle for rights and cultural authority within global contexts. The term "Harlem Renaissance" itself is questioned as a misnomer, as black cultural and political activism flourished beyond Harlem in cities like Washington D.C., Chicago, and Philadelphia, and extended to international centers such as London and Paris. The analysis highlights the international scope of the movement and challenges conventional scholarship emphasizing solely U.S. and Great Migration influences, focusing on writers like Jessie Redmon Fauset.

title: Boston University Wind Ensemble, November 20, 2014
abstract: This is the concert program of the Boston University Wind Ensemble performance on Thursday, November 20, 2014 at 8:00 p.m., at the Tsai Performance Center, 685 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts. summary: This concert program details the Boston University Wind Ensemble performance on November 20, 2014, at the Tsai Performance Center. title: Did One Veil Give Women a Better Life?
abstract: Unfortunately, a young woman in Renaissance Florence did not have many options for her future. A woman\u27s family usually decided whether she would be able to get married or would have to enter the convent, but sometimes she was able to make this choice. In this paper, I look at the lives of wives and nuns to analyze how their lives differed in responsibilities and freedoms, but also to see how all women had similar restrictions and expectations placed upon them
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Women's History, European History, Gender and Sexuality
summary: This paper investigates the limited options for young women in Renaissance Florence, focusing on the dichotomy between marriage and convent life. It analyzes the differing responsibilities and freedoms experienced by wives and nuns, while also highlighting the pervasive restrictions and expectations imposed on all women during this period. The study aims to understand the societal pressures and roles that shaped women's lives in historical Florence.

title: Enacting  Smoke, Lilies, and Jade  as Black Gay Print Culture
abstract: This essay offers a comparative analysis of the ways that Isaac Julien\u27s Looking for Langston (1989) and Rodney Evans\u27s Brother to Brother (2005) inscribe Richard Bruce Nugent\u27s landmark short story  Smoke, Lilies, and Jade  (1926). Both films are examples of how  Smoke,  which was first published in the short-lived but infamous journal FIRE!!, now functions as much more than an artifact from the Harlem Renaissance\u27s dynamic print culture. As I contend through this analysis,  Smoke  is a central diegetic element in both films. It enables Looking\u27s visual depiction of the sojourn that Nugent\u27s protagonist Alex has with his male lover  Beauty  and Brother\u27s depiction of an intergenerational collaboration that honors Nugent as a black gay male artist. Through honorific interpretations of  Smoke, Lilies, and Jade,  Looking for Langston and Brother to Brother affirm a black gay print culture as indispensable to black gay film
fieldOfStudy: History, Film Studies, African American Studies, Queer Studies
summary: This essay comparatively analyzes Isaac Julien's "Looking for Langston" (1989) and Rodney Evans' "Brother to Brother" (2005), focusing on their inscription of Richard Bruce Nugent's 1926 short story "Smoke, Lilies, and Jade." The analysis contends that "Smoke" functions as a central diegetic element in both films, enabling visual depictions of Nugent's protagonist Alex's experiences and intergenerational collaborations honoring Nugent as a Black gay male artist. Through these honorific interpretations, the films affirm a Black gay print culture as indispensable to Black gay film, highlighting its relevance for contemporary narrative representations of "transgressive Black sexuality" within the Harlem Renaissance context.

title: The Evolution of Renaissance Classicism
abstract: The term "Renaissance classicism" refers to a fundamental attribute of the period that scholars refer to as the European Renaissance, roughly 1400–1600. Renaissance classicism was an intellectual movement that sought to mimic the literature, rhetoric, art, and philosophy of the ancient world, specifically ancient Rome
fieldOfStudy: History, Renaissance, Classicism, Intellectual Movements, Ancient Rome
summary:
This entry defines Renaissance classicism as an intellectual movement during the European Renaissance (roughly 1400

1600) that mimicked the literature, rhetoric, art, and philosophy of ancient Rome. It explains that scholars, politicians, and philosophers drew inspiration from classical models, a practice termed classicism. While classical themes existed in medieval Europe, eighteenth- and nineteenth-century scholars, notably Jacob Burckhardt, emphasized the Italian classicists of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries as the origin of a modern secular worldview, despite some ignoring aspects like religion or warfare. This movement significantly shaped the intellectual life of the period.

title: Centre for Medieval and Renaissance Studies : recognition scheme for educational oversight : review by the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
publisher: Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education
fieldOfStudy: History, Medieval Studies, Renaissance Studies, Higher Education Quality Assurance
summary: This report details a review conducted by the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA) at the Centre for Medieval & Renaissance Studies in February 2012. The review's purpose was to assess the provider's management of academic standards, quality, and enhancement of learning opportunities, and to evaluate the reliability of its public information. Key findings and recommendations are presented, along with explanations. This document serves as an evaluation of educational oversight and academic quality within a specialized historical studies center, offering insights into higher education quality assurance processes.

title: Plotting the Centre: Bramante’s Drawings for the New St. Peter’s Basilica
abstract: This paper examines the concept of 'centre' in the design and symbolism of the new St Peter's Basilica, executed by Donato Bramante in the early 16th century. Drawing upon theological and philosophical notions of centre in late Medieval and Renaissance culture (specifically Nicolas Cusanus), the study argues that Bramante's drawings for the project reveal a particular understanding of centre, and its constellations of sub-centres, that broadly follow Platonic cosmological principles highlighted in the Timaeus. The paper considers how this understanding of space was also communicated in the iconography of the frescoes in the Stanza della Segnatura in the Vatican Palace, executed by Raphael at the same time as Bramante's design for the new basilica, in which Bramante is also credited as the author of the perspective construction
fieldOfStudy: History, Renaissance Architecture, Art History, Philosophy
summary: This paper analyzes the concept of 'centre' in Donato Bramante's early 16th-century design for the new St. Peter's Basilica. Drawing on late Medieval and Renaissance theological and philosophical notions, especially Nicolas Cusanus and Platonic cosmological principles from the Timaeus, the study argues that Bramante's drawings reveal a specific understanding of spatial organization, including constellations of sub-centres. The paper also examines how this spatial understanding was conveyed through the iconography of Raphael's frescoes in the Stanza della Segnatura, where Bramante is credited with the perspective construction. Key terms include architectural design, Renaissance art, theological symbolism, and Platonic philosophy.

title: Between the ideal and the reality: The human body through the eyes of European artists
abstract: The human body has always been one of the most important subjects for European artists. But the way it is displayed in art has varied in different epochs. In ancient Greece, a canon was constituted that proclaimed an ideal vision of the body, derived from the rules governing the universe. This idealization of the human body, neglected in the Middle Ages, was re‑established in Renaissance and Classicist art. However, Renaissance artists also created another image of the human body by borrowing from patterns mainly found in nature, and started to depict their models not in an ideal but rather in a more natural shape. The new non‑ideal forms of art that appeared in Mannerist art made the artists develop a much wider artistic language, which brought into being a variety of individually interpreted artistic representations of the human body. It preceded similar phenomena which became widespread in the twentieth century. Thus, the human body was not always displayed in art as strong, healthy and beautiful. On the contrary, the martyred bodies of Christ and the saints, as well as the depictions of aged, tired or ill people, also carried enormous artistic expression. A distinct problem has occurred with the ways in which corpses have been presented in art. The review concludes with a reference to the contemporary trend called Body‑Art that involves various artistic activities, such as happenings and performances, where the human body is itself used as a significant work of art
fieldOfStudy: History of Art, European Art, Art History, Renaissance, Mannerism, Body-Art
summary: This article explores the evolving representation of the human body in European art across various historical epochs, from ancient Greece to contemporary Body-Art. It examines the shift from idealized classical canons in ancient Greece, revived in the Renaissance and Classicism, to more naturalistic and individually interpreted depictions emerging in the Renaissance and Mannerism. The study highlights that art has consistently portrayed the body in diverse states, encompassing not only ideal forms but also martyred, aged, tired, or ill figures, underscoring their profound artistic expression. The article concludes by referencing modern artistic movements like Body-Art, where the human body itself becomes the artwork.

title: In Defense of His Holiness: The Cellini Plaque
abstract:
The plaque depicting Cellini was donated to Gettysburg College by Reverend Jeremiah Zimmerman, Class of 1873, who later became a lecturer at Syracuse University and a frequent benefactor of Gettysburg College. A highly educated alum, Reverend Zimmerman became a clergyman and traveled the world for over a decade to further his studies, ranging from Asian culture to ancient coinage.
The plaque itself measures 32” x 26.75” x 2.5”, is of considerable weight for a porcelain plate, and is painted in the 19th century academic style to offer a dramatic interpretation of Benvenuto Cellini’s actions during the 1527 Sack of Rome. Specifically, the scene captures a dramatized (or even perhaps imagined) moment of Cellini outside the Castel Sant’Angelo, the site of a fortress used by the Holy See to defend against outside invaders. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient Medieval Renaissance and Baroque Art and Architecture, Fine Arts, History of Science Technology and Medicine, Industrial and Product Design, Intellectual History
summary: This paper examines a large porcelain plaque depicting Benvenuto Cellini's dramatized actions during the 1527 Sack of Rome, specifically a scene outside Castel Sant'Angelo. Donated to Gettysburg College by Reverend Jeremiah Zimmerman, an educated alumnus with global studies ranging from Asian culture to ancient coinage, the 19th-century academic style plaque measures 32” x 26.75” x 2.5”. The study focuses on the historical interpretation and artistic representation of this event, analyzing Cellini's role and the cultural context of the artwork's creation and donation.

title: Review Of  The Economy Of Renaissance Florence  By R. A. Goldthwaite
summary: This review analyzes Richard A. Goldthwaite's "The Economy of Renaissance Florence," highlighting its significant contribution to Renaissance history. The book offers a comprehensive synthesis, presenting an optimistic view of Florentine economic stability and prosperity from the fourteenth to the early sixteenth century, despite challenging established narratives of crises and mass impoverishment. Goldthwaite explores the debate on the Renaissance economy and the rise of capitalism, concluding that Florentine entrepreneurs adopted some market-oriented, capitalist practices while lacking a capitalist mentality. The reviewer praises the book's insightful analysis and its potential to guide future research, positioning it as a pivotal work in the field.

title: Fossils: Digging Into the Past
abstract: Fossils collected in Renaissance collection cabinets were items of wonder and curiosity. Although sometimes mistaken for other pieces of naturalia, they were widely collected by owners of princely cabinets and scholarly collections.Though naturalists and collectors often kept fossils in their collections, they did not have the same understanding as we do today of what they are. Due to their belief in mythological monsters and naturalia with magical properties, there were often misinterpretations or mislabeled objects to something they were not. According to Kenseth’s “A World of Wonders in One Closet Shut,” some collectors believed that fossilized shark’s teeth were “adders’ tongues,” and that they could be used as antidotes to poison. Just as whale ribs were mistaken for “giant bones,” and narwhal tusks were mistaken for “unicorn horns,” fossils were also often misunderstood. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This paper examines the collection and interpretation of fossils during the Renaissance, highlighting their role as objects of wonder and curiosity within princely cabinets and scholarly collections. It explores how Renaissance naturalists and collectors, influenced by beliefs in mythological monsters and magical naturalia, often misinterpreted or mislabeled fossils. Examples include shark's teeth mistaken for 'adders' tongues' used as antidotes, and whale ribs for 'giant bones.' The study emphasizes the differing understanding of fossils compared to modern paleontology, focusing on their aesthetic and speculative value rather than scientific classification. Key entities include Renaissance collections, naturalia, mythological monsters, and fossil misinterpretations.

title: Chop-suey: Asian Bodies Consumed in the Harlem Renaissance
fieldOfStudy: History, African American Studies, Literature in English, North America, Ethnic and Cultural Minority Literature
summary: This essay explores the overlooked representation of Asian bodies and the consumption of Asian culture within the Harlem Renaissance, challenging dominant narratives that primarily focus on Black and White racial dynamics. It critiques figures like W.E.B. DuBois and characters in novels like "Quicksand" for their failure to acknowledge or uplift Asian people, often reducing them to exoticized objects or commodities. The author argues that this oversight perpetuates a form of white supremacy by neglecting the diverse experiences of non-white populations, especially Asian immigrants and workers, during this pivotal period in American history. Key concepts include racial essentialism, exoticism, and cultural consumption.

title: Preface [to \u3cem\u3eItalian Renaissance Masters\u3c/em\u3e]
summary: This preface introduces the exhibition "Italian Renaissance Masters," organized by the Haggerty Museum of Art as part of Milwaukee's International Festival for the Arts. The exhibition features 45 works from various collections, aiming to enhance public appreciation and scholarly understanding of Italian Renaissance art from the 15th and 16th centuries. It highlights the period's vitality in art history, making visual and historical connections among the presented paintings and decorative artifacts, and encourages further academic review. The accompanying catalogue supports both public and scholarly engagement with the art and artists.

title: The Significance Of The Erosion Of The Prohibition Against Metabasis To The Success And Legacy Of The Copernican Revolution
abstract: Although one would not wish to classify Copernicus’ own intentions as belonging to the late-medieval and Renaissance tradition of nominalist philosophy, if we are to turn our consideration to what was responsible for the eventual success of the Copernican Revolution, we must also attend to other features of the dialectical context in relation to which the views of Copernicus and his followers were articulated, interpreted, and evaluated. Accordingly, this paper discusses the significance of the erosion of the Aristotelian prohibition against metabasis to the eventual success of the Copernican Revolutio
fieldOfStudy: History of Philosophy, History of Science
summary: This paper explores the factors contributing to the eventual success of the Copernican Revolution, moving beyond Copernicus's personal intentions to examine the broader dialectical context. It specifically discusses the critical significance of the erosion of the Aristotelian prohibition against 'metabasis' for the revolution's triumph and lasting legacy. The study considers how the views of Copernicus and his followers were articulated, interpreted, and evaluated, highlighting the role of conceptual shifts in scientific inquiry. Key concepts include Copernicus, Copernican Revolution, scientific revolution, astronomy, cosmology, mathematization, nominalism, parsimony, metabasis, mathesis universalis, and scientiae mediae.

title: Review article: Renaissance philosophy
summary: This review article examines the underappreciated field of Renaissance philosophy, focusing on two significant scholarly works: Christopher C. Celenza's edition of Angelo Poliziano's Lamia and Stephen Clucas, Peter J. Forshaw, and Valery Rees's edited volume, Laus Platonici Philosophi: Marsilio Ficino and His Influence. The article highlights how these texts emphasize the continuity of philosophical thought from medieval to early modern periods, challenging the view of Renaissance philosophy as a neglected backwater. It explores connections between key figures like Ficino, Hobbes, Locke, and Simplicius, advocating for more in-depth philosophical studies and translations to further explore this crucial historical period.

title: Thomas Linacre -- Humanist, Physician, Priest (Part 1)
summary: This article, "Thomas Linacre -- Humanist, Physician, Priest (Part 1)" by Fred M. Taylor, provides an initial exploration into the life and intellectual contributions of Thomas Linacre (1460-1524), focusing on his roles as a humanist, physician, and priest. The text delves into historical methodology, emphasizing that history encompasses extraordinary events and the evolution of human ideals, not merely dates and names. It highlights Linacre's intellectual prowess and his influence on prominent contemporaries such as Erasmus and Thomas More, particularly his role in teaching Greek and Aristotle's scientific works. The study aims to illuminate Linacre's impact on Renaissance thought and education.

title: 3. The Expansion of Europe
abstract: Concurrent with the political and diplomatic developments just described, and exercising a significant influence upon them, there occurred a vast overseas expansion of Western Civilization. Although the Crusades were the first phase of this expansion, not until the early modern period did European energies burst forth with sufficient vigor that their impact became worldwide. In the intervening centuries such things as the growth of commercial capitalism, the rise of the strong national state, and the intellectual upsurge associated with the Renaissance prepared Europeans for the mighty task of discovering, exploring, and colonizing areas in all parts of the globe. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This chapter examines the extensive overseas expansion of Western Civilization, particularly from the early modern period (1500-1789), influenced by developments like commercial capitalism, the rise of national states, and the Renaissance. It details how European energies led to the discovery, exploration, and colonization of global territories. The text also discusses the economic impact of this expansion, including the "price revolution" caused by an influx of silver leading to inflation, which affected Spain significantly and later other regions. It highlights the social consequences, noting how wage earners and fixed-income individuals were hurt, while the business class benefited. Furthermore, the expansion fostered a European sense of superiority over native populations.

title: Cosimo de’ Medici: Patron, Banker, and Pater Patriae
abstract: This paper investigates the connection between art, money, and power in the life of Cosimo de\u27 Medici. It discusses several important art works commissioned by Cosimo, including the Medici Palace and Donatello\u27s bronze David. It also examines Cosimo\u27s life as a businessman and a political figure
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient Medieval Renaissance and Baroque Art and Architecture, Renaissance Art
summary: This paper investigates the intricate connection between art, money, and power in the life of Cosimo de' Medici, a pivotal figure in Renaissance Florence. It examines his role as a patron, banker, and political leader, focusing on significant art commissions such as the Medici Palace and Donatello's bronze David. The study explores Cosimo's influence as a businessman and political figure, highlighting how his financial and political acumen intertwined with his artistic patronage, shaping the cultural and political landscape of Florence. Key concepts include Renaissance art, Medici family, Florence, and political patronage.

title: Renaissance
abstract: Zu Lebzeiten Goethes [G.] existierte noch kein Epochenkonzept, wohl aber ein disparates, andelbares Renaissance-Bild in Philosophie, Historiographie und Literatur. Das im Laufe des 18. Jhs. aufkommende historische Denken entwickelte zunächst, bei Bayle und Voltaire, das aufklärerische Konzept der « renaissance des lettres et des arts ». Die neue Kultur der italienischen Renaissance wurde entweder mit der Exilierung Gelehrter beim Fall Konstantinopels 1435 (Katastrophentheorie) oder mit dem Import neuen Wissens durch die Kreuzzüge (Kreuzzugstheorie) erklärt und auf unterschiedliche Art mit der deutschen Reformation in Verbindung gebracht. Vorherrschend war im 18. Jh. ein unreflektiertes Gefühl der Verbundenheit mit der neuzeitlich- fortschrittlichen Kultur der Renaissance. Eine dem Epochenbegriff von Jules Michelet und Jacob Burckhardt (1855/1860) entsprechende, klare Grenzziehung zwischen Spätmittelalter und Renaissance ist noch nicht zu erwarten. „Epoche“ bedeutete zunächst Einschnitt oder Schwelle, noch keine Entität im Sinne des späten Historismus
summary: This study examines the evolving concept of the Renaissance during Goethe's lifetime, noting the absence of a defined epoch concept but the presence of a fluid understanding of the Renaissance in philosophy, historiography, and literature. It traces the development of the Enlightenment's 'renaissance des lettres et des arts' concept, attributing the Italian Renaissance's emergence to events like the Fall of Constantinople or the Crusades, and its connection to the German Reformation. The text highlights a prevailing 18th-century sense of connection to the progressive culture of the Renaissance, predating the clear demarcation of the period established by Michelet and Burckhardt.

title: The Dismissal of the Greek Envoys—A Forgotten Trajectory Within the Web of European Renaissance
summary: This study examines "The Dismissal of the Greek Envoys" within the broader context of the European Renaissance, focusing on Polish Renaissance literature and the works of Jan Kochanowski. It aims to re-evaluate the integration of Polish culture into European Christian traditions, highlighting Kochanowski's poetic innovations and their influence on Classicism. The research analyzes adaptations, translations, political treatises, and poetry to trace the operational ideologies of the Renaissance on Europe's "peripheries," ultimately seeking to reposition Polish Renaissance on the European cultural map. Key concepts include Polish Renaissance, Jan Kochanowski, European tradition, literary innovation, and cultural integration.

title: Skating With Donovan: Thoughts on Librarianship as a Profession
abstract: James M. Donovan’s article: Skating on Thin Intermediation:  Can Libraries Survive?, 27 Legal Reference Services Q. 95 (no. 2-3, 2008) argues that librarians place more emphasis than they might on providing service to library users at a time when information seekers are relying less on intermediaries, and that over-emphasizing service to the detriment of other values diminishes the status of librarianship as a profession. The article presents two contrasting models of librarianship. This article discusses Donovan’s models and comments on the continuing importance of the service model to librarianship
summary: This article critically discusses James M. Donovan	's argument from "Skating on Thin Intermediation: Can Libraries Survive?" (2008), which posits that librarians overemphasize service, potentially diminishing their professional status as information seekers rely less on intermediaries. The author examines Donovan's two contrasting models of librarianship, ultimately emphasizing the continued importance of the service model. Key themes include the evolving role of librarians, professional identity, and the balance between service provision and other professional values within librarianship, particularly in legal contexts.

title: City portrait, civic body, and commercial printing in sixteenth-century Ghent
abstract: This article discusses a woodcut series with an elaborate iconographic representation of the Flemish city of Ghent, printed in 1524 by Pieter de Keysere. The three-sheet composition consists of a city view, an image of the allegorical Maiden of Ghent, and an extensive heraldic program with the coat of arms of prominent Ghent families and of the Ghent craft guilds. The print series’ production and consumption are unraveled and framed within the wider debate on civic religion in Renaissance Europe. The main argument is that while in this region of Northern Europe civic ideology was equally strong as in Italy, it was not the exclusive playground of the ruling elites. Pieter de Keysere’s woodcut series was aimed at a socially broad, local audience, most particularly Ghent’s corporate middle groups
summary: This article analyzes a 1524 woodcut series by Pieter de Keysere, depicting the Flemish city of Ghent with iconographic representations of its city view, allegorical Maiden, and heraldic program. The study unravels the production and consumption of these prints, framing them within the broader discourse of civic religion in Renaissance Europe. It argues that strong civic ideology in Northern Europe was not limited to ruling elites, demonstrating that Keysere's series targeted a socially broad, local audience, particularly Ghent's corporate middle groups. Keywords: woodcut, Ghent, Pieter de Keysere, civic religion, Renaissance, civic ideology, commercial printing.

title: Jasper Skulls and Memento Mori
abstract:
The jasper skulls in this Curiosity Cabinet sit on the scale atop the touch-ables table. Jasper, a type of impure silica usually a reddish color, is commonly carved for small sculptures, as we see in the skulls.
The reddish tones of both skulls match the overall tone of the cabinet nicely, as well as complimenting the rich medium blue of the walls. Thematically, skulls perfectly align with other objects in the cabinet.
A ubiquitous theme of curiosity cabinets in the 16th and 17th century is the inevitability of death. Symbols of this notion in art work are known as Memento mori or vanitas. Memento mori is derived from Latin, and roughly translates to, “remember you will die.” Vanitas is a related term with similar meaning: all Earthly pursuits are feeble because they are temporary. (excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Art History, Intellectual History, Interdisciplinary Arts and Media
summary: This paper analyzes jasper skulls and their role as Memento Mori in a Curiosity Cabinet, exploring how these objects symbolize the inevitability of death. It examines the aesthetic integration of reddish jasper skulls within the cabinet's theme, aligning with 16th and 17th-century notions of mortality (vanitas). The study discusses various representations of Memento Mori, including actual skulls and symbolic elements in Romantic Era landscape paintings by Louis Hoguet, highlighting fragility of life through seasonal changes and the sublime. Keywords: Memento Mori, vanitas, jasper skulls, Curiosity Cabinet, Romanticism, art history, symbolism.

title: Wonders of Nature and Artifice
abstract: A stuffed blowfish, a meticulously-drawn insect, a ravishing lily, and a rhinoceros horn carved with scenes of plants and animals—these were among the wonders of nature and artifice, the marvels that fueled the Renaissance quest for knowledge. This exhibition explores the intellectual and aesthetic motivations of Renaissance naturalists and collectors, whose wonders of nature and artifice were displayed in elaborate gardens, illustrated books, and remarkable cabinets of curiosities. Collectors were driven by curiosity and a sense of wonder about what seemed to be an ever-expanding world. Students from Prof. Felicia Else’s upper-level art history course and Kay Etheridge’s First Year Seminar will draw connections between art and science, and curate a Renaissance-inspired “Chamber of Wonders” in Schmucker Art Gallery with resources from Gettysburg College’s Fine Arts and Special Collections, departments across campus, and individual loans. More informationhttps://cupola.gettysburg.edu/artcatalogs/1022/thumbnail.jp
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient Medieval Renaissance and Baroque Art and Architecture, Fine Arts, History of Science Technology and Medicine, Intellectual History, Interdisciplinary Arts and Media
summary: This exhibition explores the intellectual and aesthetic motivations of Renaissance naturalists and collectors, focusing on how "wonders of nature and artifice" fueled the Renaissance quest for knowledge. Displayed in elaborate gardens, illustrated books, and cabinets of curiosities, these marvels, from stuffed blowfish to carved rhinoceros horns, illustrate a world expanding through curiosity. Students will curate a Renaissance-inspired "Chamber of Wonders" at Schmucker Art Gallery, connecting art and science using resources from Gettysburg College and individual loans, highlighting the interdisciplinary nature of Renaissance intellectual pursuits.

title: Knowing their loves: knowledge, ignorance and blindness in ’Tis Pity She’s a Whore
summary: This paper examines John Ford's play "'Tis Pity She's a Whore," focusing on the intricate themes of knowledge, ignorance, and blindness. Building on previous critical attention to recurring motifs like "blood," the analysis delves into Ford's complex use of these concepts to explore human understanding and perception within the drama. It considers how characters' awareness, or lack thereof, shapes the tragic narrative and contributes to the play's enduring critical fascination. The study leverages textual analysis to illuminate the interplay of intellect and emotion in Renaissance drama.

summary: This study examines the overlap between natural philosophy and humanist imitation in two works by Thomas Moffet: Insectorum sive Minimorum Animalum Theatrum (c.1589) and The Silkewormes, and their Flies (1599). Both works utilize extensive contemporary and classical sources to create intertextual collages that evoke the natural unity of the Garden of Eden. The author argues that The Silkewormes' compositional style aligns more with Guillaume de Saluste, Sieur Du Bartas's Sepmaine than with Virgilian didactic poetry. The study also considers Elizabethan notions of authority, composition, and originality, concluding that The Silkewormes is notable for its skillful synthesis of diverse material.

title: Under the Wing of a Creature of the Night
abstract: Magnificent in its sheer power and beauty, this owl wing has a wingspan of 18 inches and measures 10 inches from the shoulder bone to the secondary feathers. Wings such as the one displayed play a vital role in the lifestyle of owls and other hunting birds who fulfill their dietary requirements through stealthy foraging in the dark of the night. Being predatory animals, an owl depends upon its wings as a weapon, equipping it with an arsenal worthy of any hunter. Because of their composition of downy feathers, soft fringes, and comb-like primary feathers, these light appendages create less audible sound waves through air, giving an owl the advantage of nearly silent flight. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: History, Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance and Baroque Art and Architecture, Fine Arts, History of Science, Technology, and Medicine, Industrial and Product Design, Intellectual History
summary: This paper describes the physical characteristics and functional importance of an owl wing, highlighting its role in the stealthy hunting lifestyle of owls. It details the wing's dimensions (18-inch wingspan, 10 inches shoulder to secondary feathers) and its composition of downy, soft-fringed, and comb-like primary feathers, which enable nearly silent flight. The text also explores the dual scientific and artistic interpretation of such natural objects, particularly within the context of Renaissance culture and curiosity cabinets, emphasizing how birds like owls were considered wondrous creatures during this period, blurring lines between analytical and aesthetic value.
