summary: This paper investigates the introduction of Renaissance architectural forms in Spain during the sixteenth century, noting that Gothic practices persisted due to their established validity. The architectural renovation was diverse, influenced by individual master training and engagement with Italian innovations, resulting in a hybrid architectural landscape. Through significant historical texts and graphic documents, the study traces changes and continuities in architectural design during this transitional period. The analysis is structured around three interconnected yet autonomous categories: space, mass, and ornament, crucial for understanding the Gothic-Renaissance transition and design processes. Keywords: Renaissance, Gothic, architectural design, Spain, sixteenth century.

title: History as Allegory
summary: This article explores the recurrent phenomenon of "history as allegory" in historical writing, where past events or individuals are perceived and represented in terms of others, often with commentators more intensely preoccupied with present concerns. The study focuses on circumstances in which historical narratives, and even visual representations, are used to comment on one event while subtly addressing another. It aims to analyze the various ways this allegorical approach manifests in historical discourse and its implications for understanding the past and present. Key themes include historical representation, allegory in history, and the intersection of past and present narratives.

title: A performance of 2 dimensional ultrasonic vibration assisted milling in cutting force reduction, on aluminium AL6061
abstract: This paper were investigate a performance of 2 Dimensional Ultrasonic Vibration assisted Milling (UVAM) toward Aluminium Al 6061. The focus is to find the performance of reduction of cutting force compared to the conventional machining in the industries shop floor. Due to the major effect of cutting force of production in industries, the excessive cutting force problem must be investigated deeply as it will cause shortens tool life and reduces the production rate. A scientific approach has been found in order to reduce the cutting force during machining which is integrating the ultrasonic concept into workpiece. The modelling of vibration cutting ratio has been simulated to find the time force contact and non-contact. Thus, less cutting force could be found. The ultrasonic vibration platform that generated by XY25XS from Cedrat Technologies is travelled in X direction as a feed movement. Thus, the X and Y axis vibration actuate along the workpiece for the machining process. The performance of UVAM in cutting force reduction found the superior benefits of UVAM is come from the alternating cycle’s between tool and workpiece. The comparison between UVAM and conventional machining in reduction of cutting force is 32%. The potential of the UVAM tool wear and tool life will be discussed deeply in finding and next in the conclusion section
summary: This paper investigates the performance of 2 Dimensional Ultrasonic Vibration assisted Milling (UVAM) for Aluminium Al 6061, focusing on cutting force reduction compared to conventional machining. The study highlights the significant impact of excessive cutting force on tool life and production rates. By integrating ultrasonic concepts into the workpiece, a scientific approach was developed to reduce cutting force. Modelling of the vibration cutting ratio helped determine time force contact and non-contact, leading to a 32% reduction in cutting force compared to conventional methods. The superior benefits of UVAM stem from the alternating cycles between the tool and workpiece.

title: Approaches to the use of iconography in historical reconstruction, and the curious case of Renaissance Welsh harp technique
abstract: It is an oft-repeated cliché that ‘smart is sexy,’ and while cynics may find plenty of reason to scoff at the thought, some solace can be taken in the economic success and increase in the social cachet of the ‘historically informed performance’ (or HIP) movement. Countless millions of people over the last thirty years have been drawn to the world of medieval and renaissance music, many as a result of the exciting new sounds created through the thoughtful synthesis of artistic and intellectual sensibility demonstrated in historical reconstructions of early instruments and their playing techniques. In light of this economic and cultural success, it therefore seems fitting to take a step back and think about how individuals today arrive at a view of historical reality in the world of instrumental performance, especially when faced with images and artifacts which may be interpreted in many different ways. This research, as ‘an authentic expression of our contemporary cultural condition bringing new experiences and insights into our world,’ 1 is immensely valuable. However, are we justified in going further and asserting that our modern reconstructive work sheds light on ‘the way things actually were,’ or in other words, that it reveals objective historical truth? In the following pages I will take a closer look at the research methodology of historically informed performance and propose a refinement based on a probabilistic analysis of the data produced. While the areas of research which might benefit from such an inquiry are virtually unlimited, my specific focus for the purposes of this exercise is the harp technique in late medieval and early renaissance Wales. This is one branch of the musicological tree which remains relatively infrequently visited in early music circles, yet one which, as we will see, is richly rewarding when explored through the multifaceted methodology and interdisciplinary orientation of modern HIP research
summary: This research explores how individuals interpret historical reality in instrumental performance, particularly within the 'historically informed performance' (HIP) movement. It questions whether modern reconstructive work reveals objective historical truth and proposes a refined research methodology based on a probabilistic analysis of data, moving beyond subjective interpretations of iconography. The study specifically focuses on harp technique in late medieval and early renaissance Wales, an under-explored area in early musicology, aiming to provide new insights through interdisciplinary HIP research. Keywords: historically informed performance, historical reconstruction, iconography, early music, harp technique, medieval Wales, renaissance Wales, probabilistic analysis.

title: Skating With Donovan: Thoughts on Librarianship as a Profession
abstract: James M. Donovan’s article: Skating on Thin Intermediation:  Can Libraries Survive?, 27 Legal Reference Services Q. 95 (no. 2-3, 2008) argues that librarians place more emphasis than they might on providing service to library users at a time when information seekers are relying less on intermediaries, and that over-emphasizing service to the detriment of other values diminishes the status of librarianship as a profession. The article presents two contrasting models of librarianship. This article discusses Donovan’s models and comments on the continuing importance of the service model to librarianship

title: Sharing a Taste? Material Culture and Intellectual Curiosity around the Mediterranean, from the Eleventh to the Sixteenth Century
abstract: Within the context of a research project that seeks to explore new concepts and, possibly, arrive at more productive paradigms, it is interesting to observe the degree to which the study of the transfer of artefacts between the Islamic Middle East and Europe has already evolved away from early art-historical modes of enquiry. It has become increasingly attuned to the need to take account not only of political and economic factors but also of ideological issues, and has begun to address what may be couched in contemporary terms as hybridity and transformations of meaning and identity. Above all, alongside the perennial concern with periodic conflict set against a background of wary coexistence, recent approaches have shown a greater awareness of transcultural impingement, so that however fundamentally a European phenomenon the Renaissance may be, it can be seen as one within which contacts with the Islamic world were embedded
summary: This research project explores the evolution of studying artefact transfer between the Islamic Middle East and Europe, moving beyond early art-historical methods. It emphasizes considering political, economic, and ideological factors, addressing concepts like hybridity and transformations of meaning and identity. The study highlights increased awareness of transcultural impingement, demonstrating how contacts with the Islamic world were embedded within the Renaissance, despite its fundamentally European nature. Keywords include: Islamic Middle East, Europe, Renaissance, artefact transfer, art history, transcultural impingement, hybridity.

title: In the footsteps of the "Great Jewish Composer" : Don Harrán, Salamone Rossi: Jewish musician in late Renaissance Mantua. Oxford University Press, 1999, 310 pp. [Rezension]
fieldOfStudy: History, Music Historiography, Jewish Music, Renaissance Music
summary:
This essay reviews Don Harr
án's book, "Salamone Rossi: Jewish Musician in Late Renaissance Mantua," which culminates a century of scrutiny into the work of the Italian Jewish composer, Salamone Rossi. The author discusses the historical context of Rossi's music, particularly his collection "HaShirim asher liShlomo," and highlights how Jellinek's 1861 report initiated significant interest in Rossi's contributions. The review also critiques the Eurocentric bias in Jewish music historiography, which has often excluded non-Western and 
"operatic" Jewish composers like Avtaliyon and Tamburi Izak, despite their cultural significance. The essay aims to foster future discussions on the historiography of Jewish music and culture, made possible by Harrán's extensive work on Rossi.

title: The \u3cem\u3eAgricultura cristiana\u3c/em\u3e of Juan de Pineda in the Context of Renaissance Mythogprahy and Encyclopedism
summary: This study analyzes Juan de Pineda's "Agricultura cristiana" (1589), a catechistic and encyclopedic manual aimed at the spiritual cultivation and education of Christians. The work, framed as a dialogue imitating Hermes Trismegistus's "Asclepius," is examined within the context of Renaissance mythography and encyclopedism. It explores how Pineda, a Franciscan ascetic, integrates classical myths and philosophical ideas to convey Christian doctrine, reflecting broader Renaissance tendencies toward the unity of knowledge and universal analogy. The analysis highlights Pineda's methods of moralizing and allegorizing myths, positioning his work alongside contemporaries like Juan Pérez de Moya and Baltasar de Vitoria, and emphasizes its historical and literary significance.

title: [Review of] Allen L. Woll and Randall M. Miller. Ethnic and Racial Images in American Film and Television: Historical Essays and Bibliography
abstract: Allen Woll and Randall Miller in Ethnic and Racial Images in American Film and Television have compiled in one volume the writings about the images of ethnic and racial groups in American television and film. Woll and Miller state in their Introduction that the purpose of their book was to  attempt to unite the work (the nature and importance of mass media stereotypes and their effects on society) from a wide variety of disciplines, languages and fields of study in order to expand the vistas of scholarly research in this area.  Ethnic and Racial Images is divided into twelve chapters, with each considering specific ethnic or racial groups: (in alphabetical order) Afro-Americans, Arabs, Asians, East Europeans and Russians, Germans, Hispanic Americans, Irish, Italians, Jews, and Native Americans. The first chapter is a general overview of the subject of racial and ethnic images and the final chapter is a kind of miscellaneous section entitled  Others  which includes Africans, Armenians, Dutch, East Indians, Greeks, Hawaiians, Louisiana Cajuns, Norwegians, Swedes, and Turks
fieldOfStudy: History, Ethnic Studies, Film and Television Studies
summary: Allen Woll and Randall Miller's "Ethnic and Racial Images in American Film and Television" compiles scholarly writings on portrayals of various ethnic and racial groups in American media, including Afro-Americans, Arabs, Asians, and Native Americans. The book aims to synthesize interdisciplinary work on mass media stereotypes and their societal effects, expanding research vistas. It explores how groups like African Americans, Asians, and Germans have been depicted, analyzing cultural and social antecedents of these images in film and television, acknowledging existing criticism while encouraging more interdisciplinary approaches. This compilation serves as a guide for ethnic studies scholars to understand the historical trajectory and future directions of research in this field.

title: The Art of Dialectic between Dialogue and Rhetoric: The Aristotelian Tradition
summary: This review critically examines Marta Spranzi's "The Art of Dialectic between Dialogue and Rhetoric: The Aristotelian Tradition," focusing on its engagement with ancient Greek and Italian philosophers. The reviewer notes Spranzi's detailed interpretation of linguistic evidence, particularly regarding Posidonius and Plutarch, and Polito's analysis of Asclepiades and Heraclides. Key criticisms include the book's limited scope, omitting non-Greek/Italian developments of Aristotelian dialectic, and its failure to address the meaning of "Aristotelian tradition" or formulate specific historical questions. Despite these, the work offers valuable textual analysis for scholars of Aristotelian dialectics, especially during the Italian Renaissance.

title: Worthy of faith?: Authors and readers in early modernity
abstract: This chapter will consider how the traditional (classical Roman and Europeanmedieval) definition of the “author” as “one worthy of faith” (the faith of thereader, obviously) is put increasingly to the test during the early modern period, as the notion of literary writing gradually moves from epistemological (vatic) and/or ethical-rhetorical models toward what Terry Eagleton has called “the ideology of the aesthetic” – that is, toward suspension of readerly belief in the moral fidelity and intellectual credibility of the literary writer. In a classic formulation, the literary author as a distinctive “personal” and individual presence, indeed as willful demideity “making worlds,” first emerges in what we sometimes still call the Renaissance: first in the Italy of Dante and Petrarch, and then, gradually, spreads throughout the nascent vernacular traditions of western Europe. What follows will rehearse some clichés of the topic, one hopes in an appealing way, and lay out to shift the terms of the discussion in others. In particular, I will focus on the intuitively obvious, yet not always thoroughly explored, point that any notion of authorship is intricately tied to ideas, and realities, of readership. More especially, I will explore, on the one hand, the question of authorial control over the meaning of a text as this takes shape in the experience of its readers and, on the other, how such readers may either trustingly embrace the offered sense of the text or willfully recast it
summary: This chapter examines how the traditional definition of the "author" as "one worthy of faith" was challenged during the early modern period. It explores the shift in literary writing from epistemological or ethical-rhetorical models to the "ideology of the aesthetic," where readerly belief in the writer's moral and intellectual credibility is suspended. The emergence of the literary author as a distinctive, individual presence, particularly in the Renaissance with figures like Dante and Petrarch, is discussed. The analysis focuses on the intricate relationship between authorship and readership, investigating authorial control over text meaning and how readers may either embrace or recast that meaning.

title: Lute, Vihuela, and Early Guitar
abstract:
Producción CientíficaLutes, guitars, and vihuelas were the principal plucked instruments in use in Europe until around
1800. Ancient forms of the lute existed in many parts of the ancient world, from Egypt and
Persia through to China. It appears to have become known in Europe, where its earliest
associations were with immigrants such as the legendary Persian lutenist Ziryab (b. c. 790–d.
852), who was established in Moorish Spain by 822. The origins of the various flat-backed
instruments that eventually became guitars are more difficult to trace. The vihuela is one such
instrument that evolved in the mid-15th century and was prolific in Spain and its dominions
throughout the 16th century and beyond. Very few plucked instruments, and only a handful of
fragmentary musical compositions, survive from before 1500. The absence of artifacts and
musical sources prior to 1500 has been a point of demarcation in the study of early plucked
instruments, although current research is seeking to explore the continuity of instrumental
practice across this somewhat artificial divide. In contrast, perhaps as many as thirty thousand
works—perhaps even more—for lute, guitar, and vihuela survive from the period 1500–1800.
The music and musical practices associated with them are not well integrated into general
histories of music. This is due in part to the use of tablature as the principal notation format until
about 1800, and also because writers of general histories of music have for the most part
ignored solo instrumental music in their coverage. (For example, the Oxford Anthology of
Western Music, Vol. 1 (2018), designed to accompany chapters 1–11 of Richard Taruskin’s
Oxford History of Western Music, does not contain a single piece of instrumental music prior to
Frescobaldi [1637]). Contrary to this marginalized image, lutes, vihuelas, and guitars were a
revered part of courtly musical culture until well into the 18th century, and constantly present in
urban contexts. After the development of basso continuo practice after 1600, plucked
instruments also became frequent in Christian church music, although the lute was widely
played by clerics of all levels, particularly during the Renaissance. It was also one of the
principal tools used by composers of liturgical polyphony, in part because tablature was the
most common way of writing music in score. From the beginning of music printing, printed
tablatures played a fundamental role in the urban dissemination of music originally for church
and court, and plucked instruments were used widely by all levels of society for both leisure and
pleasure. After 1800, the lute fell from use, the guitar was transformed into its modern form with
single strings, and tablature ceased to be the preferred notation for plucked instruments.Este trabajo forma parte del proyecto de investigación “La obra musical renacentista: fundamentos, repertorios y prácticas” HAR 2015-70181-P (MINECO/FEDER, UE
fieldOfStudy: History of Music, Organology, Renaissance Music, Early Plucked Instruments, Lute, Vihuela, Early Guitar
summary: This work explores the historical evolution and cultural significance of lutes, guitars, and vihuelas, which were the primary plucked instruments in Europe until around 1800. It traces the lute's ancient origins and its arrival in Europe, particularly noting the influence of figures like Ziryab in Moorish Spain, and examines the more obscure development of flat-backed instruments leading to guitars, with a focus on the 15th-century vihuela in Spain. The study highlights the scarcity of pre-1500 artifacts versus the abundance of works from 1500-1800, emphasizing their marginalized status in music histories due to tablature notation and the focus on solo instrumental music. It ultimately reveals their pervasive role in courtly, urban, and church musical cultures.

title: Tropic Architecture
abstract: Mannerist architects in the Cinquecento created what can be called “tropic architecture.” They set out to break the rules of classical architecture, but the rule-breaking was done systematically, by applying rhetorical tropes, or figures of speech, to architectural composition, the four most common being metaphor, metonymy, synecdoche, and irony. According to Paul Oskar Kristeller, rhetoric was an important basis of Renaissance humanism. Students learned tropes and other figures of speech from well-circulated classical texts such as the Rhetorica ad Herennium and Quintilian’s Institutio oratorio. Examples of tropic devices can be found in works such as Giulio Romano’s Palazzo del Te and Michelangelo’s Porta Pia. There are many examples of mannerist works of architecture in the twentieth century that used the same tropic devices. The use of tropic devices in architectural composition results in an architecture that is a form of poetry
summary: This conference proceeding introduces "tropic architecture," a concept where Cinquecento Mannerist architects systematically broke classical rules by applying rhetorical tropes like metaphor, metonymy, synecdoche, and irony to architectural composition. Drawing on Renaissance humanism and classical texts such as Rhetorica ad Herennium and Quintilian’s Institutio oratorio, the study highlights examples in works like Giulio Romano’s Palazzo del Te and Michelangelo’s Porta Pia. It argues that this use of tropic devices transforms architecture into a form of poetry, with continued relevance in 20th-century Mannerist works, emphasizing rhetoric, architectural theory, and historical analysis.

title: “BODY-SNATCHING”: Changes to coroners legislation and possible Māori responses
abstract: The term body-snatcher has enjoyed a renaissance in the media recently, as various Māori have moved to reclaim their deceased relations. From a Māori perspective, the claiming of bodies has nothing to do with body-snatching, a term that referred to episodes in the West. Indeed, Māori may see some laws themselves as instruments that snatch the body, in contravention of Māori customs. One of these laws, the Coroners Act 2006, may have made some progress by quietly acknowledging these customs in many ways, but that is merely the start of a greater dialogue between Māori and the Crown in relation to proper Māori respect of the dead body
summary: This paper examines the contemporary media use of the term "body-snatcher" in relation to Māori efforts to reclaim deceased relatives, arguing that this misrepresents Māori customs. It posits that, from a Māori perspective, current laws, such as the Coroners Act 2006, can be seen as instruments that contravene their traditional practices regarding the dead. The study investigates whether the Coroners Act 2006 has begun to acknowledge these customs, suggesting that such acknowledgement is merely the beginning of a necessary dialogue between Māori and the Crown concerning the respectful treatment of the deceased. Keywords: body-snatcher, Māori customs, Coroners Act 2006, cultural understanding, respect for the dead.

title: Illustriousness in the farmhouse villa: reading virtue from a Flemish-Veronese merchant family's history
abstract: The Italian nobility has a long history tied to landownership, a dynamic example of which lies in the history of Verona from the late sixteenth century. Sweeping economic change, intellectual currents, agricultural policies, and the built heritage facilitated the rise in status of some mercantile families. Tracing the pressures facing a foreign merchant family emigrating to Venice and settling in Verona’s Valpolicella reveals the importance of social integration for the family’s members. Their farmhouse villa estate represents an enduring monument not only to the contemporary value of civic virtue but also to the construction of a noble identity
publisher: Australian and New Zealand Association for Medieval and Early Modern Studies
summary: This study examines the rise of mercantile families to noble status in Verona from the late sixteenth century, focusing on the social integration of a foreign merchant family settling in Valpolicella. It traces how economic changes, intellectual currents, agricultural policies, and built heritage facilitated this upward mobility. The family's farmhouse villa estate is analyzed as a monument reflecting civic virtue and the construction of a noble identity, demonstrating how such properties legitimized families and secured elite status amidst Venetian political struggles. Key methods include tracing family history and interpreting architectural heritage to understand cultural outlook shifts and status maintenance.

title: Religious Life
abstract: Religious life is a generic term for a variety of forms of Christian life that originated, as a radical response to the gospel, in the rst century and continue to develop in the present, predominantly among Roman *Catholics and *Eastern Orthodox but also, especially recently, among Protestants and Anglicans. The Protestant community of *Taize in France has fostered ecumenical exchange
summary: This chapter explores the concept of religious life, tracing its origins as a radical Christian response from the first century through its modern development across Roman Catholics, Eastern Orthodox, Protestants, and Anglicans. It highlights the ecumenical role of the Taizé community in France and discusses historical shifts in religious freedom, such as the revocation of the Edict of Nantes. The text further delves into the Renaissance's redefinition of human existence, moving from medieval moral judgment to a new understanding of spiritual truth influenced by the transience of life and the instability of perception, impacting psychology, ontology, and visual arts.

title: Le Glouton et les éditions de la Renaissance
abstract: Dans la symbolique de la Renaissance, le Gulo (Glouton) représente l'homme gourmand, notamment celui qui vit dans l'Europe du Nord. Son image, d'origine très ancienne, s'est différemment développée, en se liant à des traditions écrites et orales, cultivées et populaires à la fois. Au fil de son histoire, cet animal a fini par former un tout avec la tradition des éditions de la Renaissance, qui ont hérité de son sens symbolique principal.The Renaissance tradition considered the Gulo (Wolverine) as a symbolic animal, representing the glutton, with specific reference to populations from Northern Europe. The animal's image developed into rich written and oral traditions, and its main symbolic meaning translated into the Renaissance
summary: This article examines the symbolic representation of the Gulo (wolverine) in Renaissance tradition, particularly its association with gluttony and Northern European populations. The study traces the animal's ancient image through diverse written and oral traditions, both cultivated and popular, demonstrating how its primary symbolic meaning was integrated into Renaissance editions. The research highlights the Gulo's role in Renaissance symbolism, connecting it to historical depictions of vices and other symbolic animals. This work is valuable for understanding the cultural and symbolic interpretations of animals during the Renaissance period.

title: Globalism,transformation and social cohesion. Bertelsmann Stiftung Interview 2019
abstract:
Globalization and the changes it brings pose challenges for
social cohesion. Uncertainty is growing as many people are
concerned about their economic future, social inequality
and growing diversity in societies as a result of global
migration. At the “Trying Times” conference addressing
the issue “Rethinking Social Cohesion” hosted by the
Bertelsmann Stiftung in Berlin from September 4-6 in
2019, thought leaders from around the world convened
to discuss the future of social cohesion. Ian Goldin,
Professor of Globalisation and Development at Oxford
University and Director of the Oxford Martin Programme
on Technological and Economic Change, gave the keynote
speech at the High-Level Round Table kicking off the
conference. In his speech “Globalisation, Transformation
and Social Cohesion,” he discussed the effects of
globalization and its potential in shaping the future. In
the following interview, he explores various aspects of
his argument in further detail and emphasizes the key
pillars of strengthening social cohesion in the future:
demonstrating solidarity with others and rediscovering
our own capacity for action
summary: This document explores the challenges globalization poses to social cohesion, emphasizing growing uncertainty, economic concerns, social inequality, and increasing diversity due to global migration. Based on a keynote speech by Ian Goldin at the 2019 "Trying Times" conference hosted by the Bertelsmann Stiftung, the text discusses the effects of globalization and its potential to shape the future. It highlights key pillars for strengthening social cohesion: demonstrating solidarity and rediscovering individual capacity for action. This discussion is crucial for understanding contemporary societal dynamics and future policy directions in a globalized world.

title: Ornamented intabulations and derived fantasias: parody, imitatio, and genre in Vincenzo Galilei’s lute arrangments of Alessandro Striggios “Nasce la pena mia”
abstract: Jean-Michel Vaccaro in 1981 proposed a four-fold classification of sixteenth-century pieces for solo lute, ordered by the degree to which the composer is constrained by fidelity to a pre-existent model, usually a polyphonic vocal work such as a chanson, madrigal, motet, or mass movement
summary: This paper analyzes Vincenzo Galilei's lute arrangements of Alessandro Striggio's "Nasce la pena mia" within the context of sixteenth-century solo lute music. It revises interpretive conclusions based on Jean-Michel Vaccaro's classification and Canguilhem's taxonomy of imitation, informed by Renaissance literary theory. The study applies new interpretive principles to Galilei's three lute versions, comparing them to his other works and his own precepts for vocal model arrangements for solo lute. Findings aim to significantly contribute to the critical interpretation of Renaissance instrumental music, focusing on parody, intabulation, and derived fantasias.

title: Kennedy\u27s  British Quakerism 1860-1920: The Transformation of a Religious Community  - Book Review
fieldOfStudy: History, Christian Denominations and Sects, History of Christianity
summary: This is a book review by Brian D. Phillips of Kennedy's "British Quakerism 1860-1920: The Transformation of a Religious Community." The review examines the book's exploration of the historical evolution of British Quakerism, focusing on key figures like Benjamin West and John Greenleaf Whittier, and analyzing the impact of changing theological and intellectual rigor within the community. It discusses how Quaker dispositions reconciled with artistic and personal gifts, and the challenges faced, including reconciling tradition with new freedoms and addressing issues like salvation and holiness. The review highlights the book's contribution to understanding the religious and social transformation of Quakers.

title: Banks and development : Jewish communities in the Italian Renaissance and current economic performance
abstract:
Are differences in local banking development long-lasting? Do they affect long-term economic performance?

I answer these questions by relying on an historical development that occurred in Italian cities during the 15th

century. A sudden change in the Catholic doctrine had driven the Jews toward money lending. Cities that

were hosting Jewish communities developed complex banking institutions for two reasons: first, the Jews were

the only people in Italy who were allowed to lend for a profit and, second, the Franciscan reaction to Jewish

usury led to the creation of charity lending institutions, the Monti di Pietá, that have survived until today and

have become the basis of the Italian banking system. Using Jewish demography in 1500 as an instrument, I

provide evidence of (1) an extraordinary persistence in the level of banking development across Italian cities (2)

large effects of current local banking development on per-capita income. Additional firm-level analyses suggest

that well-functioning local banks exert large effects on aggregate productivity by reallocating resources toward

more efficient firms. I exploit the expulsion of the Jews from the Spanish territories in Italy in 1541 to argue

that my results are not driven by omitted institutional, cultural and geographical characteristics. In particular,

I show that, in Central Italy, the difference in current income between cities that hosted Jewish communities

and cities that did not exists only in those regions that were not Spanish territories in the 16th century
publisher: Department of Economics, University of Warwick
summary: This study investigates the long-term impact of local banking development on economic performance using historical data from 15th-century Italian cities. It leverages a unique historical event: the shift in Catholic doctrine that led Jewish communities to establish complex banking institutions, which later formed the basis of the Italian banking system. Using Jewish demography in 1500 as an instrument, the research reveals a persistent level of banking development across Italian cities and significant effects of current local banking development on per-capita income. Firm-level analysis suggests well-functioning local banks enhance aggregate productivity by reallocating resources. Keywords: banking development, economic performance, Italy, Jewish communities, financial history, Monti di Pietà.

title: Bruno zevi, the continental European emissary of geoffrey scott’s theories
abstract: Peer ReviewedPostprint (author's final draft
fieldOfStudy: History, Architecture, Art History, Architectural Theory
summary: This article explores Bruno Zevi's role as the continental European disseminator of Geoffrey Scott's architectural theories. It traces the origins of Scott's methodologies, which adapted Bernard Berenson's art historical analytical methods like space-composition and life-enhancement from Renaissance painting to architecture. The study highlights Scott's recognition in English aesthetic circles versus his neglect in Continental Europe, focusing on the limited influence of his book, "The Architecture of Humanism" (1914). The analysis reveals how Zevi became the crucial figure in introducing and interpreting Scott's ideas, thereby bridging an academic divide and broadening their impact on architectural discourse.

title: Lambert and the scholarly culture : the intellectual world of the Liber Floridus
summary: This text explores Lambert of Saint-Omer's role as a compiler and collector, rather than an original theorist, in the creation of the Liber Floridus. It highlights his methodology of selecting and copying source fragments, with originality stemming from his selection and compilation choices, particularly in cartography. The study reveals Lambert's connection to the twelfth-century renaissance, sharing interests in natural philosophy with contemporaries like Adelard of Bath and William of Conches. His visual language, particularly in mappae mundi, integrated cosmographical knowledge from Isidore of Seville and Bede, bridging classical exegesis with contemporary scientific thought, while carefully aligning with Church teachings. His work, Liber Floridus, is an encyclopedia and significant for its selection of sources, its imagery, and its contribution to twelfth-century scholastic culture.
